title: SPA hosts Malcolm Todd to perform at Bryce Jordan Center
author: Rebecca Fein | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Student Programming Association (SPA) will host singer-songwriter and producer, Malcom Todd, at the Bryce Jordan Center on March 24.

Malcolm Todd is known for his eccentric, R&B and indie pop fusion music. Todd released his first album in 2025 entitled “Malcom Todd” and quickly rose to fame with the album's single, "Chest Pain (I Love),” making the Billboard Top 100.

Tickets go on sale Tuesday, Feb. 24 at noon on Ticketmaster.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Breaking down Luke Lilledahl’s competition at 125 pounds for potential postseason run
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s Luke Lilledahl is the top-ranked wrestler in the 125-pound weight class this year. After finishing third in the 2025 NCAA tournament, Lilledahl will look to win his first national championship this March.

However, despite being the top seed, the path to glory will be anything but smooth for the sophomore. Lilledahl faces a field of familiar faces and differentiating styles in college wrestling’s lightest weight class.

Lilledahl’s most recent opponent, Nic Bouzakis of Ohio State, is viewed as the toughest matchup for Lilledahl in the class. While Lilledahl defeated him in the Bryce Jordan Center, Bouzakis was dealing with an injury entering the contest. On top of that, he has been splitting time at the weight class while dealing with the effects of cutting weight.

Bouzakis competed at 133 pounds last season. Bouzakis has many impressive wins on the year, including a pinfall over Dean Peterson of Rutgers and a tech fall against Maryland’s Abram Cline two days after the Penn State dual.

When healthy, Bouzakis matches up in a unique way with “Lightning Luke.” While Lilledahl is known for his speed, Bouzakis is known for power at 125. A match between these two can go either way depending on which skill aspect gains the advantage.

Behind the Buckeye is defending national champion Vincent Robinson. The NC State lightweight broke out at the end of his freshman year, making a shocking run through the NCAA tournament in Philadelphia. This season, the results haven’t come as easy. He sits at 11-3 after a loss to Eddie Ventresca.

Speaking of Ventresca, the Virginia Tech junior has turned on the ignition in 2026 after a slow start to his season in the fall. Lilledahl defeated Ventresca in the consolation semifinals in 2025, but Ventresca has defeated every top-15 opponent he’s faced since then. The Hokie is known for competing in low-scoring matches this season, with five of his victories coming by four points or less.

Ventresca’s latest tight win came in sudden victory against Troy Spratley of Oklahoma State. Last year’s national runner-up has struggled in big matchups this season, to the tune of a 2-3 record against top-16 foes. The combo of Spratley and Robinson reaching last year’s national finals emphasize the unpredictability of the weight class.

Sitting sneakily behind the top of the class is Peterson, who bested Lilledahl last season, 4-1, in a slow match. This season, Paterson has defeated every opponent he’s faced outside of Lilledahl and Bouzakis.

One of the most unpredictable upsets in the tournament last season came at the expense of Lilledahl, when Lehigh’s Sheldon Seymour refused to let Lilledahl move in the tiebreaker to close off a semifinal stunner. This season, Seymour hasn’t lost a match. A revenge match is still on the cards for Lilledahl, as Seymour was scratched from Lehigh’s dual against Penn State early this season.

Seymour is 4-0 against top-16 wrestlers, but none of those opponents were ranked in the top-10 at the time of the bout. All of those wins were by decision, with his highest touted being a 9-6 victory over Stevo Poulin of Iowa State. If Lilledahl matches up with Seymour again, he will have to avoid letting Seymour stall as much as he did last year.

Being a sophomore with a year under his belt, Lilledahl has shown more confidence in pushing opponents in matches like that, with his victory over Bouzakis being a prime example of what to expect out of him in this year's national championship.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: THON 2026 headliner predictions
author: Katie Herron | Lifestyle Editor
description:
With THON Weekend mere days away, rumors are circulating about the highly anticipated surprise headliner.

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

Over the course of 46 hours, THON engages the community with games, dancing and plenty of music. Past headliners have included The Fray, Walk The Moon and Bea Miller.

Here are predictions for what surprise act will rock the Bryce Jordan Center stage this THON Weekend.

Imagine Dragons

It is impossible to create a pump-up, dance playlist without adding at least one of Imagine Dragons’ hit songs. With bangers like “Believer” and “Thunder,” it is hard to not pump your fist along with the pop rock band.

With the resurgence of 2016 culture and music in 2026, Imagine Dragons will pack the throwback punch needed to keep dancers moving.

Surfaces

A feel good sound to recharge spirits during the long THON weekend, Surfaces is the perfect pick to brighten up the stage. Although the duo has been laying low in recent years, they have posted hints about the possibility of new music, and what better place is there to drop a preview than the Bryce Jordan Center?

Hits like “Sunday Best” and “Come With Me” express the warm fuzzy feelings entering the community’s hearts over the 46 hour weekend.

Djo

How does his hit song, “End of Beginning,” go again? “And when I'm back in the BJC, I feel it.”

Maybe that’s not right, but even so, Joe Keery, known for his role as Steve Harrington in “Stranger Things” would definitely turn the stadium upside down.

Keery is also no stranger to performing for a good cause, donating proceeds of ticket sales for his “Another Bite Tour” to the Ally Coalition, a cause supporting LGBTQ+ youth.

Audrey Hobert

This rising star, known for being close friends with fellow pop icon Gracie Abrams, released her debut album “Who’s the Clown” in 2025. Her songs “Sue Me” and “Bowling Alley” quickly launched her into the spotlight, gaining considerable traction on social media platforms like TikTok.

Her songs are hard not to dance along to, although many dancers may wish they were in their bedrooms singing along with a hairbrush.

Bruno Mars

Definitely a long shot, but with the release of his new album “The Romantic” at the end of February, it would be a great chance to show off what he’s got. The first song released from the album, “I Just Might,” is a peppy pick-me-up ready to rejuvenate the BJC.

With his tour not starting for another few months, Mars has just enough time to pause the press tour and finesse a performance for THON.

Colbie Caillat

The prediction I am most confident in is Colbie Caillat, a two-time Grammy Award winning singer-songwriter, known for her early 2000s hits “Bubbly” and “Realize.”

Her most successful single, “Bubbly” perfectly encapsulates the feeling of being at THON: “I've been awake for a while now, you've got me feeling like a child now.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Penn State buildings named after Black alum, notable figures
author: Emma Cherubini I For the Collegian
description:
Penn State is home to a diverse community of individuals, many of whom after their time here are honored in different ways. Here are six campus buildings named after notable Black figures and alumni.

The Shirley M. Malcom Building

In 2022, 329 Building at Innovation Park was renamed The Shirley M. Malcom building, to honor her accomplishments and breakthroughs in the science field.

Malcom earned her Ph.D in ecology in 1974. She’s the co-author of the report “The Double Bind: The Price Of Being A Minority Woman In Science,” which examines the challenges Black women face in the science field.

Currently, Malcolm serves as the senior advisor to the CEO and director of the SEA change initiative at the American Association for the Advancement of Science. She was formerly a member of the National Science Board, and served on the President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology during Bill Clinton’s presidency.

The Guion S. Bluford Jr. Building

In 2021, a building previously known by its address 230 Innovation Boulevard was named The Guion S. Bluford Jr. Building, was renamed to honor Guion “Guy” Bluford.

Bluford is an alum of Penn State’s aerospace engineering program, and internationally renowned in the engineering field and astronaut field.

After completing his undergraduate career in 1964, he went to graduate school at the U.S Air Force Institute of Technology where he received his master’s and doctoral degrees. Along with his academic accomplishments, he became the first African-American to go to space. He flew aboard the Space Shuttle Challenger in 1983.

The Warren M. Washington Building

The Warren M. Washington Building was renamed in 2019 to celebrate Warren M. Washington, who earned his doctorate in meteorology from Penn State in 1964.

The building, located at 328 Innovation Boulevard, houses the National Weather Service, honoring Washington’s status as the second African-American to earn a meteorology doctorate nationwide.

Washington contributed to the Nobel Peace Prize winning Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Assessment Report of 2007, and was awarded the 2009 National Medal of Science from former President Barack Obama.

In 2019, he received the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement alongside Michael Mann, who’s a professor of atmospheric sciences at Penn State.

The Paul Robeson Cultural Center

The Paul Robeson Cultural Center, located inside the HUB-Robeson Center, is dedicated to Paul Robeson, a scholar, athlete, performer and activist. Robeson attended Rutgers University on a four-year scholarship, the third black student to attend the university since its opening in 1776.

Robeson was a performer, singing in 11 major plays for the United States and United Kingdom. His time in the arts won him the Donaldson Award for his renowned performance and leading role in William Shakespeare’s “Othello.”

He was also an outspoken civil-rights activist.

George T. Clark Memorial Lounge

In 1983, the George T. Clark Memorial Lounge became the first University Park facility to be created and named after a Black faculty or staff member.

It’s located in the Findlay Commons at East Campus Halls. The dedication was requested by the 1982 East Halls Black Student Union, following Clark’s death. Clark served as the head of Minority Recruitment, during his tenure at Penn State.

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey’s path to a four-peat in the AHA Tournament, players to watch
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State dominated Atlantic Hockey America with a 22-2 conference record, earning itself the first-place seed and a pair of byes in the upcoming AHA Tournament. The Nittany Lions have only lost to No. 13 Mercyhurst, the No. 2 seed, and unranked RIT, the No.4 seed, both in overtime.

Although postseason action begins on Thursday as No. 6-seeded Robert Morris takes on No. 7-seeded Delaware, Penn State will kick off its tournament play in the semifinals on Feb. 27.

Penn State’s advantage

Penn State has ruled the AHA for the past three years, capturing three consecutive championships. Part of this advantage is due to being well-rested after a bye straight to the semifinals.

But the blue and white aren’t the only team to be on the verge of a championship berth. Mercyhurst got a pass into the other semifinal game due to its second-place finish in the regular season.

The Lakers, the first AHA team to defeat the Nittany Lions this season, are the only other team in the conference to be nationally ranked and are fighting for a spot in the NCAA Tournament.

Penn State, maintaining the No. 4 position in the national rankings, has likely earned itself a spot in the national tournament regardless of the AHA Playoffs results. The only way another team from the conference could make the national tournament would be to win the AHA Championship and mount an upset over the Nittany Lions in the process.

The path to Pegula

In order to face Penn State in the conference semifinals, the winner between Delaware and Robert Morris has to face No. 3-seed Lindenwood in the quarterfinals. The other quarterfinal game is set to be between RIT and No. 5-seed Syracuse.

The lower-seeded team that makes it out of the quarterfinals has a date with the Nittany Lions in Pegula Ice Arena. Meanwhile, the team with the higher seeding will head to Erie, Pennsylvania, to face Mercyhurst.

In the opening round and quarterfinals, teams only play a single game to decide who advances. Once in the semifinals and championship rounds, winners are decided in a best-of-three series structure.

The blue and white — while far-and-away the top team in the conference, with 68 points in the standings — aren’t unbeatable, especially when stacked up against hungry teams that aim to knock the Nittany Lions off their throne.

Players to watch

Grace Outwater paces the conference with 24 goals, shortly followed by captain Tessa Janecke and linemate Maddy Christian, who’ve each tallied 19. Janecke missed a stretch of action due to Olympic duties with Team USA and is set to return in the AHA Tournament.

Kendall Butze was the top playmaker for the Nittany Lions, registering 25 assists on the season to pace the defensemen in that figure. Mikah Keller, known for her position as the tactician on Outwater and Christian’s line, only sits one behind Butze, with 24.

Lindenwood’s Molly Henderson and Robert Morris’ Alaina Giampietro are the highest-scoring non-Penn Staters with 16 goals each.

However, the Colonials’ offensive ace, Jessica MacKinnon, ranks tied for second in the conference with 39 points, matching Outwater and only one shy of Janecke’s 40 points. MacKinnon, a sophomore transfer from Clarkson, is a playmaking forward, posting 25 asesists and 14 goals to help on all fronts.

Julia Perjus and Sofia Nuutinen are Mercyhurst’s top performers. Perjus, a freshman from Stockholm, leads the Lakers with 36 points, good for fourth in the conference. If she’s the shot, then Nuutinen is the pass, as the Vantaa, Finland, native paces Mercyhurst with 23 assists.

Ava Drabyk, a true-freshman netminder, is Syracuse’s defensive backbone. In her first collegiate campaign, the Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, native posted a .925 save percentage, a 2.32 goals-against average, which place third in the AHA. Drabyk has also posted four shutouts, second in the conference.

title: Ryan Clanton striving to bring ‘overall violence’ to Penn State’s OL
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Ryan Clanton made it abundantly clear the kind of coach and leader he is in the two months following his move to Penn State.

The first indication was an X post from the Nittany Lions weight room that read “READY TO RUN THROUGH A WALL FOR THIS PLACE.” The second was a beer chug in Pegula Ice Arena. And the third came when he spoke with the local media for the first time.

Clanton said his philosophy as a coach is “overall violence.” His goal has always been to let the front five hit the grass on Saturdays with nothing on their minds except the desire to attack whoever is in front of them.

“I just want to cut them loose. They'll know what I'm saying when I say that, you know, let those guys really go,” Clanton said on Feb. 4. “And that's the big battle with offensive line. If you can get those guys to play really fast and play fearless and to be feared, that's when you've got a really good group.”

Penn State’s offensive line was — like the rest of the team — supposed to be one of the best in the country last season. But a poor start to the year cost the unit, and it only came close to its potential near the end of 2025.

Clanton said the Nittany Lions’ offensive line last year featured plenty of talent, but he feels they were too in their heads. Sometimes that was to their benefit, but oftentimes it resulted in one or two small missteps that can’t happen,he said.

“You're going to need to analyze in this conference and the people you're going against,” Clanton said, “but a big part of it too is like, when you're playing against guys like that, even from my experience, you're going to have to play fast and you're going to have to catch them off guard.”

Clanton’s philosophy and coaching style is different from what Penn State experienced last year under Phil Trautwein, so Clanton said guys like Anthony Donkoh and Cooper Cousins are going to have to adjust their techniques and learn more gap schemes.

But what Clanton won’t have to teach them is to be violent.

“(Donkoh), Coop, those guys have some bad intentions,” Clanton said. “The way that they can get off the rock and kind of run through something, you know, and then we'll have to kind of see everybody else as we kind of go through it.”

Donkoh and Cousins were two of the first few players to announce they’d return to Penn State for 2026, but it took them wanting to stay and Clanton believing they’re a good fit for his group to make that happen.

Clanton’s criteria was simple, and similar to the entire coaching staff’s ideology when building the 2026 roster. He wanted humble leaders who bleed for Penn State.

“You'll find guys that are like, ‘I play (offensive line) because I love football, I love this team. I bleed for that logo, and I want to run through somebody's face.’ And you’re like, ‘I can work with that,’” Clanton said. “So that's the first thing, when you kind of talk to guys, I try to find out the real reason why they play football and why they're here.”

Through just over two months learning more about the guys in his unit, Clanton is most impressed with their willingness to learn from someone new as they all try to make the most of this adjustment period.

“Sometimes you come in and you'd see (guys say) ‘well I've already been here for this long and, so just manage me.’ None of them are like that,” Clanton said. “And I couldn't coach them anyway if they were like that. So they've been really adapting to the new tips and tricks and new techniques, lifting, diet, supplementation. I think that's what's made them fun to coach, that they're eager to grow.”

title: Winter styles takes over Penn State’s campus
author: Carolena Bongi | The Daily Collegian
description:
As freezing temperatures settle over campus, Penn State students are reaching for their long winter coats and scarves to battle the cold. But that doesn’t stop students from still showing up to class in style.

For Caya Kassaraba, winter fashion starts with pieces that elevate her everyday outfits.

“My go-to winter staple this season has been a scarf and a good pair of jeans,” Kassaraba, a second-year student studying elementary and early childhood education, said.

Kassaraba said she plans her outfits so they are practical and chic, rather than sacrificing one for the other.

“One way I balance staying warm and expressing my personal style is by layering and wearing my winter coat,” Kassaraba said. “This allows me to stay warm when outside but still express my style once I get inside.”

Kassaraba said she refuses to trade in her jeans, even on the cold days. Although she’s considered wearing sweatpants for their extra warmth, she still sticks with the denim because she believes that looking good helps her feel good.

Jillian Shortridge said winter dressing is about making small adjustments.

“I am definitely a spring, summer girl, so most of my tops are tanks, which is tough during the winter,” Shortridge, a fourth-year studying plant sciences, said. “But I love throwing on this knit cropped sweater so I can still show the tank top’s pattern but stay warm while doing so.”

Lucy Ann Hinkle said she sees winter style centers around a statement accessory.

“My most-used winter item is my cream cable-knit scarf because it’s long and wide enough that I can wrap it around my head like a hood to keep warm without earmuffs,” Hinkle, a second-year majoring in health policy and administration, said.

Hinkle said even when she dresses for the colder weather, she keeps the core of her style intact. She chooses winter pieces that match the colors she typically gravitates toward, and always incorporates jewelry she already enjoys wearing.

She also gravitates toward bold outerwear.

“Colorful and textured jackets or sweaters add a lot to my simple daily-wear winter outfits,” Hinkle said.

For Abby Roniger Alarcon, winter style is all about timeless outerwear.

“My go-to winter staple is a cropped trench coat,” Roniger Alarcon, a third-year majoring in public relations, said. “There’s this sound on TikTok, ‘trench coat buttoned to the top,’ and that really inspired me because it kind of channels Lily-Rose Depp vibes and I feel like it goes with everything while also being aesthetic and timeless.”

She said layering is the foundation of her outfits because it allows her to add warmth underneath while still styling a more intentional look on top. She added that even when she is bundled up, her accessories help her to maintain her personal style.

“If you get a bag that you adore, it can change everything, even if you’re wearing something simple, a cute bag pulls the whole outfit together,” Rongier Alarcon said.

She’s been enjoying the way scarves and gloves have become more stylish on campus. She said when she was younger, those pieces weren’t considered fashionable, but now students are wearing them in ways that enhance their outfits.

Additionally, even in freezing temperatures, she refuses to give up ballet flats.

“If you wear them right, they can bring every outfit together and no matter if it’s two degrees, I’m not willing to sacrifice my flats. Ballet flats are a lifestyle,” Rongier Alacron said.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: 3 Penn State men’s lacrosse players earn Big Ten weekly honors
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State picked up a big win over the weekend against No. 3 Princeton, and the conference’s weekly honors reflected that.

Hunter Aquino was named the Big Ten Offensive Player of the Week, Preston Hawkins earned Freshman of the Week and Alex Ross added to it with Defenseman of the Week honors

B1G recognition 🤝Aquino - Offensive POTWHawkins - Freshman OTWRoss - Defensive POTW pic.twitter.com/bSwUBXNo3b— Penn State Men’s Lacrosse (@PennStateMLAX) February 17, 2026

Aquino had three goals in last weekend’s win, adding to his season total of 10. The former Big Ten Freshman of the Year is averaging 3.33 goals per game this year.

Hawkins, meanwhile, had his best performance in net throughout these first three games with a season-high 11 saves.

Ross tallied his first goal of the year in the win while picking up three ground balls and three caused turnovers.

The three Nittany Lions are back in action against Navy at noon Saturday.

title: Penn State notebook | Guy Gadowsky talks injuries, forward depth, Laubach
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a 1-0-1 weekend against No. 2 Michigan that featured a narrow shootout loss and a blowout defeat, No. 6 Penn State returns to Pegula Ice Arena for a two-game series against Ohio State.

With his squad at 18-9-1 entering the season’s final stretch, Guy Gadowsky addressed the media on Tuesday regarding Reese Laubach’s recent surge, his team’s latest injury updates and how he expects to utilize his forward depth moving forward.

Here’s what Gadowsky had to say.

Injury Updates

Dane Dowiak, who was injured in the second period of Penn State’s 5-4 shootout loss on Friday, will miss the remainder of the season with an upper-body injury, he announced Tuesday on social media.

“This past weekend in Ann Arbor, I unfortunately suffered a season-ending upper-body injury,” Dowiak wrote in a message posted on X. “...I’m ready to attack this recovery with everything I have, come back stronger and return to the ice next season better than ever.”

💙 @PennStateMHKY pic.twitter.com/RRsVgfwC5g— Dane Dowiak (@danedowiak) February 17, 2026

The junior forward was named Penn State’s captain before the season and is recognized by his teammates as the team’s leader. Gadowsky lamented the loss of Dowiak, not only for his leadership, but also for his gritty playstyle alongside linemates Aiden Fink and Gavin McKenna.

“(It’s) a tough one for us,” Gadowsky said. “(Dowiak) is still our captain. He's still gonna be a huge part of the team. We didn't need to lose another centerman. He was our top guy in draws. But he's still our captain. He brings great value as a captain and a leader.”

After a few weeks of trial and error, Gadowsky had settled on Dowiak to center a line with Fink and McKenna. Now, without his captain, Gadowsky must find a replacement to center his top offensive line.

A potential option is Luke Misa, who centered that line in Dowiak’s absence.

Alex Servagno, Charlie Cerrato and Braeden Ford remain sidelined. Servagno and Cerrato will miss the remainder of the regular season, while Ford continues to recover from an injury that Gadowsky said will cause him to miss a “significant amount of time.”

Casey Aman, a traditional defenseman, has filled in at forward as the Nittany Lions look to their depth amid a plethora of injuries.

Navigating injuries

With Dowiak sidelined, Penn State was without five of its forwards for the second half of Game 1 and all of Game 2 against Michigan.

It caused Gadowsky to get creative with his lines, using defensemen Nick Fascia and Aman at forward and, at one point, deploying a line with four defensemen and just one forward.

But the long-time coach doesn’t want to change the way his team plays. He doesn’t want to change the “stripes” that have molded Penn State hockey into the tough, gritty team that’s ranked No. 6 in the nation.

“We change personnel because we have to, but we don't want to change our stripes, because to change your stripes takes months,” Gadowsky said. “You don't just come in and say, ‘Hey, for this team, we play like this now. If you’ve heard the adage, ‘We only ran two plays all year, we just ran them better than anybody else,’ we absolutely agree with that. We're not changing this team. We have our stripes, and that's how we play.”

Laubach’s surge

Penn State’s forward group has been depleted by injuries, but one goal scorer has surged in recent weeks.

After tallying six goals in his first 24 games, Laubach has scored five times over his last five games, including a two-goal effort in the Nittany Lions’ 6-3 loss to Michigan on Saturday.

“We are extremely proud of Reese. He does whatever the team asks in whatever role is asked. And it's guys like that, that when they have offensive success, everybody's happy,” Gadowsky said. “He's a really tough kid. He's worked extremely hard on walking that fine line between being a warrior and staying out of the box. And he has done a great job.”

A #B1GHockey best 3️⃣ Goals and 4️⃣ Points earns Laubs some weekly recognition following back-to-back multi-point efforts against Michigan last weekend!! 🏒⭐️ Read More ➡️ https://t.co/C9aHHcyZpP#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/iZTHEuNLeE— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) February 17, 2026

The junior forward was named the Big Ten’s Third Star of the Week following his four-point weekend. It marked his first Big Ten weekly honors this season and the fourth of his career.

title: Penn State women's volleyball's Kennedy Martin, Ryla Jones named to national team collegiate training roster
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After standout seasons, two Penn Staters are taking their talents to the national team.

Ryla Jones and Kennedy Martin were named to the U.S. women's national team collegiate training roster on Tuesday, with a chance to make the national team.

Training with 🇺🇸Kennedy and Ryla are headed to the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs!#WeAre pic.twitter.com/mpruFiNqJM— Penn State Women’s Volleyball (@PennStateVBALL) February 17, 2026

Jones is coming off an AVCA East Coast Region Honorable Mention season with Pitt, where she recorded 222 kills. She transferred to the Nittany Lions in December.

title: Former Penn State safety Lamont Payne Jr. transfers to Delaware State
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
The portal news never truly stops.

Former Penn State safety Lamont Payne Jr. announced his transfer commitment to Delaware State on Tuesday via his Instagram.

Through three seasons with the Nittany Lions, the Carnegie, Pennsylvania, native appeared in seven games and didn't record a tackle.

Payne is a former 3-star recruit via the 247Sports composite rankings, and was the Developmental Squad Defensive Player of the Week twice in his freshman season in 2023.

title: Weekly Recap | Penn State softball has successful weekend in Lone Star State
author: Brielle Gari | The Daily Collegian
description:
Over the weekend, Penn State softball headed down south to the Lone Star State for their second weekend series, the Houston Invitational.

The Nittany Lions went 4-1 over the course of five games against nonconference opponents.

Falling short in their opening match of the weekend to then undefeated Incarnate Word, 5-4.

Quickly bouncing back after a walkoff loss, Penn State faced off against the host team, the Houston Cougars, their second undefeated team of the weekend.

The Nittany Lions were able to close out the game in six innings, ending it 10-2.

Securing a Saturday sweep, the Nittany Lions traveled over to Husky Field to take on Lafayette and Houston Christian. Getting their second run-rule victory of the season, the blue and white ended their first game of the day in five innings after 14-1.

Then defeating the Huskies 4-1on their home field, to end their second day of the Houston Invitational. Facing off against in-state rival Pitt, the blue and white had an astounding second inning, scoring eight runs that ultimately gave the win.

Closing out their weekend in Texas in five innings, beating the Panthers 11-2.

Freshman Spotlight: Allison Onearce

True freshman Allison Onearce was the highest-ranked individual prospect in Penn State’s 2025 signing class. Her performance in the blue and white jersey has been nothing less than straight dominance.

Receiving honors of Big Ten Freshman of the week and D1 Softball and Softball America National Freshman of the week after just her second full week as a collegiate athlete.

The Alpharetta, Georgia native has had a sensational showing, leading the Nittany Lions to a 4-1 weekend in Houston. Mustering a .407 batting average on the year, a new team high of six home runs, highlighted over this weekend with her eight total bases against Incanate Word.

Onearce is in the top 30 of the Big Ten conference overall players with her six homers and .407 batting average. Establishing herself as one of the most prominent power hitters in all of D1 this early in the season.

Offense sets the tone

Throughout the weekend, what really stuck out for Penn State softball was the aggressive at-bat performances. Finding their rhythm at the plate, creating consistent contact across all five games.

Outsourcing opponents 33-9 throughout the weekend, the lineup from top to bottom produced on the plate, showcasing depth and balance throughout the order.

One of the blue and white's top performers was junior Brooke Klosowicz, who capitalized on opportunities on the plate across both games on Saturday. Finishing 4-for-5 with two runs scored, a home run and OPS of 2.233.

Sunday saw an impressive showing from sophomore center fielder Natalie Lieto, who had quality at-bats that helped drive the Nittany Lions' scoring. A 1-for-4 showing with 3 RBI and a home run.

Crushing Pitt for their final game of the weekend, it was powered by the hungry offense in the bottom of the second. Scoring eight runs that included three home runs. Fuelled by eight hits from seven different Nittany Lions.

Command in the Circle

As the offense dominated the weekend, the Penn State pitching staff set a foundation throughout the Houston Invitational. Keeping opponents on a short leash and limiting momentum across the five games.

Bridget Nemeth had a complete game performance against Houston Christian, allowing only a single earned run. The junior from Glendora, California, had her first complete game, throwing all seven innings since May of 2024.

Left-handed pitcher, Brevyn Kellepouris, made her way to the circle as a reliever, picking up her first victory at the collegiate level on Sunday. Facing 13 batters, Kellepouris allowed only two hits while striking out two Panthers and allowing zero runs.

True freshman, right-hand pitcher Mackenzie Ducan received her second appearance of the series against the Cougars on Friday. With 2.2 innings in the circle, the rookie showed up with five strikeouts and finished the day with an earned run average of 2.63.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: THON Weekend parking, traffic information
author: Alex Fischer | The Daily Collegian
description:
With THON Weekend just around the corner, here's parking and traffic information to keep in mind the weekend commences in the Bryce Jordan Center.

Where to park

General visitor parking will be available at the Stadium West, Jordan East and Porter North lots throughout THON Weekend. Signs in these lots say parking is prohibited from 2-4 a.m., a parking constraint that will be lifted during THON Weekend.

Due to the weekend's men's hockey games, Stadium West will be closed to THON traffic from Friday at noon through Saturday at 8 p.m.

The small Jordan East lot across from the All-Sports Museum will be reserved for ADA parking.

The Orange L lots, east and south of the BJC, and a small section in the middle of the main Jordan East lot will be reserved for THON family parking.

Road and parking lot closures, delays

Curtin Road, from University Drive to Porter Road, will be closed from 2-7 p.m. Friday and University Drive, from Hastings Road to Curtin Road, will be closed from 4:15-4:30 p.m. Friday to allow for dancers to arrive at the BJC.

The Centre Area Transportation Authority (CATA) buses and the campus shuttle will both operate on their normal schedules, but delays are possible due to traffic, congestion and road closures.

High-traffic times

On Friday, THON dancers will be dropped off at the Silver J lot from 2:45-4:15 p.m. The lot will remain open to permit holders, but traffic is expected to be heavy in the intersection of Hastings and Bigler roads during the weekend.

There will be four athletic events Friday evening: Men's volleyball at 6 p.m. in Rec Hall, wrestling at 7 p.m. in Rec Hall, and men's hockey at 8:30 p.m. in Pegula Ice Arena and Track and Field at the Indoor Multisport Facility.

There will also be two athletic events Saturday: Men's volleyball at 3 p.m. at Rec Hall and men's hockey at 8 p.m. at Pegula Ice Arena.

MORE THON COVERAGE

title: What to know about reported new Penn State WRs coach Kashif Moore
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State was originally set on Noah Pauley to be its wide receiver coach in 2026, but plans had to change after Pauley left for an NFL job with the Green Bay Packers.

Nearly two weeks later, news broke that the Nittany Lions are set to hire Colorado State’s Kashif Moore as their wide receivers coach to replace Pauley, filling out the last open position on Matt Campbell’s first staff in Happy Valley.

Here’s what to know about the expected new wide receivers coach.

Coaching history

Moore was only temporarily the pass game specialist and wide receivers coach with the Rams as he followed new head coach Jim Mora from UConn to Colorado State this offseason. He spent three seasons as the Huskies’ wide receiver coach.

Moore helped UConn pass for 3,697 yards this past season with three wide receivers with over 400 receiving yards. In 2024, the Huskies’ wideout room managed to tally 1,960 receiving yards.

Prior to his time with the Huskies, Moore was the wide receivers coach at Albany, which passed for 3,027 yards in 2022. He was the running backs coach at Cornell in 2021 after getting his first college job at Wesleyan University as wide receivers coach a year before.

Moore began his coaching career at Conard High School in Connecticut as an assistant coach from 2019-20.

Notable players coached

Throughout his last two seasons at UConn, Moore guided wide receiver Skyler Bell. Bell was a finalist for the 2025 Biletnikoff Award, which is given out annually to the nation’s top pass catcher.

Bell appeared in 12 games this past season, totaling 101 receptions for 1,278 yards and 13 touchdowns. He had more than 100 yards in seven games, including a season-high 158-yard performance against Rice.

Bell’s now going through the pre-draft process ahead of the 2026 NFL draft in April.

Another notable year under Moore was wide receiver TJ Sheffield, who had 54 catches for a career-high 505 yards along with three touchdowns with UConn in 2024, his sixth and final season after spending the first five at Purdue.

Playing days

Moore was a four-year player for UConn from 2008-11, where he had 126 catches for 1,699 yards and 13 touchdowns throughout his career, including a 604-yard senior year. His career-best game happened when he tallied 112 yards on eight catches against Western Michigan in 2011.

Moore also played in the 2011 Fiesta Bowl against Oklahoma, totaling 62 yards on four catches in a loss to the Sooners.

Following his college career, Moore signed with the Cincinnati Bengals as an undrafted free agent following the 2012 NFL draft. He also spent time with the Indianapolis Colts, San Diego Chargers, Houston Texans, Pittsburgh Steelers and Kansas City Chiefs, but he never appeared in an NFL game.

Moore was last released by the Chiefs ahead of the 2016 season.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's hockey captain Dane Dowiak announces season-ending injury
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
A Nittany Lions team already decimated by injuries is hit with another one.

Penn State captain Dane Dowiak sustained a season-ending upper-body injury, he announced on X on Tuesday.

💙 @PennStateMHKY pic.twitter.com/RRsVgfwC5g— Dane Dowiak (@danedowiak) February 17, 2026

"I'm ready to attack this recovery with everything I have, come back stronger and return to the ice next season better than ever," Dowiak said in his post to X.

The injury occurred on Friday in Ann Arbor after a Michigan player poked at goaltender Josh Fleming's pad. Dowiak got into a scrum and was injured during it, unable to serve his minor penalty for roughing.

Dowiak was pacing for a career year, posting 18 points, nine goals, nine assists and a plus-16 net rating in his junior campaign. For perspective, his previous best season offensively was 20 points.

The Nittany Lions, as mentioned earlier, are already playing thin in their forward group. Penn State had to play two defensemen at right wing in Saturday's series finale against Michigan. Dowiak joins a list of Charlie Cerrato and Keaton Peters as centers who are on the shelf for the Nittany Lions.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's basketball reflects on recent change in form
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a very slow start to the Big Ten season with 11 straight conference losses, things have started getting better for Penn State.

With two weeks remaining until the conference tournament, the Lady Lions have won two of their last four games, feeling the best they have all year.

“We just want to stack our days, one game at a time,” coach Carolyn Kieger said during her weekly media session. “It’s a lot of carrying over from how we’ve been playing the last two weeks, and obviously still continuing to fix the things that are weaknesses for us.”

The blue and white opened February with an overtime win against Purdue, earning its first victory since Dec. 20. After two close losses to ranked Michigan State and Maryland, the Lady Lions emerged victorious again, this time defeating Northwestern on Sunday.

“I think everybody’s mindset is very good right now,” Kieger said. “We talk about getting better, learning and growing. I think everyone can see the team getting better day by day.”

A big contributor to the team’s recent growth has been Kiyomi McMiller, who’s had four of the best games of her career in recent weeks.

Starting with the team’s win against the Boilermakers, McMiller has scored over thirty points in each of the last four games, marking the first Lady Lion in school history to reach that feat. Against Northwestern, the former Rutgers standout also recorded a double-double with 12 rebounds, marking her third of the season.

“I think Kiyomi is just super confident from all three levels right now,” Kieger said. “Her three-ball has been falling, but I think getting to the free throw line has drastically helped.”

Not only has the amount of scoring from McMiller increased, but her efficiency shooting has significantly grown over the past few games. Up until the Purdue victory, McMiller was averaging 43% from the field. But in the past four games, she’s shot at a much-improved 49.5%.

“Her mid-range has been elite her entire career,” Kieger said. “She’s super confident, and you can tell she’s playing free and clicking on all cylinders right now.”

After winning on Sunday, the Lady Lions are in need of at least two wins to clinch the Big Ten tournament, barring any major upsets from lower-ranked teams. The first step to success is a matchup with Rutgers on Saturday.

Penn State played the Scarlet Knights earlier this season, losing after leading for most of the game. With a month of reflection following the game, the Lady Lions are prepared for Rutgers this time around.

“Obviously, we had a lead, we built the lead, and they came back,” Kieger said. “A lot of it came down to the defensive rebounding and the physicality. So we’re going to be talking a ton about physicality and hitting first.”

Even with a win on Saturday, Penn State wouldn’t be in the Big Ten tournament, needing different results from other teams. However, Kieger’s squad isn’t focused on the other teams’ performances with the season on the line.

“I think we’re obviously just focusing on what we can control,” Kieger said. “We’re controlling our own destiny right now.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's hockey's Reese Laubach earns Big Ten's Third Star of the Week
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Reese Laubach was named the Big Ten's Third Star of the Week following his four-point weekend against No. 2 Michigan.

A #B1GHockey best 3️⃣ Goals and 4️⃣ Points earns Laubs some weekly recognition following back-to-back multi-point efforts against Michigan last weekend!! 🏒⭐️ Read More ➡️ https://t.co/C9aHHcyZpP#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/iZTHEuNLeE— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) February 17, 2026

The junior forward tallied a point and an assist in No. 6 Penn State's 5-4 shootout loss last Friday. He scored twice in the Nittany Lions' 6-3 loss last Saturday.

After tallying six goals across his first 24 appearances this season, Laubach has scored five times over his last five games.

The award marks Laubach's first Big Ten weekly honors this season and the fourth of his career.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball third baseman Allison Oneacre unanimously named National Freshman of the Week
author: Brielle Gari | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State softball just closed out its second weekend of the season in Houston for the Houston Invitational, and one of its true freshmen has received national honors.

Freshman Allison Oneacre was named National Freshman of the Week by both Softball America and D1Softball after her dominant performance this past weekend.

the people’s freshman.#WeAre | #AllIn pic.twitter.com/OVDhTNuqnC— Penn State Softball (@PennStateSB) February 17, 2026

The rookie third baseman had a successful weekend, leading the Nittany Lions to a 4-1 record. The Alpharetta, Georgia native had a .582 batting average, knocking seven hits with six of those going for extra bases.

Blasting a team high of four home runs, the true freshman racked up 21 total bases and a 1.750 slugging percentage. She dominated the defensive side, as well, with a 1.000 fielding percentage.

This is her second honor for the week, as Onearce just received Big Ten Freshman of the Week.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Mike Rhoades says what Penn State must do to add top high school talent, reiterates need to get older
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State was a finalist for 5-star 2026 guard Dylan Mingo, but the highly ranked prospect ultimately committed to North Carolina as announced via ESPN on Tuesday.

Earlier this season, Mike Rhoades said Penn State isn’t currently in a position to add the highest levels of talent out of high school, but he has a belief that the team will. He explained where that belief comes from and what has to happen in order to accomplish that while also reiterating the need for veteran players during his press conference on Monday.

“I think we got to continue to just keep pushing the envelope forward of men's basketball here in everything we do,” Rhoades said. “That's the key to it, and when you bring recruits on campus and they see how awesome it is here, how much fun our student-athletes and our students are having here, the people you could be around, and you get a chance to play in the Big Ten. I mean, that's appealing. We got to continue to do our part, too.”

Had Dylan Mingo committed to the Nittany Lions instead of the Tar Heels, he would’ve become Penn State’s highest-rated recruit in program history and helped Rhoades’ efforts in building a successful basketball team in Happy Valley.

The Nittany Lions were in the running for Dylan Mingo throughout his recruitment, too. He visited Penn State last September and is the younger brother of current freshman Kayden Mingo, who’s having a standout year in his first season on the team.

Regardless, the Nittany Lions missed out on a potential program-changing commitment from Dylan Mingo. It’s a miss in Penn State’s high school recruiting, but Rhoades isn’t always looking at the high school player pool as the transfer portal is also an option to find well-regarded prospects.

“Recruiting has changed, and it's changing as we're speaking right now,” Rhoades said. “You always want to get high school talent, without a doubt, but you also make sure, like in the Big Ten, you got to be completely open to getting older all the time because that's what our league is doing, and that's what power-four teams are doing.”

Penn State’s roster is the youngest in the Big Ten this season, and it’s had to face teams like No. 1 Michigan. The Wolverines’ starting lineup features five veteran players who were all once transfers.

It’s possible for the Nittany Lions to add impact players from the transfer portal, as they’ve done before under Rhoades. Notably, center Yanic Konan Niederhauser came to Penn State in 2024-25 after two seasons at Northern Illinois before becoming a first-round pick in the 2025 NBA draft.

Guard Freddie Dilione V and forward Josh Reed both didn’t begin their collegiate careers at Penn State but are having productive years as Nittany Lions this season. Wing Eli Rice, who transferred in from Nebraska ahead of the 2024-25 season, has shown promise as a sharpshooter as well.

Reed will run out of eligibility after this year, but Dilione and Rice both have the chance to return to Penn State in 2026-27 as redshirt senior and redshirt junior, respectively. Guard Dominick Stewart would be in his junior year, forward Saša Ciani would be a senior, and the eight freshmen would all be in their second collegiate years.

Prior to any potential transfer portal movement and with the addition of incoming freshman Jamison White, the Nittany Lions’ roster projects to have those 13 players in 2026-27.

Perhaps Penn State will make a push to find veteran talent in the portal this upcoming offseason, but whatever the case might be, the team won’t have Dylan Mingo. Still, Rhoades knows the work needed to land instant-impact high school recruits in the future.

“I think we have a really good staff that has great relationships with people,” Rhoades said. “I think we evaluate well. We recruit. The one thing about here at Penn State in the basketball program that we got to continue to work on is building our program in so many different ways to continue attracting those guys, those types of players like Kayden Mingo and like an Ivan (Jurić) who could take your program through another level when you get a bunch of those guys.”

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State men's basketball misses out on five-star 2026 recruit Dylan Mingo
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State lost out on multiple opportunities to boost morale on the hardwood this season, and the outlook for the future only worsened.

Dylan Mingo, a top-10 2026 recruit, announced his commitment to North Carolina on ESPN First Take, forgoing his chance to play with his brother, Kayden.

The Nittany Lions had been in the running for the five-star prospect, and even appeared to lead the pack in recruitment over top basketball programs.

"I'd say Penn State was second," Dylan Mingo said on First Take.

The guard stands 6-foot-5, with a wingspan five inches longer. He has incredible two-way abilities, which helped Dylan Mingo stand out at Long Island Lutheran High School, a school known for producing NBA-level talent, including current Philadelphia 76ers star V.J. Edgecombe.

Dylan Mingo, the top-ranked prospect out of New York, narrowed his list to his top four on Nov. 25, consisting of Baylor, UNC, Washington and the Nittany Lions, where his brother, Kayden Mingo, who also attended Lutheran High School, is a star freshman guard.

Kayden Mingo is a former four-star recruit and Penn State’s top all-time recruit; his brother would’ve taken that position if he’d opted to join him in Happy Valley.

For the blue and white, its recruiting class sits with only one incoming freshman for 2026, Jamison White, compared to seven newcomers last season.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions around the nation | Lock Haven Open, dual season headline weekend of Penn State wrestling
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
An open tournament was back in play for Penn State as multiple backup wrestlers competed in the Lock Haven Open. Some Nittany Lion transfers also continued their dual season with their respective new colleges.

Here’s a look at the Nittany Lions, and wrestlers with Penn State ties, who competed over the weekend.

Lock Haven Open

Each of the five Penn State wrestlers competed unattached, not counting as a date towards potential redshirts.

At 141 pounds, Hayden Cunningham kicked off his day with a close 7-6 decision loss to Penn’s Alex Almeyda. Cunningham was trailing entering the third period before an escape and takedown put him in the lead. Despite this, he allowed Almeyda to escape both times, giving the in-state foe the decision victory.

He responded with a 48-second fall before defeating CJ Carr of Lock Haven in the fifth-place match with an 8-0 major decision. Cunningham utilized a first-period takedown, and a third-period takedown sealed things for the Nittany Lion.

Up one weight class, Dalton Perry had a successful day at 149 pounds. Perry started with a 10-4 decision over Rutgers’ Devon Magro after two takedowns in the opening period.

He followed it up with a 17-3 major decision over Buffalo’s Justin Holly with three takedowns in the third period. In the semifinals, Perry saw a much different match — a 2-1 decision with the Nittany Lion’s second first point coming on a penalty to Columbia’s Rawson Iwanicki. Perry escaped from the bottom in the third period and didn’t give up any other points to win 2-1.

Perry rolled in the finals, defeating Army’s Easton Broxterman 8-2, winning with his offense rather than his defense from the semifinals.

At 157 pounds, Ty Watson competed and lost his opening match by a 5-0 decision. Watson responded with a 15-0 tech fall, almost getting the fall with four-nearfall points in the middle frame.

Watson cruised to the fifth-place bout defeating American’s Cameron Milheim, 12-1, with another set of four-nearfall points in the third period. In his final match, Watson lost by fall at the 2:42 mark ending his run with a sixth-place finish.

Sean Degl at 174 pounds found no success in his weight class. He opened things with a 7-2 decision loss against Lehigh’s Richie Grungo, conceding two takedowns.

In consolations, he lost to another Lehigh wrestler in Dom Federici in an 8-5 decision, finishing with an 0-2 record.

Mason Ellis competed at 197 pounds, but had to medically forfeit in his first match. He didn’t compete in his second match, defaulting out of the open.

Transfers

Alex Facundo continued his strong first season with Oklahoma State. In the highly anticipated dual against Virginia Tech, Facundo defeated No. 30 Sergio DeSiante by a 4-1 decision, with his victory proving big in the overall dual match. The Cowboys ultimately defeated the Hokies 19-12.

At George Mason, Jack Kelly had a successful Senior Night weekend. In his match at 197 pounds against Clarion, Kelly won quickly in 1:47 by pinfall. He followed it up with a 17-5 major decision against Central Michigan to keep things rolling.

No. 7 David Evans has continued to show that it’s back-to-back years with successful Penn State transfers at Utah Valley, with Terrell Baraclough being the wrestler a season ago. At 149 pounds, Evans won by tech fall twice in matches during Utah Valley’s duals against Air Force and North Colorado.

Aurelius Dunbar has struggled with Duke. In the Blue Devils’ dual against No. 8 NC State, Dunbar lost to unranked Will Denny by a 21-10 major decision. He’ll likely need to overperform in the ACC tournament to qualify for the NCAA Championships.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Cole Mirasola's rise headlines Penn State wrestlers in latest InterMat rankings
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following Penn State’s dual against the Ohio State, the Nittany Lions saw a lot of movement in this week’s Intermat rankings.

At 133 pounds, Marcus Blaze moved from No. 4 up to No. 2 after defeating the former No. 2 in Ben Davino. After the loss, Davino fell to No. 3 behind Blaze.

Cole Mirasola saw the biggest jump, rising from No. 12 to No. 6 after defeating Nick Feldman. The Buckeye fell from No. 3 to No. 7 as a result of the loss.

Despite his loss to Jesse Mendez at 141 pounds, Braeden Davis held his N0. 12 spot at 141 pounds, while PJ Duke remained at No. 4 at 157.

Luke Lilledahl, Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines, Rocco Welsh and Josh Barr all remained at No. 1 at their respective weight classes following victories in the Bryce Jordan Center dual.

author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian

The winter season is keeping Penn State indoors.

First ranked matchup 🔜See you at Holuba tomorrow at 5⃣ pic.twitter.com/elISVZHl9E— Penn State Women’s Lacrosse (@PennStateWLAX) February 17, 2026
