title: Column | Black literature preserves what America won’t
author: Mercedes Hamilton | Editor-in-Chief
description:
When Audre Lorde argued that creativity is a form of power, in her 1977 essay “Poetry is Not a Luxury,” she was speaking to a lineage of Black writers who have shaped this country’s moral compass.

For centuries, writing has transformed lived experience into record, resistance and survival in a country that has often refused to document the Black experience honestly. This refusal is not accidental; erasure and attempts to sanitize history are deliberate attempts to deny Black people humanity and legacy.

From Frederick Douglass’ “Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave” to Harriet Jacobs’ “Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl,” Black writers have provided firsthand accounts of the egregious brutality of white slave owners in ways that are largely absent from public records, including sexual exploitation and denial of literacy.

Attempts to erase uncomfortable histories have real consequences for how Americans understand their country. At times, our lawmakers have acknowledged that federal and state institutions have failed to adequately preserve records of Black history since America’s inception, prompting legislation such as the Preservation of Records of Servitude, Emancipation and Post-Civil War Reconstruction Act, which mandated the Archivist of the United States to preserve, digitize and publicize records from the aforementioned periods. Even still, history remains vulnerable to political agendas

Contemporary Black writers like Terrance Hayes and Angie Thomas explore generational grief, joy and identity in ways that push readers to grapple with a modern America that continues to navigate systemic racism. Works like “American Sonnets for My Past and Future Assassin" and “The Hate U Give” will live on as classics detailing modern-day police brutality and a resurgence of loud racism in a post-Obama America.

Black writers fill the gaps left by the enduring systemic neglect and denial of the realities of America’s past and present. And they do it with courage. In spite of indifference and hostility.

On Jan. 22, the National Park Service removed an exhibit from Philadelphia’s Independence National Historic Park that documented the lives of nine people enslaved by George and Martha Washington. It was part of Donald Trump’s “Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History” executive order which directs national museums, parks and monuments to remove references that “undermine the remarkable achievements of the United States by casting its founding principles and historical milestones in a negative light."

The city of Philadelphia sued Interior Secretary Doug Burgum and acting National Park Service Director Jessica Bowron, arguing that slavery is an integral part of the President House Site’s history.

We will turn to Black writers to make sense of this erasure, just as we did during the Harlem Renaissance. During that cultural movement, poets and authors documented realities ignored by mainstream America.

Langston Hughes wrote poems and essays centered on everyday Black life from families to workers to artists. Zora Neale Hurston preserved Southern Black dialect, folklore and community life in “Their Eyes Were Watching God” and other works.

During a time when popular culture reduced Black life to caricature and stereotype, Black writers portrayed communities filled with love and recorded joy and individuality, not just struggle.

Others, like James Baldwin, documented the emotional and social aftermath of segregation. Baldwin’s essays and novels explored how racism shaped both public policy and private life and insisted that America confront the contradictions between its democratic ideals and systemic reality. Toni Morrison later dove into the psychological and generational impact of slavery, emphasizing that America’s troubled history is not distant from today.

Across generations, Black writers have created an archive of American life and provided raw perspectives large institutions ignored. Their work documents migration, discrimination, protest and resilience, but also the everyday details that rarely make it into history textbooks.

Let this Black History Month remind us that language and literature is the means through which lived experience and emotion becomes knowledge and where survival begins long before it is recognized — or when it is actively being erased — by institutions and public policy.

And it is not a luxury. It’s essential.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Big Ten recap | Top-25 matchups highlight Week 15 of women’s basketball season
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten tournament is just two weeks away, and there’s plenty of action as teams gear up for the final stretch.

Between top-25 matchups, the battle of Michigan and some big games by bottom-feeder teams, here’s a look at the action across the Big Ten last week.

Top-25 matchups

All year long, the Big Ten has been one of the premier conferences in women’s basketball. This week, seven teams ranked in the AP Top 25, including three in the top ten, and there were four games between ranked teams.

UCLA and Michigan State kicked off the week with a battle in East Lansing. Despite playing on the road, the Bruins earned a 23-point victory behind Lauren Betts’ 22 points.

That night, Washington traveled to the Midwest to Carver-Hawkeye Arena to try and upset struggling Iowa.

The Hawkeyes lost their three previous games — including two to unranked opponents — but emerged victorious with a nine-point win on Wednesday night. Chazadi Wright led the way with 21 points, followed by 14 from Hannah Stuelke and 11 from Ava Heiden.

Sunday afternoon marked the battle of Michigan, as the No. 7 Wolverines hosted the No. 13 Spartans.

The higher-ranked Wolverines earned the victory in their second matchup of the year, sweeping the series between the in-state foes. Syla Swords and Olivia Olson each scored over 20 points as Michigan won 86-65.

Maryland upset Ohio State

Among the top-25 matchups that didn't end in the higher-ranked team winning, No. 20 Maryland earned a big upset over No. 8 Ohio State to end the week.

Both teams had lost a handful of conference matchups heading into Sunday’s game, including four straight losses from the Terrapins to end January. However, their three-game winning streak, including an upset of No. 12 Michigan State, propelled them past the Buckeyes.

A look at the biggest contributors would lead many to believe it was Ohio State in the win column, as Jaloni Cambridge and Chance Gray combined for 54 points.

Maryland, however, had four players in double-digit scoring in addition to Mir McLean’s eight-point performance.

Yarden Garzon played all 40 minutes of the contest, tying for a Maryland-high 17 points alongside Oluchi Okananwa.

After being outscored 28-15 in the first quarter, the Terrapins had their own run to start the second half, closing the gap to just three points. Maryland went up 76-69 with two minutes left in the game, and despite not scoring the rest of the game, came out victorious, 76-75.

Bottom-tier teams stay alive

Despite only two weeks until the Big Ten tournament and several teams already clinching a spot, no one has been eliminated from the 15-team tournament.

Rutgers, Penn State, Northwestern, Indiana and Purdue are the bottom-five teams with the biggest chances to get cut.

However, the Lady Lions earned a much-needed victory over Northwestern on Sunday. On Saturday, Purdue earned its fourth conference win of the year over the Scarlet Knights, sending them to the bottom of the standings.

The Hoosiers and Wildcats were positioned for possible spots in the tournament in 15th and 16th places, but both went 0-2 this week.

Northwestern fell to Michigan and Penn State, while Indiana lost to USC and UCLA.

Currently, Northwestern, Penn State and Rutgers sit outside the Big Ten tournament, each with just a few games left in the season.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Weekly Recap | Pitching woes, newcomers highlight Penn State baseball’s opening weekend
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State began its highly anticipated third season under coach Mike Gambino with a trip out west to Arizona for the MLB Desert Invitational. However, it was a rocky road trip for the Nittany Lions, finishing opening weekend 1-2, with both losses being blowouts.

After a scoreless tie over the first three innings, Air Force pulled away in the season opener with a 15-3 win. Penn State bounced back in its next game behind a productive offense and quality pitching with a 9-3 win over Grand Canyon.

Yet, the Nittany Lions couldn’t carry their momentum into Sunday’s 24-5 loss against Kansas State, as the game turned into a total rout.

Now, the blue and white have some areas to fix before the team travels again for a road series against Richmond this weekend.

Pitching Woes

The results from the mound weren’t pretty for two of the three games. Redshirt senior Colin Fitzgerald had a solid first start as a Nittany Lion against Air Force. The Lititz, Pennsylvania, native allowed two earned runs, four hits and recorded three strikeouts over 3.1 innings. However, he also surrendered four walks, which drove up his pitch count.

As the anchor in Penn State’s rotation, the blue and white likely need more innings in future starts. Junior Kyle Emmons was the only pitcher who didn’t surrender any runs over 0.2 innings.

The game got out of hand when junior Mason Horwat took over. The Pittsburgh native threw two innings and surrendered five runs, two earned and four hits. While the right-hander didn’t have his best outing, Penn State’s defense didn’t help as the squad finished with five errors.

Freshman Robert Brown III didn't have a smooth collegiate debut in one inning of relief. The North Andover, Massachusetts, native gave up four earned runs, along with three hits and two walks.

It was the same story against Kansas State, with the pitching staff allowing 21 hits and 22 earned runs. Freshman Isaiah Shayter got the start and threw 3.1 innings, allowing six runs, seven hits and three walks.

If Penn State’s starters can’t provide quality starts, the pressure turns on the bullpen to pitch most of the game, which can tire them out as the season progresses. Redshirt senior Frankie Sanchez was the lone pitcher to allow no runs against the Wildcats.

Sophomore Matthew VanOstenbridge and freshman Braden Leed allowed four runs each, with Ostenbridge failing to retire any batter and Leed retiring just one. Mason Butash had another rough outing and surrendered six runs and six hits over 0.2 innings of work.

Penn State needs better production from its starters and bullpen to keep its offense in the game.

The Transfers

The one bright spot in pitching this weekend was sophomore Ben Hudson’s start in the win over Grand Canyon. The West Virginia transfer delivered a quality start in his debut for Penn State, as he allowed just one run on two hits and one walk over five innings. The Medford, New Jersey, native also racked up six strikeouts.

Hudson will be a key piece in Penn State’s rotation, so his outing should make fans excited for future starts on the mound.

Vanderbilt transfer, senior Jayden Davis, delivered an impressive offensive debut throughout the weekend. As the blue and white’s second baseman, the Cookeville, Tennessee, native totaled five hits and two RBI in 14 plate appearances.

With an infield full of many fresh faces, Davis may become an anchor in the diamond for the Nittany Lions as the year progresses.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Weekly Recap | Penn State women’s basketball continues February turnaround in split week
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
After failing to win any January games, Penn State is experiencing a turnaround. The Lady Lions continued to improve this week, splitting their two games.

The blue and white suffered a 19-point loss against No. 20 Maryland, after trailing behind at just four at halftime. Penn State picked itself up with a 10-point win over Northwestern to earn its second conference victory of the season.

The McMiller show

With a 30-point showing against Maryland and 32 against Northwestern, sophomore guard Kiyomi McMiller has now posted fourth straight 30-point performances. The Silver Spring, Maryland, native has been a big part of the Lady Lions late season success.

Additionally, in the two games combined, McMiller recorded six assists, eight steals and 15 rebounds, all the while missing less than a minute of action in each contest.

After last week's performance, McMiller boosted her team-high scoring average to 21.0 points per game, while also pacing Penn State with 4.3 assists per game.

If McMiller’s last few performances indicate anything, it’s that she’ll be the centerpiece to getting the Lady Lions to the Big Ten Tournament in Indianapolis.

Pink Zone victory

Sunday afternoon marked the 20th anniversary of Penn State’s annual ‘Pink Zone’ game. In a day that was bigger than basketball, the Lady Lions fought hard for their second conference win over Northwestern.

The blue and white led for all but 24 seconds, and got up by as many as 20 points. The Wildcats had their chances to creep back, cutting the lead to as few as three late in the fourth quarter, but Penn State held its own.

Aside from McMiller, the Lady Lions had double-digit outings from redshirt juniors Gracie Merkle and Moriah Murray. Merkle was the team's second leading scorer with 19 points, 12 of which came in the second half. Murray finished with 14 points behind a 4-of-11 effort from beyond the arc.

Penn State shot a strong 46.7% from field goal range, while holding Northwestern to a 37.3% shooting percentage.

Despite being outscored by the Wildcats 49-45 in the second half, the Lady Lions’ 14-point cushion after the first half was enough to keep the game in their hands.

Opening strong, closing struggles

The biggest takeaway from Penn State’s last two games was its ability to start quickly. On the other hand, the Lady Lions struggled in the second half in both contests.

The blue and white ultimately fell to No. 20 Maryland 81-62, but trailed 38-34 at halftime, and even had the slight 17-16 edge over the Terrapins after the first quarter.

Comparing the two halves against Maryland, Penn State shot 46.8% from the field in the first half, but that number fell to 35.7% in the second.

The Lady Lions kept the game close enough in the first half to trail by just eight after the third quarter, but the closing frame is where the game slipped away from the blue and white.

Penn State was outscored 23-12 in the fourth quarter, and nine of those points came from McMiller. The Lady Lions shot 4-of-16 in the final frame, while turning the ball over six times. Maryland capitalized on the blue and white’s shaky ending and scored 12 points off turnovers in the fourth quarter alone.

The final frame was the only one in the entire game where Penn State never held a lead.

Similarly, against Northwestern, the Lady Lions led 36-22 through two, but allowed the Wildcats to creep back late in the game.

The blue and white opened its Sunday afternoon matchup on a fast start, leading Northwestern 22-13 after the first quarter. Penn State forced seven Wildcats’ turnovers, while committing just two of its own.

The Lady Lions had a strong third quarter, shooting 57.1% from the field, but allowed Northwestern to score 27 points, cutting the lead to nine heading into the final frame.

Penn State committed nine second-half turnovers, after just five in the first half. Sloppy offense allowed the Wildcats to come back and make it a one-possession game.

The Lady Lions' saving grace in the fourth quarter was taking 16 trips to the foul line, with just eight attempts from the field. The blue and white went 12-of-16 in this frame, which was enough to keep its lead intact.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse looks for biggest win of season over Pitt
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is off to a hot start this year and is looking to carry that momentum this week.

The Nittany Lions host Pitt at 5 p.m. on Wednesday in Holuba Hall with a chance to start their season 4-0 for the first time since 2023.

With the toughest matchup on the horizon, here’s a look at Penn State’s history against Pitt coming into Wednesday’s game.

All-time matchups

The Panthers are one of the newer teams in the NCAA, having played their first game in 2022. As such, the Nittany Lions have played only four games against their Pennsylvania rival.

The two teams first faced off in 2022 as Penn State won three consecutive games against Pitt.

The first and last wins for the blue and white came by eight points, while the second game was a much closer three-goal contest.

Last year, the Panthers earned their first win of the series in a 12-10 battle in Pittsburgh. The Panthers pulled ahead with an early 11-3 lead, but Penn State’s five-goal fourth quarter wasn’t enough to land in the victory column.

2026 Panthers

Pitt is having as good a start as the Nittany Lions, going 2-0 to start the year.

Unlike Penn State, Pitt’s wins have been against a pair of strong teams. Its first win came against Ohio State, 10-13. On Thursday, the Panthers upset No. 14 Duke 17-10.

After losing the 2025 leading goal-scorer Jenna Hendrickson and No. 2 scorer Sydney Naylor to graduation, Pitt has worked to fill that void over the past week.

Junior Paige Telatovich has played a big role in the team’s 2-0 start to the season, scoring seven goals and an assist. Outside of Telatovich, junior Avery Moon leads the team in points with six goals and four assists.

In the goal, senior Molly Cain has started for her second straight year, recording 18 saves and a 47.4% save percentage in the two wins.

Wednesday’s matchup

After entering the top-25 in this week’s IWLCA coaches’ poll, Pitt has a lot to fight for to keep that ranking alive. However, the Nittany Lions have a lot to gain with the biggest game so far of coach Kayla Treanor’s Happy Valley career.

The Syracuse alum has put a lot of trust into her squad, especially freshman Rocquette Allen. Through three games, Allen is the leading scorer, scoring 12 goals, the most on the team.

Outside of Allen, the blue and white have seen a lot of success all over the field. Between senior Erika Ho’s six goals and five assists, the blue and white have no shortage of scorers. Ho, Payton Wainman, Kelly Mackinney, Allen and Greco all posted three-goal games over the stretch.

While Pitt has had success building a new identity this year, the Nittany Lions are hot in Year 1 with Treanor, building up for a big matchup on Wednesday in Panzer Stadium.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State DC D’Anton Lynn, DL coach Ikaika Malloe give glimpse into scheme up front
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
Defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe and defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn led a top-ranked defense at UCLA in 2023, and now they’re set to give their shot at doing the same in Happy Valley.

The two’s entrance into Happy Valley brings a multitude of changes — which, most importantly, is the unit’s identity. The new scheme, and new era, in Happy Valley spells two key themes for the Nittany Lions within the trenches.

“We are into eating up gaps and protecting (linebackers coach Tyson Veidt's) guys,” Malloe said at National Signing Day media.

Once Malloe was hired, he brought in three defensive linemen listed as at least 310 pounds, including the 320-pound Keanu Williams and 310-pound Siale Taupaki from UCLA.

He additionally gets to coach Iowa State transfer Alijah Carnell, who he said has already added 15 pounds and will play on the inside in Happy Valley. It’s a contrast from the Deion Barnes-led front that featured the 294-pound Zane Durant along with the 305-pound Alonzo Ford Jr as its starters.

“We like two big defensive tackles,” Lynn said. “We like playing four to five guys with all those guys we like being big, 300-plus pound guys.”

There’s still some parallels in the schemes, as Barnes went five-deep often in 2025 and guys like Durant were known for their abilities to free up others, but said trait is expected to mean even more under new leadership.

So far, Malloe has been impressed with his returns. The presence of Taupaki and Williams has added some comfort and foundation during install periods, and even the transfers Malloe has never coached seem to fit what he’s looking to do at Penn State.

“Dallas is one of the more athletic people at his size,” Malloe said of Utah transfer Dallas Vakalahi. “So we’re definitely going to use that.”

Malloe continued, “Armstrong (Nnodim) from Oklahoma State, his teaching is very similar. The defensive line coach and coach Lynn are tied in together.”

He even considered returnees Liam Andrews and Ty Blanding “really impressive,” and said they’ll “compete” during spring ball. Malloe also thinks Carnell, who’s listed at 6-foot-5, will be something special with his size paired with athleticism.

The interior guys will be a part of the defense that should return to a 4-3 base look after running a 4-2-5 under former defensive coordinator Jim Knowles.

While Malloe placed a big emphasis on the advantages in the run game, the front’s size is also something he knows will help his squad get to the quarterback. As part, Penn State hired former Northwestern defensive line coach Christian Smith to be its edge rushers coach.

The defensive ends, featuring returnees Yvan Kemajou and Max Granville along with Iowa State transfer Ike Ezeogu, will have a chance to be premier pass rushers. It’s a role that Malloe compared to his former Bruin in Laiatu Latu, who won the Ted Hendricks Award after totaling 13 sacks in 2023.

“Could’ve been a center, could’ve been a guard that Laiatu Latu’d line up with, and everybody else would eat up for,” Malloe said. “We’re gonna find a way to get the Micah Parsons’s of the world, the Abdul Carters of the world … on the fish of the week.”

But whether it’s in the pass or run game, the opportunity to open opportunities for others doesn’t just come from the interior guys’ ability to take on blocks, it also comes from football IQ.

“Every defensive lineman that I worked with can draw all 11 (players) on the board,” Malloe said. “Those guys understand schemes, to man pressure to zone pressure — they can draw them all up.”

Said IQ also comes from experience, which Lynn and company made sure it had plenty of.

Taupaki’s entering his eighth year in college football while Williams is headed into his sixth. Even Vakalahi, a junior, has played 499 defensive snaps in college football while Blanding saw 228 snaps in his redshirt sophomore campaign last season.

Still, production hasn’t accompanied the unit's range of experience. Taupaki, Blanding and Nnodim tallied two tackles for loss each in 2025, the most among the 2026 Penn State interior defensive line.

But the good thing in Lynn’s scheme is they don’t need to stuff the stat sheet as the measurement of their success is rooted in a unit Penn State’s prided itself on for decades.

“This is really built for linebackers to make plays,” Malloe said. “And if we can do our job, then we should have really, really good linebackers that are making tackles for losses over and over again.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Review | Charli xcx transcends ‘Brat’ summer on ‘Wuthering Heights’
author: Ashlyn Kafer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Turning “Brat” summer into “Wuthering Heights” winter, Charli xcx continues to bring innovation and the synthesis of sound into the mainstream flow of music with the release of her seventh studio album, “Wuthering Heights,” on Friday.

The album was written for Emerald Fennell’s movie adaptation of Emily Brontë’s “Wuthering Heights” starring Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi, emphasizing the contemporary component of the film.

The first track on the album is “House featuring John Cale.” The lead single sparked a social media frenzy with many users creating edits from TV shows to the line "I think I’m going to die in this house.”

The track begins with a steady, yet haunting violin melody and cello strums beneath the full-bodied voice of John Cale, before the amped-up vocals of Charli cut through the end of the number.

The orchestral element presented in this piece continues throughout the album, combining with the techno influence of Charli’s typical pop-centric melodies to further modernize “Wuthering Heights.”

The album continues to “Wall of Sound,” introducing the overall theme of being consumed by love until it becomes all-encompassing, battling between knowing what’s best for you and the desire for something more.

The subtly eerie violin drones are emboldened by deep bass tones and the surprisingly smooth vocals of Charli, as she comments on the pressures of love and desperately wanting someone to need her.

“Wall of Sound” crescendoes into “Dying for You,” sounding more like Charli’s signature style on previous albums like “SUCKER” or “Pop 2.”

The song is upbeat and infectious, though the lyrics utter something much more sinister, highlighting the need to keep seeking out love no matter if it feels like it’s killing you, repeating “I’ll keep dying for you.”

The album takes a turn with “Always Everywhere,” utilizing less suspenseful and unstable sounding orchestral melodies, and instead emulating a wedding march as Charli sings of seeing signs of your lover at every end of nature.

Her vocals are more steady and reminiscent of a ballad, opposed to her usually short and quick singing style. The theme of going mad from the intoxicating essence of the love around you persists in this song's lyrics.

“Always Everywhere” is followed by “Chains of Love,” the second single from the album.

The piece is more bass forward, yet incorporates soft violins beneath Charli’s lyrics, recounting the guilt of feeling like a prisoner in her relationship as the chains of love constrain her heart.

“Chains of Love” feels like a track expected from Charli, though the following tracks “Out of Myself” and “Open up” break up her traditional sound entirely.

Continuing to bring modernity into a period piece, Charli incorporates anticipatory sounding violins that stress feeling on the edge, like you’re about to lose yourself in the love you’ve been so desperate for, as “Out of Myself” implies.

Breaking her pop mold further, “Open up” is a fairly short atmospheric and gut-wrenching piece. It’s absolutely necessary to tell the story of the album and echo the devotion in “Wuthering Heights.”

“Open up” listens like an ambient piece from singer-songwriter Ethel Cain, holding dual meaning as the lyrics beg for the receiving party to “open up,” leaving it up for interpretation whether it can be taken literally or metaphorically, such as opening up your heart or mind to another.

“Seeing Things” continues the “crazed by love” storyline throughout the album, though the piece includes less elements than previous tracks. It’s somewhat forgettable and falls short in comparison to the more enveloping sound present up until this point.

“Altars” juxtaposes jazz influence with harmonic orchestral sound, incorporating more raw sounding vocals from Charli. She sings about recognizing the toxic nature of her love before mixing the characteristic violin drones from previous tracks with the sultry vocals of Sky Ferreira on “Eyes of the World featuring Sky Ferreira."

The bass and drum hits work in opposition to the screeching violins, but it comes together to create an unstable and climactic tone, transitioning flawlessly into “My Reminder.”

“My Reminder” mimics the feeling of moving on, recognizing faults and embracing forgiveness. Yet, with the inclusion of mildly frightening violin riffs in between the relatively normal bass-hit forward backtrack, it feels like being on the edge of wanting to fall back into the pattern of toxic devotion.

The album concludes with a standout track: “Funny Mouth.”

The piece accentuates the overall genius and originality of Charli xcx. Echoing the same haunting sounds heard in “House featuring John Cale,” she transforms them into powerful and hopeful beats, replicating coming out victorious at the end of a brutal romance.

“Wuthering Heights” is a display of Charli xcx’s ability to inspire both freedom and thoughtfulness, moving people through her mastery of sound.

From the eerie sounds of violin scratches to swelling organ-focused ballads, Charli xcx expertly highlighted the equally intoxicating yet dreadful feeling of losing yourself to love, making an album that perfectly pairs with Emily Brontë’s Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Weekly recap | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey splits final regular season series against RIT
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State closed the book on a historic regular season with a series against RIT last weekend. For the Nittany Lions, they got to do it in front of their fans inside Pegula Ice Arena.

Although Game 1 ended with a 3-2 overtime loss for the blue and white, over 1,400 fans came back the next day to witness a season finale 4-2 victory.

With their rebound win in Game 2, the Nittany Lions completed the regular season with a 22-2 conference record and a 29-5 overall record. Penn State ended another season leading the AHA in the standings.

Century mark Roberts

One of the major headlines coming out of the series against the Tigers was Katelyn Roberts earning her 100th career point. The Chanhassen, Minnesota, native finished the weekend with a goal and an assist, totaling a two-point series.

The forward’s historic point came as she skated behind the goal line and fed a pass to Kendall Butze in the faceoff circle. The defenseman's shot was rebounded directly to a waiting Abby Stonehouse, who buried the first goal of Game 2.

Following her secondary assist on the play, Roberts is only the sixth player to earn 100 career points in program history.

She finished her senior season with a new career-high in goals at 15. She matched that number in assists and finished with 30 total points.

Maynard’s first-year magic

Roberts wasn’t the only player ending the season in the record books. Danica Maynard has climbed in the records in only her first year on the team. Although only recording an assist in the series against RIT, Maynard used that point to continue to climb in program history.

The defenseman made sure she was on the stat sheet for the better part of the season, as she currently holds the most single-season points by a defenseman with 31. Maynard is also tied in single-season goals by a defenseman with 9.

The Lake Country, British Columbia, native proved her two-way ability throughout the year, from positioning herself to score in the offensive zone to speedy backchecks to stay in front of oncoming breakouts.

With a historic first regular season with Penn State in the books, Maynard will look to continue to contribute on both the offensive and defensive sides as she heads into her first collegiate playoffs.

The look ahead

While there have been several records tied and broken, the regular season is behind the Nittany Lions, and another postseason is on the horizon. Penn State earned its fourth-straight conference title and will have home ice throughout the playoffs.

However, the blue and white will have to wait a week to hit the ice again as it has an upcoming bye after finishing as the highest seed. The Nittany Lions have possession of home ice throughout the AHA playoffs and would automatically enter the NCAA tournament with a championship win.

Although there isn’t a solidified opponent or time yet, the certainty is that Penn State returns to Pegula on Feb. 27 for Game 1 of the three-game semifinals.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Preview | Penn State men’s basketball battles fellow Big Ten bottom-feeder, Rutgers
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State ends its West Coast operations with a lone weekday Bryce Jordan Center clash against Rutgers, and it poses an opportunity for the Nittany Lions to pick up some steam as the season winds down.

The blue and white have a favorable outlook for its return to Happy Valley and here’s why.

Shared struggles

Both Penn State and Rutgers are bottom-feeders in this year’s Big Ten season. Both sit in the bottom five of the conference, with the Nittany Lions dead last due to tiebreaking head-to-head results.

The Scarlet Knights fare only slightly better, with their three Big Ten wins outpacing the blue and white by one, although Rutgers is the lone squad without an away conference win this season.

Both units have the same record, 2-8, over their last 10, and despite other marginal differences in the standings, these squads appear relatively level. KenPom has three Big Ten teams outside its top 100: Rutgers, Penn State, and Maryland.

The Terrapins are sandwiched between the two, with over 20 spots separating them. While statistician Evan Miyakawa has the two teams narrowly battling for the bottom of the Big Ten in his formulas, ESPN predicts a 67% chance that Penn State will win.

There are multiple angles to predict who’s winning this one, with the blue and white holding a slight advantage via the numbers. But no matter how you shake it, it’ll be a close one, with the only uniformity being the shared struggles at the bottom of these two.

Player personnel

For the starting units of both squads, only one starter returns from last year’s pair of clashes between the squads, which were split and both decided by within ten points.

Freddie Dilione V posted double-digit points in both outings he started against the Scarlet Knights last season. His playmaking and efficiency followed, as he hovered around 50% shooting marks and didn’t turn over the ball at all against Rutgers.

The redshirt junior endured a hot streak recently, improving to a team-best 14.4 points per game, and hasn’t missed a game all season. The Fayetteville, North Carolina, native has led Penn State in scoring with his slick handles and midrange buckets for four of its last five games.

Coincidentally, Rutgers is also led by its own upperclassman guard in the form of junior Tariq Francis. Standing four inches shorter than Dilione, at 6-foot-1, Francis hasn’t let his smaller stature stop his scoring.

The Pittsburgh native averages over 16 points per game, while only turning the ball over 1.2 times per game on average. The head-to-head matchup between the two primary scorers will be essential because, outside of that, there isn’t much creation of buckets.

The Nittany Lions have a pair of double-digit scorers joining Dilione, with Josh Reed and Kayden Mingo, who can assist Dilione on the offensive end. Outside of Francis, the Scarlet Knights only have sophomore Dylan Grant, who averages double-digit scoring.

The forward provides solid rebounding but can have streaky offensive moments that limit his efficiency.

It’ll be back to the fundamentals for Penn State and Rutgers, as the paint battle matters just as much as the duel between the guards. Nittany Lions’ freshman 7-footer Ivan Jurić, who at times has struggled against physical big men, will see that exact flaw tested once again.

Senior Emmanuel Ogbole leads the Scarlet Knights off the glass and averages over a board more per game than Juric. Despite the 6-foot-10 Ogbole losing the height battle, he has the weight advantage to dominate Jurić down low and even became a minor internet sensation earlier this year for his impressive physique.

As for injuries, both squads are only slightly affected. Rutgers listed a pair of questionables on its availability report before its last game, while Nittany Lions forward Tibor Mirtić marks the only absence for the blue and white, still day-to-day from a shoulder injury

The game is set for streaming on the Big Ten Network, with a 6 p.m. tipoff for Penn State’s “Academic Achievement Night and Faculty and Staff Appreciation Night.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's soccer midfielder Kennedy Ring gets called up to USYNT
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State's own Kennedy Ring officially received the call-up to the U19 United States Youth National Team.

Another one gets the call🇺🇸🤳Congrats to Kennedy Ring on her call up to the U19 USYNT‼️#WeAre | #PSWS pic.twitter.com/yESvxI7WgW— Penn State Women’s Soccer (@PennStateWSOC) February 16, 2026

Ring played in 18 games for the blue and white this year, totaling 423 minutes across the season.

Before her years at Penn State, Ring was named to the U.S. U17 and U19 Youth National Team Camps.

The sophomore joins the recent list of Penn Staters who have received calls from the USYNT. Bella Ayscue, Emma Johnson and Kealey Titmuss all received calls to the U20 USYNT late last week.

title: Projecting Penn State men’s basketball’s Big Ten Tournament seed with 5 games left in regular season
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A season ago, Penn State was one of three Big Ten squads to miss the 15-team conference tournament field due to finishing 17th in the standings, and Mike Rhoades voiced his displeasure with that format.

This year, the Nittany Lions are guaranteed a spot in the Big Ten Tournament regardless of their record, as the conference expanded it to a full 18-team field. Penn State hasn’t found much success in the Big Ten this season, but nevertheless, it’ll have a postseason to look forward to inside the United Center, beginning on March 10.

With five games left in the Nittany Lions’ regular season, here’s a look at their seeding projection for the Big Ten Tournament.

Current seeding

At 2-13 in Big Ten play, Penn State sits tied for 17th in the conference standings with Northwestern. For seeding tiebreakers, the Wildcats would have the advantage as they won the regular-season matchup between the two teams, which gives the Nittany Lions the No. 18 seed in the tournament.

If the tournament started right now, Penn State would face No. 15 seed Maryland in the first round on March 10, and the Terrapins defeated the Nittany Lions 96-73 during the regular season.

Were Penn State to beat Maryland in that hypothetical matchup, it’d face No. 10 seed Indiana in the second round on March 11. The winner of that game would play No. 7 seed UCLA in the third round on March 12, and No. 2 seed Illinois would await in the quarterfinals on March 13.

Upcoming week

Penn State has another pair of Big Ten games this week, starting with a home matchup with Rutgers on Wednesday before an away contest against No. 9 Nebraska on Saturday. Depending on those results and other games across the conference, the Nittany Lions’ seeding could change at the conclusion of this week.

If Penn State goes 2-0, the team could jump up four spots to the No. 14 seed following this week’s slate of games. It would depend on Rutgers, Northwestern, Maryland and Oregon all remaining under four Big Ten wins after their games this week.

The Scarlet Knights and the Terrapins are tied for 15th in the standings at 3-11 each. The Ducks are 16th at 2-12 in the Big Ten, while the Wildcats are 2-13.

Penn State has the opportunity to get the head-to-head tiebreaker over Rutgers following this week, but the two teams will meet again at the end of the regular season. Otherwise, the Nittany Lions lost the head-to-head tiebreaker to Northwestern, Maryland and Oregon, so minimizing the number of wins they get will be best for Penn State.

A 1-1 week wouldn’t create much improvement for Penn State seeding-wise. Whether the win comes from the Rutgers or Nebraska game, the Nittany Lions would most likely end the week with the No. 17 seed.

If the Nittany Lions posted a 0-2 week, they would remain in the No. 18 seed. Due to its lack of holding many head-to-head tiebreakers, Penn State is going to need to stack some wins in order to move up in seeding.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's volleyball outside hitter Sean Harvey named EIVA Offensive Player of the Week
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State's Sean Harvey is officially a two-time EIVA Offensive Player of the Week.

𝟮𝘅 𝗘𝗜𝗩𝗔 𝗢𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗲𝗲𝗸🦁 Two wins at Princeton🦁 Hit .333 w/ 4.25 kills and 1.38 digs/set🦁 Career-high 22 kills in 5-set win on Friday#WeAre pic.twitter.com/azi8Sph1Z0— Penn State Men's Volleyball (@PennStateMVBALL) February 16, 2026

Harvey was all over the court this weekend and helped the Nittany Lions bring home two wins against Princeton.

The redshirt sophomore hit an impressive .333 with 4.25 kills and 1.38 digs per set. His efforts made all the difference.

Harvey also reached a career-high 22 kills in Friday's five-set match.

The blue and white will face Harvard this weekend at 6 p.m. Friday from South Gym and 3 p.m. Saturday from Rec Hall.

McMiller was named to the Big Ten Weekly Honor Roll on Monday after her performance against Maryland and Northwestern.

title: Report: Penn State hiring Colorado State's Kashif Moore as WRs coach
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
After Noah Pauley's sudden departure to the NFL, Penn State has filled his open position.

The Nittany Lions are hiring Colorado State's Kashif Moore as wide receivers coach, per Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports, to fill out Matt Campbell's staff.

Moore had just joined the Rams staff in December 2025 after three seasons as the wide receivers coach at his alma mater UConn.

He spent one year as a wide receiver in the NFL in 2012 and has been coaching ever since. Moore got his start at Conard High School as an assistant coach before heading to Wesleyan to coach wide receivers.

Moore, 37, coached UConn's Skylar Bell into a Biletnikoff Award finalist in 2025 after he tallied 1,278 yards.

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades recaps split week during West Coast trip
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State returned from its six-day West Coast trip late Saturday night after going 1-1 across its games against Washington and Oregon.

Mike Rhoades returned to the Bryce Jordan Center for his weekly press conference Monday afternoon and provided insight into the results as the Nittany Lions sit at 11-15 overall and 2-13 in Big Ten play this season.

Here’s what Rhoades said during his presser.

Looking at Washington win

Penn State won its second conference game of the year when it defeated Washington last Wednesday, 63-60. Rhoades has a pair of takeaways from the matchup he wants to carry into future games.

Firstly, Rhoades thought the defense was “very good” versus the Huskies. Washington shot 37.7% from the field and 33.3% from 3-point range, and 60 points is the least amount of points scored against the Nittany Lions in Big Ten play this season.

“I thought it was our best 40-minute game of the year defensively,” Rhoades said. “I thought guys guarded the ball really well. We guarded the ball as a team. I just thought we sustained our defense throughout the game more than we have all year long.”

Throughout a close contest down the stretch, the Huskies were held without a field goal for the final 2:44 of the game.

Rhoades also mentioned interior offense as another takeaways as Penn State scored 32 points in the paint and went 7-of-9 on layups.

“I thought on the offensive end, even though the way they tried to guard us, I just thought we were really assaulting the paint, attacking and getting to the rim a lot,” Rhoades said. “It's just a good formula for these guys.”

Rhoades added that he felt the practice the Nittany Lions had a day before the Washington game, and the team carried the momentum into the matchup.

Dealing with adversity

During the Oregon game, Penn State tied the score 46-46 but eventually lost, 83-72. Rhoades attributed the runs the Ducks rattled off to secure the win to his players not responding well enough.

“I thought we allowed a possession here or there to make them bother us too much, like you got to move on to the next play,” Rhoades said. “I just thought we were sensitive at times, and I've used that with our guys. If a play doesn't go your way, it's how you respond, not how you react. Reacting doesn't have you ready for the next play.”

Rhoades said he told his players it’s “really hard” to win if they hold onto plays that happened in the past. He reiterated that it’s important to be ready for the next play.

In the Washington win, Rhoades felt his players were “really good” in dealing with adversity and moving on to the next play. However, the Nittany Lions didn’t respond enough to come back against Oregon.

Penn State has the youngest team in the Big Ten and one of the youngest teams in the country, according to Rhoades. He thinks players get better at dealing with adversity when they get older.

“If you want it to get better, it will get better,” Rhoades said. “Some fight it. Some get better at it. Some see the difference when they start handling it the right way and dealing with it the right way. They see their game take off, their mentality take off, their competitive approach take off. The team gets better.”

3-point defense vs. Oregon

Part of the reason why Penn State lost to Oregon was its 3-point defense. The Ducks, who shoot 32.9% from 3-point range this season, drained 14-of-27 shots from deep, including 7-of-10 in the second half.

It continued a trend for the Nittany Lions, who are allowing Big Ten opponents to shoot 41.6% from 3-point range this season.

“Getting in rotation very early in the clock gets you behind, and then when that ball gets hot, when that ball gets moving, you're late,” Rhoades said. “Look, there's good players, so the more open they are, the easier it is to shoot it. I think that part of it has been the hardest thing for our defense.”

With the lack of a true shot blocker, Penn State tends to double an opposing player when they drive into the paint. While that could shut down the chance for a shot in the interior, a shooter typically becomes open beyond the arc.

There are examples like the Washington matchup where the 3-point defense held the other team to less efficient shooting. With five games left in the regular season, how well Penn State’s perimeter defense performs could determine if the Nittany Lions can pick up any more wins.

“A couple games where we've done a good job of keeping the ball in front and not getting an early rotation and early in the clock, we've been much better at it,” Rhoades said. “We're just not very consistent at it.”

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Review | What Olivia Dean’s ‘The Art of Loving’ can teach us about adoration
author: Rebecca Fein | The Daily Collegian
description:
“Best New Artist” Grammy winner, Olivia Dean, knocked it out of the park with her second studio album “The Art of Loving.” The British singer-songwriter wrote a masterpiece that veraciously depicts the meaning of love.

The album starts with a 40 second soft-spoken song entitled “The Art of Loving (Intro).” Although very short, the few lyrics packed a punch.

Dean sings, “It’s the art of loving, it wasn’t all for nothing, yeah you taught me something.” These lyrics being repeated over a mushy melody set the album up for listeners to go in with an open-mind about love, rather than their preconceived notions of good or bad.

The album continues with the slightly more upbeat “Nice To Each Other.” As we join Dean on this journey of exploring love, she gives us the ultimate situationship song. “Nice To Each Other” highlights the balance of living in the moment versus thinking ahead to the future.

Sometimes when you enter a relationship, you know it won’t work out, but Dean says if we let loose, have fun and are nice to each other, we can experience unexpected enjoyment even if it’s short-term.

Following “Nice To Each Other” is “Lady Lady.” A relationship is nothing without personal growth and this bluesy R&B number reminds people to not get used to the person you are because we are all in a stage of becoming. Whether that’s becoming something new, nicer or different, it is something fresh and it is okay to embrace it.

Next on the album is “Close Up.” In this song, we switch back to the softer vibes presented earlier in the album, but this time with a minor scale twist, making the song a little eerie at first. It then picks up in the chorus with short steady trumpet blairs in the background, to keep the pacing quick.

This song harps on the idea of beating yourself up for falling for the wrong person. With lyrics like, “I can’t tell if you need me or want me all that much. Did I misread completely, every single touch,” we get vibes of desperation and anguish.

This energy is quickly washed away when the next song, “So Easy (To Fall In Love)” comes on. This cheery, jazzy, almost dream-like song reminds us that when love is right, it will feel simple and easy.

With “Let Alone The One You Love,” the dejected tone is back. This song is very important, especially to people pleasers who put others before themselves every time.

This song tries to show that if somebody truly loved you they wouldn’t try to diminish you or make you feel less then. But most importantly, they wouldn’t try to hold you back because as Dean says, “who would do that to a friend, let alone the one you love.”

“Man I Need,” Dean’s next song and arguably her most popular, is a fan favorite on the album. “Man I Need” is about exactly its name. In the new year, we’re raising our standards and waiting for someone who is kind, patient and takes care of us. This song blew up on TikTok in late 2025 and was used as the soundtrack for women to claim to the world they are done putting up with lousy guys.

The following track “Something Inbetween” has a quick tempo that is kept by a drum being played in a repeated pattern. This song details the point in a relationship where one could feel an imbalance between dependence and individualism. It’s a gray area. How do we reach equilibrium so yourself as a person and yourself in a couple is equal?

“Loud,” contrary to its name, is about the deafening silence that comes when a partner feels unheard. The daunting melodies in the background, with Dean singing in an untraditional diatonic scale, leads to this gut-wrenching masterpiece.

Dean says “And everything’s unspoken now, I'm out, the silence is so loud,” alluding to the idea that sometimes in relationships, people feel silenced or stifled, but this is no way to have a healthy, stable connection with someone.

As we transition to the end of the album we reach “Baby Steps.” This is a tender and passionate song about navigating heartbreak and welcoming independence. Its upbeat, yet cautious tone heads as a warning that although the process may be slow, you will make it through.

Next is “A Couple Minutes,” a ragtime inspired tune with a swing refrain, this song explores the ideation of running into a past lover. In those few minutes you see this person, your world stops. Maybe you sit and chat for a little, maybe it is just a glance, but either way, you have to remember that real life is waiting for you to return.

Lastly is “I’ve Seen It,” which to put simply, is a beautiful song. An album that depicts the grapples, but also the jubilation that comes with love needed a cohesive, yet reflective ending, and this song did that perfectly.

From “The Art of Loving (Intro)” all the way to “I’ve Seen It,” Olivia Dean tells a compelling story. There will be sorrow, there will be bliss, but where there is love there is existence, waiting to be reveled in.

title: Penn State men's hockey stays at No. 6 in USCHO poll
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State stays at No. 6 in this week's USCHO poll, after its series with No. 2 Michigan last weekend.

The Nittany Lions ended with a 4-4 draw in the first of the two-game series, fueled by freshman defenseman Jackson Smith's two-goal night, breaking the all-time program record for goals by a defenseman in a single season.

title: Tessa Janecke, Team USA defeat Nicole Hall, Jessica Adolfsson, Team Sweden in Olympic Semifinal
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Team USA faced off against Team Sweden on Monday, both 4-0 so far in the Olympic tournament, and both were the zeitgeists of the tournament. Team USA showed exactly how much talent they have, shut out Team Sweden and advanced to the gold medal match 5-0.

The first period opened up with Sweden, which showed immediate control over the puck and looked to get Team USA on its toes early on. The beginning of the period saw a lot of back-and-forth possession, and the United States really looked to get the puck out and around Sweden, often shifting control over to Caroline Harvey.

Team USA kept that control and allowed Cayla Barnes to put the puck through Sweden and score with 14:51 left in the first period.

Team USA received its first power play of the game with 8:21 left in the period, with Sweden's Sara Hjalmarsson getting sent to the box for boarding. That allowed for a boost of confidence for the already strong Team USA to get the puck right up where it wanted it. Team Sweden got back to full strength and immediately got its first shot on goal.

The first period ended 1-0 for Team USA and already showed what kind of game this would be. Team USA came in hot with 13 shots on goal, and Team Sweden continued to sneak around the Americans and use the perimeter around the net, hoping to find a crack in the USA defense.

The second period began, and the Swedes showed obvious fervor, immediately notching two shots on goal and making contact with multiple Team USA players. American goalkeeper Aerin Frankel continued to ward off Team Sweden's attempts at a goal, but obvious cracks began to show in Team USA’s defense.

Team Sweden got its first power play of the game after USA’s Hayley Scamurra received two minutes for tripping.

Team USA grabbed its second goal with 10:51 left in the period after Taylor Heise lobbed it into the net with quality teamwork from Hannah Bilka and Abbey Murphy.

Team Sweden hoped to get back at Team USA by tapping into its second power play of the game and continued to utilize the rest of its roster. Swedish defensemen and former Nittany Lion Jessica Adolfsson was really driving the play down the ice, maneuvering through Team USA.

Murphy snuck around the corner of the Sweden goal and put No. 3 into the net with 15:12 left in the period. Kendall Coyne-Schofield utilized the frenzied Team Sweden and grabbed the fourth goal and Hayley Scamurra put away the fifth, all within two minutes of each other, to take a 5-0 lead.

Tensions continued to rise, and it ended up being 4-on-4 to end the second period, with Murphy and Adolfsson ending up in the box.

With both teams back at full strength, the last period started off with the USA immediately fighting to widen its goal margin, and Sweden trying to create a chance at a goal or two. Nittany Lion Tessa Janecke continued to work around the Swedes and kept herself around the perimeter of Team Sweden’s territory.

Sweden gets a power play with 1:26 left in the third period, but it wasn’t enough to grab a last minute goal, and Team USA will head to the gold medal match after beating the Swedes 5-0.

Up Next

Team USA will face the winner of the Team Canada-Team Switzerland matchup, hitting the ice again for the gold medal game at 1:10 p.m., Thursday, Feb. 19 in Milano, Italy.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Weekly Recap | Rejuvenated Nittany Lions put up mixed results across the nation
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has had an interesting last two weeks, showcasing some life from a team that was struggling to find a win at the beginning of the Big Ten schedule.

Since the last rundown, the blue and white dropped three of four, with two tight games that went both ways for Penn State and a pair of not-so-close outings highlighted by a 41-point battering by No. 2 Michigan in Ann Arbor.

Can’t celebrate the clip

Let’s start with that outing in the Great Lakes State, where Penn State’s three-point shot couldn’t buy a bucket, as the Nittany Lions finished with a measly two makes on 20 attempts. The Nittany Lions’ primary big man, 7-footer Ivan Jurić, had the flu and missed the game, and that long-range approach wasn’t the needed medicine for Penn State’s absence.

That game highlights the sentiment of the blue and white’s play over those four outings; it couldn’t establish a presence from beyond the arc, making just over a quarter of its shots.

This struggle is apparent for Rhoades and Co. The only game in the stretch in which it posted a more efficient three-point performance than its opponent was against Washington, but the Nittany Lions shot a tied season-low 13 long-range attempts in that game, and the Huskies had more makes.

Maybe “less is more” for the Nittany Lions, but it’s clear they need to find a long-term remedy for their streaky three-point shooting. Penn State allowed a team like Oregon, which posts similar marks on the season, to get hot and outshoot it by 20% from three in a double-digit rout.

Nittany Lions, assemble

It wasn’t all bad for the Nittany Lions on the hardwood, as they also saw their unit’s ranks refilled by injury returnees.

Sharpshooter wing Eli Rice returned after a two-game absence due to a midgame head collision suffered against Minnesota, and his services provided crucial support in Penn State’s triumph over the Huskies. The Gallatin, Tennessee, native played 27 minutes and posted an efficient 12-point outing, making the majority of his shot attempts and committing no turnovers.

It didn’t go as well for Rice against the Ducks, with only one make in six shot attempts, but for a Penn State group struggling from long range, it’ll be appreciated to have Rice back, the blue and white’s leader in three-point percentage by over seven percent.

The redshirt sophomore wasn’t the only player who came back; forward Sasǎ Ciani returned after a stint on the bench due to an ankle injury, bringing a needed physical piece back. The Nova Gorica, Slovenia, native appeared in 20 minutes across Penn State’s West Coast trip, and logged four fouls, a steal and a rebound in his time on the court, with no shot attempts.

It leaves only one absence for Penn State, forward Tibor Mirtič, but he’s been reported as day-to-day and has been seen without the sling previously used to help nurse his shoulder injury, so a return could be imminent.

Last-minute deciders

Well, there are two marquee moments left to talk about: USC’s silver screen-esque buzzer-beater to defeat the blue and white, courtesy of hyped Alijah Arenas, and a late-game back-and-forth exchange against the Huskies that ended in Penn State victory.

Happy Valley had to play the victim to possibly Arenas’ first moment as a star in the game of basketball, and it was a stellar move with almost nothing Penn State could have done to stop it. Rhoades did claim postgame that a Penn State player, whom he didn’t name, failed to switch correctly on the possession.

The Nittany Lions almost suffered the same fate against Washington, accidentally leaving a man open with six milliseconds left on the clock to huck up an open three that would have sent the game to overtime – except it didn’t fall.

It would’ve soured the Nittany Lions' day, as they fought to control a game late, which was tied with a little over a minute on the clock.

Although these two games stick out over the stretch of recent play by Penn State, there is one that needs to be praised more than any, and that's of the blue and white’s only real returning rotational player from last season, Freddie Dilione V.

Dilione has had some of the craftiest buckets the Bryce Jordan Center has ever seen, fitting of the Kobe’s he can be seen rocking. The influence on Dilione’s game is clear, as the Penn State guard has begun to make a home in the midrange.

Over the last four games, the Fayetteville, North Carolina, Native has led the Nittany Lions in scoring in all but one game.

The junior has been a real iron man of sorts for Penn State, only trailing freshman Kayden Mingo in minutes per game for Penn State, while being one of four players to play all 26 games. That continued over this last stretch, where Dilione played all 40 minutes against the Wolverines.
