title: Column | The unsung hero in the Bob Dylan canon
author: Emma Strickling | The Daily Collegian
description:
When you think of Bob Dylan, what comes to mind? Is it his “inability” to sing? Is it his songwriting prowess? Or is it the fact that Timothée Chalamet portrayed him in a movie last year?

Love him, hate him, or are completely unfamiliar with him, there’s no question that Bob Dylan is one of the most significant figures in music and culture. Throughout his lengthy career, he’s created roughly 40 studio albums and has received several accolades, including 10 Grammys, an Academy Award for Best Original Song, and, most notably, the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016.

But if you dig through all the work he’s done, there’s one project that doesn’t get enough recognition: his radio show.

Debuting in May of 2006, “Theme Time Radio Hour” was a show hosted by Bob Dylan. It aired on the SiriusXM channel Deep Tracks and ran until April 2009. Although the show no longer runs on the platform, recordings can be found via YouTube.

With every episode, the mood is set by its signature “nighttime in the big city” introduction read by actress Ellen Barkin. It’s poetic and oftentimes moody, describing the atmosphere of life in a big city and the people in it. It can be spoken with chatter, jazz music and the sound of rain in the background.

After the ambience has been set, enter the host, Bob Dylan. Each episode, he introduces a theme around which each music selection is centered. Some of the themes that have been used include, but are not limited to, wedding, the moon and days of the week.

The song selection isn’t one that’s obvious. It’s an eclectic mix of tunes, mostly featuring songs from the mid-twentieth century, possibly the music that inspired a young Dylan while he was in Minnesota. In between each song, Dylan provides facts about the artists as well as poetry related to the theme and even his own legendary commentary.

While this might seem obscure and irrelevant now, its value is something that continues to last.

The show highlights the work of artists who have contributed to the music scene and might not be as well-known today as they were at the time of their artistry. Much like a memory, their work and their own image can fade away if not kept alive. The show acts as a reminder of the music that has helped to shape music into the way it’s now.

It provides the listener with the experience of the evolution of music and the people who helped lay the foundation for certain genres. For example, one artist who has been featured on “Theme Time Radio Hour” is Sister Rosetta Tharpe, who is considered to be the godmother of Rock n’ Roll and is ranked number six on Rolling Stone’s “250 Greatest Guitarists of All Time.”

Now I’m not saying this show saved her from disappearing from history; her talent and music can stand on their own. But it’s through a show like Dylan’s that her music reaches a broader audience and further broadens their musical horizons.

It’s an engaging space, one that you can often leave with more information than you came with, either about the theme of the episode or about a musical artist. It’s a new take and isn’t some redundant and dull commercial type of radio.

In terms of Dylan himself, the show is an opportunity for him to showcase another side of himself. He has been known to adopt many personas throughout his career. It’s hard to say where the distinction between fabrication and reality lies. While the DJ version can seem like yet another mask in a closet full of them, Dylan’s wit and interest in music seem to be qualities that are genuine, providing a more personal look into the enigmatic artist.

Much like Bob Dylan, “Theme Time Radio Hour” is another singular entity. While it might only exist through YouTube now, the value of the show still lives on. Wannabe radio show hosts can try and select music to a theme while inserting their own commentary, but only Dylan’s essence can deliver a show of such caliber.

MORE COLUMNS

title: ‘I've never met anyone like him’| Penn State couple shares their love story
author: Lily Dorf | The Daily Collegian
description:
As the season of love comes to a close, many college students are mourning the crushes and long-lost loves that never came to be. Dating in college is no easy challenge. However, for two students, the near impossible became a reality.

Keerthana Rajamohan and Ansh Ahuja have been together for three and a half years, and started dating during Rajamohan’s first year when a mutual friend introduced them.

The two met in-person during a night out, and the rest is history. Rajamohan, a fourth-year student studying supply chain management, said she easily recalls how they fell in love.

“We just got along right off the bat,” Rajamohan said. “He is very respectful and such a great gentleman. Honestly, I've never met anyone like him before, so I was hooked.”

For Ahuja, the moment he fell for Rajamohan was straight out of a romantic comedy.

“I remembered that I was just walking around the Palmerton — literally in circles — on the phone with my mom and talking about this girl,” Ahuja said. “I told my mom during my junior or senior year of high school that I don't think I could get into a relationship because I love myself too much, (and) it sounds a little narcissistic, I know. But the fact that I was pacing around, contemplating this, I hung up the phone, and I kind of knew that I really wanted to do this because I wouldn't have even considered this if I was really hesitant about it.”

Ahuja graduated with a degree in labor and human resources in spring 2025 and the two are now long-distance.

Rajamohan’s friend, Danielle Bocchieri, has seen the couple through all of their stages and describes their relationship as “supportive.”

“I think that they both do a really good job putting their personal lives first and foremost, and then using the relationship to kind of just support them and help them grow and be the best version of themselves,” Bocchierri, a fourth-year student studying biology said.

For many, the idea of having a relationship in college isn’t possible, from schedules not lining up to hours of studying and other priorities taking hold. However, Rajamohan sees it differently.

“I think that being in college has definitely made us stronger and I think that we are both focusing on ourselves, but also being there for one another,” Rajamohan said. “We both have our lives. He has his job and I have school.”

Ahuja said he’s happy he was able to experience a college love story, despite there being stigma around college relationships.

“I wanted a deep and meaningful personal relationship with someone who I truly like and I truly love,” Ahuja said. “So I'm glad that I got to experience, I guess, the unpopular experience in college.”

Rajamohan and Ahuja said they’re always there for each other. The pair know if a trip to see one another doesn’t work out, they’ll still end the day with each other over the phone.

When talking about the challenges of long distance, Ahuja said they support each other as people first, not just another person in the relationship.

“I didn't want her to come to college, get into a relationship and be solely focused on the relationship,” Ahuja said. “Rather, she came to college for a reason, as did I. So again, we're really supportive of … each other's hobbies, our goals and our aspirations.”

Ahuja said he doesn't view their relationship as a chore.

“I think it's about perspective as well,” Ahuja said. “I don't view this relationship as something I have to do. Rather, it’s something I get to do.”

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Penn State dual-sport athlete Maggie Mendelson is ‘high-level’ on both courts
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
On Dec. 20, 2025, Maggie Mendelson took the hardwood court holding a basketball just 14 days after finishing her Penn State volleyball career.

Mendelson became the first two-sport athlete for Penn State since 2019 — when Mac Hippenhammer played both football and baseball for the school — when she announced her decision to join the Lady Lions on June 25.

“When I was going through recruiting, my parents told me not to let anyone force me to do something I didn’t want to,” Mendelson told The Daily Collegian. “I think it’d be a really cool opportunity if I could play two sports, and nobody ever told me I couldn’t.”

While the North Ogden, Utah, native finished her career playing both volleyball and basketball in Happy Valley, it wasn’t that straight of a path for the two-sport star.

“Growing up, I always played a lot of sports like volleyball, basketball, softball, tennis, track and kind of just did it all,” Mendelson said. “My dad also played basketball and baseball in college, so playing multiple sports was just running in the family.”

Mendelson was ranked 32nd in the nation in basketball and fourth in volleyball, giving her an opportunity to play either sport collegiately.

When she went to Nebraska, her coaches gave her the chance to play both sports, which she did her freshman year.

The 6-foot-5 forward played in 22 games with the Cornhuskers, averaging 2.0 points and 2.2 rebounds per game. On the volleyball court, she appeared in 14 matches and recorded 47 kills.

“When I went to Nebraska, I decided to play volleyball and basketball just because they had a great plan,” Mendelson said. “It just felt really welcoming and open.”

After her first year in both sports, Mendelson put her basketball career on the side, focusing on her more dominant sport in volleyball.

Mendelson saw a slight decrease in playing time her sophomore year, playing just 26 sets. Following Year 2, she entered the transfer portal and landed at Penn State in 2024.

In her first year with the blue and white, Mendelson played a career-high 127 sets in 37 matches, recording 242 kills.As the season progressed, Mendelson’s efforts as a leader became apparent, helping the Nittany Lions to several big wins en route to an NCAA tournament appearance.

“She’s a phenomenal leader,” coach Carolyn Kieger said.

Following the conclusion of the regular season, the Nittany Lions earned wins in the NCAA first round, second round, regional semifinal and regional final before taking the court against Nebraska in the NCAA semifinals.

Shocking the volleyball world, Mendelson and Penn State engineered a reverse sweep against the Cornhuskers, clinching an NCAA championship appearance. After sweeping Louisville earlier in the season, the Nittany Lions won the national championship 3-1 amidst coach Katie Schumacher-Cawley’s cancer journey.

“What volleyball did to win that national championship, I think it still gives everybody chills,” Kieger said. “Fighting through adversity and being a phenomenal leader and having their team play with so much joy and so much passion on that floor for that jersey.”

The Nittany Lions ended their season victorious, and in the months to come, Mendelson announced her decision to rekindle her passion for basketball and compete in both sports for the 2025-26 season.

“I’m so excited for Maggie,” Kieger said. “She’s high level, not only on the volleyball court, but the basketball court as well.”

Mendelson took the volleyball court for her senior season, and despite not earning another national championship, made her mark on the program’s history.

After seeing her success on the volleyball court, the Lady Lions were excited for her to join them on the basketball court later that season.

“I think she’s got a live, active body, in terms of energy,” general manager Jason Crafton said. “She runs the floor very well, she’s long. She’s just a high-energy player that’s a competitor.”

The Nittany Lions’ volleyball season ended on Dec. 6 with a shutout loss to Texas in the NCAA first round, and within a few days, Mendelson was already in the Bryce Jordan Center practice gym, looking to earn playing time on the court.

“(The transition) has been pretty difficult, I’m not gonna lie,” Mendelson said. “It’s just a completely different sport. The physicality is something that I’ve definitely lost touch with for the past couple years, just because there’s the net between you in volleyball, so now I’m definitely getting bruised up.”

Despite the tough transition back into the game, Mendelson earned her first minutes on Dec. 20 against VCU and appeared in the starting lineup for the first time the following day.

While she recorded only eight points in nearly 30 minutes, her playing time was highlighted by her on-court leadership that helped motivate the Lady Lions in a difficult loss.

“I think I really try to bring my winning mindset to practice every day and just make sure that I’m putting myself into the most competitive mindset so it feeds off onto everybody else,” Mendelson said. “I think that if you’re around winners all the time, a winning mindset starts to become natural.”

Over the past month-and-a-half of action, Mendelson’s time on the court has decreased slightly, and she’s only scored seven total points through the last nine games.Regardless, Mendelson said she’s grateful for the opportunity to play two sports.

“I think it’s a really cool opportunity for me to be a role model for a lot of young kids who are always told to just choose one,” Mendelson said. “I just want to be a role model to those kids, that you don't have to choose one, you don't have to limit yourself, because there's a lot of opportunities for you to follow your dreams to the fullest extent. I always just want to be a role model and live out my dreams and really become the best person and athlete that I can be.”

With her first year with the Lady Lions coming to a close over the next few weeks, Mendelson will have the opportunity to suit up for Penn State one last time next year and bring success to her squad.

“She’s been to where we’re trying to get,” Kieger said. “I have zero doubts that she’s going to come in here and help the program from Day 1.”

MORE SPORTS COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling Black history through Collegian reporting
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State introduced its wrestling program in 1908 and has since become one of the most storied programs in the sport’s history. However, much like the program’s success, its history of trailblazing Black athletes is a more recent trend.

For the first 80-plus years of the program, there were no records of a Black national champion. This is due to the sport as a whole taking a long time to become more inclusive throughout the 20th century. As the demographics of the sport changed, the Nittany Lions were the home of history for Black athletes both in college and beyond.

In 1992, Penn State welcomed the man who would be their first Black national champion in Kerry McCoy. The heavyweight entered the program as a coveted prospect, having only lost one match in his final two years of high school and competing internationally before arriving at Rec Hall.

McCoy’s sophomore year in 1994 saw him rise to the top of the nation, becoming Penn State’s first Black national champion, and its first wrestler to win a title in his sophomore season. By the end of his collegiate career, McCoy won two national championships, three Big Ten titles, and went on an 88-match winning streak. He later qualified for two Olympic rosters, including a fifth-place finish in 2000.

But McCoy is also known for his status as an advocate for inclusion in the sport of wrestling. He began this ambition while he was in high school, and has continued to speak on diversity in wrestling throughout his career.

As the millennium crossed into the year 2000, the landscape of wrestling began to shift into the modern diverse demographic seen today. Penn State employed trailblazers in the decade, including one of the most unique stories in college sports history in paraplegic wrestler Rohan Murphy who lost both of his legs at birth.

Murphy dreamt of becoming an athlete in his youth and in ninth grade, he tried out for wrestling. After receiving training from former NCAA, UFC and WWE Champion Brock Lesnar, Murphy saw success in his senior year before attending Penn State.

When Murphy asked to join the Penn State wrestling team, coach Troy Sunderland met him with skepticism. He invited him down to Mount Nittany where he directed his team to run to the top as their first day of training. Murphy crawled up the mountain, reaching his teammates in 90 minutes.

The New York City native managed a 5-15 record against able-bodied opponents in the Big Ten, and since graduating, became a power lifter and motivational speaker seeking to inspire youth going through similar struggles for himself.

In 2008, Penn State celebrated its second Black champion, Phil Davis. Known as “Mr. Wonderful,” Davis was the first Black Nittany Lion to become a four-time All-American between 2004-08. It took him until his senior year to secure his elusive national title.

Immediately after winning his national title, Davis transitioned to mixed martial arts, where he made even more of a name for himself. The Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, native won the Bellator light heavyweight championship in 2016 and continued competing in the sport until 2025. Davis set the precedent for future Nittany Lions like Bo Nickal, Carter Starocci and Greg Kerkvliet to take their skills into MMA.

The 2010s marked over 100 years of the Penn State wrestling program, where it saw the start of the dynasty it has become. Since Cael Sanderson took over in 2011, the Nittany Lions have revolutionized wrestling with a diverse group spearheading the legacy.

Two years into Sanderson’s tenure, the first pair of Black teammates to win national championships together in blue and white occurred. Ed Ruth and Quentin Wright won individual titles in 2013. It was the second national title for each of them, with Ruth going on to win a third in 2014. After his 136-3 college career ended, Ruth joined McCoy in his advocacy for the sport of wrestling.

Ruth also set off a run of success at the 174-pound weight class for Black athletes at Penn State, as after he graduated, Mark Hall made an impact at the weight class.

Hall was the first Black freshman to take home a national championship trophy to Happy Valley. Hall graduated in 2020, giving up the 174 pound spot to Starocci, which led a trio of history makers for Penn State in the first half of the decade.

Starocci, Kerkvliet and Aaron Brooks accomplished historical feats that seemed mathematically impossible as recently as 2019. Due to the COVID-19, Starocci and Kerkvleit were able to become five-time All-Americans.

Brooks and Starocci combined to become the first teammates to win four-individual national titles in the same lineup. Brooks went on to win a bronze medal in the 2024 Olympics, while Starocci remained with Penn State to become the only wrestler in history to win a fifth National Championship.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: This week in State College
author: Reese Igou | The Daily Collegian
description:
A busy week approaches as students, staff and community members around State College prepare for THON weekend. Here are some events to look forward to this week.

Monday, February 16

Study Smarter Session

As students gear up to take midterms , Penn State Learning is hosting a Study Smarter Zoom workshop at 6 p.m. for students to improve their studying skills.

The session is an interactive workshop based on metacognition research evidence to help promote efficiency in studying and retaining information.

Students can RSVP for free through Discover or on the Penn State Learning website.

Yoga & Meditation

Join Penn State Health Promotion and Wellness for their weekly body and mind restorative practice.

There are two times offered on Monday, one at 12:30 p.m. in the HUB-Robeson Center and the other at 5:30 p.m. in the Pasquerilla Memorial Lounge. No RSVP is required.

Tuesday, February 17

Mardi Gras 2026

The Education and Public Policy Undergraduate Student Association concludes its Mardi Gras festivities with a celebration on Fat Tuesday in the Rackley Building.

The event will be held from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., with fun activities and free food. It’s free to attend and you can RSVP to the event through the Discover PSU page.

Wednesday, February 18

Meal Planning for Balanced Nutrition Workshop

The Sustainable Food Systems Program is hosting a free workshop to help attendees enhance meal planning skills and promote overall nutrition.

The event will take place in the HUB from 12-1p.m. with free snacks for all registered attendees.

Leverage Your Pride: Virtual Career Support Event!

Penn State World Campus Career Services and Alumni Career Services are hosting an online training event at 7:30 p.m. on Wednesday.

Attendees can participate in two mini training sessions as well as ask questions about networking tools, interview etiquette, job searches and other career-oriented elements.

Anyone who is interested in the event can register through this link.

Penn State Basketball vs. Rutgers

The Penn State Nittany Lions take on the Rutgers Scarlet Knights Wednesday in the Bryce Jordan Center at 6 p.m. This is the first of two games the Nittany Lions will play against the Scarlet Knights this season.

Tickets are on sale through Ticketmaster starting at just $10.

Friday, February 20

THON Weekend

On Friday, State College and Penn Staters will gather in the Bryce Jordan Center at 6 p.m for the 46-hour-long, no-sitting, no-sleeping dance marathon.

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

Penn State Men’s Hockey vs. Ohio State

At 8:30 p.m. in the Pegula Ice Arena, the Penn State Nittany Lions will take on the Ohio State Buckeyes for the first game in their weekend series. Penn State is currently ranked fifth in the country and third in the Big Ten conference.

Tickets start at $24 and are for sale on Ticketmaster.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Happy Valley Golfing Levels Up at Bellefonte's Wyndham Gardens
author: Collegian Business Division
description:
The blankets of snow will be melting before we know it, welcoming golfers to hit the greens. Here in State College, that means going to Mountain View Country Club in Boalsburg.

Although Mountain View once may have only been known for traditional, outdoor golf, the club is leveling up with two brand new golf simulators and two professional-grade racing simulators.

If your golf skills aren’t up to par and you want to get some practice in before the season starts, or you just prefer the idea of staying indoors, Hacktivist Happy Valley is the place for you.

Just a flight of stairs down from The View restaurant, sits the Hacktivist Happy Valley lounge where the simulators are housed. Complete with couches, multiple TVs and high-top tables, this space is perfect for a casual gathering with friends and family or for a more upscale social for a club or organization.

Hacktivist Happy Valley Lounge

It’s not just your ordinary golf practice space either. Its warm, welcoming ambience creates a sense of comfort that will make you want to come back again and again. Open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., Hacktivist Happy Valley is a space for all Penn State students, faculty and staff to unwind and de-stress.

“Hacktivist Happy Valley is social, welcoming and reflects where hospitality is heading, which is towards experiences that bring people together in meaningful ways” Charles Creek, the Food and Beverage Director for Wyndham Garden and Mountain View Country Club, said. “We’re proud to offer something that feels fresh for Happy Valley, while honoring the tradition of Mountain View County Club.”

If you’ve never used golf or racing simulators before, there’s no need to worry; they don’t require any experience. Hacktivist Happy Valley gives everyone, no matter the skill level, the opportunity to take a break from the stress of school and work and just have an enjoyable time.

With additional interactive games such as mini-golf programmed into the golf simulators, and many extra features on the racing simulator, there’s a ton of different options to choose from so that everyone can get involved, no matter their interests.

The View

You can also order food and beverages from The View restaurant through a kiosk in the lounge, making the area the ideal place to hang out, grab a bite to eat and have a great time. The View offers delicious options including shareable appetizers and elevated comfort food. One of Creek’s personal favorite dishes is the Loaded View Chips (piled high with toppings).

For students who may be on a budget, there are plenty of food deals that won’t break the bank. There’s also themed days such as Burger Night Wednesday and Wing Thursday.

Creek mentioned that Hacktivist Happy Valley is a social lounge first and a golf practice area second. It’s a place for people to get together and just have fun.

“Ultimately, Hacktivist Happy Valley and The View are about connection,” Creek said. “We wanted to create a space where people can step away from routines, share a great meal, enjoy a little friendly competition and leave feeling like they experienced something memorable.”

title: Win on the court and in the battle | Penn State women’s basketball earns big win over Northwestern in Pink Zone game
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Twenty years ago, a $5,000 check marked the beginning of the Pink Zone, an annual partnership between the Pennsylvania Pink Zone and Penn State.

On Sunday, the 20th anniversary of the Pink Zone game was held during the Lady Lions’ matchup against Northwestern.

“This is a wonderful event,” Tammy Miller, the Pennsylvania Pink Zone president, said. “The main goal of today is to recognize survivors."

Including a pre-game ceremony with survivors walking the “pink carpet” and a halftime dedicated to recognizing survivors, Sunday’s game featured moments to honor those who've experienced breast cancer.

The Lady Lions’ game was also full of big moments, as they defeated Northwestern 81-71 for their second conference win of the year to stay alive in postseason play.

“I’m glad we were able to get a win in front of them tonight because it means so much more than playing a game of basketball, and the fight of their life is so inspiring to us,” coach Carolyn Kieger said. “It’s good to give them a little joy today.”

After starting hot with a 22-13 first quarter, Penn State’s success continued into the second half, extending the lead by five points.

During halftime, the breast cancer survivors took over the court with signs displaying how long they’ve been cancer-free. For some, it was just a few months, but for others, it was 65 years of survivorship.

The hundreds of survivors in attendance totaled 1,932 years, seven months and 20 days of breast cancer survivorship.

“It’s a really fun game to look forward to. We look forward to it every year,” Moriah Murray said. “We’re really playing for something bigger than ourselves, and we love getting the crowd engaged. Just seeing all the survivors and everyone fighting really gives us the energy going into the game.”

For the Lady Lions, it was more than just the survivors in attendance, but people who were close to them.

Per freshman Tea Cleante’s Instagram, her grandmother was diagnosed a few months ago with breast cancer.

For Maggie Mendelson, women’s volleyball coach Katie Schumacher-Cawley was the one she was playing for. After being diagnosed with breast cancer on Sept. 24, 2024, Schumacher-Cawley led Mendelson and the Nittany Lions to a national championship, becoming the first female head coach to earn the honor.

“Since Maggie is on our team, we get to see coach Katie,” Murray said. “I just think it’s so special to play again for something bigger than ourselves, especially someone that we know so close in coach Katie, who’s an amazing person.”

After the lead was cut to just nine points in the third quarter and even closer throughout the fourth, Penn State closed out the game on a 7-0 run in front of thousands of fans and survivors.

“There’s a sisterhood here,” Miller said. “Some people in here will be diagnosed next week, some people were diagnosed a year ago, and some are going to be 35-year survivors. It’s the sisterhood that obviously, you’re not alone.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball avoids comeback bid, defeats Northwestern for second conference win
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State welcomed Northwestern for its annual ‘Pink Zone’ game on Sunday afternoon. The matchup was a battle of two teams at the bottom of the conference standings fighting for a spot in the Big Ten Tournament.

“I just want to highlight the 20th anniversary of the pink zone,” coach Carolyn Kieger said. “And it's so awesome to play for survivors and play for something bigger than yourself.”

The Lady Lions escaped the Wildcats comeback, winning 81-71.

“I was extremely proud of our composure in that fourth quarter,” Kieger said.

Northwestern won the jump, but after a missed layup from Tayla Thomas, Gracie Merkle grabbed the rebound for Penn State as the ball found its way to Tèa Clèante for two points to get the scoring started

Senior guard Caroline Lau answered with a three-pointer on the other end to get the Wildcats on the board, but then it was all Lady Lions.

Penn State exploded for an 8-0 run to take a 10-3 lead just about three minutes into the opening frame.

After a 1-for-2 effort on the free throw from Merkle gave the Lady Lions an 11-5 advantage, scoring went silent on both sides for about two minutes until Lau hit her second three-pointer of the day to make it a one-possession game.

Northwestern couldn’t threaten anymore, allowing the blue and white to go on another scoring run, this time for seven unanswered points to take an 18-8 lead with three minutes left in the first quarter.

Penn State completed its stellar opening frame with a 22-13 edge behind nine points from Kiyomi McMiller. Defense was the story of the Lady Lions’ first quarter effort, recording four steals and scoring 11 points from the seven Wildcats’ turnovers.

Moriah Murray got the party started in the second frame with her second three-pointer of the game. Lau attempted to match her on the other end, but instead, McMiller snagged the rebound and found Merkle on the other end for two points.

“Today, we put four quarters together, which is something we've been talking about,” Kieger said. “So we're trying to stack days, trying to stack practices. We're trying to stack film sessions and just keep teaching, keep getting better.”

The blue and white kept the game in its hands, exploding for a 9-0 run to start the quarter. The Wildcats, on the other hand, started the second quarter 0-for-8 from field-goal range. The drought was broken by an and-one from forward Grace Sullivan.

Penn State answered with another deep ball from Murray to take a 34-16 lead with five minutes to play.

Sullivan scored the next four points of the game, all from the charity stripe, but Northwestern couldn’t extend its run after McMiller went 2-for-2 in her first trip of the day to the free throw line.

After a two-point jumper from Casey Harter for the Wildcats, both teams went scoreless for the last three minutes of the half, giving the Lady Lions a 36-22 lead.

McMiller led all scorers with 13 points, as Penn State built off Northwestern’s 18% first half shooting percentage.

Penn State picked up right where it left off, scoring six unanswered points to start the third quarter. The Wildcats answered with four straight points from Kat Righeimer.

After Nyla McFadden recorded her first points of the game on a fastbreak layup, Righeimer continued her strong quarter with an and-one on the other end.

The Lady Lions responded with five straight points to go up 49-34, but back-to-back threes from Harter and Xamiya Walton helped Northwestern chip into the lead.

With just under three minutes to play in the third, McMiller put Penn State up 53-40, but three foul shots from Righeimer put the Wildcats within 10.

Following a Lady Lions’ turnover, Sullivan posted a 1-for-2 effort from the line, but McMiller got three points back on the other side.

Northwestern outscored Penn State 5-2 in the final 30 seconds to make it a 58-49 game heading into the final frame.

Merkle scored the first points of the quarter, but five points from Lau brought the Wildcats within six.

A fastbreak layup from McMiller was outdone by a three from Righeimer as Northwestern kept creeping closer. The Wildcats made it a one-possession game for the first time in a long time, with a layup from Lau.

However, the Lady Lions held their own, going on a 6-0 run to take a 69-59 lead with five minutes left.

A three-pointer by Walton and a pair of free throws from Lau put Northwestern within five once again, but a couple of trips to the foul line helped conserve Penn State’s lead as the blue and white held a 72-66 edge with under two minutes remaining.

The Wildcats got two points of their own from the charity stripe to cut the lead to four with a minute left. Merkle immediately matched with a layup on the other end.

Northwestern wasn’t done yet, down six with 43 seconds left, Sullivan came up with an and-one to make the score 74-71.

“It got away from us a little bit there on a couple of those silly turnovers, but we weathered it,” Kieger said. “We got composed and we bounced back, which was really good to see.”

In the bonus, McMiller went 2-for-2 from the foul line to regain a two-possession lead as the Wildcats called a timeout to receive the ball on the sideline.

Clèante came up big for Penn State on the defensive end, drawing a charge to give the Lady Lions the ball back.

McMiller hit two more foul shots with 30 seconds left to give herself a fourth-straight 30-point outing and just about seal the deal for Penn State.

Up Next

Penn State travels to New Jersey for its second meeting of the season against Rutgers, with tipoff set for 4 p.m. Saturday.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball suffers blowout loss to Kansas State in final game of MLB Desert Invitational
author: Ashley Felsberg I The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State was fresh off a 9-3 win against GCU, ahead of Game 3 in the MLB Desert Invitational against Kansas State. That game saw strong pitching, keeping the Antelopes scoring to a minimum.

As Penn State took on Kansas State Sunday afternoon, the Nittany Lions saw quite the role reversal, losing 24-5 in seven innings.

The Nittany Lions started the game in the field, with freshman Isaiah Shayter pitching. The first inning saw no offensive action on either side. Kansas State had one hit, but a groundout, along with a strikeout and Robby Bolin got caught stealing at second.

Penn State second baseman Jayden Davis knocked a double in his first at-bat, but the Nittany Lions weren’t able to get a run under their belts, with designated hitter Michael Anderson grounding out, along with center fielder Cohl Mercado and third baseman Bryce Molinaro striking out swinging.

The second inning is where the bats came alive and each team capitalized. Redshirt sophomore Micah Kendrick got his first hit of the season, a double to right field. This spark of momentum allowed both redshirt senior Kyan Lodice and junior Dee Kennedy to score.

After conceding two runs, Penn State’s Joey DeMucci knocked a single to reach base. Following his hit, bases were loaded. Shortstop Preston Yaucher gets an RBI, sending right fielder Jack Porter to get Penn State on the board.

Following the second inning, Penn State’s scoring began to gradually decline, whereas the Wildcats kept going strong. Bolin and Grant Gallagher each got on base and scored following Shintaro Inoue’s single base hit.

As the game entered the third inning, Penn State regained a short moment of momentum, with a Davis single, Anderson walk and Porter double, allowing Davis to score the blue and white’s second run.

Things began to heat up in the bottom of the fourth, and Kansas State coach Peter Hughes was thrown out of the game. Following this confrontation, Penn State scored their third run following Mercado’s single to center field.

It seemed as though Penn State would go on a run at any moment to close the gap between the two offenses, but just when the Nittany Lions were able to score, Kansas State shut it down with a double play to end the fourth inning.

As the fifth inning crept in, Kennedy continued to lead the Wildcats in an offensive domination, with a home run hit over the left field wall. With this, Penn State continued to dig itself a hole. Scoring didn’t stop there for Kansas State, as sophomore Ty Smolinski’s hit allowed AJ Evasco to earn the Wildcats’ eighth run, Penn State still frozen at four.

At the bottom of the sixth, left fielder Jesse Jaconski earned his first home run of 2026, and gave Penn State its fourth run of the matchup.

The seventh inning was Kansas State’s sixth straight inning with scoring, and seemingly wiped out Penn State’s chances of a late-game revival. Kennedy continued to dominate, hitting a grand slam to left field. This home run was Kenedy’s third homer of the weekend, and second of the day, along with his 13th RBI.

Penn State seemed as though it couldn’t catch a break, regardless of its two outs. A shortstop error allowed Kansas State’s Cadyn Karl and Nick English to score, and the Wildcats lengthened their lead to 20 runs, 13 of them coming from the top of the seventh inning.

The bottom of the seventh inning was where the Nittany Lions saw their last look of offensive life with a hit from Davis. While Davis grounded out, Justin Turcovski scored Penn State’s fifth run. The offense was short-lived, as Avery Smith struck out looking and Porter grounded out, concluding the game at 24-5 in the seventh inning by mercy rule.

Up Next

Penn State will play Richmond at 1 p.m. Friday at Pitt Field in Richmond, Virginia, for a nonconference matchup.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Preview | 3 Penn State women’s hockey players to face off in Olympic semifinals
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Team USA and Team Sweden — after coming away with shutout victories in their respective quarterfinal games — are set to face each other in the semifinals of the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games’ women’s ice hockey tournament at 10:40 a.m. on Monday.

Both teams boast undefeated, 5-0, records as the only teams remaining in the tournament to have not lost a game so far. Team USA and Team Sweden are playing to see who’ll face the winner of the reigning Olympic champions from Beijing 2022, Team Canada, who faces Team Switzerland in the other semifinal game.

American dominance

Team USA has been the team to beat all tournament long. Currently, the Americans are on a four-game shutout streak, most recently defeating Team Italy, 6-0, in the quarterfinal game.

In the preliminary games, Team USA defeated Team Czechia, 5-1, before stringing together a series of 5-0 victories over Team Finland, Team Switzerland and Team Canada.

The Americans, having only allowed a single goal, rank as the top penalty kill in the tournament with a perfect success rate on all eight of their disadvantages.

Team USA, backed by Boston Fleet (PWHL) goaltender Aerin Frankel, outscored its opponents 26-1 through five games. Frankel, having played in three of the five games, paces all goaltenders with a .978 save-percentage and .033 goals-against average.

Caroline Harvey, a senior defenseman for the Wisconsin Badgers of the WCHA, currently leads the tournament with nine points. Her seven assists lead the statistics.

Hannah Bilka and Team Sweden’s Thea Johansson stand at the top of the tournament’s goal-scoring charts with four goals each.

Tessa Janecke is the lone Nittany Lion to represent Team USA in Olympic ice hockey this year and has performed aptly in her role as the fourth-line center. While Penn State’s captain hasn’t scored thus far, she’s contributed four assists in five games, with her most recent helper coming in the quarterfinals.

Team USA has five players tied for third with four assists each, including Janecke, Abbey Murphy, Laila Edwards, Britta Curl and Megan Keller.

Swedish streak

Team Sweden’s 2-0 victory over Team Czechia was deemed an upset, as the Czechs placed third in Group A, posting a 1-2-1 record.

The leaders of Group B are on a three-game shutout streak and have only allowed two goals in total in the tournament, outscoring its opponents 20-2.

Team Sweden possesses the second-ranked powerplay in the tournament, with a 31.3% success rate. On the other end of the ice, it has the third-ranked penalty kill with an even 90%.

Hanna Olsson leads Team Sweden with seven points in the tournament, scoring three goals and adding four assists, tied for second in the tournament. She is closely followed by Johansson, who’s tallied six points.

Goaltender Ebba Traff Svensson ranks second, right behind Frankel, with a .976 save percentage and a 0.50 goals-against-average through four games played.

Penn State has one current player and one alumna listed on Team Sweden’s roster. Nicole Hall, a sophomore at Penn State, has yet to register a point. Meanwhile, Jessica Adolfsson, Class of 2021 and member of the Ottawa Charge (PWHL), scored her only goal of the tournament in Team Sweden’s 6-1 victory over Team Italy in the preliminary round

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE

title: Recruiting roundup | Recapping Penn State’s latest efforts heading into February dead period
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
After a busy January on the recruiting trail for Penn State, the February dead period has arrived.

Here’s a recap of all the action the last few weeks.

Junior Day

Penn State hosted its second Junior Day of the Matt Campbell era during the final weekend in January. Recruits watched the men’s hockey team take on Michigan State in Beaver Stadium.

That weekend also brought the Nittany Lions’ first 2028 commitment under Campbell, landing a pledge from 2028 cornerback Deonte Flemings. He was unranked when he committed but is now a 3-star in the 247Sports composite rankings.

He’s the No. 132 player nationally, No. 12 cornerback and No. 3 player in Pennsylvania.

Three-star 2027 defensive lineman Stanley Montgomery was also in attendance. He was committed to Syracuse at the time of the visit, but backed off his pledge after Junior Day.

Montgomery, who plays for Archbishop Ryan High School in Philadelphia, was visited twice at school by the staff. The first time was by defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe and edge rushers coach Christian Smith. The second group of visitors were Campbell and running backs coach Savon Huggins.

There were also a trio of former Iowa State priority 2027 targets in attendance in 4-star linebacker Case Alexander, 4-star interior offensive lineman Will Slagle and 3-star linebacker Blake Betton.

Alexander is the brother of Iowa State transfer and current Penn State tight end Cooper Alexander and son of former NFL tight end Stephen Alexander. Slagle was a former Cyclone commit. Betton locked in an official visit for the summer.

An offensive lineman who visited and has a connection to the current roster was 4-star 2027 offensive tackle Davis Seaman. He plays for Bishop Watterson High School in Ohio, which is where 2026 signee Pete Eglitis attended.

Other ranked visitors in the 2027 class included 4-star linebacker Tysir Young, 3-star running back Kelvin Morrison and 3-star athlete DJ Davis. Unranked prospects in the 2027 class who made the trip were defensive lineman Cahron Wheeler and a pair of cornerbacks in Ryan Drakeford and DeNairo Girton Jr.

Final lists

Recruits are starting to narrow down schools, so with a handful of prospects releasing their final group of schools, Penn State made the cut for some but also missed out on others in the 2027 class.

The Nittany Lions made the top-4 schools for 3-star safety Zayvon Miller, top five for 4-star interior offensive lineman Kyler Kuhn, top eight for 4-star defensive lineman George Toia and top 10 for 5-star defensive lineman Marcus Fakatou.

Penn State didn’t make the final four schools for 5-star interior offensive lineman Maxwell Hiller and 4-star linebacker Noah Glover.

Hiller’s current finalists are Ohio State, Alabama, Florida and Tennessee. Assuming he takes an official visit to all of his top schools, the in-state talent will have one weekend open for Penn State to potentially re-enter the race.

Glover was a target for both the new and old staff, as he was re-offered by the Nittany Lions in January. The Haymarket, Virginia, native notably included Virginia Tech in his top-six schools after being re-offered by James Franklin in addition to Georgia, Notre Dame, Oregon, Miami and Texas A&M.

Pittsburgh native Jimmy Kalis, who plays for Central Catholic High School dropped a top six of Ohio State, Georgia, LSU, Texas, Clemson and Miami, but reports from both Steve Wiltfong of On3 and Brian Dohn of 247Sports said that Penn State is still in play. He was re-offered by the new staff, and is the son of former NFL offensive lineman Todd Kalis.

Visits materializing

After the February dead period, next up for 2027 recruits are spring practice visits and then summer official visits.

4-star cornerback Kei’Shjuan Telfair, cornerback Semjay Robinson, running back Gary Walker and safety Rico Jackson have all added Penn State official visits to their schedule.

The aforementioned players will join Betton, 4-star wide receiver Khalil Taylor, 4-star safety Gabe Jenkins, 4-star safety Malakai Taufoou, 3-star running back Aiden Gibson, 3-star athlete Jonathan Galette and 3-star cornerback Zachary Gleason Jr. as high schoolers to lock in visits for the summer.

On the spring visit front, a pair of 4-stars made plans to return to State College in defensive end Mekai Brown and offensive tackle Layton von Brandt.

Brown was re-offered by the new staff after an in-home visit with Smith, and was in attendance for the Nevada game this past year. Per Chad Simmons of On3, he will be in town on April 3.

The visit to Happy Valley will have somewhat of a familiar feel for von Brandt, a previous commit. He was visited at school by Campbell and Clanton, and also had an in-home visit with Clanton. The offensive tackle has the Nittany Lions in his top-8 schools and will visit on April 18.

Targets committing elsewhere

Penn State made a late push to add 4-star 2026 Michigan State commit Samson Gash on campus for a visit in the middle of January before the February National Signing Day period. Gash’s dad, Sam, played fullback for the Nittany Lions. He was never offered by the old staff, but picked one up in December.

Despite the late efforts, the receiver stuck with his pledge to the Spartans.

In the 2027 class, 5-star running back Kemon Spell, a former Penn State commit, pledged to Georgia. The in-state tailback from McKeesport was originally slated to visit for the first Junior Day in January, but couldn’t make it due to the snowstorm that weekend.

Spell ended up visiting Georgia the next weekend, where he committed to the Bulldogs shortly after. There was buzz leading up to Junior Days that the running back would re-commit to Penn State as multiple national recruiting reporters logged predictions for him to do so.

A handful of reporters logged predictions for him to end up at Notre Dame before his first commitment to Penn State, so this recruitment seemingly has a long way to go.

It wouldn’t be a shock if Spell found himself back on campus for a Penn State visit as well as pursue trips across the country due to his pedigree.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball’s offense stays hot, picks up run-rule win over Pitt
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s last game at the Houston Invitational brought about the classic intrastate keystone rivalry against Pitt on Sunday afternoon. While the Nittany Lions entered the game leading the series record 19-9, they lost 16-8 last year in Happy Valley.

It wouldn’t take long for Penn State to get some revenge, as the offense and pitching stayed hot and the Nittany Lions picked up the lopsided 11-2 win over Pitt in five innings.

Both teams carried momentum into Sunday, with the blue and white on a three-game win streak and the Panthers on a two-game win streak. Coach Clarisa Crowell started junior McKenna Young on the bump, while Pitt gave the ball to sophomore Gwen Sparks.

The Panthers jumped on Young early in the first and pulled ahead with production from their top batters. Tieley Vaughn smashed a one-out double over the head of center fielder Natalie Lieto, and Calle Henne followed with a single up the middle. Cleanup Gracie Helton delivered an RBI single through the left side, putting Pitt ahead 1-0.

Though Henne also scored off a sacrifice fly, Young minimized the deficit to 2-0. However, the blue and white’s bats would quickly strike back in the bottom half of the first.

Freshman Allison Oneacre and junior Brooke Klosowicz both drew walks and set up sophomore Macy Chamberlin for a pivotal early opportunity to knock in runs. The Wauseon, Ohio, native came through with two outs and smoked a two-run double to the right-center gap, tying the game at two.

After Young provided a quick shutdown inning, Penn State grabbed hold of the lead in the second. With one out, junior Kaylie Walters sneaked a single down the left field line. Lieto followed her by blasting a two-run home run over the center field wall, giving the blue and white its first lead, 4-2.

Sparks was unraveling, so Pitt turned to its bullpen and brought in freshman Amelia Long to stop the bleeding. Yet, Penn State’s offense jumped on the right-hander just as fast. Oneacre, the blue and white’s leader in home runs, added to her total again.

The Alpharetta, Georgia, native launched her sixth home run deep into left field, extending the Nittany Lions’ lead, 5-2. Long couldn’t slow down Penn State as she hit Kirsten Finarelli, then Klosowicz followed with the third home run of the inning. The Panthers soon found themselves down 7-2, and the blue and white showed no signs of slowing down.

A pair of two-out walks gave freshman Breanna Hanik a chance to drive in even more runs. The Oak Lawn, Illinois, native slapped a double to left field and scored junior Michela Barbanente from second.

The game continued slipping further away from the Panthers and they made another pitching change, this time bringing in left-handed sophomore Bekah Duck. However, she wasn’t able to keep the deficit at six.

Duck walked Walters on just five pitches, and she didn’t get help from her defense after shortstop Shelby Frazier muffed a routine groundball, plating both Cara Bohner and Hannik. The eight-run inning finally ended with Duck striking out Oneacre, but the Nittany Lions took a commanding 10-2 lead into the third.

While Pitt couldn’t produce any offense in the top half of the third, Penn State added another run later in the inning. Klosowicz whacked a one-out single up the middle and scored off three straight walks.

Despite the blue and white’s offense dominating, fans shouldn’t overlook how well freshman Brevyn Kellepouris pitched in relief. The Olathe, Kansas, native picked up the win with two strikeouts and allowed no runs and just two hits.

With the victory, the Nittany Lions take a 7-2 record back to Happy Valley.

Up Next

Penn State travels to Orlando, Florida, for the SpaceU Classic, with its first game against Charleston Southern at 2 p.m. on Friday.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

Tunes from the Newsroom is a series showcasing local artists in the Penn State and State College community.

This episode features Parkin Corley.

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse continues undefeated season with dominant win over Bucknell
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
For the third time in a little over a week, Penn State took the field in coach Kayla Treanor’s first season in Happy Valley.

The Nittany Lions battled Bucknell inside Holuba Hall, coming out with a 21-9 victory to keep their undefeated season going.

While Bucknell won the opening faceoff, Penn State’s defense outperformed the Bison in the opening minute, as freshman Susannah O'Connell forced a turnover. Penn State’s offense went right down the field and put its first goal on the scoreboard with a free-position goal from junior Delaney Radin.

“Two players for us that are freshmen and have made a huge impact are Susannah O’Connell and Rocquette Allen,” Treanor said. “They’re playing like leaders right now.”

Less than 30 seconds later, freshman Rocquette Allen took advantage of the blue and white’s quick start, scoring her eighth goal of the season and putting Penn State up by two.

After both sides exchanged defensive success, junior Kelly MacKinney found the net again for the Nittany Lions, followed by Maddie Greco’s second career goal to give Penn State a four-goal lead.

“My teammates always push me to be better every day,” Greco said. “Drive (helps me) always want to reach a different level every game.”

Through five minutes, the blue and white dominated the game, holding the Bison to zero shots on goal, three turnovers and just one draw control.

“The difference in the first half was completely draw controls,” Treanor said. “Emma Kelley had 13 in the first half and was completely dominant.”

Bucknell’s first look of success came midway through the first quarter with the shot clock expiring, as leading scorer Megan Krestinski came away with a last-second goal.

The Nittany Lions fired right back, though, as Tewaaraton Award nominee Erika Ho netted her first goal of the game. After a quick score from the Bison, Ho scored her second goal of the game to make it a four-goal game.

“(Ho’s) an excellent leader and that just carries a presence on the field that you can’t deny,” Greco said. “She’s just an awesome player and an awesome person.”

Penn State earned its third free position shot of the day, as Wainman capitalized on the opportunity for her sixth goal of the season.

After a pair of missed shots by the Nittany Lions and a green card on Ho, the Bison played man-up and earned their third goal of the game before Allen’s ninth career goal brought the lead back to five.

Both Penn State and Bucknell missed a pair of free position shots to open the second quarter, but sophomore Ellie Wisch scored at the 11:41 mark, followed by another goal from Wainman.

The Nittany Lions’ hot stretch continued as Allen scored her third goal of the game and 10th of her career, followed by Bucknell’s first goal in 13 minutes.

“It’s a lot of hard work that you have to do every single day,” Allen said. “I couldn’t do it without any of my teammates.”

Graduate transfer Anna Salerno became the ninth player to score for the blue and white, as she scored the fourth goal of the season. The Bison closed the half with their first free-position goal, cutting the deficit to single digits.

Going into the second half, Penn State made a switch at goalkeeper, putting sophomore Arden Jansen in the net, recording her first career save one minute into the period.

“Arden is another really great goalie,” Treanor said. “We have a great goalie group, and I’m proud of Arden. I thought she played very well.”

Greco earned her first career hat trick with her fourth career goal, followed by Allen’s fourth and fifth goals of the day.

With a majority of backups taking the field, sophomores Maggie Rezza and Porter Rhoades each scored their first goals of the season while the Bison earned a pair of goals to end the quarter.

Those garbage-time goals continued into the fourth period, as Bucknell cut the deficit to 11 points with a running clock. After another goal from the Bison, Wisch’s second goal of the game, and Hannah Hoyt’s first collegiate goal, the Nittany Lions emerged victorious to win their third game of the year.

Up next

The Nittany Lions return to Panzer Stadium for a matchup with Pitt at 5 p.m. Wednesday. The Panthers upset No. 14 Duke on Thursday.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

A new era is underway at Penn State.

The Nittany Lions announced their 2026 spring schedule, kicking off Rob Dow's coaching career in Happy Valley.

Spring soccer 🔜 pic.twitter.com/oxJMadVYt2— Penn State Men’s Soccer (@PennStateMSOC) February 13, 2026

The Nittany Lions then hit the road to take on in-state opponent Penn on March 28 before wrapping up the season against Syracuse at home at 2 p.m. on April 11.
