title: Penn State releases 2027-28 fiscal year budget
author: Kiera Ginn | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State released its updated budget for the 2027-28 fiscal year earlier this month, which reallocates millions of dollars across the university.

Student support for the Office of the Vice President for Commonwealth Campuses will decrease by almost 59%, from $19.8 million to $8.1 million. The change comes as six commonwealth campuses — DuBois, Fayette, Mont Alto, New Kensington, Shenango, Wilkes-Barre and York — are set to close after the spring 2027 semester.

Remaining commonwealth campuses will see increases, with Penn State Schuylkill receiving increase of 10.06%, Penn State Behrend 5.31%, Penn State Abington 3.72% and Penn State Harrisburg 2.17%

Strategic Communications, the university’s public relations office, will see a 21.20% increase, bringing its budget to $3.5 million.

WPSU’s funding was cut by 100%, after the Board of Trustees Finance and Investment Committee voted to transfer the asset to WHYY.

Other changes include a decrease of 7.72% in funding for University Police and Public Safety and a 12.20% decrease for Penn State Dickinson Law. Educational Equity’s allocation will see an increase of 7%.

MORE ADMINISTRATION COVERAGE

title: No. 6 Penn State men’s hockey blown out by No. 2 Michigan after Saturday night loss
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 6 Penn State wrapped up three straight top-five series matchups on Saturday, heading home from Ann Arbor, Michigan, with two straight losses against a top-ranked Michigan team, the first one coming in shutout fashion.

The Nittany Lions dropped Saturday’s match to the No. 2 Wolverines 6-3, sealing the victory and the majority of the points possible in the series.

A high-scoring first period was the theme of the weekend between the two Big Ten opponents. Following a four-goal opening frame on Friday night, the scoring started just over seven minutes in during the rematch.

Michigan got on the board first, after freshman forward Cole McKinney redirected a shot from defenseman Luca Fantili out in front.

The Wolverines doubled their lead about four minutes later, when junior defenseman Ben Robertson walked around a defenseman and into the crease of goaltender Kevin Reidler. Forward Nick Moldenhauer was there to clean the puck up and put it into the back of the blue and white net.

The Nittany Lions were there to respond just over a minute later, however.

Junior Casey Aman found forward Reese Laubach — who opened Penn State’s scoring just 58 seconds into Friday’s game — in the slot, and he fired a shot past goaltender Jack Ivankovic to cut the deficit back to one to end the first frame.

The second period was less action-packed, but the physicality picked up.

A high hit on junior forward Aiden Fink led to a challenge from the Nittany Lion bench for head contact early in the period, but the officials found no penalty on the play.

The game’s first trip to the box came a few minutes later, after Laubach was called for slashing just past the halfway point of the second period, and Michigan’s nationally ranked No. 3 power play unit was quick to capitalize.

A tic-tac-toe passing play from senior T.J. Hughes to Moldenhauer led to a goal in the slot from forward Jayden Perron.

The Nittany Lions got their own chance on the man advantage as the clock ticked down on the middle frame when freshman Adam Valentini was called for holding.

With about a minute to go in the second period, the blue and white couldn’t generate much, but started the final frame still with the extra man.

Despite some good chances, the blue and white couldn’t get one through Ivankovic on the power play, but got another chance a few minutes later.

A hooking penalty on defenseman Dakoda Rhéaume-Mullen sent Penn State back to the power play with about 12 minutes to go; however, the extra man was negated 50 seconds later when forward JJ Wiebusch was called for a slashing penalty.

4-on-4 hockey didn’t lead to much, but Michigan made quick work of its shortened power play.

Wolverine sophomore Will Horcoff sent a shot towards the net, and a redirection from a Nittany Lion defenseman gave Reidler little chance of stopping the home team’s fourth goal.

Michigan maintained its third-period dominance and continued to pile on the scoring. This time, Valentini found the back of the net after collecting a loose puck and beating Reidler down low.

The Nittany Lions refused to quit, however, and when they were given their third power play of the night after Horcoff was called for slashing, they got their first goal since the first period.

Freshman Luke Misa found Laubach out in front, who stuffed the puck past Ivankovic and cut into the Wolverines’ lead for his second of the night, and third of the weekend.

Star forward Gavin McKenna continued the late-game surge for the blue and white after his shot from distance made it through traffic and into Michigan's net, cutting its deficit back down to two goals.

Despite the late push, an empty net goal from Moldenhauer sealed the 6-3 game for the home team.

Up Next

Penn State returns home to Pegula Ice Arena for an 8:30 p.m. puck drop on Feb. 20 against Ohio State.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Handal Roban breaks 800m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
It's not a Penn State track and field weekend if both Hayley Kitching and Handal Roban break school records.

After Kitching broke the women's 800-meter record at 5:30 p.m. on Saturday, Roban earned a new men's school record half an hour later at the ASICS Sound Invite, running 1:44.73.

Roban lost the race to 17-year-old Nike professional Cooper Lutkenhaus, but defeated former Nittany Lion record-holder Isaiah Harris.

His time now ranks No. 2 in the NCAA in addition to holding the school's 600-meter record and No. 3 time in the 1000-meters.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball earns first win, defeats Grand Canyon in MLB Desert Invitational
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
It seemed like everything went wrong in Penn State’s 15-3 season opener loss to Air Force, but the Nittany Lions had another opportunity to win their first game of the season against Grand Canyon on Saturday afternoon.

This game proved different as Penn State clicked on all cylinders behind two huge offensive innings and won 9-2 over Grand Canyon.

While the blue and white didn’t start hot at the MLB Desert Invitational, the Antelopes won their first game over Northeastern. Under sunny skies in Arizona, a pair of right-handers got the start on the mound, with sophomore Ben Hudson for the Nittany Lions and junior Nicholas Robb for Grand Canyon.

Penn State went down quietly for the first few outs in the first, but senior Michael Anderson recorded his first hit as a Nittany Lion through the left side. Though cleanup Bryce Molinaro lifted a ball deep into right center, center fielder Griffin Cameron tracked down the ball well for the third out.

While the blue and white left a couple of runners stranded in the top half of the second, the Antelopes broke open the scoring later in the inning. Cannon Peery smacked a leadoff single through the right side, and despite Hudson striking out the next two batters, Max Charles split the left-center gap.

The sophomore’s two-out RBI triple gave Grand Canyon the early 1-0 lead. However, Molinaro prevented Charles from scoring with a diving play at third, throwing out Camden Bates across the diamond.

Similar to the first two innings, the Nittany Lions threatened with base runners, but couldn’t drive them in. Redshirt junior Cohl Mercado drew a leadoff walk, and Molinaro dropped a two-out hit into right center, but Jack Porter flew out to center to end the threat.

After another quiet offensive start, the blue and white’s bats finally came through in the fourth. Junior Spencer Barnett reached base with a walk, and with not much offense happening, Barnett was aggressive and stole second. A few batters later, redshirt senior Justin Turcovski delivered with a one-out RBI single to center, tying the game at one.

Meanwhile, Hudson kept dominating on the bump and kept the score knotted. Through four innings, the Medford, New Jersey, native recorded five strikeouts while allowing just two hits and one walk.

For the first time this season, the Nittany Lions took the lead in the fifth. The Antelopes pulled Robb for senior Elijah Higginbottom at the start of the inning, and the blue and white pounced. Senior Jayden Davis started the momentum with a one-out single to right.

A few batters later, Molinaro recorded his second hit of the day off a two-out single up the middle, advancing Davis to third. Porter didn’t waste the prime scoring opportunity, lining a RBI single up the middle and giving Penn State the 2-1 lead.

The scoring didn’t stop there as Barnett powered a ball to the warning track and over the head of center fielder Cameron. The Pittsburgh native’s two RBI triple was the blue and white’s first extra-base hit of the campaign.

With the lead at 4-1, the Nittany Lions continued pouring on the runs. Following a walk by freshman Avery Smith, Turcovski carried the momentum and plated both runners off a triple to right field, ballooning the Penn State lead 6-1.

Following the explosive five-run inning, both offenses were kept quiet until the seventh. Redshirt senior Ben DeMell ran into a bases-loaded jam with no outs. Grand Canyon’s comeback push started with a routine fly ball error by first baseman Barnett, which allowed Bates to reach.

Troy Sanders batted a long single to center and moved Bates to third. Followed by a walk by Cameron, Bates scored off a sacrifice fly to center fielder Mercado. Coach Mike Gambino brought in sophomore left-hander Matthew VanOstenbridge to face the heart of Grand Canyon’s lineup.

The Sinking Spring, Pennsylvania, native retired the next two batters and minimized the damage with Penn State’s lead still comfortable at 6-2. However, the Nittany Lions added more insurance in the next inning.

Penn State delivered a three-run eighth inning against senior right-hander Luke Moeller. Starting with a one-out single from Davis, Molinaro continued his monster offensive day with a two-out single to center. Porter then smacked a double into the gap in center and drove in both runners, pushing the Nittany Lions’ lead to 8-2.

After Porter advanced to third off a wild pitch, Kevin Karstetter took advantage of a rattled Moeller and sneaked an RBI single up the middle. He was stranded on second after a stolen base, but the blue and white took a large 9-2 lead late.

Grand Canyon wouldn’t score again as senior Dimond Loosli threw two shutout innings and secured the blowout victory for the Nittany Lions.

Up Next

Penn State wraps up its time at the MLB Desert Invitational against Kansas State at 2 p.m. on Sunday.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball closes out trip to the Lone Star State with matchup against Pittsburgh
author: Brielle Gari | The Daily Collegian
description:
In their second day of the Houston Invitational, the Nittany Lions came out victorious. Winning both games against Lafayette and Houston Christian.

Due to inclement weather in the greater Houston area, Penn State got right back on the dirt early on Valentine’s Day after blowing out the Houston Cougars just around 14 hours before the first pitch.

Penn State softball concludes its weekend in the Lone Star state on Sunday, for an in-state rivalry, against the Pittsburgh Panthers.

Keystone State matchup

Sunday’s game against the Panthers will be the 29th meeting between the two programs. The blue and white currently hold a 19-9 record against Pitt.

The last time these two met on the diamond, the Panthers earned a road win, 16-8.

Pitt ranked 12th in the ACC last season with a 7-17 conference record and 20-32 overall.

As of their 2026 campaign, the Panthers are 5-4. 2-2 in the Houston Invitational, starting off the weekend with hard losses to Houston, then Michigan, but turning things around Saturday afternoon, beating Houston Christian 3-2, then Incarnate Word 8-7.

Handing Incarnate Word their second loss of the season, erasing an early five-run deficit with a six-run third inning and holding on for the win. The Panthers fought back after going down early.

Tiley Vaughn started things off with a single and a stolen base. Following up on the rally, Calle Henne got an RBI double to continue the momentum. Ultimately, Shelby Frazier finished off the inning with a three-run home run to deep right field, giving Pitt the lead.

Penn State looks for its 20th win against its state rival, Pitt. As well as to close out their weekend in Texas with their fourth straight win of the season.

After a close game against the Cardinals early Friday, the Nittany Lions have fought back. With big help from freshmen in the circle, only allowing four runs scored in the last four games.

The Nittany Lions close out their trip to the Southeast on Sunday at 1 p.m. back at Cougar Softball Stadium.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball defeats Princeton, completes weekend sweep
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
After sweeping Saint Francis last weekend in a one-and-one home and away series that saw Mark Pavlik picking up his 700th career victory, Penn State took to the road to head for Princeton, New Jersey, to take on the Tigers.

The Nittany Lions squeaked out a 3-2 victory last night after winning the first two sets but losing the third and fourth, narrowly avoiding the reverse sweep.

It was much of the same on Saturday, as Penn State blanked Princeton 3-0 to complete the series sweep and drop the Tigers to 2-6 on the season.

Penn State played Princeton three times last season, when the two teams split the regular season series. The Nittany Lions got the last laugh in the EIVA Championship, where they picked up a 3-0 victory before appearing in the NCAA Tournament.

The blue and white got on the board first after an error on the opening serve from Nolan Kelly and held the lead until an Andrew Werner service ace tied the set at 6-6.

With the Tigers right on the heels of the Nittany Lions, 6-foot-7 Owen Rose got up for a monster block that gave the blue and white a two-point lead.

The redshirt senior middle blocker was named a “Player to Watch” in the EIVA in the preseason after being voted second-team all-EIVA last season.

Princeton took its first lead of the afternoon after an Owen Mellon service ace put the Tigers up 12-11 and held on to the advantage despite trading points back and forth. A Sean Harvey kill recaptured the lead for the Nittany Lions as they went up 17-16.

Kills were flying left and right as the blue and white took turns with the Tigers putting points on the board, including five from Tristan Hassell and four from Princeton’s Ambrose Engling.

Neither team could pull away, with the score tied at 25-25 after two more Engling kills kept the nonstop action tight.

Finally, Penn State pulled away after a wild series of events kept things rolling, but a Mellon attack error blocked by Gabriel Gaige gave the Nittany Lions the 30-28 victory in the first set.

The Tigers quickly got out to a 2-0 lead in the early running of the second set after back-to-back kills from Ethan Wells and another from Werner.

After the initial alternating scores, it was all Penn State as it went on a 6-1 scoring run, powered by several kills from Jaidyn Bethel and Hassell that put the blue and white up 10-6.

Kelly, already having a big game, picked up his sixth dig and 17th assist of the afternoon before adding an ace to that list, which brought the Tigers within two points of Penn State’s lead.

Unlike the suspense in the first set, the second frame was looking like it belonged completely to the Nittany Lions as they pulled ahead to a 17-11 lead before it dwindled down to just three points after a couple of errors from Bethel and Gaige and an ace from Werner.

Despite Princeton’s efforts, Penn State extended its lead to 22-19 as it was on the doorstep of winning the first two sets just like Friday night.

A Hassell kill put a wrap on the second set as the Nittany Lions grabbed the second set, winning 25-21. Princeton moved closer after a Rose service error, but it didn’t matter.

The Tigers and Sam Shweisky went into the third set looking to do something similar to Friday night when they nearly pulled off the reverse sweep, but with the blue and white on the brink of closing out the weekend with a series sweep, it wouldn’t be easy.

Penn State got on the board first in the third set thanks to a Michael Schwob kill, but Princeton immediately matched the score with another Engling kill.

The Nittany Lions extended their lead to 5-1 before Engling picked up his 10th kill of the evening just as Hassell picked up his 14th, a new career high.

In a rhythm since the start of the day, Hassell notched his 15th kill to add on to a career day as Penn State moved up to a 15-11 lead before a media timeout.

A Rose ace made things even gloomier for the Tigers as everything was going the Nittany Lions’ way – even an Engling error on his serve that did his squad no favors.

Pavlik and the blue and white took a timeout after Princeton worked its deficit down to just one point after a bad angle on the attack from Hassell made it 18-17 in the latter stages of the third set.

Princeton brought the score closer in the final moments of the third set after a score that the officials had to take another look at was followed by another Werner kill that tied the frame at 24-24.

Some last-minute theatrics saw Harvey notch another kill that was matched with one from Wells that made it a 26-25 Princeton lead.

Just like the first set, the two sides kept the action alive until a Gabriel ace sealed the deal for the Nittany Lions, as they picked up a 28-26 win in the third set to sweep the Tigers in the match and the weekend.

Up Next

Penn State returns home on Friday to kick off a THON weekend series with Harvard.

The Nittany Lions split their two regular-season matchups with the Crimson last season and also picked up a 3-0 victory in the first round of the EIVA tournament when the two teams met again.

Friday’s match is scheduled for 6 p.m., while Saturday’s is scheduled for 3 p.m.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Hayley Kitching breaks 800m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
For the third time this season, Hayley Kitching is a record-breaker.

Kitching broke her former school record in the 800 meters at the Husky Classic, running a time of 1:59.22 to win the event.

Saturday's performance marked the first time the Australian native ran sub-two minutes in her career.

Earlier this season, Kitching broke the 800m record and the 1,000-meter record, setting the NCAA record in the process.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball splits West Coast trip on Valentine’s Day, loses to Oregon
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s Valentine’s Day, love is in the air, and surprisingly, that sentiment enchanted the hardwood all the way in Eugene between the two squads at the bottom of the Big Ten – Oregon and Penn State.

Ultimately, as Shakespeare wrote, “Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps,” and it was Oregon that struck down the blue and white with an ambush in the clash of opportunities. The Ducks broke a ten-game losing streak and won their first Big Ten home game with the victory.

It didn’t appear to be unfavorable for the Nittany Lions entering, as it started its full first unit of Kayden Mingo, Freddie Dilione V, Dominick Stewart, Josh Reed and Ivan Jurić, which at times hadn’t appeared all together due to injury.

That unit immediately clicked and cruised to a two-possession lead after roughly six and a half minutes of play, but empty offensive possessions couldn’t nurse the lead, and Oregon fought back just before the midpoint of the half.

The blue and white retaliated, with a quick grasp of the reins following a bad decision by Oregon’s Wei Lin to pass before the shot clock, and a crafty Mingo layup.

Yet the Ducks' leading scorer, center Nate Bittle, drained back-to-back three pointers to grab the lead. Bittle started in his third game back from injury and spearheaded the Ducks’ offensive barrage on Penn State.

The blue and white defense continued to allow more open looks despite Mike Rhoades's adjustments, as three consecutive Oregon possessions with a bucket gave the Ducks the lead with just over six minutes left before halftime.

The two units traded buckets for two minutes until the Ducks ballooned their lead to ten, and the Nittany Lions appeared more lively on offense in their attempt to level the score before half.

Ultimately, at the break, Oregon led 38-32 via Bittle’s game-high 12 points, followed by bench guard Dezdrick Lindsay, who started with an efficient ten points. The senior’s season-high all year was 14 points against Creighton, ultimately breaking that figure with 16 total points at the end of the game.

For the blue and white, it was its own guard-and-big pairing orchestrating the offense, with freshmen Mingo and Juric scoring 11 and eight points, respectively, at the half.

Ball movement is where the Ducks built their edge, with a combined team total of ten assists to Penn State’s limited total of four.

Early in the second half, the Nittany Lions made it a one-possession game with a reenergized defensive effort led by their press.

The two squads traded buckets from beyond the arc and at the foul line, as it appeared Rhoades’ squad began to play with more urgency. That pace didn’t translate, as the Ducks kept the speed advantage where it mattered: the rate of buckets.

Bittle converted both shots of a one-and-one attempt at the foul line, and a Jurić travel on the other end didn’t help, as a slam by Sean Stewart of Oregon followed to give them the largest lead of the day at ten.

Takai Simpkins, who logged only two first-half points, largely led the offensive attack with 15 points throughout the midpoint of the second half. The sharpshooter anchored an efficient team shooting approach that outshot Penn State by over 20% from three.

The game got rather physical, as Jurić and Stewart each picked up their fifth fouls, leaving both units without a major presence down low aside from Bittle.

With just under five minutes left to play, Oregon expanded to a 15-point lead and only had to avoid a major catastrophe to bring home the win.

The Ducks prioritized wasting time on the clock, with slow ball movement and handles to drive the result home.

For Penn State, Mingo finished with a team-high 24 points, tied for a career best. While Oregon was led by Bittle and Simpkin’s 22 points each.

Availability Report

The lone player joining redshirt Reggie Grodin on the sidelines is forward Tibor Mirtic, who should be returning soon, as he entered Saturday’s contest as questionable due to a shoulder injury sustained in practice.

Up Next

The blue and white return to Happy Valley at 6 p.m. on Wednesday for a clash with fellow bottom of the Big Ten team Rutgers in the Nittany Lions’ “Academic Achievement Night and Faculty Staff Appreciation Night.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey earns season-finale victory over RIT
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Love was in the air on the Valentine’s Day regular-season finale for No. 4 Penn State and there was no better display of companionship than Katelyn Roberts and program history.

After having their hearts broken by Cassandra Kehler during overtime in Friday’s matchup between the two AHA competitors, the Nittany Lions concluded their regular season on a high note with a 4-2 win.

With an assist on the game’s first goal, Roberts became the sixth skater in program history to reach the century mark milestone and is the first African-American player to do so. Coach Jeff Kampersal was left speechless while putting together what Roberts means to the team.

“I don’t think I (have) words to describe the immense impact that she’s had on the program,” Kampersal said.

He further broke down Roberts not only by who she is on the ice as a player, but also by who she is off the ice as a person.

“She’s a power forward, great shot, really elite passer,” Kampersal said. “Off the ice, she’s the greatest connector of all time. I’ve been coaching 30 years and she just brings everybody together. I can’t speak highly enough of her.”

Kampersal and the Nittany Lions will go through a two-week hiatus as they await the results of the first two rounds of the AHA Tournament. As the regular season champions, Penn State has an automatic bye into the semifinal, where it will face the lowest remaining seed after the first round and quarterfinal round on Feb. 19 and Feb. 21, respectively.

It is a two-week break that Kampersal said would feature “pure rest”. While he plans to hold his regularly scheduled practices during the week, the Nittany Lions coach realizes he’s working with a team that’s missing three forwards to the Olympics and Mya Vaslet, who suffered an injury last Friday against Lindenwood. Her timetable to return is yet to be determined.

Kampersal explained that with the increase in demand out of his underclassmen during games, practices have been disjointed to accommodate the rise in production from some of the bottom-six forwards. He also explained the potential mental impact those practices have, as well as the impact from an academic standpoint.

“We just kind of get in a bad mindset. Again, today the vibe was completely different,” Kampersal said. “I think they had a big academic week, so just (the team) just kind of need rest, and then we’ll get going the week after.”

On the second power play opportunity for the Nittany Lions, Roberts sent a pass from the far corner to Kendall Butze, who ripped a shot from the faceoff dot. Her shot hit a body in front, and Abby Stonehouse tucked the puck in for the goal.

Approximately two minutes after getting on the board, Sophie Morrow handled the puck in the offensive zone and held until she found a clear lane. Once she did, Morrow’s wrist shot went off the stick of Grace Outwater to extend the Penn State lead to 2-0.

Outwater’s conference-leading 24th goal of the season came a game too late after her nine-game goal streak was snapped in the overtime loss on Friday. However, the sophomore started a new streak back on a line with Maddy Christian and Mikah Keller, a line that has been successful this season with a combined 51 goals this season.

The blue and white opened the second period with an extra skater after a Brac Kelley penalty for face masking toward the end of the first. They kept the momentum going with high-danger scoring opportunities, including a 2-on-1 chance for Roberts and Stonehouse, but Brenna McNamara held Penn State’s lead at two in her ninth career start.

Across the ice in the other crease, Katie DeSa stopped each of the first nine shots she faced through the first 30 minutes of play until RIT entered the zone on a 2-on-1.

Tilli Keränen and Ireland Stein entered their offensive zone with Taya MacDonald as the only skater back for the Nittany Lions. DeSa stopped Keränen’s initial shot with her glove, but couldn't contain it, as Keränen lobbed it over DeSa’s glove for the easy goal from Stein.

The Penn State netminder redeemed herself with a set of spectacular saves while shorthanded after Roberts was assessed a penalty for interference, but the Tigers learned from their mistake and took advantage of the next power play they received just a minute later.

With McKenna Walsh in the box after a tripping call, Stein beat DeSa with a shot that erased Penn State’s lead and tied the game at two late in the second period.

Butze was on the ice for a dangerous play in front of the Penn State bench between Roberts and Olivia Urbach. She decided the best way to retaliate was on the scoreboard with her fifth goal of the season to give Penn State a 3-2 lead.

The second line magic sparked again just 28 seconds into the third period on Christian’s 19th goal of the season.

Outwater and Keller played catch while cutting toward the net until Outwater’s backhand attempt was denied at the doorstep by McNamara. Just then, Christian, who tailed Outwater, put the rebound in the top shelf to recapture the Nittany Lion two-goal lead.

They would hold on to this lead with the aid of DeSa, who held the Tigers scoreless in the third period.

With this win, Penn State finishes the regular season with a 29-5 record, one that will still be impacted by postseason play. However, one record that is solidified is its conference record, which finished the regular season at 22-2, with both losses coming in overtime.

Up Next

Penn State will host the best-of-three semifinal round against the lowest remaining seed, with Game 1 on Feb. 27 and the time of puck drop to be announced.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics falls to Minnesota in Valentine's Day, Senior Night showdown
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s gymnastics spread the love this Valentine's Day, honoring its seniors and having a bit of friendly competition against Minnesota on Saturday afternoon. Seniors Amani Herring and Ava Piedrahita were both in the lineups for the Nittany Lions.

The Nittany Lions came off of a loss on the road against No. 3 LSU on Feb. 6, as well as a most recent loss against No. 11 Michigan State on Feb. 8. The blue and white got their third loss of the season, falling to Minnesota 197.075-196.000.

Rotation One

The Nittany Lions started off on vault, with Minnesota on bars. Elizabeth Leary opened up the scoring for the blue and white, grabbing a 9.775, and Piedrahita, as well as Allison Keampfer scored the same. Dani Latronica followed close behind with a 9.725, Jessica Johanson scored a 9.800, and Ava Cash ended the rotation and led with a score of 9.825.

The Golden Gophers finished their rotation on bars, and led the Nittany Lions 49.175-48.950, with each gymnast grabbing scores of 9.800 and above, with one 9.900 by Emma Slevin.

Rotation Two

The blue and white switched with the Golden Gophers and headed over to its strongest apparatus, the uneven bars. Johanson started rotation two with a score of 9.675, and Ellie Monahan opened up her scoring with a solid 9.825, and Leary and Cash both landed a 9.900. Piedrahita had a 9.825 and Latronica closed it up with a top score of 9.925.

Minnesota still led Penn State at the end of the rotation after putting up a solid performance on vault. The Golden Gophers had a 9.800s across the board, but the Nittany Lions came in close behind them with a 98.325 compared to Minnesota’s 98.350.

Rotation Three

The blue and white moved on to beam with Ashley Maul, who kicked it off with a 9.550. Leary was up next and put up a strong performance, which got her a 9.700. Herring grabbed a 9.650, Alyssa Kramer had a 9.775, and Latronica closed it out with a strong 9.900.

The Gophers still led at the end of the third rotation, 147.575-147.000. Minnesota looked strong on the floor with a majority of its gymnasts having 9.800s.

Rotation Four

Penn State headed to the floor with Leary, who got a strong 9.800. Monahan earned a 9.725, and Kaempfer came in right behind her with a 9.700. Johanson led with a 9.825, and Kalea McElligott grabbed a 9.800, and Kramer closed it out with a 9.850.

The Golden Gophers finished out the meet on beam and looked home a win against the Nittany Lions.

Up Next

Penn State will take on Iowa at 6 p.m. Saturday, Feb. 21, in Iowa City, Iowa.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Defense stands stall in Penn State softball’s second Saturday win over Houston Christian
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a dominant 14-1 victory over Lafayette on Saturday afternoon, Penn State had a quick turnaround facing co-host Houston Christian at the Houston Invitational. The Huskies remained winless on the season after falling to Pittsburgh and Michigan on Friday.

In a strong defensive outing, the Nittany Lions defeated the Huskies 4-1.

Junior Bridget Nementh got the start for Penn State in her third appearance of the weekend, as Houston Christian turned to sophomore Leah Hammack.

Hammack and the Huskies' defense quickly recorded two outs to start the opening frame. However, the Nittany Lions’ young bats stepped up big once again.

Freshman Allison Oneacre singled up the middle, and was followed by back-to-back doubles from freshman Kirsten Finarelli and sophomore Macy Chamberlin, giving the blue and white an early 2-0 lead.

Brooke Klosowicz worked a single to put two runners in scoring position for Cara Bohner, but instead Hammack recorded her second strikeout of the inning.

Penn State’s defense held momentum in the bottom of the frame, recording a 1-2-3 inning.

Houston Christian recorded a quick out to start the second, but back-to-back singles from Gabby Gradishar and Kaylie Walters put two runners on for Natalie Lieto. The Huskies escaped the jam by recording a double play.

Nemeth and the Nittany Lions’ defense had another flawless outing in the bottom of the frame, forcing Houston Christian to go three-up, three-down.

In the top half of the third, Chamberlin recorded her second two-out double of the game, but the blue and white couldn’t bring the catcher around to score.

Maddy Bailey got the Huskies on the offense going with a leadoff double in the bottom of the frame. Bailey advanced to third on a single from Hammack, but two strikeouts and a groundout prevented Houston Christian from getting on the board.

Hammack and the Huskies’ defense posted their first clean sheet of the game, not allowing any Nittany Lions on base in the fourth to keep a tight 2-0 battle.

Ella Herrewig reached base after an error from Klosowicz at third, but Houston Christian couldn’t find any further momentum, sending things back to Penn State for the top of the fifth inning.

Oneacre ripped a two-out double down the left field line for her second hit of the game, and was brought home on a single from Finarelli.

Finarelli reached third after an error from Hammack, but couldn’t find her way home after Chamberlin grounded out to the left side.

In the bottom of the frame, the Nittany Lions recorded their third 1-2-3 inning of the afternoon, as Nemeth’s statline stood at two hits, two strikeouts and zero walks.

Klosowicz extended Penn State’s lead just three pitches into the sixth inning with a home run to left field for her third long ball of the season.

With one out, junior second baseman Michela Barbenente knocked the Nittany Lions’ fifth double of the afternoon, but a lineout from Gradishar and ground out from Walters prevented any more runs from reaching the plate for the blue and white.

Defense continued to be the name of the game for Penn State in the bottom of the sixth, completing yet again another three-up, three-down inning that was topped off by a groundout to Nemeth.

The Nittany Lions entered the final frame with their two, three, four hitters up and a chance to extend their lead.

Sophomore Natalie Lieto started the inning with an infield single, but got out at second after a fielder’s choice off the bat of Oneacre.

Following a strikeout from Finarelli and a groundout from Chamberlin, the blue and white couldn’t do any damage, but still held a four-run cushion heading into the final chance for Houston Christian’s offense.

Penn State recorded two quick outs, but a home run from senior Karlie Barba kept the Huskies alive.

Houston Christian couldn’t do anymore damage, with Hammack grounding out to third base, completing the Nittany Lions' strong defensive effort.

Up Next

Penn State will wrap up its Houston trip with a battle against in-state rival Pittsburgh at 1 p.m. Sunday.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: 'This is what I live for’ | Penn State wrestling’s Cole Mirasola earns biggest victory of his career
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
As the calendar turned to 2026 and the Big Ten wrestling season continued to play out, the eyes of the nation had Feb.13 circled as the potential best dual of the season between No. 1 Penn State and No. 2 Ohio State.

Up until Friday, the meet was expected to be a close one, before injuries turned the potential shootout into a celebration of Penn State wrestling, as 16,006 fans witnessed how far ahead of the rest of the country the Nittany Lions really are.

“We’re really thankful for everyone who showed up, the record crowd was awesome,” Cael Sanderson said. “And I don’t think the tickets were very cheap either.”

The showcase ended with the breakout of Penn State’s heavyweight that everyone in the Lorenzo Wrestling Center has been waiting to see.

Originally, No. 12 Cole Mirasola was facing the potential of having a dual-deciding bout against No. 3 Nick Feldman, but with Penn State leading Ohio State 33-5, Mirasola looked to claim victory all for himself.

“I watched my teammates just do what they do,” Mirasola said. “This is what I live for, a sold out Bryce Jordan Center, I’ve wanted to do this my whole life.”

However, Mirasola was one of the few Nittany Lions that weren’t favored to win. A portion of the crowd was skeptical of Penn State’s heavyweight as well, with one fan quipping before the dual, “we can leave before the last match” as his friends grew impatient in line. Mirasola has had many chances to defeat a top-tier heavyweight, but hadn’t gotten the job done entering Friday.

“I’ve had some losses this year, but I feel like I’m right there,” Mirasola said.

Feldman, meanwhile, is a national championship contender who has beaten common opponent AJ Ferrari of Nebraska twice this season. Mirasola fell to Ferrari at the last BJC dual.

The concern for Mirasola at heavyweight was him being undersized compared to the top of the class. However, according to Jeff Byers of the Penn State radio broadcast, Mirasola only gave up nine pounds to Feldman. The match would be a test of pure skill on the mat.

“It’s the same kind of story again,” Sanderson said Wednesday. “(Mirasola) just has to trust in his gameplan and what he does well, which is a lot of things.”

Regulation of the match went as many high pressure wrestling matches do, with the only scoring coming via escape. Feldman spent much of the match retreating from an aggressive Mirasola, narrowly avoiding a takedown in the final seconds.

Once the match hit sudden victory, Mirasola lost his patience and Feldman lost his footing. Mirasola got the takedown seconds into the extra frame, while Feldman laid on the ground in shock.

“I knew the whole time that I had him,” Mirasola said. “I looked at his face and he was gone.”

The crowd that might’ve doubted Mirasola stood and applauded him as he celebrated the 4-1 victory, and all doubts about his place in the lineup were put to bed as the night came to a close.

Sanderson spent weeks touting Mirasola’s potential, but the proof hadn’t arisen in results prior to Friday. After the dual, Sanderson gleamed pridefully as the wrestling world finally witnessed what he had been preaching all season — Mirasola is a threat at heavyweight.

“His ability to win scrambles and attack the legs as a big guy shows that he has a ton of potential,” Sanderson said. “He’s very offensive-minded and will shoot right away, and we love that about him.”

The victory capped off the Big Ten Dual Meet Championship victory. Mirasola celebrated the seemingly annual achievement with his team.

That title isn’t the only one the team is hoping to carry and after the win, Mirasola has more confidence in his ability to win a few titles of his own. The redshirt freshman had his defining moment in the Bryce Jordan Center, but bigger stages are still to come for Mirasola.

“I’m ready to win the national title,” Mirasola said. “Losses aren’t going to define me. I’m really excited to see what happens for me.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Katelyn Roberts becomes sixth player in Penn State women’s hockey history to record 100th career point
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Katelyn Roberts reached 100 career points on Saturday, when she assisted Abby Stonehouse’s goal to open the scoring in the first period against RIT.

Roberts is only the sixth player in women’s team history to reach triple-digit points. She also sits alone as the first African-American player to hit the milestone.

The Chanhassan, Minnesota, native has been a key contributor throughout the 2025-26 season, scoring 15 goals and adding 15 helpers for 30 points so far in her senior campaign.

Last year, Roberts was named to the All-AHA First Team with a career-high 35 points. Heading into the postseason, the forward has already surpassed her previous career-high 13 goals, two power-play goals and three game-winning goals.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 15 Penn State men’s lacrosse rebounds with upset victory over No. 3 Princeton
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 15 Penn State traveled to Princeton, New Jersey, to face the No. 3 Tigers at noon on Saturday in its first road trip of the 2026 season.

The blue and white surged with seven goals in the first quarter to outpace Princeton, 13-7. Penn State improved to 2-1 on the season while Princeton fell to 0-1.

First half

Penn State took early advantage of Princeton’s young defensive core, keeping possession and continuing to drive to the net as the Tigers’ defense failed to slide when their first defender was beaten.

Luke Walstrum kicked off the game with a goal 43 seconds in as he wrapped around the cage and beat his matched defender to free his hands for an overhand shot. Hunter Aquino, the reigning Big Ten Freshman of the Year, delivered his first goal of the game less than a minute later to take a 2-0 lead.

After the second goal, the Tigers got the ball. Tucker Wade streaked down the center of the box and ripped an underhand shot under freshman goaltender Preston Hawkins’ stick to cut Penn State’s lead to one.

The blue and white elected to slow the pace of play on both sides of the ball, allowing Hawkins to routinely clear the ball and the offense to settle in. The switch worked as the Nittany Lions blazed on a six-goal run.

Hobart-transfer John Jude Considine drove hard towards the cage under tight coverage but beat goalie Ryan Croddick. It was followed by Kyle Lehman, shooting overhand through traffic.

Freshman Jack Iannantuono picked up a loose ball from Princeton’s failed clearance and bounced a shot under Croddick’s stick to take a commanding 5-1 lead. Walstrum followed that up, driving from behind the cage with a step on the defender. No slide came his way as he pinpointed the top right corner to take a five-goal lead with 5:39 remaining in the first quarter.

After Owen Fischer slashed Liam Matthews, Michael Faraone was credited with a man-up goal to end the quarter, as Finn Fox tried to swat down his interior pass but delivered an own-goal instead.

Nate Kabiri got Princeton off on the right foot in the second quarter, receiving a pass from his long-time teammate Colin Burns before sniping a shot over Hawkins’ stick.

The majority of the second quarter was back-and-forth. Croddick made a series of saves as Princeton’s defense limited Penn State to the outside, although the Tigers’ offense experienced the same turbulence.

Iannantuono brought energy back to the Nittany Lions with 7:42 remaining in the half as he scored his second goal of the game while falling to his back to take an 8-2 lead.

Faraone — after Matthews and Patrick Carragher nearly added their first goals of the day — capped off an intense possession with a wide-open shot to give Penn State its largest lead, 9-2, of the game with 2:21 left in the first half.

Kabiri ensured that the Tigers entered the locker room with the last goal as he bounced a tight-angle shot past Hawkins to cut the lead to 9-3.

Second half

After Hawkins made a chest save on the doorstep, Aquino took the ball from the top of the box and knifed through the defense before finding the bottom right corner of the net to take a 10-3 lead.

Hawkins and the Nittany Lion defense continued to shine, as All-American defender Alex Ross cleanly stripped Kabiri of the ball for his third caused turnover of the game.

Princeton had a trio of golden opportunities but all were turned aside by Hawkins. First, the netminder made a save but fell to his back before diving to make a stick save on Burns from point-blank range. Then, Hawkins made a foot save to keep the seven-goal lead.

However, Burns earned the Tigers’ fourth goal of the game, firing a mid-range shot past Hawkins.

Chad Palumbo scored his first goal of the game on the man-up in the fourth quarter after Aquino took a 30-second penalty for pushing from behind. Peter Buonanno tallied Princeton’s third-unanswered goal after driving past Will Costin. Wade carried the momentum on a four-goal run

Carragher stalled Princeton’s energy with an individual effort, scoring a diving goal with one-second left on the shot clock. Aquino claimed a hat trick on a goal reminiscent of Matt Traynor’s in last season’s NCAA Quarterfinal, shooting one-handed while falling to the ground to take a 12-7 lead.

Matthews iced the game with 3:36 remaining in the game, scoring on a tight-angle shot to increase the lead to six. Hawkins closed out the game with 11 saves on 18 shots, for a .611 save-percentage.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions are set to close their two-game road trip against Navy at noon on Saturday, Feb. 21, in Annapolis, Maryland.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Freshmen step up big in Penn State softball’s run-rule win over Lafayette
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off a 1-1 Friday outing, Penn State returned to the field on Saturday morning to face in-state foe Lafayette in Houston. The Leopards went 0-2 in their opening slate of the Houston Invitational, falling to Incarnate Word and Houston.

The Nittany Lions defeated the Leopards 14-1 in five innings.

Freshman right-hander Mackenzie Duncan got the starting nod for Penn State after earning the win against Houston on Friday night. The Leopards turned to sophomore right-hander Jordan Goedel.

The Nittany Lions got first licks, and junior shortstop Kaylie Walters worked a four-pitch walk to get things going. Sophomore Natlie Lieto followed suit, but Lafayette recorded an out after Walters got caught stealing second base.

Freshmen Allison Oneacre and Kirsten Finarelli recorded the third and fourth straight walks of the inning, bringing up junior Michela Barbanente with bases loaded and one out.

The Leopards escaped the scare after a ground ball to Goedel resulted in a 1-2-3 double play.

Duncan walked sophomore Caroline Hall to start the bottom half of the first, but the Penn State defense stood tall, following with three straight outs.

The Nittany Lions put two runners on in the top of the second, thanks to a walk from Cara Bohner and a single from Brooke Klosowicz, but with first and third and one out, Lafayette once again ended the threat with a double play.

Following two free bases and a double from senior catcher Maggie Klug, the Leopards loaded up the bases with just one out in the bottom of the second frame.

Duncan battled Olivia Catalina with a full count, with the Nittany Lion ultimately losing the fight to walk in the first run of the game. This called for coach Clarisa Crowell to go to the bullpen, bringing in sophomore Abigail Britton.

Britton only had to face one batter, with Hall grounding into a double play to end the inning.

Penn State answered quickly as Walters worked another walk, and scored from first on a double from Lieto.

Lafayette wasted no time bringing in a new arm, calling sophomore Makayla Lecky to the circle.

The Nittany Lions brought in another run after Lieto advanced to third on a wild pitch and scored on a sacrifice fly from Oneacre, giving the blue and white a 2-1 advantage.

Britton only needed four pitches in the bottom of the third, as the Penn State defense recorded its first 1-2-3 inning.

Klosowicz led off the fourth with a walk, and a sacrifice bunt from catcher Madison Seidel turned into another Nittany Lion run. Lafayette second baseman Kylee Sweet committed a throwing error, allowing Klosowicz to find her way home.

That wasn’t close to the end of the fourth inning, scoring for Penn State.

Following back-to-back two-out singles from Walters and Lieto, Oneacre drove one down the left field line for an RBI double.

Just moments after, Finarelli knocked a three-run home run for her second long ball of the weekend, breaking the game open to give the Nittany Lions a 7-1 edge.

The Leopards made their second pitching change of the day, bringing in freshman Andy Hegarty, who didn’t allow any more damage.

Lafayette couldn’t build off a lead-off single from junior third baseman Katie Harrington, keeping the blue and white’s six-run lead intact heading into the fifth.

Penn State needed just two runs in the fifth inning to reach the run rule margin, and the Nittany Lions reached that mark in no time.

A single from Klosowicz and a walk from Macy Chamberlin brought up freshman Gabby Gradishar with a chance to record the first RBI of her collegiate career. Gradishar did just that, knocking an RBI double.

Gradishar was followed by an RBI single from Jordyn Jochims to extend Penn State’s lead to 9-1.

Two straight walks from Hegarty allowed for another Nittany Lions run and forced another Lafayette pitching change.

Junior Parker Rowden entered to face Finarelli, who grounded into a fielder’s choice, but still recorded her fourth RBI of the game.

A double from Barbanente and a fielder's choice from Jordan George brought in three more runs to give Penn State a 14-1 lead heading into the bottom of the fifth.

Britton didn’t allow any Leopards on base in the fifth, completing the Nittany Lions' run-rule victory.

Up Next

Penn State will have a quick turnaround, facing Houston Christian at 1:30 p.m.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘The more days we have like this the better’ | Penn State's School of Music celebrates the Lunar New Year
author: Kyla Jones I The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s School of Music welcomed the Lunar New Year at the Recital Hall Friday evening. The event featured performances of vocal arrangements, string instruments, piano, flute and other traditional Asian selections.

The children’s vocal ensemble, Corl Street & Ferguson Township Schools, opened the concert greeting the audience and leading them in a traditional Chinese New Year song “Gong Xi Gong Xi ("Best wishes").

The opening song selection marks the beginning of a new season, and expresses good fortune.

Mathew Olmstead previously performed in the concert choir and initially came to support fellow members, but felt inspired to see younger performers and a deeper meaning behind the event’s celebration.

“I’m appreciative to be exposed to a different culture,” Olmstead, a PhD student, said. “It’s a reminder that different cultures celebrate the new year at different times.”

Mason Li who played the guzheng and Kevin Kang, an eighth grader from Park Forest Middle School who played the piano, arranged the piece “Spring Dawn in Snowy Mountains,” inspired by traditional songs.

“I arranged the piece from two composers, originally written for guzheng, but I arranged it for a piano duet,” Mason, seventh grader from Mount Nittany Middle School, said. “I had to adjust some places (in the song) for it to fit together properly.”

After a brief intermission, the performance had songs of reflection and hope for the 2026 Lunar New Year.

Chancellor Jungwoo Ryoo at Penn State DuBois and his wife Hyeseon Kim recited a Korean piece titled “Water” by Jeong Kang Kim in their traditional Hanbok clothing.

“There's something about wearing your traditional outfit that really brings out a unique cultural identity,” Hyeseon Kim said.

Before beginning the poem, the couple described their connection to water, while a scroll with the word written in blue lined characters was handed to them. This reflected their connection and inspiration for reciting the poem.

According to Ryoo, the poem is meant to set the tone and symbolize a new transformation into the new year and moving forward — like water — as it “shows you a handful of life.”

The Recital Hall was not only full of lively music but of families with their children observing the concert in traditional wear and friends taking in all of the moments of celebration with grand applauses after performances.

Ryoo said many individuals within the Asian diaspora who live in the United States can sometimes feel disconnected from their heritage.

“These holidays are not really celebrated in Western culture so we tend to forget,” Ryoo said. “By being able to come together like this, it’s really a community that just keeps us connected.”

The concert concluded with "Chinese Rhapsody Op. 2, Prelude and Dance” by Wenyi Xiong, played on the piano by An-Lun Huang. The performance was followed by a reception for friends and family to enjoy snacks and connect.

“Everyone really enjoyed themselves and just being happy, it’s golden,” Ryoo said. “The more days we have like this the better.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: ‘They care about each other’ | Penn State wrestling’s bond paves way to on-mat success
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Following a 36-5 win over Ohio State, Penn State flocked to the center of that mat with each wrestler wearing either a blue or white jumpsuit.

Standing in the middle was 174-pounder Levi Haines, who hoisted the trophy for the Nittany Lions, clinching the regular season Big Ten title. Surrounding him were his teammates, who had their arms around each other and boasted beaming smiles.

The chemistry of the group has stood out in the 2025-26 campaign, and on Friday evening, it pushed Penn State to a blowout win over the previously undefeated Buckeyes.

“We have a great team. Our culture is the friendship, and the camaraderie is — I don't think it's ever been anything close to what we have right now,” Cael Sanderson said. “I think a lot of it has to do with all the changes in college athletics, and the kids are coming here because they want to be here and they want to be a part of something special.”

The buy-in from the coaches, wrestlers and strength staff is what Sanderson believes makes the team as great as it is. There’s an endless support system stemming from the Lorenzo Wrestling Complex, and it shows year after year, with Penn State bringing home 12 national championships under Sanderson’s reign.

A tight-knit group is the goal each season, and that’s been on display with this year’s bunch, with encouragement being at a premium from the wrestlers. In front of a sold-out crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center, one in which totaled 16,006 fans that set the NCAA wrestling indoor attendance record, that support was on display.

It pushed guys like No. 1 Luke Lilledahl over No. 2 Nic Bouzakis at 125 pounds, No. 4 Marcus Blaze past No. 2 Ben Davino at 133 pounds and No. 12 Cole Mirasola over No. 3 Nick Feldman at heavyweight.

“We're getting a lot of like-minded people that fit in with what we're trying to do,” Sanderson said. “They're close and they care about each other, and they want to see each other win. That's what makes your job fun as a coach, is seeing a team that cares about each other, and their parents want to see the other kids win and that kind of stuff. It's special.”

The investment has made the program historically one of the most dominant dynasties across all collegiate sports. Sanderson has concocted a recipe that builds success year in and year out.

And it’s entertaining for those who step into Rec Hall and the Bryce Jordan Center. In the steamrolling of the Buckeyes, Matt Campbell, Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics Pat Kraft and UFC fighter and former Penn State wrestler Bo Nickal were in the building. Kyle Snyder, who was an Ohio State wrestler and now wrestles for the Nittany Lion Wrestling Club, was sporting a Penn State hat as he watched from his seat.

There’s the daily grind filled with sweat equity for the wrestlers. There’s the flash of what it takes to wrestle in the blue and white singlet. But as Mirasola explained, it starts with the coaches pouring everything they have into the wrestlers.

“Our coaching staff is the best in the world,” Mirasola said. “Can't thank any of them enough for what they do for us. Love our coaches. Love our staff and love all of our team.”

Friday brought buzz to a dual that Penn State hadn’t seen in a significant period of time. There was some noise that Ohio State could hang with the Nittany Lions, but despite being the No. 2 team in the country, Penn State showed there’s a true gap between it and everyone else, proving why it’s the No. 1 team nationally.

Next Friday, the Nittany Lions will host Princeton at 7 p.m. at Rec Hall in what will more likely than not be a tune-up match before heading into the Big Ten Championships at the Bryce Jordan Center.

The matchup against the Buckeyes gave Penn State a taste of what the postseason will feel like, but in the meantime, the wrestlers will ride the support of each other in pursuit of the greater goal — a Big Ten title and a national championship win.

“It’s a close group, and a lot of obviously tough battles tonight, and our guys fought hard,” Sanderson said. “We're able to go find those points at the end, and really good matches. So, that's something we need to keep doing as we prepare for the postseason.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball moves up Saturday's games against Lafayette and Houston due to inclement weather
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Heavy rain forecast for the Houston area has affected the start times for both the blue and white games on Saturday.

bumping things up⏰Due to inclement weather forecasted in greater Houston, tomorrow’s games have been adjusted and will begin at 11 a.m. (ET) / 10 a.m. (CT) from Husky Field on the campus of Houston Christian University.#WeAre | #AllIn pic.twitter.com/zDjVpcD4d5— Penn State Softball (@PennStateSB) February 14, 2026

The first pitch against Lafayette is now scheduled for 11 a.m., followed by the second game against Houston Christian at 1:30 p.m.

Both games will be played at Husky Field on the campus of Houston Christian University.

Penn State wrapped up its first doubleheader of the weekend on Friday, with a 5-4 loss against Incarnate Word and a 10-2 win over Houston.

The Nittany Lions carry a 5-2 record into Saturday's doubleheader.

title: Penn State baseball opens season with big loss to Air Force
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
While Penn State fans sat in Happy Valley in freezing temperatures, the Nittany Lions traveled Southwest to open the season.

Penn State played its first game of the MLB Desert Invitational against Air Force in Goodyear, Arizona, opening the season with a 15-3 loss.

Redshirt senior Colin Fitzgerald, who transferred to the blue and white from Maine, started on the mound on Day 1. His Penn State career opened on a high note, recording a groundout and strikeout.

After walking Walker Zapp, Fitzgerald recorded another groundout to close the top of the inning.

The bottom of the inning featured no movement for the Nittany Lions as Cohl Mercado, Jayden Davis and Jack Porter went 1-2-3 to end the first inning.

Fitzgerald slipped in his first throw of the second inning, as the Falcons found base on a single from outfielder Brooks Burdine. The Lititz, Pennsylvania, native then retired the next three batters, bringing the Nittany Lions back to the batter’s box, where they recorded another three outs.

Penn State opened the top of the third with a ground out, but quickly fell behind as Fitzgerald recorded back-to-back base on balls.

Back at the top of the lineup, Zapp recorded the first of two outs, bringing Penn State back to bat.

After a groundout by Kevin Karstetter to start the bottom of the third, the Nittany Lions looked to score after a single from Nate Voss turned into a third-base opportunity after a stolen base and a balk by Air Force’s Gaines Estridge.

Mercado started the top of the lineup with a walk, putting runners at first and third base.

However, Penn State’s scoring opportunity was put to rest as Mercado was thrown out trying to advance to second base.

Air Force quickly responded to that threat with its own scoring run, which found success in the top of the fourth. While throwing no outs, Fitzgerald walked Burdine, who stole second base, and allowed another pair of runners on base as he ultimately scored.

Up 1-0, the Falcons took advantage of Fitzgerald’s poor pitching and earned another run, leaving two on base as junior Kyle Emmons came on in relief of Fitzgerald.

Fortunately for Air Force, Emmons wasn’t having any luck either, as a throwing error allowed T.J. Oster to score and made it a three-run game.

Emmons escaped the top of the fourth with a pair of outs, sending the Nittany Lions back to bat. However, Porter, Bryce Molinaro and Spencer Barnett each recorded an out, giving the Falcons another chance to score.

Junior Mason Horwat, who recorded four wins in his 11 starts this year, took the mound for Emmons and was walked all over by Air Force.

Horwat recorded one out before allowing three runners on base, each who scored and took a 6-0 lead to the bottom of the fifth.

With four innings down, Penn State only recorded one hit, and that abysmal record continued as just Voss made his way onto the base from a hit. Outfielder Justin Turcovski recorded a walk, but both were sent back to the dugout after a Mercado flyout.

With the Nittany Lions back on the mound, Horwat let another pair of runners find their way home as Air Force pulled ahead by eight runs. After two outs by Davis and Porter, Molinaro walked onto base, but Penn State was sent back with its third out.

Penn State tabbed its fourth pitcher of the night in freshman Ethan Bauerschmidt, who started strong with a pair of outs. However, the Falcons found their way back on the scoreboard after an error by Molinaro sent Trip Garrish home, followed by three more runners.

In the bottom of the seventh, the Nittany Lions scored their first two runs of the day off Karstetter and Voss. Through the two scores, Penn State only recorded one hit, but Air Force had a walk, a wild pitch and hit Voss with the pitch.

The Nittany Lions’ attempted comeback continued with another run by Turcovski, but freshman pitcher Robert Brown III let in another four runs for Air Force, taking a 15-3 lead for the mercy rule.

Up next

Penn State continues the MLB Desert Invitational with a 3 p.m. matchup against Grand Canyon on Saturday.

MORE BASEBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State softball presented with chance to continue momentum at Houston Invitational
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
Continuing their weekend in the Lone Star State, Penn State is set to face off against the Houston Cougars and Lafayette Leopards for their second day of the Houston Invitational.

The blue and white started the weekend by facing off against Incarnate Word. The Cardinals boosted their winning streak to seven after their afternoon matchup against the Nittany Lions.

An upset that ended 4-5, the Cardinals scored their last four runs late in the 7th inning.

Penn State fell short at the end of each program's first meeting.

On the first day of the tournament, the Nittany Lions ended with positive momentum, defeating Houston on its home field to give the blue and white its fifth win of the season.

Set to face off against two teams the following day, here's a closer look at what the Nittany Lions are expecting.

Lafayette

Penn State is set to face off against Lafayette at 11 a.m. on Saturday for its third game of the weekend.

This was the second time these teams faced off in the dirt; the Nittany Lions hosted the Leopards and run-ruled Lafayette 13-0 in five innings.

Saturday’s game will be an in-state matchup; the Leopards finished 5-13 in the Patriot League and 7-31 overall. Finding the second-to-last in their conference in the 2025 season.

Lafayette took a 2-1 loss to Incarnate Word to start off their weekend in Texas and then suffered a 12-4 thumping at the hands of Houston. Putting their record for the 2026 season to 0-2.

Their matchup against the Nittany Lions will be their third game of the season.

Houston Christian

For their fourth matchup of the tournament, the Nittany Lions will face the Huskies at 1:30 p.m.

Houston Christian went 0-4 in its inaugural weekend of the season, and finished winless against Pitt and Michigan at the Houston Invitational the following week.

This will be the first meeting between the Huskies and the Nittany Lions. Chloe Foster stands at the top of the team’s leaderboard in batting average with a .375 mark, while Jocelyn Briseno narrowly trails Foster’s team-high RBI figure of four by one.

Leah Hammack leads the pitching staff with a 5.25 earned run average.

In their 2025 campaign, the Huskies went 17-33 overall and 10-17 in the Southland Conference.

Penn State has a chance to build a strong start to its 2026 campaign, with wins against these nonconference opponents.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball dominates behind offensive power, blows out Houston 10-2
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
The opening game for Penn State at the Houston Invitational ended in a tough walkoff loss, but the Nittany Lions had a chance to get back in the win column against Houston on Friday night. For the second straight game, the blue and white faced an undefeated squad with the Cougars entering the contest at 6-0 after a win over Lafayette earlier in the day.

The Nittany Lions clicked on all cylinders and ran away with a lopsided 10-2 win over Houston.

While Coach Clarisa Crowell opted to start an experienced pitcher in Bridget Nemeth, Houston started freshman London Park on the bump. The Nittany Lions broke through offensively with their first crack at Park in the game.

Freshman Allison Oneacre batted in all four runs for Penn State in its loss to Incarnate Word and she wasted no time picking up where she left off in the first. Sophomore Natalie Lieto walked on four pitches and Oneacre hammered a two-run home run deep into center, which gave the blue and white the early 2-0 lead.

After Nemeth shut down the Cougars quietly in the bottom half of the first, the blue and white’s bats went right back to work in the second. Junior Brooke Klosowicz hit a dribbler up to Park, who opted to throw out Cara Bohner at second, but Klosowicz caught the Cougars’ defense off-guard and advanced into scoring position.

With one out, senior Madison Seidel battered a single through the left side and drove in Klosowicz to extend Penn State’s lead 3-0. Seidel turned on the jets and made it to second off the throw home, but a couple of groundouts ended the scoring.

While the Nittany Lions added on to their lead, Houston cut into their lead in its very next half inning. Despite having the count at 1-2, cleanup Makenna Mitchell drilled a double to the right-center gap, putting early pressure on Nemeth. Then Kylei Griffin walked on five pitches, making it second and first with no outs.

After Ronnie Esparza grounded out to second baseman Michela Barbabente, Leilani Garcia sent a ball back to Nemeth, who opted for the out at first, but in doing so plated Mitchell in from third. However, Nemeth kept the lead at 3-1 with her second strikeout to retire the side.

Houston went to its bullpen in the third, bringing in redshirt senior Paris Lehman to face the top of the blue and white’s lineup. However, Penn State’s freshmen continued producing huge offensive numbers. Lieto walked for the second time in the night and freshman Kirsten Finarelli launched a two-run home run deep into center, punching right back and making it a 5-1 game.

Crowell also turned to her bullpen and called upon freshman Mackenzie Duncan to face the Cougars’ lineup in the third. While the Winter Garden, Florida, native started the inning off strong with a strikeout, Ariel Redmond blasted a high pitch far into left field to keep Houston in striking distance, 5-2.

However, Duncan locked back in and retired the next two Cougars. While the Nittany Lions couldn’t drive Seidel in from second in their half of the fourth, Duncan collected two strikeouts in the bottom half of the inning and kept the lead at three.

While Penn State was shut down for a few innings, the bats came back alive in the fifth and poured on the runs. After loading the bases with three walks and just one out, Houston called upon senior Nicole Bodeux to face power hitter Klosowicz. The Johnsburg, Illinois, native delivered for the Nittany Lions with a two-run single to right and made the lead 7-2.

The scoring didn’t stop there as a two-out wild pitch by Bodeux allowed Bohner to score from third, 8-2. The Cougars prevented any more runs from scoring, but they couldn’t cut into the lead as Duncan and freshman Brevyn Kellepouris provided a joint shutdown inning.

It didn’t take long for Penn State to pour it on even more in the sixth. After a few walks, Barbabente flared a one-out single to shallow right and scored Oneacre from second. With an error by first baseman Griffin, Finarelli advanced to third and then scored on another wild pitch.

The blue and white didn’t score for the rest of the inning, but took a large 10-2 lead into the bottom half of the sixth. Kellepouris secured the victory for the Nittany Lions with three groundouts and Penn State improved to 5-2 on the season.

Up next

Penn State continues its schedule at the Houston Invitational against Lafayette at 1 p.m. on Saturday.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘We got to go back to playing good habits’| Penn State women’s hockey reflects on overtime upset to RIT
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
Head coach Jeff Kampersal began his postgame statement in a common thankful mood; however, it quickly changed when discussing the game against RIT. In his lengthy, immediate comments on the 3-2 overtime upset loss, Kampersal didn’t sugarcoat the reason he felt his team lost.

“I thought it was a distracted vibe today,” Kampersal said. “A couple of our teammates (are) playing games in Italy and not being necessarily locked in. I thought we were ready, but we weren’t necessarily ready to play.”

Before the puck dropped on Game 1 of the final regular season series, the Penn State bench looked short with three players in Italy for the Winter Olympics. Additionally, Mya Vaslet was ruled out of the game due to an “upper body injury.” With a smaller bench comes additional minutes on individual shifts, ultimately leading to tired skaters.

It took until the second period for No. 4 Penn State to record its first goal of the game against RIT. The early momentum for the Nittany Lions quickly shifted towards the Tigers after they were able to score two unanswered goals. RIT spent the majority of the second period in the lead.

However, Katelyn Roberts tied the game in the last seconds of the period. After a scoreless third period, overtime approached. Nearly four minutes into the overtime period, Cassandra Barnes found the net with her game-winning goal.

The Tigers were able to utilize power play opportunities to add to the scoreboard as one of their three goals came on the man-advantage.

“They have a dynamite power play,” Kampersal said. “We take too many penalties, so it caught up with us.”

The Nittany Lions came into the game giving up the second-most penalties in the conference. While RIT leads the conference in power play goals with 35.

With one game left in the regular season and the playoffs quickly approaching, a loss like this gives Kampersal cause to call on his team to use it as an example of what they need to shape up.

“We play good defense, but we give second chances because we try to make fancy backhand passes or we pass to the person we’re supposed to be covering,” Kampersal said. “That is what we have to shape up because we play a certain way and get away with it until we get out of the lead, and then we get smacked in the head for it. So, we got to go back to playing good habits.”

The Nittany Lions face a quick turnaround as they begin Game 2 against RIT on Saturday at 3 p.m.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Ex-Penn State basketball center Yanic Konan Niederhauser competes at NBA Rising Stars
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Center Yanic Konan Niederhauser showed off his potential at the pro level on Friday night.

The former Penn State standout competed for Team Austin at the NBA Rising Stars event, starting in the semifinal game against Team Melo. Despite his squad losing 40-34, Konan Niederhauser tallied a team-high 11 points, two rebounds, one assist and one block on 5-of-8 shooting across nine minutes.

Konan Niederhauser capitalized on multiple alley-oops throughout the contest, displaying his lob-threat trait.

Yanic Konan Niederhauser with a dunk in Game 1 of the NBA Rising Starspic.twitter.com/g48oZxeEWu— Will Horstman (@WillHorstman_) February 14, 2026

NBA Rising Stars is a four-team event with two semifinal games and a championship game, showcasing young talent in the league. The winners of the semifinals were decided by the first team to 40 points.

With Team Austin, Konan Niederhauser was competing on the G League squad in the event. The 7-footer had some range to his game as well by making a 3-pointer.

Yanic Konan Niederhauser showing off the range with this 3-pointer at NBA Rising Starspic.twitter.com/wRAdyb7Qan— Will Horstman (@WillHorstman_) February 14, 2026

Konan Niederhauser is a rotational player for the Clippers this season, currently serving as the backup center to Brook Lopez after Ivica Zubac was traded to the Indiana Pacers. He's averaging 3.7 points and 2.3 rebounds with 67.6% shooting across 9.0 minutes per game in 34 appearances.

There have been four games in which Konan Niederhauser played at least 20 minutes this season. During those occasions, Konan Niederhauser averaged 12.0 points, 7.3 rebounds and 1.3 blocks per game.

The Swiss native has seen some action with Los Angeles' G League affiliate, the San Diego Clippers, as well in 2025-26. Across eight games played, Konan Niederhauser averaged 14.5 points, 9.5 rebounds and 2.4 blocks per game.

Last offseason, Konan Niederhauser shot up on draft boards after he performed well at the G League Elite Camp and the NBA Draft Combine. He ended up cracking the first round with the Clippers selecting him 30th overall in the 2025 NBA draft last June.

Konan Niederhauser spent one season with Penn State in 2024-25 after transferring in from Northern Illinois. He earned an All-Big Ten honorable mention, averaging 12.9 points, 6.3 rebounds and 2.3 blocks per game with 61.1% shooting across 29 appearances.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State track and field dominates set of invitationals
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another week, another set of school records for Penn State.

Amongst the David Hemery Valentine Invitational, the Tyson Invite and the Husky Classic, the Nittany Lions earned several top places, school records and top marks in NCAA history.

David Hemery Valentine Invitational - Friday

Graduate student Allon Clay kicked off the action similar to how he’s done all year, running one of the fastest times in NCAA history.

Clay ran a school record 2:17.29 in the men’s 1000-meter, breaking his previous record of 2:18.09. Not only did his time win the race, but he also set the No. 2 time in NCAA history.

The fast track action continued in the men’s mile, where Justin Healey took two seconds off his personal best and ran a 4:02.04 for 39th place out of 321 competitors.

Penn State earned another school record Friday afternoon when Nick Sloff improved on his own 3,000-meter school record. Running a time of 7:42.68, Sloth finished ninth in

The men’s 3000 invite, breaking Penn State’s record.

Tyson Invite - Friday

Continuing the Nittany Lion tradition of school record-breaking, sophomore Jake Palermo earned an all-time best in the men’s 400-meters, breaking his previous school record in 45.33 seconds.

Later that day, fellow sophomore Ajani Dywer earned a spot in the men’s 60-meter championship finals after running 6.56 seconds for fifth place in the prelims.

Racing against a pair of Olympians, Dwyer ran 6.58 seconds for sixth place in the finals.

On the field, Gabby Cope and Alex Pancoast each earned personal bests in the women’s weight throw. Cope finished 16th in the event with a throw of 20.18 meters, while Pancoast threw 19.49 meters for 19th place.

Husky Classic - Friday

The Nittany Lions wrapped up Day 1 of action with the women’s distance medley relay, where Hayley Kitching, Alexandria North, Boh Ritchie and Ada Rand competed. The four athletes finished sixth overall, running 10:51.68 for the second-best time in school history.

David Hemery Valentine Invitational - Saturday

After a pair of records in Boston on Saturday, the David Hemery Valentine Invitational was a little quieter on Sunday for Penn State.

Senior Katie Dallas earned a big personal best in the women’s 3000-meter, running 9:16.91 for 21st place.

Several Nittany Lions finished the evening in the women’s 5000-meters, where Charlotte Costich led the way with a 27th-place finish in 16:06.46. Claire Daniels finished shortly behind in 16:21.24 for 45th place, followed by Claire Zubey in 55th place with a personal-best 16:27.10.

Tyson Invite - Saturday

The Tyson Invite continued to be the spot a majority of the Nittany Lions competed, with several top marks popping up in Arkansas on Saturday.

The field action got things going with Hannah Riolo and Gwen Cudmore competing in the women’s high jump. The duo each jumped 1.70 meters, finishing in fifth place.

In the men’s high jump, freshman Trip Campbell finished eighth out of 17 competitors, jumping 2.11 meters. Besides his personal best 2.15 meters, he jumped earlier this year, Campbell’s performance at the Tyson Invite marked the best among the Nittany Lions this year.

The one jumper that earned a spot in the record books on Saturday was Lizzie Schreiber, who broke the school record in the triple jump. Schreiber finished sixth with a record-breaking jump of 13.12 meters.

On the track, Niko Schultz and Kaleb Nastari kicked off the 800-meter action for Penn State.

Competing in the men’s championship, Schultz finished fourth with a personal-best time of 1:46.53, while Nastari finished ninth with 1:48.02. Schultz’s mark came just 16 seconds from the fifth-best time in school history.

The men’s shot put wrapped up the field events at the Tyson Invite, as Dylan Lambrecht improved on his fifth-best throw in school history, finishing third with 19.51 meters. Senior Ryan Henry finished sixth with a throw of 19.25 meters.

The men’s 4x400m relay was the final Penn State event in Arkansas, as the four athletes ran a season-best 3:07.52 for sixth place in the championship heat.

Husky Classic - Saturday

The West Coast delivered some excitement for Penn State on Day 2 with four Nittany Lions competing in a pair of events.
