After running a near record-breaking DMR on Friday night, Rand came back and ran the third-fastest mile in school history. The sophomore standout ran 4:33.38 for sixth place in the meet, followed by Lea Hatcher’s 4:35.84 for eighth place and a personal best.

The women’s 800m was the arguably the biggest race of the weekend as Kitching ran sub-two minutes for the first time in her career.

The Coffs Harbour, Australia, native ran 1:59.22 to win the invite 800m, followed by Ritchie in fifth place with a near-personal best 2:01.65. Not only was Kitching’s time a school record, but also marked the third-fastest 800m in NCAA history.

ASICS Sound Invite - Saturday

While the men’s 800m school record holder wasn’t at the three invites the rest of Penn State was at, senior Handal Roban took his talents to the ASICS Sound Invite to compete in the Diagrid Family Wealth men’s 800m.

Racing against former school record holder Isaiah Harris, Roban finished second in the event with a new school record of 1:44.73, falling to 17-year-old Nike athlete Cooper Lutkenhaus.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s volleyball takes win after five set battle against Princeton
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 15 Penn State opened its two-game series against Princeton with a 3-2 win after going the distance in five sets on Friday.

The first set opened with a kill from Sean Harvey, but the Tigers responded immediately to open up some back-and-forth scoring.

Gaige Gabriel and Matthew Luoma came up with a big block to pull the blue and white ahead 5-2. But again, Princeton responded by scoring the next three points to tie it.

The Nittany Lions answered back, scoring the next four points with a kill from Jaidyn Bethel and a few blocks.

Up 9-6, Owen Rose responded to a Tigers’ kill immediately with a massive kill of his own. Following the first service ace of the match from Luoma, the blue and white went up 11-7.

Kills from Luoma and Rose allowed the blue and white to keep a steady lead during the early moments. But Gabriel and Luoma's attacking errors allowed the Tigers to get back within two, making the score 14-12.

At 18-14, with Penn State leading after kills from Luoma, Gabriel and Bethel, the Tigers called their first timeout.

A kill and service ace scored the Tigers back-to-back points as they looked to diminish the Penn State lead, but it was too wide for any recovery.

The Nittany Lions took the first set 25-19 with a kill from Tristain Hassell to close it.

The second set of play opened with back-and-forth scoring, but Penn State pulled away 6-3 after a kill from Gabriel and a block from Rose and Bethel.

Princeton’s response was immediate, and the blue and white’s lead was shut down with three back-to-back points from the Tigers, tying it up at 6-6.

From there, scoring went back-and-forth once more, with each point from either side seeing an immediate response from the other. But after kills from Luoma and Bethel, and an ace from Harvey, the blue and white pulled away 14-11.

But again, Princeton managed to shut down the lead in quick fashion, tying it back up at 15-15.

After a few more points, the Nittany Lions challenged a point that would put the Tigers back within one at 18-17. After a long pause to review the contested point, the point stood, closing the blue and white’s lead by just one.

Penn State quickly took back a larger lead again after a Princeton service error and an ace from Rose, forcing a timeout from the Tigers.

After back-to-back points from the Tigers to get back within one at 21-20, the Nittany Lions called a timeout as the end of the set approached.

After a few quick points, Princeton called their second timeout of the set at 23-21, hoping to pull ahead and take the second set.

The Nittany Lions, however, were quick to shut things down. The second set ended with a service error from Princeton, allowing the blue and white to take the set 25-22.

The third set opened with more back-and-forth scoring from both sides, and the score remained relatively close through several points. But four back-to-back points from the Tigers gave them an 8-5 lead.

After continuing to dominate with a 12-8 lead, the Nittany Lions called their first timeout of the set to regroup.

And regroup they did. The Nittany Lions came off the timeout and closed the lead to 13-11 with the help of some errors from Princeton and a kill from Luoma.

It wasn’t long after that that the Tigers shut down any hopes of a Penn State recovery. After several points, they took a six-point, 21-15, lead and forced yet another timeout from the blue and white.

Penn State was able to close the lead within two with an ace from Hassell and multiple kills, and after two long rallies, the Nittany Lions were within one at 23-22.

After a valiant effort from Penn State, the Tigers took the third set 25-23, forcing a fourth.

The fourth set opened in a similar fashion, with scoring remaining relatively close. But after three back-to-back points from the Tigers, they pulled ahead 12-9.

While Hassell and Rose were able to make some big kills, the lead stayed with the Tigers, 15-12, as a media timeout hit the court.

Tying things up after the break, the blue and white were back in it. But after Princeton retook the lead 19-16, Penn State called a timeout.

After more back-and-forth, Princeton took the fourth set 25-22, forcing a fifth and final winner-takes-all set.

The fifth set saw an early ace from Michael Schwob and big kills from Gabriel and Bethel to take an early lead 6-3.

Gabriel produced a number of crucial blocks, allowing the blue and white to take the lead by six at 9-3. And once the blue and white got going, it couldn’t be stopped.

With the lead at 14-11, Penn State was looking at match point. And with his 22nd of the night, Harvey closed out the match with a kill.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions return tomorrow for a Saturday, Valentine's Day clash to close out the series against Princeton. Streaming is set to begin at 4:00 p.m. on ESPN Plus.

MORE VOLLEYBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State women's basketball to take on Northwestern in annual Pink Zone game
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
With four games left in the season, Penn State is eyeing every matchup as an attempt to get one step closer to the Big Ten tournament.

On Sunday, the Lady Lions will have another chance as they take on Northwestern at 4 p.m. in the Pink Zone game.

Despite historically dominating the Wildcats, this weekend’s matchup may be one of the closest in the teams’ history, as both squads sit at eight wins on the year.

All-time matchups

While the Lady Lions fell to Northwestern last year, they’ve been historically dominant against the Wildcats.

Since the two started playing in 1979, Penn State has built a 42-13 all-time record. During the past seven seasons with coach Carolyn Kieger, Northwestern has won six times while the blue and white’s come out victorious just four times.

Before Kieger’s time in Happy Valley, the Lady Lions experienced 13 straight wins against Northwestern. In the late 90’s and early 2000’s, Penn State had a similar experience, winning 12 straight matchups.

2025-26 Northwestern

Similar to Penn State, the Wildcats have been among the worst teams in the Big Ten, with an 8-16 record this season.

Northwestern started the season strong with seven straight wins, but lost seven straight games to end 2025. After defeating Rutgers and Wisconsin to earn their only wins of the conference season, the Wildcats have lost six straight heading into Sunday’s matchup.

Despite the team’s overall struggles, senior Grace Sullivan has been a star for the Wildcats, averaging 22.2 points per game.

As the second-lowest scoring team in the conference at 65.5 points per game, Sullivan averages over one-third of Northwestern’s scoring on any given night.

Sunday’s matchup

After Sullivan, only junior Casey Harter averages double digits with 10.1 points per game. In last year's contest with the Lady Lions, she recorded 10 points, with five of them coming from the charity stripe.

Of this year’s Penn State returners, only Gracie Merkle, Vitoria Santana and Moriah Murray saw action against them, combining for 25 points.

It was a low-scoring matchup last year, just 69-63, and this Sunday’s matchup could be similar with two of the lower-ranking teams in the conference.

For Penn State, the key to success will be limiting Sullivan. Without her, Northwestern could potentially be held to 50 or fewer points. But on the other hand, if Merkle, Murray and Kiyomi McMiller are held quiet, the rest of the Lady Lions will struggle to produce.

Pink Zone

While Sunday’s contest should be a close contest between a pair of eight-win teams, it will also remember and celebrate those who have been diagnosed with breast cancer.

“People understand how big of a game it is, but I don’t think people really understand that we really aren’t playing for ourselves,” Murray told The Daily Collegian. “Before the game, getting to walk through the practice gym and seeing all of the people who have fought cancer or are still fighting, it really means a lot to me and my teammates.”

Organized by the Pa. Pink Zone, the 20th annual Play4Kay game allows survivors and fighters to gather before the game for various activities and to be honored at halftime.

At the 2025 Pink Zone game, there was a total of 1,620 years, nine months and 15 days of survivorship in attendance.

“It’s a great cause every single day,” Murray said.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 6 Penn State men’s hockey loses to No. 2 Michigan in shootout, earns tie in NCAA standings
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
Sixth-ranked Penn State, after its last bye week of the regular season, traveled north to Ann Arbor for a top-six matchup against No. 2 Michigan on Friday, the first of two games at Yost Ice Arena.

Yost Ice Arena has been a haunted house for the Nittany Lions in the past, as heading into Friday’s contest, they owned a 7-16 record in Ann Arbor since joining the Big Ten. However, they won three contests on the road against the Wolverines last season, including a series sweep in the quarterfinals of the Big Ten tournament.

That success in Ann Arbor continued on Friday, but it resulted in just a tie in the NCAA standings. A back-and-forth thriller ended with a Michigan 4-4 shootout victory.

First period

Penn State was in full throttle offensively to begin Friday’s matchup, which set the tone for the first period.

After the Wolverines cleared their defensive zone just 50 seconds into the game, left wing Matt DiMarsico reentered with the puck and kicked it out to right wing JJ Wiebusch at the right dot. Wiebusch patiently waited, then fed center Reese Laubach across the ice for a one-timer, putting the Nittany Lions in front 1-0.

After approximately nine minutes of back-and-forth play, Michigan finally struck back. Right defenseman Drew Schock skated into free ice by the left circle and fired a wrist shot, where right wing Garrett Schifsky tapped the puck into the back of the net off a rebound and past goaltender Josh Fleming, tying the game 1-1.

The programs exchanged two goals in the next four minutes following Schifsky’s tally. Left defenseman Jackson Smith was the first to score, taking control of a Wolverine turnover in his offensive zone and sniping a goal from a tough angle by the bottom of the right circle.

His goal gave Penn State a 2-1 lead and moved him into first all-time in school history for the single-season record of most goals by a defenseman, scoring his ninth on Friday.

The glory and excitement didn’t last for long, however, as Big Ten leading scorer T.J. Hughes scored on a 5-on-3 from another impressive angle. Hughes' goal was the last of a first frame that featured fireworks.

Second period

The second period began with Penn State fending off a multitude of penalties, which included killing Wiebusch’s five-minute major and game misconduct that he took towards the end of the first frame.

After those hardships, the Nittany Lions retook the lead via a goal from an unexpected player — fourth-line center Nic Chin-DeGraves. The scoring opportunity stemmed from left wing Shea Van Olm generating a takeaway in the Wolverines defensive zone.

Van Olm skated towards the left dot and then fed Chin-DeGraves, where he roofed the shot past Michigan goaltender Jack Ivankovich to give Penn State a 3-2 lead.

However, a mere three minutes later, the Wolverines answered, just as they had the entire game.

Center Michael Hage, a Montreal Canadiens former first-round pick, skated around the right side of the boards and fed right defensemen Asher Barnett by the left dot, where he beat Fleming and tied the game 3-3.

Third period

Michigan took its first lead of the contest at the 10:21 mark of the third period, scoring a goal after a turnover from left wing Lev Katzin, which led to a 4-on-2 rush for the Wolverines.

Left wing Malcolm Spence led the high-danger opportunity, shooting the puck at Fleming, which was initially saved. Hughes swatted the rebound into the back of the net to give Michigan a 4-3 lead.

After six minutes of game time and seven combined penalties, Penn State responded on the power play. Right-wing Ben Schoen handled the puck at the point near the left boards and fed a seam pass to Laubach across the ice.

Laubach, who scored earlier, one-touched the puck to Smith, who fired a wrist shot past Ivankovich to tie the game at four, ultimately forcing overtime.

Overtime

Penn State and Michigan engaged in a back-and-forth overtime period that sustained multiple high-danger chances for each team. The Nittany, however, earned a majority of the best chances, including two in the last 15 seconds of the period.

Both Chin-DeGraves and McKenna were all alone in front of Michigan’s goaltender. Ivankovich stopped both opportunities to send the game into a shootout.

Shootout

Penn State’s DiMarsico, Aiden Fink and McKenna went 0-for-3 in the shootout, while Michigan’s Hage beat Fleming on his first attempt.

Injury Report:

Captain Dane Dowiak left the game in the second period, but there’s been no update on his designation.

Up Next:

The Penn State-Michigan series finale is set for 5 p.m. ET Saturday, airing on the Big Ten Network.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 1 Penn State wrestling wins Big Ten regular season title, snaps No. 2 Ohio State's undefeated record
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
No. 1 Penn State against No. 2 Ohio State received a lot of hype for multiple weeks leading up to the dual. However, with multiple Buckeye wrestlers out with injury, the dual became less intriguing for the national audience.

The Nittany Lions continued their dual winning streak in front of an NCAA-record crowd of 16,006 fans with a 36-5 score over Ohio State. The win clinched the Big Ten regular season championship

Here’s how the dual went down.

125 pounds: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 2 Nic Bouzakis (OSU)

The dual kicked off with the most anticipated match of the night, No. 1 vs. No. 2. The wrestlers didn’t give up any ground and traded attacks at each other but neither found any success.

Both earned an escape point and with a minute left in the seven-minute time, which made it look like it’d go to sudden victory. As time was expiring, Lilledhal secured a takedown, but the clock hit zero before he fully got to Bouzakis.

After motioning to keep the match moving, Lilledahl got the takedown, and sent the sold-out BJC crowd into a frenzy.

Penn State got out in front 3-0.

133 pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 2 Ben Davino (OSU)

A similarly paced match occurred at 133 pounds. Marcus Blaze and Ben Davino sat at 1-1 as time expired in the normal seven minutes.

Sudden victory showcased more of the same — two highly touted wrestlers who’ve faced each other in the past, not giving up a single inch. Tiebreakers would decide the match.

Blaze started on top and could only keep Davino down for nine seconds, meaning he’d have to escape before nine seconds in the second tiebreaker. Blaze couldn’t escape prior to the nine seconds, but grabbed Davino’s leg and reversed him, keeping him down for the final seconds and pulled off the victory.

Penn State’s lead doubled to 6-0.

141 pounds: No. 12 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 1 Jesse Mendez (OSU)

Things began to open up scoring wise at 141 pounds. Jesse Mendez, one of the favorites for the Hodge Trophy, completely outmatched Braeden Davis.

Mendez utilized a first-period takedown to get things started. An early escape in the second period put the Buckeye up 4-0. A second takedown, followed by three-nearfall points put Davis into a hole.

Davis couldn’t control the overpowering Mendez who notched a final takedown in the third period to get the 18-2 tech fall.

Penn State leads 6-5.

149 pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. Brogan Fielding (OSU)

What was expected to be a top-10 matchup between Shayne Van Ness and No. 6 Ethan Stiles didn’t happen. Stiles didn’t wrestle and Van Ness took advantage of a backup wrestler in Brogan Fielding, who wrestled up a weight class.

The Nittany Lion led 3-0 with over a minute of riding time after the first period, before finding more offense in the second frame. Three takedowns and an escape put the top-ranked wrestler up 13-3 after the second period.

He capitalized on multiple stalling calls, and finished off Fielding with a takedown to win by tech fall, 20-5 at the 6:17 mark.

Penn State’s lead extended to 11-5.

157 pounds: No. 4 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Daxton Chase (OSU)

PJ Duke also faced a wrestler who wrestled up a weight class. No. 1 Brandon Cannon remained out of the lineup for Ohio State, and just like Van Ness, Duke took advantage.

The freshman showcased his offensive repertoire, taking down Daxton Chase five times in the opening period. Duke added another takedown and before taking down Chase a seventh time, grabbed his arms and put him on his back. Duke’s pinfall gave Penn State a 17-5 lead heading into the intermission.

165 pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. No. 16 Paddy Gallagher (OSU)

Mitchell Mesenbrink continued his dominant season with his match against Paddy Gallagher. It was all Mesenbrink in the opening period, as two stall calls and one takedown gave him a 4-0 lead with 2:47 in riding time.

Mesenbrink escaped Gallagher and notched another takedown in the second period to extend his lead. He added a third takedown in the third period and despite pushing for a tech fall, had to settle with a major decision with a 12-2 victory.

Mesenbrink’s victory extended Penn State’s lead to 21-5.

174 pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. T.J. Schierl (OSU)

Levi Haines took on an unranked wrestler in T.J. Schierl after Carson Kharchla was announced as the starter prior to the dual.

Haines held an 8-1 lead after one period with over two minutes of riding time, dominating Schierl. He continued that dominance into the second period, pushing for a fall. After a lengthy time holding Schierl on his back, the Buckeye returned to his stomach and the whistle blew.

Haines’ four-nearfall points sealed the 16-1 tech fall, giving the Nittany Lions a 26-5 lead.

184 pounds: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 8 Dylan Fishback (OSU)

Rocco Welsh faced his former team for the first time in his career after transferring to Penn State in the offseason.

Dylan Fishback secured the first takedown of the match and held over a minute of riding time before leading 4-0 after his second-period escape. Welsh pushed for points following that, but couldn’t find success until the third period.

After escaping Fishback’s grasp, he notched his first takedown to knot things up at 4-4. Welsh released the Buckeye, giving Fishback the 5-4 lead before taking him down with under 30 seconds to go.

The Nittany Lion rode out Fishback and took the 7-6 decision over his former teammate.

Penn State’s lead pushed to 29-5.

197 pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 10 Luke Geog (OSU)

Josh Barr continued to prove he’s in a tier of his own at 197 pounds.

An early takedown gave him the lead and he never looked back. He added a takedown in the second period to extend his lead to 7-0, still holding his shutout.

A third-period takedown sealed things, earning yet another top-10 win with an 11-2 major decision victory.

Penn State extended its lead, 33-5.

285 pounds: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. No. 3 Nick Feldman (OSU)

A rematch of last season’s heavyweight matchup during Penn State and Ohio State’s dual, Cole Mirasola faced Nick Feldman, this time as the starter.

That result was a 10-3 decision in Feldman’s favor, holding a significant size advantage on the smaller Mirasola.

This year’s edition saw a much closer bout. With 1:30 remaining on the clock, the match sat at 1-1, with Mirasola coming close to a takedown on multiple attempts.

The heavyweights went to sudden victory before Mirasola finished on a takedown attempt, avenging his loss from last season to end the dual on a high note for the Nittany Lions with a 4-1 sudden-victory win.

Penn State took the dual with a dominant 36-5 victory.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State breaks NCAA wrestling indoor attendance record at Bryce Jordan Center
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State broke the NCAA wrestling indoor attendance record at its second Bryce Jordan Center dual of the calendar year. The highly anticipated matchup against No. 2 Ohio State sold out the venue with 16,006 fans in attendance.

Among those watching the dual includes Penn State football coach Matt Campbell, UFC fighter Bo Nickal and members of the 2016 national championship team.

The Bryce Jordan Center also hosted the previous record crowd with 15,998 fans for a dual against Iowa on Feb. 12, 2018. Before that, Penn State’s dual against Pitt in 2013 held it with 15,996 fans.

The all-time attendance record for NCAA wrestling is held by the Iowa Hawkeyes during their dual at Kinnick Stadium, their football stadium, on Nov. 14, 2015, which had 42,287 people in attendance.

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey suffers first loss on home ice, falls to RIT in overtime
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey returned to Pegula Ice Arena for its final regular-season series against RIT, squaring off in Game 1 at 6 p.m. Friday.

The Nittany Lions’s perfect record on home ice fell as RIT rallied to defeat Penn State, 3-2, in overtime. Penn State falls to 28-5 on the season and 21-2 in the AHA.

Penn State played with a noticeably smaller roster than usual, with Tessa Janecke, Matilde Fantin and Nicole Hall representing their respective nations in the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games. Mya Vaslet was also scratched for her second-straight game, prompting coach Jeff Kampersal to move Danica Maynard from defense to left-wing.

“We had a distracted vibe tonight with some of our teammates playing games in Italy,” Kampersal said. “We weren't necessarily locked in.”

The length of the first period flew by with limited scoring opportunities on both ends of the ice. Although the majority of the possession time was spent in RIT’s zone, the Tigers’ defensive unit controlled the netfront presence. On the other hand, Penn State was highly successful on the breakout and made key blocks to protect goaltender Katie DeSa.

The Nittany Lions were awarded their first power play with 13:12 remaining in the period. While Taylor Lum entered the zone with the puck along the wall, Addie Alvarez delivered a crushing body check, which resulted in a minor penalty.

However, the power play was unsuccessful as the Tigers routinely shut down all of Penn State’s advancements.

The Nittany Lions’ best opportunity of the period came with only 29 seconds remaining in the frame. Grace Outwater blazed through the neutral zone on a 2-on-1, dishing a pass to Maddy Christian, who fired a shot that goaltender Brenna McNamara saved with the shaft of her stick.

All it took was a small amount of “puck luck” for Penn State to break the ice early in the second period.

Christian received a pass from Danica Maynard before taking it behind McNamara’s crease. The Elk River, Minnesota, native performed a wraparound maneuver and tucked the puck between the short-side post and the goalie’s skate to take a 1-0 lead with 16:17 remaining in the second period.

But the Tigers pounced quickly to tie the game just under four minutes later. Madison Buziak fired a shot from the blue line that bounced off a defender, splashing into the top corner of the net over DeSa’s glove.

Katelyn Roberts was sentenced to two minutes in the penalty box for interference, and Penn State’s first penalty kill of the evening didn’t go according to plan. The Nittany Lions failed to clear the zone, and Ireland Stein tapped in the loose puck past DeSa to take a 2-1 lead with 8:48 remaining.

“We need to handle adversity and stay out of the box,” Kampersal said. “Because that's in our losses. We're getting killed taking penalties and teams already make us pay. We haven't learned that lesson.”

Penn State’s second power play of the game, resulting from an interference call on Tilli Keranen, was unsuccessful as the Nittany Lions were unable to generate offense.

However, Roberts avenged RIT’s previous power-play goal by netting one of her own. She took the puck from the top of the right face-off circle and sniped the top-right corner of the net to even the tides, 2-2.

To kick off the third period, Zoe Ziotas received an interior feed for a short breakaway on DeSa. She deked to the right of the goalie but was stopped on the doorstep to keep the score tied.

DeSa continued to shine when Leah Stecker took a cross-checking penalty with 15:57 remaining in regulation, making a series of desperation saves. Meanwhile, Abby Stonehouse had a shorthanded breakaway but came up empty.

Penn State went back on the penalty kill, as Outwater was handed a minor penalty for elbowing, but the blue and white dominated time-on-attack despite playing 5-on-4.

The Nittany Lions spent the remaining regulation time on offense, pressing deep into RIT’s zone. After a series of scoring chances, the buzzer sounded and the teams entered a 3-on-3 overtime frame.

Although Penn State controlled possession for the majority of the frame, Cassandra Barnes dealt the finishing blow, ripping a shot under DeSa’s glove to hand the blue and white its first home defeat.

“I'm assuming our seniors will take care of it,” Kampersal said. “I gave it to them pretty good at the end of the game, but they know that I don't play and hopefully they'll take care of it.”

Injury Report

Vaslet wasn’t listed to dress due to an undisclosed injury.

Up Next

Penn State returns to Pegula Ice Arena to close out its regular season with Game 2 against RIT at 2 p.m. Saturday.

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Penn State men's hockey's Jackson Smith breaks single-season record for goals by defenseman
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
There's a new record holder at Penn State.

Nittany Lions defenseman Jackson Smith broke the single-season record for the most goals by a blueliner in school history, scoring his ninth on Friday against No. 2 Michigan.

Your NEW Penn State single-season record holder for goals by a defensemen, Jackson Smith!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/g1y5eqpfdy— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) February 13, 2026

Before Smith broke the record, there was a four-way tie between former Penn State defensemen Vince Pedrie, who scored eight goals twice, Cole Hults, Luke Juha and Kris Myllari. The record was held for 10 years before Smith surpassed the feat.

Smith still has seven regular-season games to add to it, with likely many more postseason contests to play as well.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Fire department responds to reported "smoke" in Sparks, confirms false alarm
author: Mia Debelevich | News Editor
description:
An individual called University Police and Public Safety (UPPS) and reported smoke coming from a vent on the ground floor of the Sparks Building on Friday afternoon, a chief from Alpha Fire Department said.

The fire department was then dispatched to the building and told the Collegian it was a false alarm.

Penn State’s Office of Physical Plant told The Daily Collegian the incident was steam-related, and no one was harmed. Students are safe to enter the building.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS COVERAGE

title: Tessa Janecke, Team USA shutout Matilde Fantin, Team Italy in quarterfinals at 2026 Winter Olympics
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
The quarterfinals of the 2026 Winter Olympics started off with a low-scoring game between Team Sweden and Team Czechia. The two Nittany Lions, Nicole Hall and Jessica Adolffson, advanced to the semifinals as they continued to represent Penn State.

Focus quickly shifted over to the two remaining Penn Staters, Tessa Janecke and Matilde Fantin, as Team USA faced the host country, Team Italy. Janecke, representing Team USA, contributed to the Stars and Stripes’ dominance throughout the preliminary round as it entered the game undefeated through four games.

For Fantin and Italy, it has been the opposite. Italy entered the quarterfinal game against the USA with a record of 2-2. However, Fantin has made a name for herself by scoring three goals in her four games.

The Americans spent nearly the entire game in their attacking zone, leading to a 6-0 shutout victory over Team Italy.

The opening 10 minutes started as some would expect, with a dominant USA offense against a struggling Italy team. Gabriella Durante had to stand on her head as she was bombarded with continuous shots.

That was until Megan Keller broke the ice for the USA. Following a faceoff win in the offensive zone, Laila Edwards sent a pass over to Keller that was blasted to the back of the net in an instant.

A one-sided opening period came to a close after a sprawling stick save from Durante robbed Abbey Murphy with under 20 seconds to go. USA poured on 20 total shots in the first period, only finding the net once.

Team USA got its next two goals of the game off the stick of Kendall Coyne. The four-time Olympian found herself in the right spot at the right time on back-to-back goals.

Edwards soon followed with a goal of her own after a swift wrist shot from the high slot beat the right shoulder of Durante. Immediate “USA” chants filled the arena following the fourth goal of the game.

The Americans were not done scoring. This time on the penalty kill, Britta Curl found the loose puck and scored on a wrap-around attempt. Italy followed this goal with its first shot on net in the period with seven minutes left on the clock.

Fantin had one of Italy’s best scoring chances of the period as she found herself behind the defense. The Como, Italy, native’s quick wrist shot was denied by the right pad of Gwyneth Philips.

The middle frame came to a close after a post-whistle scuffle between the teams ensued following a Hannah Bilka goal with over a minute and a half left. The Americans went into the final intermission ahead of Italy 6-0.

It was all said and done heading into the third period. USA continued to suffocate Italy in its defensive zone, leading to a late power play for the Americans.

Although Janecke was held off the scoresheet, the Orangeville, Illinois, native contributed to the offensive attack, totaling four shots by the end of the game. As with the first 40 minutes, the remaining 20 were spent in the attacking zone for USA as it added to its shot total.

By the final buzzer, the Americans tallied 51 shots to Italy’s 6 in a dominant display of offense heading into the semifinals.

Up Next

Janecke will meet fellow Nittany Lions Hall and Adolffson in the semifinals, as Team USA plays Team Sweden. No matter the outcome, a Penn Stater will play for a gold medal with their respective country.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field continues record-setting weekend with Nick Sloff's 3000m
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another race, another record for Penn State.

Nick Sloff broke the school record in the men's 3000-meter at the David Hemery Valentine Invitational, running 7:42.68 for ninth place.

The State College, Pennsylvania native also held the former school record, which he set at the Penn Elite earlier in January with a time of 7:48.55.

The Nittany Lions have now broken three school records on Friday, just four hours into the weekend's invitationals.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: Penn State softball falls to Incarnate Word via late rally, kicks off series with loss
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a successful 4-1 opening weekend, Penn State had a chance to carry its momentum into the Houston Invitational against Incarnate Word on Friday afternoon. While the Cardinals entered the game undefeated at 7-0 and had a chance to extend their winning streak.

While the blue and white entered the seventh up three runs, Incarnate Word rallied and plated four runs in the inning to walk off the Nittany Lions 5-4.

Both squads sent out right-handed pitchers in the circle. Coach Clarisa Crowell gave the ball to junior McKenna Young, while senior Bella Mitchell faced the Nittany Lions. Both pitchers had a handful of appearances in the young season before this game and delivered quality outings.

The first inning brought little offense for either lineup. Junior Michela Barbabente singled up the middle, but Mitchell swiftly retired the next two batters. However, it wouldn’t take long for the blue and white’s bats to get going as Penn State struck in the second.

One of the early storylines in the Nittany Lions’ season is the impact of the freshmen offensively, and the narrative continued. Sophomore Natalie Lieto kicked off the inning with a hard double down the left field line, then freshman Allison Oneacre smashed a two-run home run deep over the center field wall and gave Penn State the 2-0 lead.

Though the blue and white scored no more runs in the inning, the offensive pressure didn’t stop there. Graduate student Cara Bohner walked on six pitches, and freshman Breanna Hanik also drew a one-out four-pitch walk as Mitchell seemed rattled. Following a sacrifice bunt, Barbabente had a chance at driving in both of them from second and third, but flew out to left field.

After gaining some cushion from her offense, Young ran into some trouble in the bottom half of the second. The Brodhead, Wisconsin, native walked leadoff Bryanna Fuentes on four pitches, and while she forced a groundout to shortstop Kaylie Walters, Dominique Guerra still reached first. With two outs, Carmen Uribe found a gap in left center, but Young struck out Aynsli Lawson with a runner in scoring position to end the inning.

It was the Oneacre game as she made more damage in the third. With the heart of Penn State’s lineup due up, Incarnate Word brought in right-handed senior Sam Portillo in for relief. Lieto reached base on a fielder’s choice, then advanced to second on a wild pitch.

With one home run already under her belt, Oneacre stepped in with more on her mind. The Alpharetta, Georgia, native blasted another two-run home run deep into left field, making the blue and white’s lead 4-0. The top recruit of Penn State’s 2025 class has shown early why she was ranked so high out of high school, with three homers already credited to her name.

While the Nittany Lions extended their lead in the top half of the third, the Cardinals got on the board in their half of the inning. Young walked Ayla Gonzales on five pitches, and with her team down four runs, she was aggressive and stole second. While Young struck out the next batter, she lost control and hit Jaisy Caceres.

Cleanup hitter Fuentes delivered with two outs and singled to right center, driving in Gonzales and bringing the Cardinals closer, 4-1. After Fuentes stole second, Young locked in and struck out Dominique to strand the runners in scoring position.

The blue and white were aggressive on the base paths in the fourth and had an opportunity to add more runs, but cleanup Brooke Klosowicz flew out to center and left Kirsten Finarelli stranded on second.

Crowell turned to her bullpen again and brought in freshman Mackenzie Duncan for the bottom half of the fourth. The Winter Garden, Florida, native ran into a small jam after she walked a few batters, but got Victoria Altamirano to fly out to Lieto in center.

The Nittany Lions flashed some glove and kept Incarnate Word from scoring in the bottom of the sixth. After Duncan hit the leadoff batter, Prisais Quintero smacked a double to the left-center gap, but Lieto quickly rallied the ball to Walters at shortstop, who then threw out pinch runner Guerra at home. Prisas made it to third off the sequence, but sophomore Abigail Britton mowed down the next two Cardinals.

Sophomore Jenny Robledo shut down the blue and white’s bats over three innings, totaling two strikeouts and surrendering just one hit. While Penn State was quiet on offense, Incarnate Word made it a game in the seventh.

Gonzales started the rally with a leadoff single down the left field line, and Altamarino came up clutch and launched a two-run home run into deep center. With the lead now at just one run, Crowell turned to her most reliable arm, junior Bridget Nemeth. However, she couldn’t stop the bleeding and Sydney Zenon hit a rocket into left field and tied the game at four.

The game was quickly unraveling for Penn State as Caceres doubled to left-center. The Cardinals now had the game-winning run on second with no outs after entering the last inning down three. With the game on the line, Crowell brought Young back in hopes of extending the game to extras.

However, Fuentes singled to center, which advanced Caceres to third and she was brought home for the game-winning run off a sacrifice fly, leading to a 5-4 loss for the Nittany Lions.

Up Next

Penn State looks to bounce back against Houston for the second game of its doubleheader at 7 p.m. on Friday.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State track and field's Jake Palermo breaks 400m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A Penn State track weekend calls for several broken school records.

The Nittany Lions earned their second school record of the weekend after Jake Palermo ran 45.33 in the 400 meters at the Tyson Invite.

Palermo broke his former school record of 45.65, which he set in his second collegiate race last year.

Earlier Friday, graduate student Allon Clay broke the 1,000-meter record for Penn State at the David Hemery Valentine Invitational, running 2:17.29.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball faces Oregon on Valentine's Day with chance to create loveable results
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State faces practically its greatest opportunity of the season on Valentine's Day, when the Nittany Lions get a chance to finally form results on their schedule that they could maybe say they love on its second-ever Big Ten West Coast road trip.

The blue and white found success on their first-ever trip to Washington. On the same day Seattle hosted the Super Bowl parade, Penn State marched to a late-game win, its second conference win of the year in spectacular fashion.

Now, Penn State hits the Oregon trail to face the Ducks in Eugene for the first time, and the outlook for the contest looks mixed, with little positive narratives entering, but still huge implications when both teams leave.

Finding gold on the west, falters on the fault line

The sunny skies of the Golden Coast have cast their rays in the new era of westward Big Ten expansion, as squads expand into new horizons, but for others, the lights have been too bright.

Last season, the first year that former Pac-12 units appeared on the Nittany Lions’ Big Ten schedule, the blue and white dropped both of its games on the West Coast against UCLA and USC – both teams that beat it in Happy Valley this season.

In 2024-25, Penn State also fell to Washington. While it redeemed itself on that front this season, with the win in this year’s edition of the clash with the Huskies marking its first against those new conference teams, the second rendition of the Oregon game appears to continue that trend.

Host Oregon hasn’t had a good season; this time last year, it’d just fallen out of the AP Poll before eventually navigating back a month later, and if it endured that fate this year, that would’ve been comparatively tame to the struggles it's endured on the hardwood.

This season’s Ducks are the lone squad currently with only one conference win after the Nittany Lions recently dumped them to be alone in that group. It gets even worse – Oregon is also the lone squad not to post a home or neutral-site Big Ten win, bad news for the Ducks, as a rejuvenated blue and white squad arrives in town.

On the contrary, Oregon needs to get its ducks in a row, with ten straight losses, the worst streak in the Big Ten, the scenery has been anything but verdant in the Evergreen State, as every result axed all growth it's attempted. The lone game among that stretch to be decided by one possession was the first of the streak, which was also their first game of the new year.

Misery loves company, and the Ducks can at least share criticism with a team like Rutgers, which is the only other Big Ten unit that hasn’t yet courted a Quad 1 win.

While the narratives entering Eugene surely benefit Penn State, it still faces only a one-in-four chance of winning, according to ESPN.

Injuries, player personnel, analytics

Oregon arrives in this game extremely banged up, and it doesn’t look like it will get any better; most of the four players listed as available in its last game against Indiana have been confirmed as likely to miss extended time. The lone one not to have any status to be confirmed, Miles Johnson, hasn’t appeared all season.

Headlining the unit of absences for the Ducks is Jackson Shelstad. The junior averaged over 15 points, four assists and a steal per game through his 12 appearances, having not appeared since 2025.

While the Ducks won’t have their flashy guard, they’ll have their big man, as 7-footer Nate Bittle returns to Eugene for the first time in over a month after injuries nagged his season. The senior made his return to action from a foot injury two games ago, and over that pair of outings, Bittle averaged 19 points, 6.5 rebounds, four assists and 34 minutes.

The veteran center surely will be a problem for Penn State, as the Nittany Lions have struggled inside all season, but Bittle also brings shooting capabilities, averaging 33% from beyond the arc in his career.

Outside of that, the Ducks have other contributors also able to step up; Kwame Evans Jr. does it all, with double-digit scoring paired with team-high rebounding and a block and steal per game. While the junior forward is streaky from beyond the arc, he still has the most efficient field goal percentage among starters.

Picking up those misses from downtown is senior Takai Simpson, the last double-digit scorer on the squad, but he’s seen his own mistakes come back to bite him, as he holds the No. 2 spot in the Big Ten for the most turnovers in a single game at seven.

The blue and white is the worst in the conference at rebounding, so the Ducks beat it there. But for two squads that remain almost equal in possession stats, the glass and turnover battles remain essential for getting extra looks.

Statistician Evan Miyakawa ranks Oregon as the team with the highest Big Ten pace adjust, meaning the Ducks perform better in games with more possessions and worse in games with fewer.

The Nittany Lions appear almost fully healthy in this one, so Mike Rhoades has full tools at his disposal. The lone sidelined, Sasa Ciani, has already been reported as day-to-day, so a return is possible.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nicole Hall, Jessica Adolfsson, Team Sweden defeat Czechia in quarterfinals at 2026 Olympics
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
The quarterfinals kicked off in the 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games in women’s hockey. Penn State forward Nicole Hall and former defenseman Jessica Adolfsson qualified for the quarterfinals with Team Sweden from Group B to take on Czechia out of Group A in the first round.

The Swedes held off a late comeback effort from Czechia, advancing to the semifinals with a 2-0 score.

Sweden was undefeated in preliminary play and led the second group, while Czechia finished third in Group A, but automatically qualified as a member of the top group.

The matchup was about as even as the international rankings showed. Czechia entered the Olympic Games as the No. 4 team in the world, while Sweden was just below at No. 6.

However, the Swedes finished the 2022 Olympic Games in eighth place, with an opportunity to improve on that finish.

The battle was back-and-forth for most of the first period. Neither team could find the back of the net, with Czechia’s Klara Peslarova shutting down any attempt from Sweden. On the other side, Ebba Svensson Traff was dominant in net, giving the offense an opportunity to thrive.

The shots in the first period were knotted at six, with neither team finding offensive momentum. The second period gave the first opportunity to the Swedes. While on a power play, Hanna Olsson found a wide-open net and broke the ice with a man-advantage goal.

Olsson’s goal was assisted by Hilda Svensson and Maja Nylen Persson just 4:47 into the second period.

Czechia attempted to get the goal back, but four penalties in the middle frame ended any chance before the third period.

The third period saw more of the same, with neither team having any momentum. Halfway through the frame, it appeared Sweden doubled its lead. However, the goal was immediately waved off, and in turn was a penalty on the Swedes.

It was Czechia’s greatest opportunity, and the unit fired shot after shot at the net. Some of them made it to the net, while a majority were blocked by the penalty-kill unit of the Swedes.

Another penalty came just minutes later, but once again, Sweden shut down the power play and maintained its 1-0 lead. After another great set of defensive plays, Svensson found herself fending off the defense with an empty net. The Ohio State product back-handed the puck into the net, giving the Swedes a 2-0 lead.

It was all she wrote from there, as Sweden fended off any last effort from Czechia, winning 2-0 and advancing to the semifinals. The Swedes are guaranteed to play for a medal no matter the result of their next game.

For the Penn State players, Adolfsson totaled 19:16 of ice time, finishing as a plus-1 on the game. As a fourth-line player, Hall saw minimal action, playing just under four minutes of game time. Despite this, the Nittany Lion duo will have a chance to continue the rise of Swedish women’s hockey in the Olympics.

Up Next

Sweden will play the winner of Team USA and Team Italy in the semifinals. No matter the winner, the two Penn Staters will take on a fellow Penn State player, with Tessa Janecke on Team USA and Matilde Fantin on Team Italy.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Allon Clay breaks 1000m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Allon Clay is climbing the Penn State history books.

Clay broke the 1,000-meter school record at the David Hemery Valentine Invitational, running a time of 2:17.29 to win the race.

The Fujisawa, Kanagawa, Japan, native previously held the record of 2:18.09 from his performance at the Nittany Lion Challenge earlier this year, where several Nittany Lions ran the top-10 fastest times in NCAA history.

Clay's mark of 2:17.29 ranks second in NCAA history behind Tinoda Matsatsa of Georgetown, who ran 2:16.84 last year.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: No. 1 Penn State wrestling faces No. 2 Ohio State in a matchup of undefeated teams
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State will host their biggest dual meet of the season at 7 p.m. on Friday at the Bryce Jordan Center against No. 2 Ohio State.

The Big Ten slate comes to a close with a test between two undefeated programs vying for the number one position in the country. While the Nittany Lions hold the talent edge throughout the lineup, the construction of a front-heavy Buckeyes’ squad could put some pressure on Penn State if they come away with some bonus points between 125 and 141 pounds.

Here’s how the nation's two best teams stack up.

125: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 2 Nic Bouzakis (OSU)

The opening bout will be the most anticipated of the dual. While Intermat ranks Luke Lilledahl No.1, the coaches poll has Bouzakis at the top of the class.

Both of these wrestlers have a lot in common, going back to their high school alma mater Wyoming Seminary. They both also have only lost to teammates this season, which do not count as officially NCAA losses.

Both wrestlers sit above a 60% bonus rate, with Bouzakis having three pins to his name compared to Lilledahl’s one in 2025-26.

Bouzakis will have the strength advantage after dropping down from 133 pounds, but Lilledahl has the speed to counter that. The match will be fast paced as both are known for coming out of the gate hot in big matches.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 2 Ben Davino (OSU)

Marcus Blaze and Ben Davino are very familiar with each other entering this top-five clash. These two have wrestled five times since 2016, with Blaze taking the three most recent matches. To add to the drama, Davino is the last wrestler to have defeated Blaze in folkstyle wrestling back in 2023.

Both men enter the bout undefeated. Blaze has more impressive numbers on the season, with an 88% bonus rate, while Davino has an extra year of college experience under his belt. This is the biggest coin flip of the dual.

141: No. 12 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 1 Jesse Mendez (OSU)

Jesse Mendez is the defending national champion and has been a machine at 141 pounds, making a deep weight class look shallow by scoring bonus points in 15 of his 17 bouts.

Braeden Davis’ style this season of being overly aggressive cost him in his bout against Nebraska’s Brock Hardy, resulting in a pin and a misconduct point deduction for Penn State. Coming off of a skin issue, per Cael Sanderson, Davis will have to rethink his strategy to avoid gassing out against Mendez and not allow him to steal some extra points for the Buckeyes.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 6 Ethan Stiles (OSU)

Shayne Van Ness pinned Ethan Stiles in the consolation semifinals of last season’s NCAA National Championships. Since then, Van Ness hasn’t lost a match.

For Stiles, his highest-ranked opponent on the season, Cornell’s Jaxon Joy, pinned him. Stiles has shown a unique ground style that may slow down Van Ness’ rapid scoring, but he is unlikely to secure many points against the Nittany Lion.

157: No. 4 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Landon Desselle (OSU)

The 157-pound matchup was expected to be a top-five bout, but with No. 1 Brandon Cannon out with injury, PJ Duke gets an easier night inside the Bryce Jordan Center.

Desselle is 6-5 on the year and hasn’t shown any indication that he could challenge Duke on the big stage. This match is a bonus-point opportunity for Penn State.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. No. 16 Paddy Gallagher (OSU)

Countering Mendez for the Nittany Lions is their tech-fall machine Mitchell Mesenbrink.

Last season, Paddy Gallagher was scheduled to face Mesenbrink in the quarterfinals of the Big Ten tournament. However, he injury defaulted before continuing through the consolation bracket.

Mesenbrink has scored bonus points for Penn State in all 17 matches he has competed in this season. With Gallagher previously falling to Iowa’s Michael Caliendo during a rockier season, there is no indication that Mesenbrink’s streak is at risk of falling on Friday.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. No. 5 Carson Kharchla (OSU)

At 174 pounds, it sees an interesting style matchup between Levi Haines and Carson Kharchla. Watching these two compete separately, they both run a similar style on the mat.

Haines has only had three matches this season end in a decision, while Kharchla lacks momentum after a loss to Iowa’s Patrick Kennedy.

Haines defeated Kharchla 6-4 last season, but Kharchla secured the first takedown. The nature of the similar styles and slower pace in these bigger matchups means this will likely be a close, low-scoring affair.

184: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 8 Dylan Fishback (OSU)

This bout will have Rocco Welsh see his old team, as he left the Buckeyes to come to Happy Valley over the offseason. Since leaving Columbus, Welsh’s bet on himself has paid off. He rose to be the No. 1 wrestler in the 184-pound weight class.

Dylan Fishback came to the Buckeyes from NC State after Welsh’s departure and has been a steady hand in the scarlett and gray’s lineup. He has four losses on the year, but three of them occurred in sudden victory. It is unlikely he’ll let Welsh drag him down easily. Expect a close decision at 184.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 10 Luke Geog (OSU)

On paper, this looks like an easy win for Josh Barr, but Luke Geog has been on a recent tear with three straight major decisions entering the Bryce Jordan Center. However, Geog’s track record of losses places him in a tier below the top of 197 pounds.

Barr is the top of the weight class, with a 100% bonus rate since returning from injury. This bout will be an opportunity for Penn State to shut down the Buckeyes’ chances of pulling off the major upset.

285: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. No. 3 Nick Feldman (OSU)

Cole Mirasola has had multiple chances to face the upper class and larger wrestlers in the heavyweight division, from Iowa’s Ben Kueter to Nebraska’s AJ Ferrari. Friday he gets another opportunity against Nick Feldman.

Feldman has two signature wins over Ferrari this season after entering the campaign as a national title contender. The Buckeye also defeated Mirasola 10-3 in a matchup last season. This bout should be closer with more matches under Mirasola’s belt and should be as boring of a heavyweight match as can be expected in the Big Ten with the aggressive styles both men carry.

If the dual somehow comes down to the heavyweight bout, Penn State fans will be sweating this matchup closing the meet.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Setting the tone in style | Penn State professors describe outfit choices
author: Brennan Kramp I The Daily Collegian
description:
Whether it’s a suit and tie, a cardigan or a band T-shirt, you never know what kind of outfit you’ll get from your professor on any given day. Sometimes professors dress for authority, sometimes for comfort and other times to send a message. At Penn State, there’s no one specific philosophy on styling up for a lecture, but there are certainly fitting points.

Patrick Higgins, a finance professor, said he wants to express his level of effort and work ethic through the clothing he wears.

“A casual dress code can create a casual culture and could introduce some sloppiness,” Higgins, a finance professor at Smeal, said. “I take my job seriously, and I’m communicating that by the way I dress.”

Jan Reimann, a mathematics professor, has a much more laid back approach to his outfit choices, and said keeping it casual makes things go a little bit smoother between the student-teacher relationship.

“I’m a person of authority by position, but I want [the students] to feel like I take this seriously, but I don’t want them to be intimidated,” Reimann, an associate math professor said. “I don’t try to dress up for classes … but, for example, I would not wear shorts and flip-flops to class.”

Now, not everyone has to be in a classroom to attend class. Penn State’s World Campus has the second highest attendance rate among all other campuses, just behind University Park. However, this does mean the parameters on dress codes is quite a gray area.

World Campus Professor Joshua Winskowski said his previous experience teaching high school in China helped him define his professional attire going into his first year as a collegiate professor.

“Most of the other teachers over there didn’t do that, they just dressed more casually,” Winskowski, a professor of world literature, said. “I found that presenting myself in a very formal way … could allow me to be relaxed and joke around and be playful, but people would still take me seriously.”

He said getting the feel of the classroom and the students can be a great indicator of how to either dress up or down.

“If I thought it would help facilitate the class, I would dress more formally,” Winskowski said. “And if I thought dressing more casually would facilitate a better class, I would do that.”

While dress can sometimes have an effect, oftentimes it means very little to students. One professor can wear a pressed shirt and a bowtie without ever harvesting an intellectual environment and another can show up in jeans and a sweater pulled from the bottom set of a hand-me-down box their mom found and have every single eye locked on them.

“When I teach my first class, I’ll probably go in with a button up and the tie, get the feel of the room and then I’ll decide whether I want to keep doing that or whether we can just chill,” Winskowski said. “If no one’s paying any attention to what I’m wearing, then I’m not going to waste my time worrying about it.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTET

title: The most popular guilty pleasure | Why reality game shows thrive
author: Skylar Williamson I The Daily Collegian
description:
Every year, a new reality TV show takes over social media feeds and group chats. People start to create parasocial bonds with characters, live through their lives and sit on the edges of their seats each week while waiting for a new episode.

While scripted dramas and comedies cycle in and out of popularity, competition-based reality shows continue to draw loyal audiences season after season.

Reality game shows grew in popularity during the early 2000s with programs like “Big Brother,” a competition show where houseguests are put into a secluded, monitored house and participate in different games to avoid elimination, with one person winning the entire show.

Whether it’s cooking, fashion, dancing or love-based, reality game shows are framed around competition, elimination and prizes mixed with drama and suspense, unlike traditional reality shows, which are completely based on drama.

According to Matthew Jordan, reality TV has sustained popularity for a long time due to a few different reasons.

“They are cheap to produce, so they require little money for writers and actors,” Jordan, the Department head of Film Production and Media Studies, said. “They also tend to cast characters who are sensational or outrageous, so they attract people who enjoy watching train wrecks.”

In film production, budget is the most important aspect of creating new shows, so there is a lot more investment being put into reality television as a genre of film. Networks and streamers like Peacock are trying to find cost-effective ways to expand their libraries.

Cory Baker, who teaches a class on reality television this semester, said reality TV has been a positive solution to budgeting issues — especially for streaming services — over the last 40 years in American TV.

“The streamers in particular spent so much money trying to build out scripted franchises when launching their platforms between 2019 and 2021, and there’s some spender’s remorse there,” Baker, an assistant professor in media studies, said. “I think the executives look at the success of library titles like ‘Survivor’ on Paramount+, or the growth of ‘Love island’ across multiple platforms, and realize audiences still love reality TV from wherever they’re accessing it.”

Jordan said the idea of a reality show being a competition attracts viewers itself, with the “vote off” format many adopt helping to create a sense of suspense week to week for the audience.

Danielle DiLorenzo said all summer, she waited for the new episode of “Love Island USA” to air every night.

“The fact that it came on most weeknights in the summer gave me something to look forward to, and I don’t think I ever missed an episode,” DiLorenzo, a first-year studying finance, said. “After every episode, I made predictions about what was going to happen the day next and repeated this cycle all the time.”

The big question of reality television as a whole is what is real, and what isn’t. The unknown is often another reason why viewers are infatuated with the genre, but also why they might hate it.

Baker and Jordan both said creating a live show using “real” people, rather than completely scripted actors, gives audiences a connection to the show.

“Contemporary audiences know that they’re not seeing a one-to-one replication of what happened on the island or in the house because the show has been shaped and produced by hundreds of people,” Baker said. “But there’s a real pleasure in navigating that continuum of reality.”

Baker also said each show is different, and sometimes the less “real” and more outrageous a show is, the better. In other contexts, the more a show feels like a documentary might be better for other audiences.

Angeline Korompis said one appealing trait of reality game shows is that they’re fun to watch.

“It’s pure entertainment,” Korompis, a first-year studying marketing, said. “I like when a show is so insane that I can’t take my eyes off of the screen, even if I know it’s not completely real.”

With the help of social media platforms, like TikTok, reality game shows will remain popular with younger generations. The blend of strategy, suspense, social psychology — and a couple attractive contestants — is the perfect mix for people’s pleasure.

Even as television evolves, the basic appeal of competition remains constant. As long as audiences enjoy watching the drama of it all, reality game shows will continue to dominate the screens.

“They’re always popular with millions of people because they offer a great mix of predictability and unpredictability,” Baker said. “All it takes is one really great game structure or a couple of great casting decisions for a reality TV series to take audiences by storm.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Review | Worth the wait: Bill Pickle’s Tap Room burgers are here
author: Veronica Figg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Bill Pickle’s Tap Room finally released their highly anticipated burgers. The bar at 106 S Allen St announced the news last week on their Instagram.

I was excited to try them out, along with a few other new menu items that they had debuted. I started off with some of the new appetizers: Bill's Fried Pickles and Saucy Tenders.

Bill’s Fried Pickles

The fried pickles were a new addition to their daytime menu. They were fried in a crispy batter and served with their house made “Jawn Jawn” sauce. To my delight, the sauce was dairy-free.

The highlight of this dish for me wasn’t the entree, but the sauce. It was creamy with just the right amount of tang.

The breading unfortunately overpowered the pickles due to their usually strong taste being subdued by the doughy breading which was greasy, but thankfully not enough to be soggy. However, the sauce brought enough flavor to the dish for me to enjoy it.

Rating: 5/10

Chicken Tenders with Sweet and Spicy Thai Sauce

I love chicken tenders, but this dish was not it. The sauce was a nice blend, being sweet with an aftertaste of sharp heat, but it overwhelmed the chicken to where I couldn’t taste it at all.

The breading was crunchy, but too thick. When paired with the sauce, it made the chicken underneath disappear, and made for an unpleasant eating experience.

Rating: 3/10

The Billy G.O.A.T

The highly-anticipated burgers did not disappoint. I believe there are no words to describe how good The Billy G.O.A.T burger was, but as your food reporter I must try.

The Billy G.O.A.T burger comes with two beef smash patties, caramelized onions, smoked gouda, “Jawn Jawn” sauce, lettuce and tomato, although I removed the gouda from my burger.

I felt like this burger perfectly describes the word umami — a savory taste that stays with you long after your last bite. This burger was so juicy and not greasy at all, and the “Jawn Jawn” sauce elevated this dish immensely.

The sauce had a spicy kick that hadn’t come out as much with the fried pickles, but paired well with the crunchy lettuce that added a needed texture to the soft burger. The tomato was refreshing on the burger patties, and while I couldn’t taste the caramelized onions, it was still delicious.

Rating: 10/10

The Bucking Burger

Bill Pickle’s Tap Room is known for their BBQ and they definitely deliver with this burger. The Bucking Burger comes with one BBQ smash patty, pulled pork shoulder, pepper jack, caramelized onions, spicy BBQ, onion straws and jalapeños. I removed the pepper jack on top, and they placed the jalapeños on the side.

They know how to make the perfect pulled pork, as it was juicy and just the perfect amount of spicy with the BBQ sauce. The patty and pulled pork made for an umami moment, with the juiciness of both creating a great savory flavor combination.

The onion straws were crispy and added a crunch to the juiciness of the burger. Unlike the previous burger, you can taste the caramelized onions that were crunchy and sweet. This burger was just as delicious, and I would recommend either for a night out with friends.

Rating: 10/10

Strawberry Lemonade

All those burgers made me thirsty, so I ordered a strawberry lemonade to try. I knew this drink was superior because I don’t even really like lemonade, and I ordered two glasses of it.

I loved this drink — it was sweet and had a strong lemon flavor, which is par for the course with lemonade. The strawberry blended well, creating a drink that was so good I got a refill.

Rating:10/10

Veronica’s Food Sensitivity Corner

As a student who was recently diagnosed with a dairy sensitivity, I’m always on the lookout for foods that fit my new dietary needs. I’m also aware there are other students who may have similar needs as well.

All of Bill Pickle’s Tap Room’s smoked meats and table side sauces are gluten free. They also have gluten free buns, corn tortillas and wraps, along with a vegetarian menu which features the Birria Fried Plantain Tacos.

Birria Fried Plantain Tacos

These tacos were incredible, and came with fried plantain, al pastor seasoned sauteed onion/peppers/pineapple, pickled red onion and lime crema served with a side of vegan consume. With my order, I removed the lime crema.

The sweet plantains and crispy onions mixed together in a wonderful sweet and crunchy flavor combination, and the flour tortillas were crispy with a great crunch. There was a little bit of a kick, but the sweetness of the plantains made for a well balanced sweet and spicy bite. You can’t taste the pineapple or peppers as much, but I loved every bite.

Rating:10/10

Final Thoughts

I will definitely be returning to Bill Pickle’s Tap Room the next time my family comes to town, so they can experience the wonderful burgers themselves.

Bill Pickle’s Tap Room is open Tuesday to Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 2 a.m., Sundays from 11:30 a.m. to midnight or later and Mondays from 4 p.m. to midnight or later. So, bring your friends to rejoice in the fact that the burgers are finally here.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: No. 15 Penn State men’s lacrosse set for first road test against No. 3 Princeton
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a heartbreaking loss to No. 14 Villanova in Holuba Hall, Penn State will have a chance to bounce back on the road against Princeton on Saturday.

The No. 15 Nittany Lions suffered a 14-13 overtime loss to the Wildcats last weekend despite leading by a pair of goals late in the fourth quarter. Performances from midfielder Nick Lucchesi and attackman Colin Michener fueled the Villanova upset, combining for seven points in the matchup.

Despite losing to the Wildcats for the first time since 2023, several Nittany Lions delivered strong performances. Hunter Aquino and Chase Robertson scored hat tricks, and freshman attackman Jack Iannantuono put up four points to tie Aquino for the team lead.

Saturday will mark the blue and white’s third consecutive season to feature a matchup with the No. 3 Tigers, with last year’s result paralleling its defeat to Villanova. Princeton beat the Nittany Lions 11-10 in another overtime loss that was played inside Holuba Hall.

The Tigers are yet to take the field in 2026, as Saturday’s meeting with Penn State will serve as both their season and home opener.

Princeton went 13-4 last season, compiling a 5-1 record in the Ivy League. Its only losses in conference play came to eventual national champion Cornell, which beat the Tigers in both the regular season and the Ivy League tournament.

After beating Towson 22-12 in the opening round, the Tigers’ 2025 campaign came to an end in the NCAA Quarterfinals with a 19-18 loss to Syracuse.

This season, they’ve been voted as the favorite to take the Ivy League title, claiming 12 of the 14 possible Ivy League first-place votes.

Two Princeton seniors, attackman Chad Palumbo and goaltender Ryan Croddick, were named to the Tewaaraton Preseason Watchlist, with the former being selected as a preseason first-team All-American by Inside Lacrosse.

In addition to the already-named Palumbo, attackman Nate Kabiri should be a tough matchup for the Penn State defensive unit. The junior recorded 61 points and a team-high 29 assists in 2025, and is primed to improve those numbers with the departure of Princeton's all-time leading goalscorer, Coulter Mackesy.

The Tigers lead the all-time series with the Nittany Lions, holding a 4-1 record that dates back 35 years. Penn State’s lone win against Princeton came in 2023, a 13-12 victory in which TJ Malone put up a team-leading six points and midfielder Ethan Long scored five goals.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State gymnastics hosts No. 15 Minnesota in pivotal Big Ten matchup
author: Annie Gleba | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 16 Penn State returns home to Rec Hall at 2 p.m. Saturday for a Big Ten matchup with No. 15 Minnesota for the Nittany Lions’ Senior Day. This meet follows the blue and white's narrow loss to No. 11 Michigan State, 197.125-196.725.

Penn State is now 4-2 overall with a 3-1 conference record. There are two Big Ten meets remaining before the start of the tournaments. This makes Saturday’s contest an important opportunity to keep developing the Nittany Lions’ strength and scores.

Now, Penn State will have to lean on some of its more experienced upperclassmen to restart its momentum and finish out conference play on a high note. Senior leaders will be important in matches within stronger categories of both teams, like floor.

One of the Nittany Lions’ consistent top scorers is Dani Latronica. Some of the sophomores’ highest scores were a 9.9500 on the bars and a 9.9250 on the beam. She’ll be a key contributor on Saturday in keeping those categories strong for Penn State, particularly on the bars, where cleaner landings could create a separation in the scoring.

On vault, Ava Piedrahita held the top score on her team with a 9.9250. The senior brings experience that will be critical in an event that has been Penn State's lowest-scoring rotation this season.

For Penn State, the strongest performances have come on the balance beam and floor. Beam has been a stable score for the Nittany Lions, while the floor has shown strong performances. There will need to be improvements to the vault for the blue and white to achieve a higher overall score than Minnesota.

Minnesota is coming into this matchup just above Penn State, being ranked No.15. They sit with a record of 4-3 overall, being split in conference play at 2-2. They have key wins over top programs, such as No. 8 Arkansas and No. 9 Michigan.

Like Penn State, one of the Golden Gophers' best events is floor, making for tight competition. However, the Nittany Lions need to improve in the bars and beam events, creating potential scoring opportunities for the Nittany Lions.

An athlete to watch out for in Minnesota is Jordyn Lyden. The junior holds two top scores for her team, earning a 9.9250 on the bar and a 9.9500 on a floor routine. Lyden’s ability to deliver a high-performing floor routine could be a major threat to the Nittany Lions.

With both teams having similar strengths and weaknesses and the ranking difference of just one, the Senior Day meet could be one of the closest scores we’ve seen this season, potentially decided within a few tenths, allowing for very few flaws in the routines.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field’s Handal Roban is a ‘world-class’ talent
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
As Handal Roban crossed the finish line in the 800 meters at the 2025 NACAC Championships, he glanced down and saw his time: 1:42.87.

“To be honest, I thought the clock was broken at first,” Roban told The Daily Collegian. “I was just surprised.”

While Roban’s quick time marked a new personal best, it also put him at No. 2 in NCAA history, behind Oregon’s Joaquin Cruz in 1984.

“It’s pretty special, 1:42, because the only person who ran faster than (Roban) is Joaquin Cruz, who did that when he won an Olympic gold medal,” Ryan Foster, the associate head coach and distance coach, told the Collegian. “That kind of puts him in perspective talent-wise.”

Roban’s senior year success was just the cherry on top of his historic career. Right off the bat, Roban elevated his game and made himself one of the best runners in the nation.

In just his second collegiate race, Roban earned his first victory in the 600 meters with a 1:16.91. A week later, he won his first 800m in 1:47.01 at the Sykes & Sabock Invitational.

As the postseason rolled around, Roban earned a silver medal in the 800m at the Big Ten championship before finishing third at the NCAA Indoor championship. That success was echoed in the outdoor season, as he earned another bronze medal at the NCAA championship while setting the No. 4 time in school history.

“Talent-wise, he’s world-class,” Foster said. “We’ve known that for a long time, since I started coaching him.”

Entering his second season with the blue and white, Roban had high expectations following his flashy freshman year. With the help of his coaches, he started right where he left off with similar times in the 600m and 800m.

“It shows that he’s bought into what coach Foster is trying to do here with that event group,” head coach John Gondak told the Collegian. “He’s putting in the time and the effort.”

While Roban didn’t medal at either the indoor or outdoor NCAA championships in his sophomore season, he secured podium finishes at the conference championships, setting the No. 2 mark in the indoor 800m and the No. 3 mark in the outdoor 800m.

However, Roban’s biggest accomplishment in 2024 came when he represented his country, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

“It’s a pride and joy because my country is pretty small,” Roban said. “It’s just me making a name for myself and putting my country out there.”

Roban ultimately fell just short of an Olympic semifinals appearance in the 800m, but became the first Nittany Lion in school history to represent Penn State in the Olympic 800m.

“I think to see someone have the success that he’s having and is from where you’re from, I think it really opens the doors for young people to see what’s possible,” Foster said. “I know he’s super proud of who he is and where he’s from.”

As Roban entered his junior year, things didn’t go as planned during the indoor season. The 2024 Olympian missed the entirety of the 2025 indoor season due to an injury, but returned for the outdoor schedule.

“I trust the program so much that I could get back in two weeks no matter how much time I miss,” Roban said. “If I got two weeks or more, that’s enough time to run fast.”

After setting a personal best in the 1500 meters and a near personal best in the 400 meters to kick off the 2025 outdoor season, Roban climbed the ranks in the record book once again.

Roban set the No. 2 time in Penn State history at the 2025 Florida Relays as he ran 1:45.26 for second in the event.

Insert art: Penn State track and field, Roban relay

“He wants to make this a professional career for him,” Gondak said. “He’s putting himself in a great position to do that.”

While Roban’s outdoor season didn’t live up to the hype with a first-round exit in the NCAA championship, his best time of his career came soon that summer.

On Aug. 18, Roban ran the second-fastest 800m in NCAA history at the NACAC Championships in the Bahamas, recording a time of 1:42.87 while representing his home country.

“The coaches here are so supportive,” Roban said. “They encourage you to compete outside the NCAA, if it’s making a national team or representing their country. They will help as much as possible.”

Coming off his record-setting race, Roban joined an elite group of mid-distance runners at Penn State and continued to let his dominance shine.

“He’s really becoming much more from where he was as a freshman,” Gondak said. “Now he’s becoming a great leader on the team.”

In the team’s first home meet of the season, the mid-distance squad recorded four of the top-10 1,000-meter performances in NCAA history. After months of practice with the elite squad, Roban finished second in the race to set the No. 8 all-time mark in NCAA history in 2:18.72.

“Ever since we have gotten closer, it’s not even like a squad anymore,” Roban said. “It’s more like brotherhood for us.”

With half the indoor season still to come and Roban’s final outdoor season on the horizon, the senior star has a lot on his mind in his last dance.

“For me, my main goal has always been running faster than I did and being one of the best in the world,” Roban said. “Right now, I think I’m pretty close to that.”

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse looks to carry hot start to Bucknell matchup
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After two games, it's looking like Kayla Treanor was the right fit for the Penn State position, leading her team to a 2-0 record with a pair of wins.

The Nittany Lions have a chance to extend that success on Sunday, when they host Bucknell at 11 a.m. in Holuba Hall.

All-time matchups

Penn State has held Bucknell in a chokehold over the past 30 years, leading with a 22-0 all-time record.

The Nittany Lions have hosted the Bison in Happy Valley over the past three years, defeating them by an average of more than 12 goals per game. In 2024, Penn State won 22-8 in the season opener, with 11 different athletes scoring, including six goals from Nittany Lion legend Kristin O’Neill.

Bucknell has only hosted 10 of the 22 contests in its season history, but even on home turf has come away unsuccessful.

In program history, the Nittany Lions have dominated with only one shutout in 1979. Their biggest win came in 1986, when Penn State won 27-1 at Bucknell.

2026 Bucknell

Despite all-time struggles, the Bison are off to a strong start this year with a season-opening win against Youngstown State.

Bucknell came out victorious last Friday, 20-6, behind an eight-goal fourth quarter.
