After one game, senior attacker Megan Krestinski has emerged as the team’s leading point scorer for the second year in a row. Against Youngstown State, she scored three goals and recorded five assists, tallying a team-high eight points.

While the Penguins had no answer for Bucknell’s attack, junior Bella Crowley stood out in net for the Bison.

The Ridgefield, Connecticut, native recorded eight saves compared to six goals scored, posting a 57.1% save percentage.

The Bison have their home opener on Friday against UMBC before traveling to Happy Valley for Sunday’s contest.

Sunday’s matchup

Both teams appear to be high-scoring squads this season, making Sunday’s matchup an offensive showcase.

While they’ve only played one game, Bucknell scored 20 goals this season. On the other hand, the Nittany Lions average 13.5 goals per game after putting up 17 on UMass on Wednesday.

Much of the two teams’ offensive attack comes from their freshmen stars. Bucknell’s attacker Caleigh Cummiskey scored a team-high six goals against Youngstown State, while four-star attacker Rocquette Allen has scored a team-high seven goals in Penn State’s two matchups.

After a quieter, two-goal game against Richmond, Allen led Wednesday’s contest with five goals and one assist.

In addition to the young star, the Nittany Lions return last year’s leading goal-scorer, Erika Ho, who is right back to her old ways this season. While she doesn’t lead the team in goals, she’s tied with the most points, scoring four goals and recording four assists.

If both freshmen, and other supporting stars, stay as hot as they’ve been, then Sunday’s matchup will be a battle of Sydney Manning and Crowley in net, trying to limit each team’s offensive power.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Easy watches for a low-key Valentine’s Day night
author: Lexi Cannan | The Daily Collegian
description:
Valentine’s Day feels unavoidable once February hits. One minute it’s a normal week.; the next, everything is red, pink and overly romantic.

It happens fast. Couples take over your feed, restaurants fill up and someone asks about your Valentine’s Day plans. It feels like you missed a group chat you were never added to. At that point, closing Instagram feels like the right choice.

If you’re single, the move is simple. Stay in and do your own thing. No pressure to make plans or pretend you care more than you do. Put on something you’ll actually enjoy and let it just be another night.

Here are some movie picks if you’re single on Valentine’s Day and keeping it low-key.

“Legally Blonde”

This is not a love story. This is a confidence story. Elle Woods gets dumped and immediately decides to level up instead of spiraling. She goes to law school, proves everyone wrong and somehow stays positive the whole time.

Watching “Legally Blonde” when you’re single actually feels good. Elle doesn’t sit around waiting for someone else to change their mind. She focuses on herself, figures things out and keeps moving forward. That mindset hits when everyone else seems ahead.

It’s funny, comforting and weirdly makes you believe in yourself. It reminds you that getting dumped is not a personality trait and being single is not a failure, which is exactly what you want on Valentine’s Day.

“Bridesmaids”

This movie is about having your life kind of fall apart. “Bridesmaids” feels very real. Everyone is stressed, insecure and trying to keep it together. That reminder alone makes the movie worth watching.

It makes being single feel way more normal. No one in this movie has anything figured out, and that’s honestly reassuring.

It’s loud, awkward and chaotic in the best way. At the very least, it reminds you that things could always be worse — and that sometimes, laughing at the mess is the healthiest option.

“10 Things I Hate About You”

This one works if you don’t mind a rom-com and want something easy and funny. “10 Things I Hate About You” doesn’t revolve around chasing love.

Main character Kat Stratford is sarcastic, independent and very clear about not changing herself for anyone. The romance is there, but it’s not the whole point. The movie focuses more on confidence and independence.

Watching it single doesn’t feel annoying or sad. The humor carries the movie, and the characters don’t act like being in a relationship is the only thing that matters. Kat doing her own thing is honestly the best part, and it’s an easy and familiar watch.

“Anyone But You”

“Anyone But You” is a great pick if you want something popular and don’t feel like thinking too much. You can scroll, snack, miss scenes and still not be confused. Easily one of the better rom-coms being released lately.

Every scene is hilarious in its own way. You’re not watching for it to be realistic, you’re just watching to laugh and stay distracted.

Bea and Ben, played by Glen Powell and Sydney Sweeney respectively, are dramatic, stubborn and always doing the most. Watching their mess makes being single on Valentine’s Day pretty peaceful.

“Crazy, Stupid, Love”

A comfort choice if you’ve ever watched your friends give terrible relationship advice. It’ll make your dating life feel less embarrassing. Everyone in the film thinks they know what they’re doing until they don’t.

The story jumps between relationships, which keeps it interesting. Each storyline brings its own awkward moments and bad decisions that keeps things moving. By the end, all the different threads come together in a silly but satisfying way. It’s perfect if you want reassurance that you’re doing just fine.

“How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days”

The whole movie is basically two people lying their way into the worst relationship possible.

Journalist Andie is doing everything wrong on purpose to scare advertising executive Ben away. Ben stays because he’s committed to winning a bet with coworkers over the chance to represent a lucrative account. Neither of them can quit, which makes every date more ridiculous than the last.

The chaos just keeps getting worse. There’s clingy behavior, dramatic fights and fake vulnerability, while both of them think they’re winning the whole time.

It’s funny because both of them fully commit to the mess and makes being single feel like the better option.

MORE BLOGS

title: ‘I’m really privileged to be here’ | DL coach Ikaika Malloe embracing new life at Penn State
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
There’s plenty about Ikaika Malloe that’s unorthodox.

For starters, he’s a Hawaiian living in State College, and he posts “Happy Aloha Friday” on X each week. His name means “warrior,” and his coaching style focuses on beating offensive linemen at their own game.

Malloe is unlike any defensive line coach Penn State has had. Growing up in Oahu, Hawaii, and playing college football at Washington, he’s only lived on the East Coast once, so he’s just now learning about and realizing the national reach his new program has.

“In my mind, I was like, I'm hoping to just get a couple guys from the West Coast. And as I'm flying (out west), people are calling me like, ‘Make sure you stop by our school. We got a guy.’ ,” Malloe said Feb. 4. “I said, ‘Well, your guy’s committed.’ (They said) ‘I know, but he's not at Penn State.’ So the power of Penn State goes nationally, and I didn't have that respect for it at the time, and now I do.”

Malloe joined the Nittany Lions after four seasons at UCLA, serving as defensive coordinator the last two. He left the Bruins after their 0-3 start to 2025, openly admitting he felt the blame for the poor beginning should fall on him instead of DeShaun Foster, who was fired three days before his departure.

But 105 days after he and UCLA parted ways, Malloe still didn’t have a job. His former employer, D’Anton Lynn, wanted to change that. Three days after Lynn was hired to be Penn State’s defensive coordinator, he called Malloe to once again be his defensive line coach.

Lynn and Malloe only worked together for one season at UCLA in 2023, but the impression Lynn made stuck with Malloe at the time, and he was one of two key reasons the Hawaiian decided to make the cross country move.

“I had so much respect for him because of how young he was, and he was put in a role to lead, and he actually went the other way to follow,” Malloe said. “He's very humble. He walks behind the scenes. He doesn't take credit for anything. And his whole concept is, ‘can I find something to fit you?’ As opposed to, ‘I got to go find all these guys to fit me.’”

Further, Malloe felt Penn State was the right place for him because of Matt Campbell. Malloe immediately fell in love with Campbell’s message and coaching style, as it reminded him of his former boss Chris Petersen.

Petersen was the head coach at Washington for six seasons. Malloe worked under the College Football Hall of Famer as his defensive line coach for four of those years and took plenty of lessons with him, such as to embody integrity in every aspect of coaching.

But quite possibly the biggest thing Malloe learned from working with Petersen was how to build relationships with his players.

Indianapolis Colt Laiatu Latu has said on multiple occasions that he views Malloe as a father figure, following him from Washington to UCLA after the Huskies forced him to medically retire.

A few of Malloe’s other former players have expressed similar sentiments — although maybe not to the degree of Latu. It’s something he prides himself on, and it’s a promise he makes to each player he coaches.

“If you come here to Penn State, that's one thing for sure you will have is, I'm going to give you everything I've got,” Malloe said. “I want to make sure that you as a parent will respect that. I'm going to try to treat your son just like that's my own.”

Malloe is still settling into his new life in Happy Valley, but the one thing that will never change for Malloe is who he is and how he coaches. Penn State is already getting a taste of that.

“This is one of the elite, elite schools, and I'm really privileged to be here,” Malloe said. “I really am.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Meet The Daily Collegian’s 2026-27 business manager
author: Mia Debelevich | News Editor
description:
Rhea Khettry was elected as The Daily Collegian’s 2026-27 business manager during a Collegian Board of Directors meeting Thursday night.

“I’m really excited because this is something I’ve wanted since my freshman year,” Khettry, a third-year studying finance and accounting, said. “I’m glad that it all came together.”

Khettry previously served as the Collegian’s sales director.

“The biggest initiative for me is bringing the Collegian into Smeal,” she said. “There’s so many business majors who can benefit from working for the Collegian.”

Khettry said watching previous business managers has inspired her to take on the role herself.

“I’ve always been very passionate about the Collegian,” Khettry said. “I want to take initiative.”

Current business manager Amy Schafer said Khettry is one of the business division’s most consistent staff members.

“I actually pulled her aside in the fall and told her she’d be a great fit for the position,” Schafer, a fourth-year studying public relations and advertising and global and international studies, said.

Khettry has been with the Collegian since she was a freshman, which Schafer said helped prepare her for the role.

“She really cares about what she does,” Schafer said. “She’s got a lot of great ideas and she’s going to do such a great job.”

Khettry said she really wants to focus on bringing the business division together as part of her recruitment and retention efforts.

“I’m really excited to get started,” Khettry said.

HEAR FROM OUR INCOMING EDITOR-IN-CHIEF

title: SFSN, Student Farm Club hold second annual food justice summit to advance food justice
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Student Farm Club (SFC)’s food justice project team held its second annual food justice summit on Thursday in the HUB-Robeson Center.

Matthew Koah said he hoped the summit would introduce attendees to what food justice is and provide them with the pathways that would allow them to get involved.

“I want (students) to be able to work together and use their voices to come up with changes they want to see at the university and the community,” Koah, a fourth-year studying plant science, said. “I want them to work together to think about how they can implement the changes that they think that they need and I think even going beyond brainstorming and planning behind how we can create change at the university.”

The summit saw Penn State Executive Vice President and Provost Fotis Sotiropoulos address attendees as a keynote speaker.

In an interview, Sotiropoulos said he saw food insecurity as an obstacle to student success at Penn State.

He said he hoped attendees left the summit feeling energized with new ideas about how they can advance food justice.

“At every opportunity, we have to introduce our students to these bigger issues and make it very clear how they can play a big role in being the change that we need everybody to drive forward,” Sotiropoulos said. “Events like this make a difference in that.”

Following Sotiropoulos's speech, a panel of student leaders took to the stage which included Student Farm Executive Director Annie Stasney, Students United Against Poverty President Jeremy Lynn and Food Recovery Network President Emmanuel Kraft.

Sarah Landauer, a community outreach specialist with the Sustainable Food Systems Network (SFSN), which includes the SFC, said it was important to include figures like Sotiropoulos as a way to show that there is support for food justice within Penn State’s administration.

“As students, we can obviously have a voice in this movement, but when we get that buy-in from higher-level administration, it pushes it through university policy and more people are going to come and listen to us,” Landauer said.

She said the inclusion of student leaders was also a way to allow for students to voice their visions for change in their community.

The summit concluded with a group brainstorming session and workshops led by several Penn State and State College organizations.

Raymond Yan, who also attended last year’s summit, said he believed the SFSN had brought in the right stakeholders from both Penn State and the Pennsylvania state government who are able to best make a difference in combating food insecurity.

He said the summit is a good way for students to begin getting involved in advocating for food justice.

“If you're someone who's working on anything related to food insecurity or hunger, this is the place that you have to be,” Yan, a fourth-year studying agricultural and biorenewable systems management, said. “These issues are relevant to all students, no matter if you're just coming in or are about to graduate because, even after you graduate, these issues are gonna continue.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: McMiller reaches 30 points for third straight game, Penn State women’s basketball overwhelmed by No. 20 Maryland
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
The last time Penn State hit the floor, it fell 81-70 to No. 13 Michigan State, but led for the majority of the game. The Lady Lions got another chance against a ranked opponent, hitting the road for a Thursday night matchup against No. 20 Maryland.

The Lady Lions couldn’t build off a strong first half, falling to the Terps 81-62.

Maryland wasted no time, winning the jump and going on an 8-0 run to start the game. Penn State broke the run with two points from Gracie Merkle immediately after she came off the bench.

After two minutes with no points from either side, freshman Tèa Clèante drove through three Terrapins to get the layup from the left side.

The Lady Lions' run continued with a three-pointer from freshman Nyla McFadden to cut Maryland’s lead to one.

The Terps held onto their lead thanks to back-to-back two-pointers from Mir McLean outweighed a layup from Merkle.

Maryland took a 14-9 lead with just over three minutes to play in the first quarter, but five straight points from sophomore guard Kiyomi McMiller tied the score.

McLean hit another two for her sixth points of the quarter, but was matched by an and-one from Merkle on the other end. The 6-foot-6 center hit her foul shot, giving Penn State its first lead of the game and a 17-16 advantage at the end of the opening frame.

The second quarter scoring started quickly, with both teams combining for six points in the first minute.

Five straight points from McMiller were outmatched by six straight from the Terps’ Oluchi Okananwa, giving Maryland a 26-24 lead with six minutes to play in the half.

Okananwa netted her eighth points of the quarter to give the Terps a 30-26 lead, but back-to-back buckets by Clèante and McMiller tied the game for the fifth time of the night.

Merkle joined the party with two straight layups, extending Penn State’s run to 8-0 while also giving the Lady Lions their largest lead of the night.

Maryland ended the second quarter on an 8-0 run of its own to take a 38-34 lead into the locker room.

McMiller and Merkle combined for 23 of the blue and white’s first-half points. Okananwa led the Terps with nine first-half points, all of which came in the second quarter.

Both teams recorded 10 first-half turnovers, with Maryland producing 13 points of Penn State miscues, as opposed to the Lady Lions’ five points of takeaways.

The blue and white opened the third quarter scoring on a 5-0 run thanks to a two-point jumper from McMiller and a three-pointer from senior guard Vitória Santana.

However, Penn State’s lead didn’t last long, as the Terps scored eight unanswered points in 50 seconds, prompting coach Carolyn Kieger to call a timeout.

The timeout didn’t slow Maryland down, extending its run to 11-0 before McMiller ended the Lady Lions’ scoring drought with a jumper inside the paint.

The Terps still didn’t let up, scoring five straight points for their largest lead of the game at 54-41, with just under five minutes to play in the third quarter.

With under three minutes to play, down 56-45, Penn State had the chance to cut the lead to single-digits, but Merkle missed both her chances from the charity stripe. The Mount Washington, Kentucky, native had the same opportunity a few seconds later, but went 0-for-2 from the free throw line once again.

McMiller and Merkle scored five points for the Lady Lions to end the quarter, but Maryland still held a 58-50 lead heading into the final frame.

The Terps opened the fourth quarter on a 6-0 run, behind four points from freshman Addi Mack. Following a three-pointer from Santana for Penn State's first points of the frame, Maryland scored five points unanswered to take a 69-53 lead.

Yarden Garzon committed a technical foul with five minutes to play, giving the Lady Lions a chance to chip into the Terps’ lead.

McMiller made both free throws and added a layup from the left side, giving the sophomore 27 points on the night and cutting Maryland’s lead to 73-59.

The blue and white went silent for nearly three minutes, and Merkle committed a flagrant one foul under the basket, allowing the Terps to take an 80-59 lead with two minutes to play.

Despite a third-straight 30-point outing from McMiller, Penn State falls to 1-13 in the Big Ten.

Injury Report

Redshirt junior guard Moriah Murray left the game with a knee injury in the second quarter and didn’t return.

Up Next

Penn State hosts Northwestern at 4 p.m. Sunday for its annual ‘Pink Zone’ game.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Meet The Daily Collegian’s 2026-27 editor-in-chief
author: Mia Debelevich | News Editor
description:
Kahlie Wray was elected as The Daily Collegian’s next editor-in-chief on Thursday night during a Collegian Board of Directors meeting.

“I really love the Collegian,” Wray, a third-year studying English and journalism, said. “Even though at some points I was nervous and fiddling with my fingers, it went way better than I thought it would go.”

Wray described herself as having worn many hats at the Collegian, with her most challenging undertaking being the 2025-26 managing editor. She joined the Collegian her freshman year writing for the administration beat, a role she described as necessary to her journalistic development.

“That’s where I learned that journalism has the unique power to change the world and change society,” Wray said. “It’s important people on this campus know that they deserve to be here.”

Current editor-in-chief Mercedes Hamilton said Wray has demonstrated a strong interest in innovation and an unwavering commitment to the outlet during her time as managing editor.

“There’s no one more qualified for the role,” Hamilton, a fourth-year studying English and journalism, said. “She’s shown great interest in the role and is always doing a lot more than what is required of her.”

Wray said Hamilton’s mentorship was a big support system for her.

“I am standing here because of her,” Wray said.

As editor-in-chief, Wray said she wants to lean on her Jamaican upbringing to bridge cultural divides on campus. Her cultural competence will contribute to what she describes as a hands-on approach to leading the Collegian, she added.

Wray intends to pursue a career in journalism, and thanks her time at the Collegian for readying her for her career. She said she wants to defy the idea that journalism is a dying industry.

“I’m really excited, though I know it’s going to be hard,” Wray said. “But, nothing worth having comes easy.”

HEAR FROM OUR INCOMING BUSINESS MANAGER

title: Penn State men’s volleyball match against Ohio State moved to Pittsburgh
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
One of Penn State’s upcoming matches has been relocated.

NCAA men's volleyball in Pittsburgh!Our match against Ohio State will be played at Pitt's Fitzgerald Field House on March 25 🏐Get your tickets ⬇️🎟️ https://t.co/vXwvf3FIT8#WeAre pic.twitter.com/z0dMAAfIar— Penn State Men's Volleyball (@PennStateMVBALL) February 12, 2026

The No. 15 Nittany Lions’ March 25 contest with No. 11 Ohio State has been moved to Fitzgerald Field House at the University of Pittsburgh.

The Buckeyes are currently 6-3 on the season, and 1-0 in Big Ten play. The teams’ last duels came in 2024, with Penn State winning both matches.

Last season, a pair of matchups between the teams was cancelled due to illness within the Ohio State Squad.

Next month’s match is set to begin at 6:00 p.m.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: 2 former Penn State men's hockey commits flip elsewhere
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two former Penn State prospects announced their new commitments Thursday afternoon.

After decommitting from the blue and white late last year, forward Will Tomko has found a new home with Ohio State.

‼️🚨BREAKING🚨‼️The Ohio State Buckeyes have received a commitment from Will Tomko!🌰🌰🌰The ‘06 born Forward from McMurray, PA has 44 points in 42 GP during the 2025-26 season for @Musketeerhockey Previously committed to Penn State pic.twitter.com/errDywSDVn— College Puck NXT (@CollegePuckNXT) February 12, 2026

Tomko currently plays for the Sioux City Musketeers of the USHL and has put up 44 points in 42 games played.

The McMurray, Pennsylvania, native is 3rd in scoring on the Musketeers and 11th in the league.

Another forward out of the USHL, Layne Loomer, has also flipped his commitment, this time to Miami (OH).

🐦‍🔥🐦‍🔥🐦‍🔥 https://t.co/IcgTkoNQbh pic.twitter.com/S2n5yNI5Ip— College Puck NXT (@CollegePuckNXT) February 12, 2026

Loomer serves as the assistant captain of the Lincoln Stars, and currently ranks third in league scoring, with 57 points in 44 games.

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Hall, Adolfsson to represent Team Sweden in Olympic Quarterfinal game against Team Czechia
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Nicole Hall and Jessica Adolfsson will be representing Team Sweden in the women's ice hockey Olympic Quarterfinals at 10:40 a.m. on Friday against Team Czechia.

Another battle of Nittany Lions tomorrow in the quarterfinals as Tessa and Mati will face off while Nicole and Jessica play Czechia! #WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/Wr8fC4unkO— Penn State Women’s Hockey (@PennStateWHKY) February 12, 2026

Team Sweden finished the preliminary round-robin at the top of Group B with a 4-0 record, beating Team Germany, Team Italy, Team Japan and Team France. Meanwhile, Team Czechia finished third in Group A with a 1-2-1 record, having only beaten Team Finland.

Adolfsson performed aptly in the round-robin, scoring a goal and accumulating a six +/- ratio. Hall has yet to break onto the scoreboard, but she currently has a two +/- ratio.

Fellow Nittany Lions Matilde Fantin (Team Italy) and Tessa Janecke (Team USA) are set to face each other at 3:10 p.m.

MORE WOMEN'S HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Former Penn State women's volleyball assistant coach Michael Henchy named UC Santa Barbara head coach
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Former Penn State assistant coach Michael Henchy is getting a promotion.

Henchy was named the head coach of UC Santa Barbara on Thursday, marking his first head coaching role.

We are thrilled to announce Michael Henchy as our new head coach!Welcome to Santa Barbara 🌊Full release at https://t.co/4Li5JGGqu4#GoGauchos pic.twitter.com/gOLTfBp0BE— UC Santa Barbara Women's Volleyball (@UCSB_Volleyball) February 12, 2026

The Ohio State alum spent two years as an assistant coach for the Nittany Lions, where he helped lead the team to the 2024 NCAA Championship.

Prior to his time in Happy Valley, Henchy was the associate coach at James Madison following his start at American University as an assistant coach.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State field hockey's Aby Deverka named to U.S. U21 team
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State's Aby Deverka is leveling up.

Deverka was named to the United States' U-21 Women's National Team on Wednesday after participating in the junior national camp earlier this month.

The junior goalkeeper has improved in each of her seasons with the Nittany Lions, playing in 17 games last year.

Deverka recorded a 63.6% save percentage in 2025, garnering 70 saves with just 40 goals scored.

MORE FIELD HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State alum Daniel Barefoot competes in Olympic skeleton prelims
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another Penn Stater hits the history books as an Olympic competitor.

2013 graduate Daniel Barefoot competed in the first two heats of the men's skeleton at the 2026 Olympics, finishing in 18th place for both rounds.

Barefoot competed in the first go around early Thursday morning, finishing with a 57.47 time for 18th place.

Two hours later, he finished the second round with a 18th place finish, crossing the line in an improved 57.22. The Johnstown, Pennsylvania, native sits at 19th overall after half of the competition.

Barefoot will finish his Olympic debut with Heat 3 at 1:30 p.m. on Friday and Heat 4 at 3:05 p.m.

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE

title: Staff predictions | How will Penn State baseball perform in Year 3 under coach Mike Gambino?
author: The Daily Collegian Baseball Staff
description:
It’s February, and the baseball season is upon us. While the MLB’s Spring Training is set to begin in just a few weeks, Penn State baseball’s start is under two days away.

After losing five starters to the MLB Draft, the Nittany Lions will seek a chance to follow up past success with fresh faces. The satisfactory 33-23 output last season is behind Mike Gambino and the blue and white.

With the turnover and the new season, how likely is Penn State to replicate or surpass its previous record?

Here’s our staff’s picks.

Dominic Megats: 33-22

This season will speak volumes on how well Gambino can scout, recruit and utilize the transfer portal to fill voids that were left by departing players. With 13 freshmen and several additions from the portal, solidified depth can carry Penn State a long way.

The Nittany Lions begin their season in Arizona for the MLB Desert Invitational. This is where I believe Gambino will test players at different positions and see his pitchers in live games. By the end of the weekend, the skipper will have his lineup and rotation figured out. However, I think Penn State loses a game due to its learning curve.

From there, the blue and white will have several non-conference matchups under its belt. One that will pose the greatest challenge to Penn State will be Texas Tech. I think the Red Raiders will get the best of the Nittany Lions in two out of the three games in that series.

Penn State will have a favorable record heading into conference play once the middle of March rolls around. Iowa and Oregon pose some threats in Big Ten play. Both teams finished in the top three of the conference last season and ranked top five in offense.

The Nittany Lions will return to the Big Ten tournament having finished the season with a 17-13 conference record. Roster depth and new arms in the bullpen will take Penn State to the point it was at last season in the tournament.

Sam Simonic: 34-21

With a largely reshaped roster, Penn State will enter a new era with a chance of national contention. First, the Nittany Lions should have their sights set on making a run in the Big Ten Tournament.

For years, they’ve been so close yet so far, and I believe Penn State will likely finish in the upper echelon of the conference and have a real shot to compete and win. Luckily for Gambino and his squad, the schedule appears favorable as the blue and white won’t need to face the likes of UCLA, Michigan, USC or Indiana, all of whom finished last season as respectable teams in the conference.

Nevertheless, the Nittany Lions will play some interesting matchups early on, having to face Air Force, Grand Canyon and Kansas State before heading to Richmond to face the Spiders.Penn State has an intriguing blend of veterans, largely led by its outfield. Faces like Bryce Molinaro at third and Nate Voss behind the dish can also make a difference and give Penn State the edge in close games.

While I like Penn State to win a close one against Kansas State, I believe it will drop one on the road to an Atlantic 10 foe. From there, the Nittany Lions will play a three-game series against Indiana State, which will serve as another test. I like Penn State to drop a game there.

Penn State will face Texas Tech on the road, marking its first real test. I could see the Nittany Lions losing all three road games. The blue and white will bounce back against St. John’s and Georgetown before losing a game against Iowa, beating West Virginia and sweeping Purdue.

Only Illinois, Nebraska and Oregon will serve as its upcoming Big Ten challenges and Penn State will go 5-4, losing two to Oregon and two to Illinois.

Finally, the Nittany Lions will close their regular season with a loss to West Virginia and a sweep against Minnesota. They will also lose one against Washington, defeat Pitt, and lose one on the road against Maryland.

I see the Nittany Lions going as far as the semi-finals in the Big Ten Tournament and following up last season with a slightly better year.

Ashley Beres: 35-20

Penn State enters its third campaign under Gambino, and this season will show if the Nittany Lions can finally break through. After two straight trips to the Big Ten semifinals, which included a Big Ten Championship game appearance in 2024, the blue and white are teetering on the edge of making the NCAA Tournament for the first time since 2000.

With many transfers and incoming freshmen, Gambino’s squad is filled with many new faces. I have Penn State winning games over Air Force and Grand Canyon, but also dropping a game against a tough Kansas State team at the MLB Desert Invitational.

After the opening weekend, the Nittany Lions continue their long slate of nonconference games. I predict the blue and white to win multiple series over Richmond, Indiana State and St. John’s, before traveling to face Texas Tech. While this will be a challenging road test for Penn State, the Red Raiders finished 20-33 last season, so I have the Nittany Lions taking two of the three games.

The hardest Big Ten matchups will be against Iowa and Oregon. I ultimately have the blue and white dropping both series, but the Nittany Lions are more likely to pull off the upset against the Hawkeyes since the series is played in Happy Valley. I have Penn State finishing the regular season anywhere from six to eight in the conference, with a chance to make another run in the Big Ten Tournament and potentially earn an NCAA Tournament berth.

Ashley Felsberg: 33-22

Penn State baseball’s season begins Feb. 13, against the Air Force Academy in Scottsdale, Arizona.

Gambino has received 11 new players to join his squad since last season, including three top 25 prospects from the Northeast. These signings made Penn State one of two schools in the Big Ten with the most Prep Baseball Report Top 200 signings.

These new additions will change up a lot of the formation within the squad, as the new players have positions ranging all over the field.

Penn State concluded its 2025 season in the semifinals of the Big Ten Tournament against Nebraska, losing 5-3. The Nittany Lions will travel to Lincoln to play the Cornhuskers this season to begin April. This game will be a competitive one, as Nebraska has lost two key players, and only has one returning starter, whereas Penn State is coming in with a reshaped team.

Looking earlier into the season, Penn State will go on a nonconference run until mid-March, in which I believe it should dominate. A large portion of these teams, including Air Force and Texas Tech, are squads that the blue and white have never seen, or haven’t seen in over a decade.

As Penn State looks towards conference play, the games should get more competitive. Aside from Nebraska, the Nittany Lions will also see in-state rival, Pitt. The Panthers dominated Penn State last year, winning both of their matches by large margins.

Regardless of Penn State’s wins and losses this season, I believe that with these alterations and a pretty even mix of familiar and old rematches, that Penn State will see a similar record to last year.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Resource centers, advocates aim to normalize consent education
author: Sara O'Connell | The Daily Collegian
description:
Content warning: This story discusses sexual misconduct. Resources and support are available through Penn State’s Counseling and Psychological Services.

As sexual misconduct awareness and education grow, both on and off-campus advocates are pushing for a deeper understanding of what consent means.

The National Library of Medicine reports college students often lack a clear definition of consent. The Pennsylvania Coalition to Advance Respect, an organization founded in 1975 to end sexual violence, defines consent as specific, voluntary, ongoing and coherent. It must be communicated for every activity and can be revoked at any time.

Yvette Willson said there’s a need for increased education around consent.

Willson, the director of Relationship Violence Outreach, Intervention, and Community Education Center (R-VOICE), said practicing saying a firm “no” is important.

“We’ve done a horrible disservice to girls,” Willson said. “We’ve taught them: be nice, don’t hurt somebody’s feelings, and as a result, we’ve taught (them) that their own desires, own wants are not important.”

Sophia Mills said R-VOICE utilizes the “F.R.I.E.S.” consent model when discussing consent: freely given, reversible, informed, enthusiastic and specific.

Mills, associate director of R-VOICE, said the organization also designed animal stickers in an effort to normalize talking about consent. “Elephants for equality,” and “Cats against cat calling” are a few of the phrases featured on the stickers.

Sarah Allison said coercion, or one merely being unsure about a situation, are nuances that contribute to common misconceptions regarding consent.

Allison, a Centre Helps hotline counselor, said she often works with people who are unsure whether or not they gave consent. Acknowledging that uncertainty and allowing them room to understand some things may have been nonconsensual validates their situation.

“That’s okay if you’re unsure,” Allison, a fourth-year studying psychology, said. “If you’re uncomfortable, then I don’t think that’s consent.”

Allison said while there are resource fairs students can attend, not everybody discovers them in time. She added the stigma behind seeking help often results in survivors feeling fearful of not being believed, which also prevents people from seeking out resources.

“If you have any doubt at all or any worry at all about something that happened to you, it’s always okay to go get help,” Allison said.

She said it’s important for a person to separate themselves from any situation that makes them uncomfortable and to trust themselves in what they believe is best for them.

“I encourage people to understand that they are individuals,” Allison said. “You have emotions. You have feelings. You have thoughts, and all of that matters.”

Education and discussion within the classroom lead to students having a better understanding of consent, according to Jennifer Pencek.

“We all love to think we know about consent,” Pencek, the executive director of Center Safe, said. “How are you making sure that what's going on is actually okay with them? And even if they're like, ‘yes, let's go,’ but someone is incapacitated, or someone is drunk or high, there's no consent.”

Centre Safe offers protection orders from those who retaliate against the reporter.

Pencek said she’d like to see more open discussion about the importance of consent. She also said it’s important to offer support by listening to people and not bombarding survivors with an interrogation.

“It’s just making consent approachable,” Pencek said. “Stop making it seem like it’s way more complicated than it really is.”

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: State College’s Fez ‘sounds like itself’
author: Ashlyn Kafer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Shrouded in a foggy haze obscuring the walls plastered in concert posters and band decals, an animated voice called out from behind the drumset: “The Fez set is starting now — you will all be assuming characters, so do not be scared.”

Setting the scene as though the audience were a part of a 2000s football drama series, State College’s Fez, a local band, erupted into its recognizable chorale of rhythmic beats, handcrafted guitar riffs and gravelly vocals at one of its local performances on Feb 6.

The group — composed of bassist Max Hill, guitarist James “Jimmy” Connelly and drummer and lead vocalist Xavier Hons — have been playing together since high school, bringing their craft and showmanship to the State College house show scene.

“Max and I were in this class called ‘Rock Ensemble,’ that’s where we met,” Hons, a fourth-year studying music technology, said. “We eventually had a high school band and were in the same sphere of people, and then Jimmy, I met him, I think, before he even started playing guitar.”

Inspired by classic blues and soul, Fez has curated a characteristic sound that it works to develop in each practice and live performance.

In juxtaposition with its retro-futuristic aesthetic represented by the early-internet inspired theme of its website, the trio deemed itself a “scuba rock” band after finding that no existing genre could encapsulate the product generated from the combined influences of each member.

“I think we try to go beyond some of the famous punk tropes, not always just doing all power chords and stuff like that,” Connelly, a 2025 Penn State alum, said. “It’s the depths of surf, but it’s not on the surface.”

The band almost entirely plays original music from its toolbox of tracks it’s been creating since its first Spotify release in 2022, finding every live performance continues to develop its overall sound into its own distinctive genius.

“We don’t exactly have a defined sound we can pick out, so it’s hard to sometimes not know what you’re similar to,” Hons said. “We can pick out pieces where we know we’re directly inspired by certain songs or vibes from different bands, but when we put it together, I think, and at least the people we’ve talked to believe it sounds like itself.”

Fez has not only grown its discography, but its overall stage presence as a group as each member has advanced their sense of confidence on stage.

Whether it’s wearing costumes while performing to match the story of the night, such as a football helmet or old jersey, or headbanging along with each downbeat, Fez has transcended its statuesque beginnings.

“I feel like we impart a lot of our energy into our movements now,” Hill, a fourth-year studying music at Lycoming College, said. “It was always in our instruments, but now it’s more in ourselves.”

The members have found a sense of fulfillment in bringing joy to each audience, expanding their fan base through a balance of consistency and experimentation.

“If you dig deep into the lyrics, we’re not all jokes,” Connelly said. “There’s meaning in there. You have to dig for it, you have to scuba dive.”

While a momentary hiatus during Hons’ semester abroad disrupted the band’s initial momentum, Fez was still able to amass a crowd that screamed in excitement at the sound of the first few notes of each song.

“I was a little worried when I was in Vienna that ‘Okay, it’s over when we come back,’” Hons said. “But, people like it. We played at Webster’s last week and had people saying they were glad we were back. So it felt nice that we have some kind of backing in the community.”

Despite being separated for a semester and not playing consistently, through the members’ long-lasting relationship they were able to jump right back into the scene.

“Comparatively, to a lot of other bands, I think we’ve had a pretty easy time maintaining everything,” Hill said. “We all have a brotherly relationship, I would say, and it helps us be productive and keep good communication.”

Fez most commonly plays at local house shows or venues downtown, such as The 8Ball or Manny’s, but the members hope to eventually book a gig in New York City to take their music beyond State College’s borders.

The band is also dedicated to ensuring the trio is enjoying the music they are creating, taking pride in handcrafting their own sound, collaborating with each other and being able to share their melodies with various audiences.

“If there’s anything to take away from our stream of consciousness it’s that number one we like to have fun. Number two, we like to have a good time and number three, there’s a little bit of something for everybody,” Hons said.

While Fez plans to further expand as a band, it recognizes the importance of its foundation built in the trio’s Pennsylvania upbringing.

“I’ve had some really great memories over the course of the past three years we’ve been performing gigs together,” Hill said. “I think that I value that more than any of the money that we’ve made. It’s not like we’re making thousands of dollars, but I really enjoy it.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: No. 6 Penn State men’s hockey prepares for road series against No. 2 Michigan
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Last weekend’s top-five matchup between Penn State and Michigan State was the program’s first-ever outdoor game at Beaver Stadium. It also marked No. 6 Penn State’s first loss since Jan. 3, as No. 1 Michigan State snapped its seven-game winning streak with a series sweep.

The Nittany Lions’ tough schedule doesn’t stop there. Guy Gadowsky’s squad has another top-ranked matchup on tap, this one in Ann Arbor against No. 2 Michigan.

Nearly three months ago, the Wolverines dominated Penn State, 7-1, in Game 1 at Pegula Ice Arena. But the blue and white fought back to earn a gritty 4-2 win the next night.

All tied at 1-1 in the season series, the sides will meet for two more at Yost Ice Arena, with Game 1 scheduled for 6:30 p.m. Friday on Big Ten Plus. Big Ten Network will broadcast Game 2, which starts at 5 p.m. Saturday.

“We want our payback. We are confident we're the best in the country,” Dane Dowiak said. “You're gonna lose games and win games, and you've got to take lessons from both, and I think we did that after the Michigan series … we’ve got to be our best if we want to go into Yost and get out of there with two wins.”

McKenna’s availability

Gavin McKenna, Penn State’s star forward who was recently charged with felony assault before the charges were later dropped, practiced with the team Tuesday and will play this weekend against Michigan, Gadowsky said Wednesday.

“Gavin will participate in all, and continue to participate in all athletically related activities. But regarding that, I also hope you understand it's an ongoing legal thing, so (it’s) inappropriate for me to comment (further) on that.”

Penn State Athletics last week released a statement regarding McKenna’s charges. The freshman’s court date, originally scheduled for Wednesday, was rescheduled to March 11.

Scouting Michigan

The Wolverines are 23-5 after they, too, had their seven-game winning streak snapped by Michigan State last weekend.

Michigan sports the Big Ten’s most prolific offense, which scores nearly five goals per game and leads the conference with 31 power-play tallies.

T.J. Hughes, who recorded three points on nine shots against Penn State in November, leads that offense with a Big-Ten best 40 points. His 27 assists also pace the conference, with teammate Michael Hage’s 25 helpers a close second.

“(Hughes) is very cerebral. He has really good vision on the ice, but his skills are excellent as well,” Gadowsky said. “He's a really good guy. He's a talented player who has a nose for the net. I enjoyed having him on our bench. I don't like it so much when he's on the other bench. He's a very good player.”

Jack Ivankovic, Michigan’s starting goaltender, saved 49 of the 53 shots he faced in his two starts against Penn State this season. Ivankovic sports a 17-5 record and a 2.01 goals-against average, both of which rank second in the Big Ten.

Injuries

Gadowsky announced that forward Alex Servagno, who left with an injury in Penn State’s 6-3 loss to Michigan State on Jan. 30, underwent surgery on Wednesday morning and will miss “at least the remainder of the regular season.”

Gadowsky said Casey Aman, a traditional defenseman who filled in for Servagno on Penn State’s fourth forward line in Game 2 against Michigan State, will continue in that role moving forward.

Charlie Cerrato, who led Penn State in points before suffering an injury on Jan. 9 against Minnesota, remains out. Braeden Ford is still sidelined with an injury that Gadowsky said will cause him to miss “a significant amount of time.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball opens 2026 season with three games against nonconference opponents
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
The start of Penn State’s 2026 campaign is finally here as the Nittany Lions travel to Arizona for three games at the MLB Desert Invitational this weekend. Coach Mike Gambino led the blue and white to another successful season last year, with a 33-23 record and a second straight Big Ten semifinals appearance.

Now entering their third season under Gambino, the Nittany Lions have a chance to carry their momentum from the last two years and make another run in the Big Ten Tournament, while also possibly earning an NCAA Tournament bid for the first time since 2000.

The road to the postseason starts with the blue and white’s season opener against Air Force at 8 p.m. on Friday. Then the Nittany Lions face Grand Canyon at 3 p.m. on Saturday, with the opening weekend wrapping up against Kansas State at 2 p.m. on Sunday.

Air Force

There isn’t much history between the two squads, with only one prior meeting before Friday’s contest. While the Falcons look to have a bounce-back season after a rocky 2025 campaign, in which they finished 20-34, which was second-to-last in the Mountain West.

The squad finished bottom three in batting with a cumulative .281 average and also tossed an overall 7.17 ERA. However, senior Walker Zapp returns after being one of the only bright spots in Air Force’s lineup last season.

The catcher stuffed the stat sheet and finished with the team’s third-best average at .330, along with the second-most hits, home runs and RBIs. The Auburn, Alabama, native also reached base efficiently with a .999 OPS.

The Nittany Lions should have an advantage in both hitting and pitching in this matchup, with a veteran-led outfield and an experienced pitching staff. Despite Ryan DeSanto heading off to MLB, the blue and white still returned some of its star pitchers.

Senior Dimond Loosli had an impressive first season at Penn State, posting a 3.82 ERA and allowing 34 hits and 17 runs over 33 innings. The Walnut Creek, California, native will likely be a shutdown reliever in the Nittany Lions’ bullpen.

Grand Canyon

The Antelopes face Penn State for just the second time after they swept the series in 2018. Before leaving for the Mountain West, Grand Canyon finished fourth in the Western Atlantic with a 31-27 record.

In 2025, the Antelopes ranked in the middle of the conference with a team .295 average and 6.37 ERA. While Grand Canyon lost its two biggest bats in Josh Wakefield and Zach Yorke to the MLB draft, junior Cannon Peery will wreak havoc in the batter’s box.

Last season, the first baseman finished with a .317 average, with 53 hits and 38 RBI in 167 at-bats. After many of the Antelopes top hitters left the squad, they will need solid offensive production from Peery.

On the other side of the ball, senior Elijah Higginbottom will anchor the pitching staff. The right-handed pitcher posted the team’s third-best ERA last season at 4.32. Additionally, Higginbottom held a 6-0 record with 42 strikeouts over 50 innings.

This is another favorable matchup for the Nittany Lions, but they will need offensive production from one of the lone infield returners, Bryce Molinaro. The redshirt junior finished with a .267 average, 60 hits, 13 home runs and 61 RBI in 2025.

Kansas State

The Wildcats and the Nittany Lions have played four previous times, with Kansas State holding a 3-1 record over Penn State. This will be the biggest test of the weekend for the blue and white as the Wildcats enter the new season fresh off an NCAA Tournament appearance.

Kansas State finished sixth in the Big 12, with a 32-26 record, and reached the conference championship game, where it lost to Houston. Despite ranking near the bottom in the Big 12 offensively, the Wildcats can rake. The squad finished with the third-most home runs in the conference with 97, so power is one of their strong suits.

While Kansas State lost a lot of its power hitters, such as Seth Dardar, Maximum Martin and Keegan O’Connor, sophomore AJ Evasco spearheads the lineup. The infielder posted the team’s third-best average at .311, tied for fourth-most in home runs with 11 and held the third-most RBI with 52.

Pitching wasn’t a strong suit last season, but junior Adam Arther was reliable with a team-best 2.45 ERA, with 15 strikeouts and he allowed just 20 hits over 25.2 innings. The left-hander might provide Penn State with some trouble offensively if he faces the Nittany Lions.

The key for the blue and white will be limiting the power hits for Kansas State, while also providing its pitching staff with runs, so less pressure is on them.

MORE BASEBALL CONTENT

title: No. 15 Penn State men’s volleyball set to face Princeton in two-game series
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is set to travel to New Jersey this weekend for a two-match series against Princeton at 7 p.m. Friday and 4 p.m. Saturday.

Coming off back-to-back wins against Saint Francis, the No. 15 Nittany Lions look to keep their winning streak alive as they prepare to face the unranked Tigers.

The 2-4 Tigers will welcome the 6-4 blue and white to Princeton, New Jersey, coming off a loss to NJIT on Friday. Despite recent wins, the Nittany Lions have still had their issues in the serving department.

Penn State’s Owen Rose has 13 service aces on the year, with Gaige Gabriel trailing just behind with nine. But these aces have been a rarity in recent matches. Against Saint Francis, the Nittany Lions only put up five aces in two games.

In six matches this season, the Tigers have tallied 27 service aces, while the blue and white have 41 in 10 matches.

Kills, however, remain a strong point for the blue and white, especially for Sean Harvey.

With a team total of 407 kills on the season, the redshirt sophomore is currently responsible for 114 of those. But Princeton’s Owen Mellon is No. 19 in the NCAA in kills per set, whereas Harvey trails at No. 39.

Mellon currently has 72 kills on the year, averaging about 3.60 per set. And while Harvey has more, he averages slightly less with 3.35 per set.

A few of the young stars on the team have been notable in the last few matches. Both Tristan Hassell and Jaidyn Bethel have remained consistent and played with increased confidence in recent matches.

With Hassell at 39 kills and Bethel trailing only by two at 37, the two underclassmen have shown great potential and made a big impact on the court.

Defense could be the blue and white’s key to success in this matchup.

So far this year, Rose currently has 37 blocks on the year, with Gabriel trailing yet again with 30. The two middle blockers provide consistent support when shutting down the opposition's attacks, working well both individually and as a unit.

Despite this, Rose ranks No. 18, which is two places under No. 17 Tristan Whitfield in the NCAA in blocks per set. Whitfield currently has 22 blocks on the year in four less games than the blue and white.

Ryan Merk’s defensive effort can’t be ignored either. With 76 digs on the year, the redshirt senior makes a big difference when it comes to keeping play alive. He currently sits at No. 19 in the NCAA in digs per set.

Princeton’s libero, Roan Alviar, has 38 digs in four fewer matches. He ranks significantly lower in the NCAA in the very same category, coming in at No. 41.

With both competitors looking to log a few more wins this weekend, the matchup will be one to keep an eye on.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball heads to Lone Star State, faces Incarnate Word, Houston
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
After going 4-1 in Clearwater, Florida, this past weekend, the Nittany Lions have a chance to go undefeated in the Houston Invitational when the blue and white return for another weekend in the dirt.

Penn State is set to face five nonconference opponents this upcoming weekend, with matchups against Incarnate Word, Houston, Lafayette, Houston Christian and Pitt.

The Nittany Lions had a successful season opener, beating Missouri in extra innings 7-4. Then, going 7-0 against Boston College. Penn State’s pitching in the circle was a force to be reckoned with on Friday.

Saturday was another long doubleheader for the blue and white, as it defeated Eastern Kentucky 4-2. Then, in their second round of extra innings against BYU, the Nittany Lions won 4-3, holding a 4-0 record to begin the season.

However, Auburn was the final matchup of the NFCA Leadoff Classic, and Penn State ultimately fell short, 4-3.

Penn State plays a doubleheader to begin the invitational against Incarnate Word at 2 p.m., then Houston at 7 p.m. Friday.

Incarnate Word

The Nittany Lions return to the diamond on Friday to face Incarnate Word for their sixth game of the season.

Currently, the Cardinals are undefeated, opening their season at home for the UIW invitational, going 5-0.

During the Cardinals' 2025 campaign, they went 29-21 overall and finished 17-10 inside the Southland Conference.

Friday's game will be the first time the Nittany Lions and the Cardinals go head- to-head.

Houston

Penn State faces Houston for a Friday night matchup. This will be the second time these teams have met. The Cougars currently lead 1-0, with the lone game coming in March of 2018, where Houston had home-field advantage and won 3-0.

To open the season, Houston went 4-0 in the Houston Tournament. The Cougars faced Houston Christian and Fairfield twice, while giving up just four runs.

Houston coach Chrissy Schoonmaker has made a perfect start to her first year as the Cougars’ head coach, securing the program’s 800th win.

Sophomore Ariel Redmond had herself a productive weekend offensively and defensively. The Conroe, Texas, native threw out two runners heading to home plate in back-to-back innings and produced a leadoff double, as well as a pair of home runs.

Houston ranked last in the Big 12 in 2025, with only four conference wins and an overall 22-25 season record.

The Nittany Lions have a promising upcoming weekend, with an attempt to go undefeated to continue their strong start to their 2026 campaign.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey finishes regular season hosting RIT
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
With its sweep against Lindenwood, No. 4 Penn State closed the book on its road games this season. Eight total Nittany Lions found the back of the net against the Lions. Katie DeSa broke her own single-season shutout record with her 10th in the 5-0 win in Game 2 against Lindenwood.

Penn State returns home to close out its 2025-26 regular season in front of its crowd at Pegula. For the fifth-straight year, the Nittany Lions will conclude their season with a series against RIT.

Scouting the Tigers

This is the second series of the year between the two conference teams. The programs met at the end of November, where the Tigers kept it close in both games. It took a late third period goal from Danica Maynard in Game 2 for Penn State to earn the road sweep.

Following the series, the Tigers won five out of their next six games. They continued to maintain a steady record, putting them at third place in the AHA with a 10-12 conference record.

Sophia Bellina has been the go-to netminder throughout the season, recording a .915 save percentage and 2.54 goals against average. The senior made 76 total saves in the previous meeting with Penn State.

What stands out when looking at RIT is its power play unit. Led by Emma Pickering, who is currently tied for the most power play goals in the conference with six, the unit has proved its efficiency through its consistent passing and ability to open shooting lanes.

In their most recent game against Syracuse, the Tigers scored half of their four goals on the power play, adding to their conference-leading 34 power play goals. RIT not only shines on the man-advantage in the AHA, but sits at second in the nation in power play percentage.

Additionally, the Nittany Lions rank in the top 11 nationally in penalty figures. If Penn State is unable to stay out of the penalty box, the Tigers could use their successful unit to add to the scoreboard throughout the series.

Outstanding Outwater

Grace Outwater can’t stop scoring. The Picton, Ontario, native has scored a goal in the last nine straight games. Outwater continued to hold down her position at right wing against Lindenwood; however, she found a bump up to the first line in Game 2. With the adjustment, the sophomore recorded two goals, ending a three-goal weekend.

Outwater leads the AHA in goals and is now top five in the nation with 23. She also holds the most goals scored by a sophomore in program history heading into the final regular season series.

Protect the house

Penn State has the opportunity to accomplish something it hasn’t been able to since the 2020-21 season. If able to earn a conference sweep against RIT to close out the regular season, the Nittany Lions will finish with an undefeated record at home as they currently sit at 13-0.

In addition, a 15th home win would tie the program record for total home wins. This was only done once before as Penn State finished last season with a 15-2 home record. However, RIT poses a tough opponent as they are fighting for positioning in the AHA as the playoffs quickly approach.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Off the record | Your boyfriend isn't better than your girlfriends
author: Miss Behave I The Daily Collegian
description:
Editor’s Note: Off the record is a weekly column written by a third-year Collegian staffer writing under an alias. It aims to promote a space for honest conversations about love, sex and relationships. Those interested in sharing their experiences or submitting a topic are invited to do so through this anonymous form.

Dearest reader,

I apologize for my brief disappearance the past two weeks. Apparently, even love columns need a little break or maybe it was just me?

Normally, I write about hearts skipping a beat, those pesky butterflies in your stomach and all that drama that comes with dating and romance.

But today, I’m trading candlelight dinners and wine glasses for sweatpants and binge-watching Heated Rivalry. Because let’s be honest, some of the best love stories don’t involve kissing or sex at all.

I’m talking about platonic love, the kind that survives your weirdest texts, your bad moods, endless tears and unhinged rants.

Don’t get me wrong, romantic love is beautiful. It’s exciting and can oftentimes be intoxicating in the best way. Falling for someone, building intimacy, choosing someone who chooses you.

I’m not here to downplay that kind of love, because when it’s good, it’s really good.

But somewhere along the way, the larger society has placed romantic love on a pedestal. That friendships can sometimes just be placeholders until the “real thing” shows up.

And that’s where we get it wrong.

While romantic relationships may come and go, friendships are often the steady threads that hold us together in between. They’re a constant. They exist without any expectations; you’re accepted exactly as you are. No pressure to perform.

Your best friend is someone who knows all your quirks and flaws and somehow, instead of running for the hills, they learn to love them too. Because that’s what makes you, well, you.

We rarely acknowledge that friendships are often the relationships that catch us when romance falters. Friends are the ones who stay when things end. The ones who pick up the pieces and remind us of who we are and were before the heartbreak.

And sometimes, they’re the very reason we continue to believe in love at all.

This past weekend, I left campus for a little getaway. Two days without my bestie shouldn’t feel like anything, and yet it does. That’s how I measure love, not by grand gestures or memories shared, but in how quickly I run back. And more importantly, how safe it feels when I get there.

I’m her best friend and she is mine.

I know myself and how much love I carry for my bestie. And yet, somehow it still isn’t enough. There’s always more to give. And the funny thing is, none of this is romantic. It’s simply the pure joy of having someone who truly gets you.

So, I may not have found the guy I want to marry or the person I want to spend the rest of my life with. But I have found the person that I will walk through all seasons of life with.

She’s the kind of person I can tell everything to, the one who makes life feel lighter. Everyone deserves that kind of love and person in their life. I’ve found that rare soul who tolerates my extreme nonsense and still shows up with a smile. And I hope you all find someone brave enough to do the same.

Until next time, I’m sending you all lots of love this Valentine’s Day.

Yours truly,

Miss Behave

MORE COLUMNS

title: Penn State wrestling’s Shayne Van Ness finding his pace through strong 2025-26 season
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Shayne Van Ness walks out to the mat, he insists on bowing and shaking the hand of everyone around the circle. The act is a show of respect to his opponent and the fans who keep the sport relevant.

Despite being told the actions aren’t standard in college, Van Ness continued to break the mold as a show of sportsmanship since arriving to the NCAA, no matter the outcome of his matches.

“If it’s something you do whether you win or lose, I don’t think there’s a problem with it,” Van Ness said. “But if you only do it when you win, it’s not about respect at that point.”

Fortunately for Van Ness, he does a lot more winning than losing. He sits undefeated on the season, and has lost just three matches since returning from a long-term injury in 2024.

Van Ness’ key to success is a rampant pace that keeps opponents from getting balanced on their feet. By the time they are prepared to counter an attack by the No. 1 ranked 149-pounder, he already has their leg picked.

For the middle segment of the 2025-26 campaign, Van Ness didn’t keep up his pace early in matches, giving up the first takedown on multiple occasions. That trend came to a halt in Maryland on Jan. 24.

While Penn State was racing a snowstorm in their dual against the Terrapins, the Somerville, New Jersey, native took on Carter Young. Young exploded out of the gate, jumping out to a 7-0 lead behind a takedown and near fall. Van Ness still trailed entering the second period, where he mounted the comeback, en route to a 31-15 tech fall.

“I made mistakes early on but just kept focusing on getting the next point,” Van Ness said.

When Van Ness arrived in Happy Valley, he didn’t have that same mindset. While continuing his respect ritual, despite his coaches being opposed to it, the junior still carries the other lessons his coaches taught him his freshman year.

“When I was in high school, I would go down a lot in big matches,” Van Ness said. “I was nervous and now I don't make that happen.”

Getting past those big match hiccups is a benefit of wrestling in the Big Ten. Penn State’s home is the premiere wrestling conference in the nation, accounting for the last 18 national championships.

Van Ness wanted to face the best competition in the country in order to be best set to make a run at a national championship. Now, as the top-ranked wrestler in the class, he controls his own destiny towards his ultimate goal.

“Going against all these great teams going into nationals is the best preparation,” Van Ness said.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: ‘He won’t be outworked’ | Ex-Iowa State, new Penn State coaches offer input on transfer QB Rocco Becht
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Rocco is the name of Matt Campbell’s youngest son, but he’s not the only Rocco present in the life of Penn State’s new head coach.

The other is Rocco Becht, a three-year starting quarterback for Campbell at Iowa State who has followed him to State College.

“I believe Penn State football is integrity, character, class, excellence, grit. He embodies every one of those traits,” Campbell said of Becht last week. “And so to me, I felt like that was such a critical opportunity for him to finish his career with us, and with the start of Penn State football, to get somebody that I truly believe embodies what the excellence of this football program stands for both on and off the field.”

Last year, Becht tore his labrum in his left shoulder, which is his non-throwing shoulder, but still played the whole season. Campbell said he was “shot up” every Tuesday and Wednesday the last four weeks of the season just to play and give the Cyclones a chance to win.

Campbell called him “one of the greatest leaders” he’s ever been around, and other coaches who went from Iowa State to Penn State matched that sentiment.

“I love the inspiration he provides our team, because he won't be outworked,” offensive coordinator Taylor Mouser said. “He wants to do whatever he can to help the team win. He lives with the linebackers. He's always with different guys. He's throwing with different guys. He lives in the training room. Just being around that guy provides confidence in everyone because of what he brings and who he's about.”

Mouser mentioned Becht’s willingness to do what it takes to win isn’t just on the football field. He talked about Becht getting after it playing spikeball at Campbell’s house as well as on the golf course, though Mouser jokingly insisted Becht cheated at golf.

It’s not just Becht that’s driven. He has the ability for others to rally around him.

“Rocco, he's an incredible connector of people, and that's what we look for at quarterback,” quarterbacks coach Jake Waters said. “You have to connect people, wherever people are from on the offense, you got to connect them. You got to sit with a different guy at dinner every night. You got to connect (offensive) lineman, receiver, tight end, running back.”

Waters mentioned that Becht is a quarterback with “tight end blood.” His dad, Anthony, played tight end in the NFL, having a career last 11 years across time with the New York Jets, Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Arizona Cardinals and Kansas City Chiefs.

Waters also said former Jets’ quarterback Chad Pennington, who was teammates with Anthony, has helped him handle game-week preparation.

So when did the Iowa State coaches realize Becht was special? Both Mouser and Waters mentioned a 2024 comeback win over UCF at home on Oct. 19. Mouser said Becht “truly put the offense on his back.”

Despite throwing a pair of pick sixes earlier in the contest, Becht orchestrated a game-winning drive in under two minutes and crossed the pylon on a 1-yard rushing touchdown to push the Cyclones 38-35 over the Knights.

“To go back and have such mental toughness to go ‘all right, now I'm gonna do whatever it takes. I got to run to win,’” Waters said. “And he made some really good throws, and to win a two-minute drive with I don't even know how many seconds left in the game on a QB sneak to go win it, told me all I need to know.”

Waters said Becht will be able to start doing some things come halfway through spring ball following his injury, but the confidence in him to replace Drew Allar is clear from the coaching staff.

They believe in what he’s capable of as a quarterback and a leader, and believe there’s no doubt he has what it takes to be the field general the Penn State offense is looking for.

“He checks all the boxes from a character standpoint,” Mouser said. “I have a daughter, if she married someone like Rocco, it would be the win of the century. He’s got great character.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Report: Penn State analyst Allen Tucker signs with Purdue as assistant special teams coach
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former staff member is headed to a Big Ten foe.

Special teams analyst Allen Tucker is joining Purdue as an assistant special teams coach, per Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports.

Tucker joined Penn State ahead of the 2025 season and helped coach a special teams unit that was among the best in the country. He has previously been the special teams coordinator at Troy and Akron.

Purdue plays at Penn State on Oct. 31 next season.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Guy Gadowsky talks injuries, Michigan, program history
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Guy Gadowsky addressed the media on Wednesday ahead of Penn State’s series against the Michigan Wolverines this weekend.

Gadowsky spoke on Gavin McKenna, Michigan and reflected on program history as he spoke.

Here’s what he said.

Gadowsky opened by confirming that McKenna will remain a full participant for the Nittany Lions going forward. Past that confirmation, Gadowsky refused to comment on other questions regarding McKenna’s charges.

“I hope you understand it’s an ongoing legal matter, so it’s inappropriate for me to comment on it,” Gadowsky said.

Injuries

The first news of the press conference was the announcement that forward Alex Servagno had surgery for an injury that will keep him out for the rest of the regular season at minimum. The injury occurred on the Friday before the Beaver Stadium game, and saw Casey Aman step in at forward for Penn State. Gadowsky said Aman will retain that role moving forward.

“The coaching staff has full confidence in (Aman), we’re not waiting to see how he does,” Gadowsky said. “He’s stepped in at forward in the past and done well.”

Gadowsky stated that Aman’s experience as a forward means there isn’t much adjustment needed for the junior defenseman. The focus was on the physical differences between defensive and offensive forechecking, and Gadowsky stated that Aman can handle the change.

No updates were provided on Charlie Cerrato or Braedon Ford. Cerrato is expected to miss the rest of the regular season, while Ford is out “long term.”

Michigan

After addressing the elephant in the room, Gadowsky addressed the Nittany Lions' upcoming trip to Ann Arbor, Mich. Penn State split with the Wolverines in November. Gadowsky’s takeaway from the previous series revolved around the Wolverine’s lethal power play. The coach had multiple plans to avoid that problem.

“There’s two ways to handle that,” Gadowsky said. “Play disciplined hockey and be prepared.”

Gadowsky didn’t have much new to say about the matchup between elite teams. Every time a new challenge arises, Gadowsky speaks on the strength of the Big Ten and the depth of talent throughout the conference. He continued to recite that sentiment on Wednesday.

When asked about the schedule during the bye week, Gadowsky revealed that the team spent every day on the ice training for Michigan. They used the time to let the thrill of the Beaver Stadium game wear off and get back to work. Rather than focusing on time off, Gadowksy pushed his team to view their scheduling gauntlet as a positive.

“We look at it as a great opportunity,” Gadowsky said. “People talk about, at the end of the year, if you’re battle tested or not; there’s going to be no question the Big Ten teams are battle tested.”

Beaver

The final topic Gadowsky dove into is the program's history, brought out by the Beaver Stadium game on Jan. 31. He shared his perspective from the bench, seeing 40,000 people in the east-side bleachers behind him. He also expressed gratitude for the school putting the event together, while remaining amazed by the outcome.

“The Super Bowl had what, 68,000 people?” Gadowsky said. “We had 75,000.”

While speaking on the alumni to show up at the event, Gadowsky discussed the program's accomplishments over the past year. Between a Frozen Four appearance and the Beaver Stadium game, there isn’t much left on Penn State hockey’s list of accomplishments.

“Before we even played our first game as an independent, we made a checklist of every goal,” Gadowsky said. “First NCAA win, first Ross win, first playoff win, all the way down to the Frozen Four.”

The only item left to check off the list for Gadowsky: A national championship.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State women’s volleyball outside hitter Karis Willow commits to Rutgers
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn State outside hitter has found a new home in the Big Ten.

Karis Willow has committed to Rutgers, she announced on Instagram on Wednesday.

The 6-foot-4 graduate student will play her final season of collegiate volleyball for the Scarlet Knights in 2026 after graduating from Penn State.

Willow entered the transfer portal on Dec. 8 after appearing in 14 matches during her Penn State career.

The Arlington, Ohio native notched six kills in her time on the court, and should find more consistent court time on a Rutgers squad that went 12-20 last season.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: 3 Penn State baseball players named to Big Ten's Preseason Players to Watch List
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
A trio of Nittany Lions earned some preseason recognition from the Big Ten.

The conference released its players to watch list, with Michael Anderson, Colin Fitzgerald and Bryce Molinaro all being named.

Anderson is one of several transfers who fill up the infield this season for Penn State. The Havertown, Pennsylvania, native spent two seasons at Rhode Island and the 2025 campaign at Arkansas. The senior accumulated a .282 average, 105 hits, 23 home runs and 84 RBI over three seasons.

Fitzgerald is another transfer who bolsters the pitching staff after Ryan DeSanto left for MLB. The redshirt senior spent three years at Maine, and posted a 6.11 ERA, with 171 strikeouts, 232 hits and 101 walks.

Molinaro is the lone returner in the infield after multiple players from last season are now gone. In his two seasons, the redshirt junior batted a .296 average with 128 hits, 24 home runs and 106 RBI. The Drums, Pennsylvania, native is key to the blue and white's offensive success this season.

Penn State's 2026 campaign begins this weekend at the MLB Desert Invitational, with its first game against Air Force at 8 p.m. on Friday.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's hockey forward Alex Servagno underwent surgery, ruled out rest of regular season
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another Penn State player sustained a season-ending injury.

Forward Alex Servagno underwent surgery, ending his year, coach Guy Gadowsky said to the media on Wednesday.

Servagno has appeared in eight games this season, tallying one shot on goal and a negative-three net rating.

The senior spent most of his playing time this year as an extra skater, but with all the injuries Penn State has faced, Servagno has earned significantly more playing time than expected.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Guy Gadowsky confirms Gavin McKenna's status before weekend series against No. 2 Michigan
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Gavin McKenna, who last week was charged with felony assault before the charges were later dropped, will play this weekend when No. 6 Penn State travels to No. 2 Michigan, coach Guy Gadowsky said Wednesday.

“Gavin will participate in all, and continue to participate in all, athletically related activities. But regarding that, I also hope you understand it's an ongoing legal thing, so (it’s) inappropriate for me to comment (further) on that.”

McKenna was arraigned and released on $20,000 unsecured bail following an altercation last Saturday outside of Doggie’s Pub in State College. According to documents released by the State College Police Department, the freshman forward reportedly twice struck a 21-year-old in the face, which caused the victim to require corrective surgery on his broken jaw.

Penn State Athletics released a statement last Sunday acknowledging the charges but declined to comment on an ongoing legal matter. McKenna's court date, which was originally scheduled for Wednesday, was rescheduled to March 11 — the first day of the Big Ten Tournament.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: 2 Penn State men's lacrosse players named to Tewaarton Award watch list
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Hunter Aquino and Alex Ross have earned a high honor.

The two Nittany Lions were named to the Tewaaraton Award watch list, an award given annually to the most outstanding men's lacrosse player.

Major recognition early in the season 👀 pic.twitter.com/fNyOmk5Hxo— Penn State Men’s Lacrosse (@PennStateMLAX) February 10, 2026
