Aquino is coming off a solid first year at Penn State in which he was named the Big Ten Freshman of the Year with 16 goals and 21 assists. He has seven goals and three assists in two games so far this season.

Ross, meanwhile, is a senior defenseman who was named a preseason All-American by Inside Lacrosse.

Both are pivotal pieces to Penn State, which currently sits at 1-1 after an upset loss to Villanova in overtime last Saturday.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Cael Sanderson previews Ohio State, updates status of wrestlers
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
For the final time in the regular season, Penn State will wrestle in the Bryce Jordan Center, and it’s the biggest matchup of the season.

The No. 1 Nittany Lions will wrestle No. 2 Ohio State at 7 p.m. on Friday in a battle of two undefeated squads.

Here’s what Cael Sanderson said at his weekly media availability ahead of the dual.

Ohio State

In November, Buckeyes’ head coach Tom Ryan called out Penn State for not wrestling at the National Duals invitational, saying how it was a “shame” and it’s a “bit of a sign of how they see things and do things.”

Sanderson wasn’t asked about Ryan’s comments earlier this year, only offering his thoughts about the national duals, saying how it wasn’t really a consideration for the Nittany Lions to wrestle it. On Wednesday, however, he offered praise for Ryan and his team.

“Ohio State's always a great program. Coach Ryan's done a phenomenal job, very consistent every year,” Sanderson said. “They're the title contender and they have an awesome program all the way around. We're excited to compete against a very good team up and down the lineup.”

Despite the highly anticipated matchup, the mindset is still the same for Penn State, whether it’s Ohio State or the looming postseason.

“It's pretty much the same energy in here, year-round, and same perspective,” Sanderson said. “Your next match always seems like a big match, and it is always the most important match, but it's going to come and go quickly and we're going to be on to the next one. So it's more about development, being who we want to be, and then making sure we're training in the right direction.”

Rocco Welsh

Two years ago, Rocco Welsh was taking the mat for his freshman season as a Buckeye. During that campaign, he lost to former Nittany Lion Carter Starocci in the 174-pound national title matchup.

After redshirting the following year, Welsh transferred to Penn State and is currently the No. 1 wrestler at 184 pounds. On Friday, the Pennsylvania native will face his former team.

“We recruited Rocco. He committed pretty early in the process. (Pennsylvania) kid, I mean, he's pretty similar,” Sanderson said of Welsh from when he recruited him to where he is now. “He's a hammer, tough (Pennsylvania) kid. Just consistent, tough wrestling with a lot of events. Shows he loves wrestling.I think like anyone that has high aim and high goals that are coachable, they're going to keep getting better, but he was pretty stinking good in high school.”

As far as facing his former team? Sanderson inferred that Welsh isn’t concerned.

“He’s a Penn State wrestler and part of the family. He’s good,” Sanderson said.

141 pounds

The week after Braeden Davis lost to Brock Hardy of Nebraska, Sanderson told the media Davis “burned” his hand leading up to the matchup in an injury related to a “plugged-in scooter.”

This past weekend, Davis was inactive against Michigan, with Nate Desmond filling in for him.

“We couldn’t wrestle Davis last week, he had a skin issue last week, so Desmond was ready to go and he stepped up and did a great job,” Sanderson said.

The skin issue was unrelated to the burning of his hand, as Sanderson called it “something different.” After missing the dual against the Wolverines, Sanderson implied that Davis will be the starter against Ohio State.

“He’s going to give his best effort and go compete hard,” Sanderson said. “He’s shown what he’s capable of. We have to keep inching along and he’s going to be ready to rock here at the end.”

Mitchell Mesenbrink

Sanderson couldn’t really tell what happened during Mitchell Mesenbrink’s matchup against Michigan. All he saw was him and his opponent, Justin Gates, “flying around with elbows and knees.”

“He got hit pretty good and got a pretty, pretty nasty cut,” Sanderson said. “And to his credit, was able to just keep his composure and go get that next takedown and win the match.”

Mesenbrink ended up with a 20-5 victory over Gates. Despite the brutal blow, there was no concern from Sanderson as far as his status moving forward.

“You have to be careful with it. Obviously, they have face masks you can wear and kind of hope that it will take care of it,” Sanderson said. But, at the end of the day, it is what it is. You got to go forward.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse carries momentum into dominant win over UMass
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State opened the season with a victory over Richmond last year, kickstarting the Kayla Treanor era in Happy Valley.

On Wednesday afternoon, that momentum continued as the Nittany Lions defeated UMass 17-9 inside Holuba Hall.

After a pair of freshmen took the starting lineup on Saturday, only four-star attacker Rocquette Allen earned that spot against the Minutewomen.

The Nittany Lions weren’t messing around as things got underway Wednesday afternoon, as Julia Basciano forced an early turnover, giving fellow transfer Anna Salerno a shot at the net. After her first shot attempt was high, Salerno capitalized on her second goal of the season.

Over the next three minutes, Penn State went 3-for-3 shooting, as Kelly MacKinney, Erika Ho and Allen each extended its lead.

During that stretch, the Minutewomen struggled to get anything going offensively with three shots — only one on goal.

After a quieter, four-minute period where the Nittany Lions didn’t score, the action picked right back up as MacKinney put No. 2 of the day in the back of the net, putting the blue and white up by five.

Allen’s freshman year success continued as she recorded her fourth goal in two games with an assist from the recent Tewaaraton award nominee Erika Ho.

The Nittany Lions took a dominant 6-0 lead into the second quarter, which was quickly extended by a goal from Emma Kelly less than a minute into the period.

The Minutewomen entered a man-down situation after both Katie Onderdonk and Katie Peterson were issued green cards, which Allen capitalized on with her third goal of the game as she moved to the team’s leading goal scorer.

Both sides exchanged fire through the middle of the second quarter, but it was Penn State that came out again in the winning column as Ho recorded goal No. 2 of the day.

After 17 minutes of silence from UMass’ offense, Brigid Manning scored the team’s first goal after a yellow card on Susannah O’Connell. However, Penn State’s offense kept swinging and scored its 10th goal of the game off a shot from Delaney Radin.

UMass came out of the break with a bit of momentum, scoring on its first shot from Oderdonk. It scored its second straight goal six minutes later, before Allen pushed Penn State’s lead back to eight points.

Both teams exchanged goals again within just a minute of each other, as MacKinney earned her first hat trick of the season. After a foul on UMass’ Lil Hancock, Ho recorded a hat trick, as she capitalized on the free position shot.

However, the Minutewomen continued the Happy Valley shootout as Ava Connaughton trimmed the deficit, followed by another goal from Brigid Welch.

After five goals from UMass in the third quarter, the Nittany Lions took control of the fourth quarter with another goal from Radin, assisted by Ho. However, that was quickly matched by another free-position goal from the Minutewomen.

Following a foul from UMass’ Marisa Gatz, Salerno tabbed her second goal of the day, off a free position goal. Less than two minutes later, Allen scored her fifth goal of the day and seventh on the season, to make the score 16-7.

UMass added another two goals down the final stretch — capped off with another Penn State goal — as the Nittany Lions rode to the victory column for the second straight game.

Up next

The Nittany Lions stay home and will take on Bucknell at 11 a.m. on Sunday. The Bison are 1-0 to start the year and have a matchup against UMBC before taking on Penn State.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions around the nations | Penn State wrestling connections have eventful weekend
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Penn State didn’t just have 10 wrestlers compete against Michigan on Friday, but also had ties to many other events happening around the world.

The Zagreb Open, state championships and collegiate dual seasons headlined the Nittany Lions’ competing not just around the nation, but around the world.

Zagreb Open

The Zagreb Open had two Nittany Lion Wrestling Club members compete. Current Penn State wrestler Tyler Kasak, representing the USA, continuing his freestyle season while redshirting the collegiate season. He was joined by NLWC member Roman Bravo-Young.

Bravo-Young returned to the NLWC after wrestling under the Cowboy Wrestling Club with Oklahoma State. Representing Mexico, Bravo-Young kicked off the open with a victory over India’s Atish Todkar at 57 kilograms.

It appeared as if Bravo-Young and Olympic silver medalist, Spencer Lee, were on a collision course to the finals after Bravo-Young’s 12-2 victory over USA’s Anthony Knox. He made it into the finals to face Lee with a 10-0 win over Iran’s Milad Jahangir Valizadeh.

With a highly anticipated matchup with Lee, it ended quickly with Bravo-Young having to injury default partway through the match. He ended with a second-place finish.

Kasak competed at 70 kilograms, wrestling Austria’s Alexander Seiwald in the first round. He dominated with an 11-0 victory before falling in his next match to India’s Abhimanyou Abhimanyou 10-0. Kasak’s journey came to an end there, not earning a spot in the repechage.

High school state championships

With high school seasons quickly coming to an end, Penn State commits are in the midst of postseason competition. Clinton Shepherd competed in the IHSAA Regional Tournament in Indiana. Shepherd rolled through his competition at 150 pounds, winning by fall in 1:21, an 18-2 tech fall in 1:28 and a fall in the finals in just 20 seconds. He’s listed as the No. 8 recruit in the 2027 class per FloWrestling and the second-highest rated Penn State commit.

In Pennsylvania, Landon Sidun competed in the 3A PIAA State Championship Duals. Sidun, a part of Norwin’s program, defeated his first opponent by fall in just 24 seconds. Norwin won once again in the semifinals, this time against Council Rock South. He wrestled up to 127 pounds, from his usual 121 pound spot, and won by tech fall in 2:16.

Sidun and Norwin faced fellow WPIAL high school, Franklin Regional, losing 29-24. Sidun earned his team six points, winning by forfeit as Franklin Regional didn’t put a wrestler against the No. 2 prospect in the 2027 class.

Also in the 3A bracket was State High, and 2027 commit James Whitbred. The future Nittany Lion won by tech fall over Franklin Regional’s Jordan Perks at 160 pounds.

Similar to Sidun, Whitbred wrestled in a different class in the second match, wrestling at 152, except State High was in the consolations. Once again, Whitbred won by tech fall despite his school’s loss.

The two Pennsylvania wrestlers will compete in the individual tournaments that end in March in Hershey, Pennsylvania.

Transfers

Just one of the three Penn State transfers who are now with former Nittany Lion David Taylor at Oklahoma State competed in the Cowboys’ dual against Little Rock. No. 7 Alex Facundo at 174 pounds won by fall against unranked Bronson Baxter.

Facundo has bounced back from a rough first couple weeks of the season, holding a 13-4 record on the year.

No. 12 David Evans at 149 pounds also competed over the weekend. He faced an unranked Devon Harrison in Utah Valley’s dual against North Dakota State. He won by tech fall, 18-3, as the clock hit seven minutes.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: ‘They’re going to keep fighting’ | Penn State softball finds success behind Rocky Balboa mindset
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Before its season began, Penn State went on a team retreat to Philadelphia, and used it as a moment to be together as a team without worrying about softball.

“When you have moments with your squad where it’s literally just enjoying each other's company and not having to talk about softball,” coach Clarisa Crowell said in Wednesday’s media session. “I think that trip really just helped us grow together and build relationships.”

Perhaps the biggest takeaway from the team's trip was their inspiration from the Rocky franchise.

“They just really bought into the story of Rocky, in the state of Pennsylvania, especially in Philadelphia, Rocky is like a real person,” Crowell said. “He was just a blue-collar, tough, gritty guy, which is honestly the makeup of our team, and how our team has won here at Penn State.”

Winning is what the Nittany Lions did in their opening weekend, going 4-1, and showed their grittiness by battling out two extra-inning victories.

Penn State showed its toughness and fighting edge in all aspects of the game. At the plate, the Nittany Lions posted a .441 team slugging percentage. Additionally, five players finished the weekend with a .250-plus batting average.

The blue and white also showed how it can get things done in the circle, after going five arms deep in its rotation. The staff posted a 1.46 ERA and combined for 42 strikeouts.

“This year we’re going to win games because we’re going to be well-balanced,” Crowell said. “There are going to be games where it’s going to have to be pitching and defense, and there’s going to be games where we’re going to have to rely on the bats.”

To keep the Rocky theme that Penn State has embodied, in Rocky IV, the Italian Stallion takes on Russian Ivan Drago on Christmas Day in 1985. Rocky was a severe underdog heading to face Drago on his home turf in Moscow.

For the first six rounds or so, the match is all Drago, and it looks like Rocky will go down without an easy fight, but then the Pride of Philadelphia finds his momentum as Drago starts to wear down.

Rocky never stops fighting and takes Drago to 15 rounds and comes up with the improbable underdog victory, without ever giving up.

Now consider Penn State’s eight-inning victory over BYU. After three innings, the blue and white had just one hit as opposed to the Cougars’ four, and found themselves down 2-0.

Penn State continued to struggle offensively. Heading into the seventh inning, BYU held a 3-1 lead and out-hit the Nittany Lions 7-5. However, Penn State never stopped fighting and recorded two hits and two runs to send the game to extras.

The Nittany Lions ultimately broke through in the eighth inning with an RBI single from Kirsten Finarelli to win the game.

“No matter what the score is, they’re going to keep fighting to the end,” Crowell said.

It’s not just Rocky’s mindset that the team is bringing to the dugout, but they’ve got all the props to go along with it.

“When they hit home runs, one game they’re putting the Rocky gloves over the neck, then one game they’re putting on the robe,” Crowell said. “We ended up in a gift shop, and everybody was buying Rocky stuff.”

It’s safe to say Penn State will always have a piece of Rocky Balboa in its dugout, both mentally and physically, as they carry on the rest of the season.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball picks up 2nd Big Ten win of season with victory over Washington
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State entered this week with just one Big Ten win this season, but that’s changed after Wednesday night.

The Nittany Lions earned a 63-60 win over Washington inside Alaska Airlines Arena in Seattle, improving to 11-14 on the year and 2-12 in Big Ten play. It was a close game throughout that featured 15 lead changes and nine ties.

Penn State had a halftime lead in a Big Ten game for the fourth time this season, holding a 35-32 advantage at the break. Following an early 10-0 run by the Nittany Lions, both teams were battling as neither squad could pull away from the other.

The two teams were attacking the paint in the first half, with both teams scoring 20 points in the paint. Guard Freddie Dilione V made back-to-back baskets before guard Melih Tunca knocked down a turnaround jumper, which gave Penn State a six-point lead, but guard Quimari Peterson drained a key 3-pointer late to put Washington down by just one possession at halftime.

Coming out of the break, Penn State managed to build a 47-41 lead behind a pair of 3-pointers by forward Josh Reed. Wing Eli Rice, who returned from a two-game absence due to injury, also made a jumper to give the Nittany Lions their six-point advantage.

However, Penn State went on a four-minute stretch in which it didn’t make a field goal, allowing Washington to retake the lead, 49-48. The field-goal drought continued for over six minutes as forward Hannes Steinbach knocked down a triple to give the Huskies a 54-51 advantage.

Dilione pulled the Nittany Lions out of its cold streak with two baskets, guard Kayden Mingo followed it up with a layup as Penn State remained knotted with Washington, 57-57, with 3:07 left. As the two teams kept battling, Mingo made a tough basket in the paint via a goaltending call to give Penn State a 61-59 lead with 1:21 remaining.

The Nittany Lions’ defense got a key stop on the ensuing defensive possession, but weren’t able to build on their lead. Steinbach drew a foul for the Huskies, though he went 1-of-2 at the line as his squad remained down by one point.

Rice was fouled on the inbounds pass, and he went 2-of-2 on his free throws. Penn State got another stop on the defensive end, but Reed turned the ball over on the ensuing inbounds pass.

The defense got one more stop with Peterson and guard Wesley Yates III both missing a 3-pointer in the waning seconds that clinched the victory for the Nittany Lions.

Dilione ended up pacing Penn State, tallying a team-high 16 points on 7-of-14 shooting. Reed, Mingo and Rice were all in double figures as well with 14, 13 and 12 points, respectively.

As a whole, the Nittany Lions shot 48.1% from the field and 38.5% from 3-point range. Washington was less efficient at 37.7% shooting from the field and 33.3% shooting from 3-point range, but it had 15 second-chance points.

Steinbach led the Huskies with 19 points and 14 rebounds, while Yates had 11 points on 5-of-15 shooting from the field. Washington won the rebound battle 37 to 31, and it had 14 offensive boards.

Injury report

Forward Saša Ciani was listed as “questionable” on the pregame availability report. He ended up playing, first subbing in at the 13:44 mark of the second half and ending a four-game absence due to an ankle injury.

Forward Tibor Mirtič remained listed as “out” for Wednesday’s matchup against Washington.

Mirtič first picked up a knee injury in the Michigan game on Jan. 6. During his first practice back from that injury, he injured his shoulder, which has kept him out since the Northwestern game on Jan. 29.

Up next

Penn State will stay on the West Coast for the rest of this week as it’ll visit Oregon at 3 p.m. ET Saturday inside Matthew Knight Arena in Eugene, Oregon, aired on the Big Ten Network. The Ducks are 8-16 on the year and 1-12 in Big Ten play, including a current 10-game losing streak.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: NFL Scouting Combine invites 9 Penn State players
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Nine Penn State players are set to showcase their talents in front of NFL scouts.

The NFL Scouting Combine invited quarterback Drew Allar, running back Nick Singleton, running back Kaytron Allen, tight end Khalil Dinkins, left guard Vega Ioane, left tackle Drew Shelton, defensive end Dani Dennis-Sutton, defensive tackle Zane Durant and safety Zakee Wheatley to participate in the event, which lasts from Feb. 23-March 2 inside Lucas Oil Stadium in Indianapolis.

319 prospects invited to 2026 NFL Scouting Combine.https://t.co/YOakXu8d7q pic.twitter.com/uwEMPiOTk9— NFL Draft (@NFLDraft) February 11, 2026

Allar is one of 15 gunslingers who will be featured in the combine. He threw for 1,100 yards, eight touchdowns and three interceptions this past season before enduring a season-ending injury after six games.

Singleton broke his foot during a practice at the Senior Bowl in January. Prior to his injury, he set Penn State's all-time touchdown record with 55 career scores.

Allen reset the record book as well with 4,180 career rushing yards. He had 1,303 rushing yards this past season, including a 226-yard game against Rutgers, and was named to the AP All-America third team.

Dinkins started nine games for the Nittany Lions in 2025, and he totaled 37 catches for 399 yards and seven touchdowns in his career.

Ioane and Shelton both anchored the left side of the offensive line last season. Ioane earned second-team AP All-America honors while Shelton started all 11 games he played.

Dennis-Sutton notably didn't opt out of the Pinstripe Bowl, where he tallied four tackles and two sacks. It capped off a season that saw him earn third-team All-Big Ten honors.

Wheatley and Durant were both All-Big Ten honorable mentions in 2025. Wheatley racked up 74 tackles, a pass breakup and an interceptions while Durant totaled 25 tackles, 4.5 tackles for loss and four sacks.

The mark is a leap from the five invitees last season, though under the 10 players invited to the combine in 2024.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘I commend Josh Reed’ | Mike Rhoades praises Josh Reed’s versatility with Penn State
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Josh Reed is listed as a forward on Penn State’s roster, but he’s played more than just one position this season.

Most notably, Reed recently saw action at center due to numerous injuries in the frontcourt. But it hasn’t mattered where Reed plays on the floor lately — he’s scored in double figures the past eight games as he’s having a career year.

“I commend Josh Reed for playing multiple positions all year long at 30-40 pounds out of position,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “Giving up that weight and then playing 30, sometimes 35 minutes plus. He's been battling, and he's had a great year, battling and getting better as the year went on.”

Reed transferred to Penn State for his last season of collegiate eligibility after three years with Cincinnati. He’s been a regular in the starting lineup, averaging a career-high 10.5 points per game along with a personal best of 50.9% shooting from the field across 24 appearances.

The Atlanta native was a rotational player during his time with the Bearcats. He never averaged more than 4.8 points per game or shot better than 41% from the field, highlighting the jump in production he’s taken in Happy Valley.

On the glass, Reed is averaging a career-high 3.9 rebounds per game, which is the second most on the team behind 7-footer Ivan Jurić. He has 29 offensive rebounds this season, as guard Freddie Dilione V noted Reed’s ability to create extra possessions after he tallied 13 points and 10 rebounds in a 74-72 loss to No. 2 Michigan on Jan. 6.

Reed’s latest performance saw him total 17 points and four rebounds with 8-of-11 shooting from the field and 1-of-3 shooting from 3-point range in a 77-75 loss to USC on Sunday. He was one of three Penn State players with a positive point differential, finishing at +1 across 37 minutes played.

“Just trying to play confident and aggressive,” Reed said postgame. “I know how my coaches and my teammates have stressed they believe in me. I just want to win, so come out there and play aggressive and confident, and my teammates make me better as well.”

The Nittany Lions’ recent slew of injuries is beginning to subside, with Jurić already back and wing Eli Rice's return to action imminent. But there were two games where Jurić, forward Saša Ciani and forward Tibor Mirtič all missed, forcing Reed to play center out of “necessity,” Rhoades said.

Particularly in the Minnesota game on Feb. 1, Reed, who’s listed at 6-foot-8 and 230 pounds, started at center and played 35 minutes. He helped guide Penn State to a 77-75 victory after logging 18 points and four rebounds with 6-of-10 shooting from the field and 4-of-5 shooting from 3-point range.

“It was actually pretty fun getting to play the center spot,” Reed said following the win on Feb. 3. “I feel like the way we played was a little bit different. I feel like that helped us … it was definitely fun doing that — something I've never done before.”

The small-ball lineup with Reed starting at center was in action again when the Nittany Lions faced the Wolverines on Feb. 5, but Michigan’s talented frontcourt with players like 7-foot-3 center Aday Mara made it difficult to find any success. Penn State lost 110-69, which prompted Rhoades to say his team was “undermanned” postgame.

Over the Nittany Lions’ last five games, Reed’s been the team’s center 27% of the time, according to KenPom. Moving forward, Rhoades mentioned the issues with using a small-ball lineup in the Big Ten due to the size in the conference, but it’s possible to “get away with it here and there.”

If Reed continues to be a versatile player and gets more time at the five as the season goes on, he feels Penn State’s offense could create mismatches.

“I just felt like we were able to do some different things out there that we normally don't do,” Reed said on Feb. 3. “When I'm setting a screen for Kayden (Mingo) or Freddie, they get the five-man on them, and then I get the one or two-man on me. I feel like we use those to our advantage.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Professionals, students discuss gaps in sexual education
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Many students come to college and experience their first bouts of freedom, which allows them to explore their beliefs and perspectives absent of familial influence. For many, it’s at the collegiate level where they form firm views on sex and relationships.

Carmelita Whitfield, University Health Services’s associate director of community health, said talking about sexual education is important to ensuring that people, even at a young age, have the knowledge and resources to prevent the possibility of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as well as unplanned pregnancies.

She said open discussions with family members and relatives allow children to feel more comfortable asking questions.

Whitfield also said the lack of a nationwide policy ensuring comprehensive sexual education is taught across the United States, as well as a sense of discomfort from instructors to broach the subject, has left some students at a disadvantage.

“There are a lot of cultural taboos (and) there's a culture of silence that we also talk about, like, ‘If I don't say anything, then I'll just know or I'll ask my friend,’ but if you think about it, our friends are our age so what do they know and where are they getting their information?” Whitfield said. “Teachers are often uncomfortable. They can teach you the basics but they don't have the bandwidth to talk about, perhaps, sexual assault or gender identity and that's why it is so important that when you're doing this work that you are well-rounded and well-versed.”

Anne Pallozzi said her views on sex were largely influenced by discussions with her parents.

“I have a very open relationship with my parents so we've had these conversations and I was raised with two loving parents so my views didn't change,” Pallozzi, a second-year studying biology, said.

On the contrary, Joseph Galo said he didn’t begin learning about sexual education until middle school due to his parents not discussing it with him beforehand.

“We didn't really learn anything up until that point but I'm pretty sure we had the class and the talk where we talked about it in fifth grade, I think,” Galo, a second-year studying electrical engineering, said. “I guess people could be on the internet but, I mean, my parents didn't say nothing to me until that point.”

He said his sexual education during that time was limited to discussing basic topics and answering questions a “typical middle schooler could have.”

Kendall Thomas said her sexual education was often rooted in fears that stuck with her as she entered college.

“I am already overly cautious in that particular area in the first place and we did talk about sexual violence a lot in my school … so I would just say that, from the get-go, I already looked at it from a cautious standpoint so now, coming to college and it being like a hub for just chlamydia and a whole bunch of germs and other things, I've already just like, ‘Yeah, I'm good,’” Thomas, a second-year studying art history, said.

Jason Burney said Penn State should do more to promote sexual education resources through social media and in high-traffic areas on campus.

“I don't think we hear it enough, I would say, " Burney, a second-year studying finance, said. “I think we're mature enough to know about these things ‘cause a lot of people are being intimate in college as their first time.”

Izzy Roberti agrees with Burney that Penn State needs to improve its efforts when it comes to making students aware of sexual health resources on campus.

“I was in this class that was teaching philosophy of pacifism and we had a day where someone came in and she talked about various mental health resources and she had a segment specifically about resources for sexual violence or if you are part of the LGBTQ community, where you can go and feel safe,” Roberti, a first-year studying history and philosophy, said. “I feel like I've been made pretty aware of the services we have on campus, but I would not say it's a very outward thing that we talk about.”

Whitfield said disparities in sexual education greatly impact groups such as the LGBTQ+ community who may not have access to care specialized to their needs.

“If you're transitioning, you're going to need that level of care that, say, someone who is just coming in for regular birth control may not really need,” Whitfield said.

She said it’s important for there to be a wide range of sexual education resources available on and off-campus as it empowers individuals to make their own decision in regards to their sexual health.

“Sex-ed, honestly, is more than just biology. It's just teaching individuals really how to set boundaries and respect the boundaries of themselves as well as others,” Whitfield said. “A ‘no’ doesn't necessarily mean a ‘no’ forever. It could just mean a ‘no’ for right now but you got to learn to respect the ‘no.’”

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: How intimacy shapes college relationships
author: Skylar Williamson I The Daily Collegian
description:
For many college students, intimacy is often viewed as a narrow idea: dating, hook-ups or relationships. In reality, intimacy in college relationships looks different for everyone.

Whether it’s opening up emotionally to someone you trust or navigating becoming physically close to a new partner, college should be a time where people begin to understand their definition of intimacy.

Intimacy generally falls into two different categories: emotional or physical. Emotional intimacy involves trust, vulnerability and communication, whereas physical intimacy focuses on touch, affection and sex.

In college relationships, however, the environment can play a huge role in what type of intimacy is most prevalent. Busy schedules, social pressure, alcohol and evolving personal identities all play a factor in how intimacy is reflected.

For Brooke Benevento, who is interested in becoming a sex therapist, relationships should involve both emotional and physical intimacy. She thinks emotional security is the first step to a healthy long-term connection.

“When people truly feel safe, they can share their thoughts, boundaries and desires openly, which creates a stronger, healthier connection,” Benevento, a fourth-year studying rehabilitation and human services, said. “In my experience, whether a relationship is new or long-term, prioritizing clarity and security sets the tone for everything that follows, making all forms of intimacy more meaningful and fulfilling."

On college campuses, experimentation with intimacy is normal. With this level of trial and error, Benevento said college connections can lean towards prioritizing physical rather than emotional intimacy.

“Dating apps and hook-up culture make connections fast and convenient, but they can also discourage people from being intentional and authentic,” Benevento said. “College intimacy can be intense and meaningful, but it often requires extra effort to sustain emotional depth.”

As hook-up culture and quick physical connections are becoming more popular for young adults on college campuses, some students are starting to breakaway from that stigma.

Mark Kormos said many students on campus are letting go of “hook-up culture” and constant physical intimacy for something deeper.

“We are all broken and seeking to be healed,” Kormos, a third-year studying economics, said. “Sometimes we think that physical pleasure will help us with that, but eventually the pleasure wears off and we remain broken.”

Kormos said students are finding more meaningful ways to fill their time, hoping that later leads them to building strong emotional connections.

“When we find healing — possibly through prayer, meditation, friends, social groups or clubs — we then see more clearly what physical pleasure could never do,” Kormos said.

Although everyone’s version of intimacy may look different, the root of both is communication through partners. In college relationships, communication can be strained.

Dr. Autumn Keefer, a couples therapy coordinator on campus, said there are several problems she commonly sees with couples. She said seeking out solutions can be beneficial whether it's in a college relationship or not.

“Common presenting problems for couples seeking counseling include escalating conflict, infidelity, communication problems, negative interactional patterns and sexual or intimacy challenges,” Keefer said. “Addressing concerns earlier rather than later has been found significant in positively impacting relationship communication, intimacy and satisfaction.”

Ultimately, intimacy in college is deeply personal. Some students prioritize emotional closeness, while others feel more comfortable exploring physical intimacy, and some students fall somewhere in between.

College is a time where exploring intimacy is encouraged, and no answer is the right one. In an environment where comparison and assumptions are easy to make, understanding intimacy is not one-size-fits-all can be freeing.

“At the core, everyone wants to feel valued, desired and emotionally safe,” Benevento said. “Seeing both sides has made me more aware of how different environments shape the way people approach relationships.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Penn State women’s basketball travels to Maryland amidst hunt for Big Ten Tournament
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After going 1-1 last week, Penn State is back on the road with five games left on the year.

The Lady Lions travel to College Park for a matchup with No. 20 Maryland at 7 p.m. on Thursday.

Penn State has some recent history off the court with Maryland, after acquiring Ann Meyer Drysdale Award Winner Ashley Owusu from the Terrapins in 2023 and almost losing Gracie Merkle to them last offseason.

All-time matchups

Maryland is one of the few Big Ten teams against which the Lady Lions have a losing record, sitting at just 16-22 all-time.

The blue and white have struggled recently, losing 15 of its last 16 matchups to the Terrapins, including an 82-73 loss at home last season in the Return to Rec game. It was the Merkle and Gabby Elliott show, as the pair combined for 47 points.

Prior to the rough stretch, the Lady Lions held a dominant six-game win streak from 1998 to 2003, winning four of the games by a double-digit margin. Penn State’s last victory came on Jan. 28, 2024, when it beat Maryland 112-76. Makenna Marisa scored 24 points, while Owusu tabbed 16 against her former team.

2025-26 Maryland

Maryland was one of the last undefeated teams in the nation, winning 14 straight games.

On New Year’s Day, that changed, as it fell in a three-point nail biter to Illinois. Since then, the Terrapins have fallen to No. 19 Ohio State and endured a four-game losing streak to UCLA, Iowa, Washington and Oregon.

After losing Merkle in the portal, coach Brenda Frese added 6-foot-3 Indiana transfer Yarden Garzon to the squad.

Despite sitting second on the team in scoring, the Ra'anana, Israel, native leads the conference in made 3-pointers. Garzon recorded 69 baskets from behind the arc, which ranks tied for 15th in school history with five games left on the year.

Garzon has been a big part in the team’s recent success, scoring 27 points in the team’s defeats of No. 12 Michigan State and Nebraska over the past two weeks.

Thursday’s matchup

Penn State’s biggest problem heading into Thursday’s matchup is junior guard Oluchi Okananwa, who leads the Terrapins with 17.2 points per game.

In addition to her scoring success, the 5-foot-10 guard is also a dominant rebounder, leading the team with 76 offensive rebounds, the third-most in the conference.

While Kiyomi McMiller doesn't share the offensive rebounding capabilities of Okananwa, her flashy scoring will likely create a skirmish on the scoreboards between the two. McMiller leads the Lady Lions with 20.2 points per game and scored 14 last year against Maryland when suiting up with Rutgers.

Thursday night will likely be a battle of those two leading scorers and which supporting cast can generate the strongest attack.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: What to watch at the State Theatre this February
author: Talia Rittenhouse | The Daily Collegian
description:
Who doesn’t need popcorn and a movie every once in a while?

State College has its own theatre where you can see movies throughout the week, a hidden gem that provides great entertainment for students and the surrounding community.

The State Theatre has many movies coming up, some can serve as an activity for Valentine’s Day, and others for the days when you have a night free of work and meetings.

With the wintery temperatures, many students stay in their homes and watch shows and movies with friends, but why not change the scenery and have a fun time out doing the same?

“When Harry Met Sally”

The State Theatre is showing this classic romantic comedy on Valentine’s Day this Saturday — it’s almost too perfect not to spend the night here.

Whether you have a Valentine this year or not, this movie is great for the occasion, as a couple or as a group of friends.

Girls can have a wholesome Galentine’s day with friends and go see this movie, blushing over Harry and Sally’s relationship.

You can cry and laugh at all the right times and create memories with your friends simultaneously.

“Casablanca”

It’s time to go back in time to where the movies were black-and-white and stored on a VHS tape. You can see “Casablanca” in the State Theatre on Saturday.

This movie was an all-time favorite of my grandfather’s, and holds a special place in my heart for that reason.

The love Rick and Ilsa share makes this movie perfect for Valentine’s Day. This movie depicts their longing and love for one another and is a strong representation of romance in a time of hurt and violence.

Set during World War II, Rick’s Café Américain is a prominent location in the film, where many scenes unfold and the plot thickens.

“Crazy Rich Asians”

The most classic airplane movie of our generation is taking a flight right to our local State Theatre on Monday, Feb. 16.

No matter how many times you watch this movie, it just keeps getting better and better. The elegant wedding, Rachel trying on millions of dresses, the proposal, everything about it is just great.

The comedy in this movie makes it even better, and the one-liners still remain as inside jokes with my mother and I to this day.

“Crazy Rich Asians” is one of those fictional movies that you know isn’t a true story, but you still connect with so many characters through their experiences navigating family dysfunction, love and friendships.

“The Breakfast Club”

No movie can ever beat the quality and storyline of an 80s classic.

Oh, to have been a teenager when this movie first aired. “The Breakfast Club” captures the hardships and real experiences that a group of students, just like us, face in early adulthood.

The way the characters come together in detention, after normally not crossing paths and coming out so bonded, is very moving and heartwarming to see as a Penn State student.

It’s not all fluff and fun as there are deep, meaningful conversations that show viewers the reality of life and how to support one another in times of hurt.

That all being said, trust me when I say, buy your ticket now to see “The Breakfast Club” on Tuesday, Feb. 17.

“The Shining”

“Here’s Johnny!”

If you don’t enjoy romantic comedies, you can change up the genre by seeing “The Shining” later this month on Feb. 27.

The State Theatre must be on an 80s kick with the variety of movies they’re showing. “The Shining,” written by Stephen King, is a must-see horror movie if you want to be considered a movie fanatic — it’s a mandatory experience.

To those who haven’t experienced the thrill of seeing the twins at the end of the hallway, consider your ticket to the State Theatre purchased.

If these movies are not your forte, there are many other options for you to see at the State Theatre this month with genres ranging from fantasy, comedy and more.

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Big Ten Recap | Conference squads begin to separate in standings with postseason a month away
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
There is about a month until the Big Ten basketball tournament, and the conference already appears to be in postseason form.

The excitement for the tournament is palpable: for the first time, all conference teams make the postseason under the 18-team format, meaning the standings matter only for seeding, not participation.

In the last week of play, there’s been some massive shakeups in those seedings as some squads made last-minute statements before the Big Ten heads to Chicago.

Outstanding Overtimes

Saturday was one of the best single days in basketball ever; only one of the five matchups wasn’t decided within two possessions — highlighted by a pair of overtime thrillers.

Wisconsin kicked off the action on the day with a one-point defeat at the hands of Indiana.

Hoosiers star forward, Lamar Wilkerson, decided the game at the foul line, as his normally slick three-point shot failed to show up, he’d built a house with all his bricks from behind the arc, finishing 1-of-8.

Although Wilkerson still got his buckets, with a team-high 25 points, he also added four assists. It was the Badgers’ star forward, Nolan Winter, who stole the spotlight, edging out Wilkerson with 26 points on the night, shooting 9-of-13.

It wasn’t Winter who got the final shot for Wisconsin, however, as guard Braeden Carrington hucked up a three that didn’t fall. It was a questionable decision to put the ball in the senior’s hands. Carrington shoots 40.5% on the year and shot below that figure in his last four outings, including the clash against the Hoosiers.

With this win and a blowout against Oregon on Monday, in which Wilkerson posted a 41-point performance, Indiana narrowed the gap on the Badgers in the standings.

The top of the Big Ten standings also saw an overtime contest narrow the gap when, on Saturday, Michigan State upset Illinois, with the Fighting Illini unable to mount a late-game comeback against the Spartans.

Guard Jeremy Fears Jr. led the green and white’s effort in a bounce-back 26 point performance after the sophomore had a down performance against Minnesota on Wednesday. In the same game he received criticism for his polarizing backwards groin kick of a Golden Gophers defender.

In the standings, only one game now separates the Fighting Illini and Spartans for the third spot in the conference, pending results for Nebraska’s next game.

Marquee Moments

While not every game needed extra time to decide, there were still some close contests throughout the week where big-time Big Ten moments were made.

The first came as part of an effort that prevented overtime. USC standout freshman Alijah Arenas continued his hyped rookie campaign with a last-second shot over Penn State on Sunday, hijacking the Nittany Lions’ effort to earn its second conference win a week after it earned its first.

Other conference competitors delivered on their efforts to secure their second Big Ten wins; Maryland defeated Minnesota on the same day, thanks to a 29-point efficient scoring performance by Diggy Coit.

The result elevates the Terrapins into a group of three conference teams, joined by Rutgers and Northwestern, with only a pair of Big Ten wins and a chance to separate from the pack.

The group that leaves at the bottom — Penn State and Oregon — is set for a looming clash in the upcoming week, a game that’ll hand possession of the bottom tournament seed to one single squad.

In the new format, the bottom of the conference squads actually play each other in a format that resembles the NBA’s play-in tournament. All seedings on Day 1 of tournament play are currently within one game of each other in standings, so shakeups should be expected.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State women’s basketball showing signs of incoming success
author: Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hasn’t had many bright moments this season. In the midst of one of its worst seasons ever, and one that coach Carolyn Kieger will seek to leave behind, there are still signs of success.

The Lady Lions aren’t going away. As the season quickly nears the finish line, the blue and white are playing with pride.

McMiller untapped a new level

In the earlier stages of the season, Penn State had lost its identity. With many new faces and just four returners, the Lady Lions had much uncharted territory.

Who would be the leading scorer? Who would be the alpha? Who would take the next step? All those questions had to be answered, but were largely ignored amid an 11-game losing streak, with 11-straight Big Ten losses.

Hope for a notably better season quickly faded, and most importantly, many of the early green flags had turned red. The biggest one was Kiyomi McMiller.

McMiller was a highly touted recruit coming out of high school before committing to Rutgers. After averaging 18.7 points with the team, she entered the transfer portal only to end up in State College.

Across the town from New Brunswick, this Big Ten foe presented an opportunity for McMiller not only to take charge in leading the team but also to have a better chance at winning.

After a convincing start to the season, McMiller emerged as Penn State’s best offensive threat. What followed was a cold streak. While McMiller was reaching double figures — on some nights, north of 20 points — she quickly lost the spark that kept the team afloat.

Nevertheless, her play of late has propelled Penn State to some of its best basketball this season in winning its first Big Ten game on the road at Purdue. McMiller scored 30 points as well as nine assists and five rebounds in her impressive performance.

Following that, she replicated the same energy against then-No. 12 Michigan State, where McMiller scored a career-high 37 points with eight rebounds in a close 81-70 loss.

The shooting splits have been the biggest difference, as in both outings, the Lady Lion averaged nearly 50% from the field and above that from three.

To this point, it’s safe to say that McMiller is Penn State’s leader, who has loads of potential stored in the tank.

Penn State’s first Big Ten win

The impossible was possible.

The Lady Lions finally did it, and they did it in a thrilling fashion. After what felt like an endless cycle of losses and the epitome of brutality in the Big Ten, the blue and white cleaned up to earn its first conference win.

Penn State became the laughing stock of women’s basketball after an 11-game conference losing streak. The team was seriously on the brink of earning a winless season in the Big Ten.

After losing in a close defeat against Wisconsin in early January, the Lady Lions faced a tough stretch of ranked opponents and endured many blowout defeats.

Then, mid-January welcomed an opportunity to get back in the win column. The Lady Lions were facing Rutgers for its annual White Out game as the winning opportunity was hoped to be seized.

Rutgers was the second-worst team in the Big Ten and the only favorable opponent left on Penn State’s schedule. A loss would be catastrophic.

The Lady Lions went on to lose 76-72 as McMiller’s 27-point, 11-rebound double-double wasn’t enough.

However, Kieger got her girls together and sought an opportunity in West Lafayette, where they followed through. Penn State won in dramatic style in overtime, with an 85-82 victory over the Boilermakers, which finally ended the losing skid.

Penn State went into the break with a 36-34 lead, and the prize was there for the taking. But, from the product displayed thus far, the Lady Lions have proven not to be a second-half team.

Yet, it was the three-point and field goal shooting that gave Penn State the edge as many players, including Moriah Murray, Tèa Clèante and Gracie Merkle, came to the aid of McMiller. The unit played like a team.

With an impressive defensive performance, Penn State held Purdue to just 37% field goal shooting and 19% from deep.

It was a hard-fought victory that sparked momentum for Penn State.

No Merkle, no problem against MSU

Merkle was out of the lineup with a lower-body injury as she appeared in a boot on the sideline.

Without their 6-foot-6 center, the Lady Lions have proved to be a mess. But Merkle’s absence was the exact spark needed to keep Penn State in the game.

Merkle's vast presence was never going to be filled with a solo performance. While McMiller exploded, the team came together as a whole and nearly notched out its second-straight win days after an impressive victory over the Boilermakers.

Once more, it was the shooting and defensive prowess that gave way to an early Penn State lead. At halftime, the Lady Lions led 45-33.

While they ultimately fell in the second half, the signs of improvement were clear. Against one of the nation’s best, Penn State stood its ground with a generally positive overall performance.

Despite Merkle’s absence, Penn State answered the call and nearly left a voicemail for the Spartans to take home.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Highlighting the influence of Black musicians on modern music
author: Ashlyn Kafer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Before there was language, there was music.

It’s become a form of history, featuring stories of endless resistance, great love, immense toil or well-deserved triumph.

The evolution of music to its modern form was not sparked out of thin air. From Frank Sinatra to The Beatles to Taylor Swift, the core aspects of contemporary music can be traced back to Black artists who pioneered the industry.

Arreon Harley-Emerson, assistant professor of choral music, is well-versed in the customs and sounds of the Black diaspora. He said modern music does not exist without Black culture.

“I feel very strongly that in order to study American music, whether it’s classical or contemporary music, that you really have to take a look at a lot of these early Black and African musicians,” Harley-Emerson said. “They had just so many contributions, from classical music to jazz, to gospel, to hip hop, to R&B and we wouldn’t have that quintessential American sound because Black musicians were very formative of that sound of American music.”

Music historians often assert the construction of modern music began with spirituals sung in the fields during the period of enslavement in the U.S. As rhythms and techniques developed among Black musicians seeking solace, the sound stuck, building the foundation for gospel, jazz and blues that eventually evolved into pop, R&B and hip hop.

Gospel music placed the seed for rock ‘n’ roll to emerge with its sentimental appeal, syncopated beats and use of audience participation, inspiring widely popular musicians such as Elvis Presley, who grew up surrounded by Black musicians.

Artists, like Presley, reach metaphorical “king” status without the average listener understanding exactly where they got their roots. Even the way Presley chose to carry himself on stage was inspired by observing Black churches in his Tennessee hometown.

Before Presley, there was Chuck Berry and Little Richard. Before The Rolling Stones, there was W.C. Handy and Sister Rosetta Tharpe.

Studying the figures behind the development of music creates a window into Black history as a whole, as Harley-Emerson noted.

“In fashion, music and art, Black Americans have always been what I like to say, ‘pace setters,’” Harley-Emerson said. “You cannot be steeped in Black history and not also learn about these Black figures because they’re just so consequential, and so I think even knowing how music developed is important, American music more specifically.”

Several features of the industry itself were also born from the innovations of Black artists.

Joshua Mallard, a music composition lecturer at Penn State, is deeply invested in the world of music and said he sees the shadow of Black artists in music across the board.

“I think of sampling, remix and DJ culture as a whole,” Mallard said. “There are trap-style drums that you hear pretty much everywhere now, whether it’s Taylor Swift, Billie Eilish or other artists at the top of pop. They are using hip hop influenced sounds and samples, so I think there is a huge technical contribution there.”

From leading movements of resistance to setting the standard for being given royalties for sheet music, there are Black trailblazers who took the lead for all musicians to be fairly compensated for additions to the industry even if they weren’t being justly recognized for their work due to racial prejudices.

Black artists are also often sidelined by the sampling, covering and appropriation of their work without being given the proper attribution or recognition by the artist, such as “Whole Lotta Love” being released by Led Zeppelin without giving a nod to the inspiration from Willie Dixon and Muddy Waters’ “You Need Love.”

Anisa Adkins has played and studied music all her life, even teaching it to elementary students to help them understand the importance of interacting with the diversity of sound around the world.

“I don’t think it’s wrong for white people to be engaged with Black culture on this level, but I don’t think they should be claiming it as their own,” Adkins, a second-year masters student studying music education, said. “But, we're not creating this and saying it’s just for one group of people. Music is for everyone, it’s just good to be acknowledged.”

To best understand the music featured on the Billboard Hot 100 or to be able to conceptualize American history as a whole, it’s important to know how musicians have been impacted by the innovation born from the creativity of Black Americans throughout time.

“I think it can be helpful to use music as a lens through which you see the world itself, because even though I’m a music scholar, I understand world history through the lens of music,” Mallard said. “If you are a Black or minority artist of any kind, just by making music, you are having an impact, a butterfly effect, on music history.”

title: Penn State women’s basketball’s path to Big Ten Tournament
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
For the second straight year, Penn State is on the outside looking in, with just three weeks left until the Big Ten tournament.

The Lady Lions sit last in the conference with a 1-12 record, but have a better chance to pick up some wins in the coming games that could help them make a last-minute push.

Here’s a look at a few different scenarios of how the blue and white could make the 2026 Big Ten Tournament.

2 wins

This is the most likely outcome, as the Lady Lions will still need twice as many wins in the next three weeks as they have over the past six weeks.

However, with that easier schedule approaching, it’s certainly possible that Penn State could win a pair of games and see itself as the 15 seed.

The blue and white have three games that have winning possibilities, including at home against Northwestern on Feb. 15, and on the road against Rutgers and Indiana later this year. In this scenario, Penn State only needs to win two of them.

However, given the fact that the current No. 15 seed is already two games ahead of Penn State, the Lady Lions need a lot to go right to overtake the spot.

Penn State needs to leapfrog No. 17-seed Rutgers, which can only win once against Purdue, Indiana or two mid-tier teams. Each with three wins, either Purdue or Indiana must lose each of their remaining games of the year, while Northwestern — if Penn State wins — could win one more game.

3 wins

While three wins are much harder, it is still doable for the Lady Lions, as alluded to in the previous section.

Penn State has three “easier” opponents left in its schedule, and while a pair of them are on the road, it’s not 100% out of the question for these wins.

The Lady Lions are favored against both Northwestern and Rutgers, and while they’re only given a 16.9% chance to win against the Hoosiers, coach Carolyn Kieger may know the key to breaking former Penn Stater Shay Ciezki’s success.

By winning three games, Penn State would still be competing for the 14th and 15th seeds, but would have slightly more flexibility in terms of opponents winning.

If the wins come against Indiana, Northwestern and Rutgers, the Hoosiers and Wildcats could each earn another win this year, and Rutgers could earn two.

4 wins

The most unlikely scenario comes with the Lady Lions earning four wins as they have less than a six-percent chance to beat either Maryland or USC.

However, with another win, the blue and white would be in contention for the No. 12-15 seed, giving it an easier matchup in the first round of the Big Ten tournament.

The Lady Lions would need both Nebraska and Wisconsin to lose the rest of their games this year, while Indiana and Purdue could win two games and Northwestern and Purdue three games.
