title: Tessa Janecke, Team USA shuts out Canada to end Olympic preliminary round
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
In a battle of two of the top teams at the Olympics, the United States emerged victorious and finished the preliminary rounds unscathed.

Penn Stater Tessa Janecke took the ice with the fourth line as the U.S. beat Canada 5-0, ending with a 4-0 record.

The Canadians were quick on the attack, taking a shot on goal less than two minutes into the game. However, U.S. goalie Ava McNaughton earned her first save of the day, going on to make many more.

Less than a minute later, Hilary Knight earned the first shot for the Americans, but that too was saved. Fortunately for the U.S., Canada’s goalkeeper Kayle Osbourne didn’t save the second shot of the day, as Caroline Harvey gave the red, white and blue the early lead with the help of Haley Winn.

After Canada’s Blayre Turnbull got sent to the box for an illegal hit, the United States attacked the net again with shots from Taylor Heise and Laila Edwards, but came away unsuccessful after both attempts.

Back at full strength, Canada attempted its second shot of the day, but continued to struggle on the attack, while the U.S.'s attack continued to pound the Canadians with more shots from Megan Keller, Harvey, Winn and Janecke.

Both sides saw a lull in offensive action with just two shots from Canada over the next four minutes.

However, the United States struck gold again in the final three minutes of the period, as Hannah Bilka earned her first goal of the game with assists from Abbey Murphy and Harvey to end the first period up by two.

Right after the second period was underway, Canada’s Sarah Fillier was sent off for interference, allowing American Kirsten Simms to take a 3-0 lead on the power play. Simms was assisted by Janecke and Murphy at the 21:21 mark.

The Canadians were called yet again for another penalty for delaying the game, giving the U.S. a double powerplay.

Despite the advantage, the United States wasn't able to capitalize and failed again after a cross-checking penalty on Canada’s Kristin O’Neill.

After returning to full strength following an illegal hit from Simms, the United States scored its fourth goal of the game from Bilka with assists from Murphy and Harvey.

The United States entered the final period up by four goals and continued to shoot on goal in the opening minutes.

Meanwhile, Canada found itself attacking for just nine shots in the final period, failing to score.

After a garbage-time goal from Edwards, the United States emerged victorious and earned its fourth win of the preliminary round with a spot in the quarterfinals.

Up next

The United States booked its spot in the Olympic quarterfinals, kicking off at 10:40 a.m. on Friday.

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades says he doesn’t feel pressure on job status, gives injury updates
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
With Penn State on its West Coast road trip, Mike Rhoades had his weekly press conference via Zoom on Tuesday.

Rhoades spoke on if he feels any pressure on his job status amid a rocky start to Big Ten play, insight into the team’s travel plan this week and injury updates.

Here’s more of what Rhoades said.

Any pressure on job status?

As Penn State holds a 10-14 record so far this season, Rhoades was asked if he feels any internal or external pressure regarding his job status. He said he doesn’t.

“Nobody puts more pressure on me than me,” Rhoades said. “That's how I've always been my whole life. My focus every morning when I wake up is, ‘How can I make this program better? How can I push forward?’ Some things you can control. There's other things out of your control. You just got to keep pushing forward all the time.”

Rhoades was hired ahead of the 2023-24 season, signing a seven-year contract. He’s in Year 3 of that agreement, and he mentioned he’s at Penn State for the “long haul” with four more seasons left on his deal.

The Nittany Lions went 16-17 with nine Big Ten regular-season wins during Rhoades’ first year in Happy Valley. They followed it up with a 16-15 record in 2024-25, including six conference victories.

This season, Penn State has gone 1-12 to start Big Ten play. Over the Nittany Lions’ last 32 games against power-conference opponents, the team is 5-27.

Rhoades said Penn State has a “not great” basketball tradition, saying he knew how hard the job of building a program would be when he was hired.

“We have a very good staff,” Rhoades said. “We just got to continue to try to find ways to make our program better and build it so we could find a way to fight in this landscape, and that's important.”

For those wondering, Rhoades’ buyout sits at $9 million this season, and it drops to $6 million in the 2026-27 season. It goes down further to $3 million in 2027-28 and $1.5 million in 2028-29.

West Coast travel

Penn State is out west this week with road games against Washington and Oregon. Up first is the Huskies with tipoff set for 10:30 p.m. ET on Wednesday.

The team arrived in Washington on Monday after flying out of State College Regional Airport and refueling in Bismarck, North Dakota.

“Guys handle it well,” Rhoades said. “We got in the gym last night and got some work in, a lot of shots up, got some work in and preparing for Washington.”

It’s the second time the Nittany Lions have had to fly to the West Coast since the Big Ten added USC, UCLA, Oregon and Washington to the conference. Last season, the team traveled to face the Trojans and the Bruins on the road, and it lost both games.

Penn State has another practice on Tuesday before its gameday against the Huskies. Rhoades said if this long-distance travel is made a “big deal,” it becomes a “big deal.”

“I've always felt that way,” Rhoades said. “I've rode on buses for six, eight, 10 hours to go play. I've driven the white vans for six, eight, 10 hours to go play. So we're flying across the country to go play a Big Ten game. It's how you approach it, so you'll never get in a complaint or an excuse.”

Ivan Jurić’s return

Freshman 7-footer Ivan Jurić made his return from a two-game absence due to illness during Sunday’s matchup with USC. Rhoades said he thought Jurić was “great” in his first game back.

“I was really impressed how much he played, and how he played because I thought he'd be coughing up a lung a couple times throughout the game and really zap his energy,” Rhoades said. “He's a tough dude, man, and I thought he played very well.”

Jurić totaled 13 points, eight rebounds and three steals with 4-of-9 shooting from the field and 1-of-3 shooting from 3-point range. The big man was a team-high +7 in his 26 minutes on the floor during the 77-75 loss.

Jurić said postgame that he was still dealing with discomfort in his lungs. He’s since had two more days to recover and has one more day until tipoff against Washington.

“He felt a lot better yesterday when we got on the plane, and he looked pretty good yesterday, moving around in the arena,” Rhoades said. “So hopefully he's feeling better and better.”

Other injury updates

Rhoades gave updates on wing Eli Rice, forward Tibor Mirtič and forward Saša Ciani as well. Notably, Rhoades said Rice is set to make a return against Washington.

“Eli will be good to go today (at practice),” Rhoades said. “He'll be available to play this week.”

Rice exited the Minnesota game on Feb. 1 after hitting his head against an opposing player, and he hasn’t played since. He participated in pregame warmups before the USC game even though he was listed as “out” on the availability report.

As for Mirtič and Ciani, Rhoades said both are “day to day.”

Mirtič first endured a knee injury during the Michigan game on Jan. 6. During his first practice back, he injured his shoulder, causing him to wear a sling on his left arm. He was first spotted in that sling during the Northwestern game on Jan. 29, but he was no longer wearing it last Sunday.

Ciani hasn’t played since the Ohio State game on Jan. 26 with an ankle injury.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Subu Vedam deportation order vacated
author: Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
After spending over four months in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) custody, Subramanyam “Subu” Vedam’s deportation order was vacated by the Justice Department’s Board of Immigration Appeals on Feb. 3.

Vedam’s initial deportation order was based on his 1988 murder conviction. However, after the charge was vacated in October 2025, the order was reopened related to a conviction regarding controlled substances. In 1984, Vedam was convicted of selling LSD in State College.

In October 2025, Vedam’s lawyers argued for his immigration case to be reopened based on his exoneration and good behavior while in prison for 44 years.

While Temporary Appellate Immigration Judge Paul A. McCloskey acknowledged in court documents that the motion was untimely, being filed nearly 25 years beyond the 90-day deadline to reopen final administrative orders of removal, he also acknowledged the “extraordinary circumstances” around the case.

“Given the facts and circumstances in this particular case, we conclude that the record before us presents an exceptional situation that warrants the exercise of our sua sponte reopening authority,” McCloskey wrote in the ruling.

This ruling allows a new hearing for Vedam and restores his permanent U.S. resident status.

Vedam was convicted with first-degree murder following the 1980 disappearance of his roommate Thomas Kinser in Centre County. Kinser’s body was found in nearby Harris Township in September 1981 with what was determined to be a .25 caliber bullet hole in his skull.

Vedam’s legal team appealed his conviction, saying that Vedam had not purchased the .25 caliber gun that was used to convict him until after the murder had taken place. Vedam was retried in 1988, but convicted of first-degree murder again.

Vedam spent over 40 years in a Centre County prison following this conviction, with good behavior. In 2023, the Centre County district attorney found previously hidden evidence, allowing Vedam’s legal team to appeal for another trial. The evidence left out included forensic analysis from the 1988 trial showing that a .22 caliber bullet was used instead of a .25 caliber bullet.

His conviction was revisited in early 2025 under the Post Conviction Relief Act (PCRA), where Judge Jonathan Grine ruled that not all evidence was presented in the 1988 trial, in violation of Vedam’s 6th Amendment right to due process.

Vedam’s murder conviction was then vacated in August 2025 and a new trial had been granted.

On Oct. 2, Centre County District Attorney Bernie Cantorna announced that the charges against Vedam would be dismissed. Vedam was 19 at the time of his conviction, and was exonerated at age 64.

A day later it was announced Vedam had been taken into ICE custody. Vedam legally immigrated to the U.S. as a baby from India, growing up in State College as his father taught at Penn State. Vedam was held at the Moshannon Valley Processing Center, just outside Centre County.

In November, two judges temporarily blocked Vedam’s deportation proceedings, with his lawyers filing a motion to reopen his immigration case through the Board of Immigration Appeals.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball's Dimond Loosli named to NCBWA's Stopper of the Year watch list
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Dimond Loosli earned a top preseason nod before the Nittany Lions' season begins this week.

The senior was selected to the NCBWA's Stopper of the Year watch list for the nation's top reliever.

On the watch list for the country’s top reliever!@DimondLoosli #WeAre pic.twitter.com/rYSPzg2JkF— Penn State Baseball (@PennStateBASE) February 10, 2026

The Walnut Creek, California, native had an impressive 2025 campaign in his first season at Penn State. Looslie posted a 3.82 ERA, fourth-best on the team, and 30 strikeouts in 33 innings.

The right-handed pitcher was also reliable, with a 5-1 record. It's the second straight season that a Penn State reliever has been named to the list, as left-hander Anthony Steele was added to the list prior to the 2025 season.

Penn State travels to Arizona and begins its 2026 campaign as part of the MLB Desert Invitational. The first game is slated against Air Force at 8 p.m. on Friday.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey tops Lindenwood in battle of Lions
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Last weekend, No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey completed its final road trip of the regular season with a series against AHA opponent Lindenwood.

In this battle of the Lions, the ones reigning from State College came out victorious.

With a 6-3 win on Friday and a 5-0 win on Saturday, the Nittany Lions completed a season sweep over Lindenwood and outscored them 22-4 in the process.

AHA record

With a win on Friday, coach Jeff Kampersal led Penn State to its 20th conference win of the season, a new record.

Kampersal made AHA history just last season when Penn State finished 19-1 in conference play.

The Nittany Lions head coach improved that record to 21 conference wins on Saturday with the completion of the sweep, and has a chance to set the new record at 23 with one last set of conference games to play against RIT this weekend.

Game-winning Grace

Grace Outwater scored the first goal in Penn State’s shutout on Saturday, doubling it as the game-winning goal, as well. Outwater now has six game-winning goals this season, which puts her in a tie for the most in the nation with teammate Katelyn Roberts and six other skaters.

The sophomore winger also tied the game in Friday’s contest just 23 seconds after Lindenwood took a rare 1-0 lead over the Nittany Lions.

With goals in both games, Outwater has now scored a goal in each of her last nine games played and has recorded 13 points over that span. Her active streak of nine games is second in the nation to Minnesota’s Abbey Murphy, who scored in each of her last 10 games before heading to Italy to represent the United States in the Olympics.

Outwater increased her season scoring total to 23 goals, which is good enough for the most in the AHA and fifth in the nation.

Double-digit Desa

Penn State goaltender Katie DeSa blanked the Lions in a 5-0 shutout on Saturday, her 10th of the season.

DeSa’s 10 shutouts are a new program record for the most shutouts in a single season, and are the most shutouts in the nation this campaign.

The senior goalie also made 34 saves on Friday against Lindenwood, the second most she has made in a single game this season.

DeSa finished the weekend 2-0 with a .952 save percentage and a 1.50 goals-against-average.

With three goals allowed over the two games played last weekend, Penn State statistically has the best defense in the nation.

The blue and white as a team have allowed 42 goals in 32 games played this season, an average of 1.31 goals allowed per game, the lowest across the NCAA.

Lions on the board

With three forwards out due to the Winter Olympics, the Nittany Lions have been skating with a somewhat depleted roster that still contains three defensive pairings, but only three lines of forwards.

However, that has allowed for more players to receive more ice time than what’s customary. With more ice time, more players have a chance to earn their way onto the scoring sheet. That’s exactly what Penn State did last weekend.

Of the 15 skaters that hit the ice, 14 of them, as well as DeSa, recorded at least one point against Lindenwood. DeSa recorded an assist on Mikah Keller’s second-period goal on Saturday.

Leading the total scoring over the weekend for the blue and white was Danica Maynard, who finished with four points. The freshman defenseman managed to record all four of her points in the first period of Friday’s game with a power-play goal and three assists.

Maynard sits in a three-way tie for the second-most points by a defenseman in the nation with 30 and is also tied with Keller for the seventh-most points by a freshman.

Maddy Christian was one of four skaters to finish the weekend with three points that she put together with a goal and a pair of assists.

The senior winger has recorded a point in each of her last seven games with nine points total over that span.

Penn State returns to Pegula Ice Arena for its final home series of the regular season against RIT. Puck drop is scheduled for 6 p.m. on Friday.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women's hockey earns two weekly conference honors after final away series
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
After earning a win in both games over the Lindenwood Lions, Penn State goaltender Katie DeSa has been tabbed as the AHA’s Goalie of the Week.

4️⃣ players from 3️⃣ programs. 1️⃣ solid week 🙌#NCAAHockey pic.twitter.com/cMRAtx6ZXO— Atlantic Hockey America (@Atlantic_Hockey) February 10, 2026

The senior netminder posted a 2-0 record, making a total of 60 saves on 63 shots faced. She put up a .952 save percentage and a 1.50 goals-against-average in the 120 minutes she played.

It is her fourth time earning this honor this season, having done so on Sept. 30, Oct. 21 and Nov. 4.

DeSa has improved her record this season to 22-2, with a .936 save percentage and a 1.26 goals-against average. She has also recorded nine shutouts, the most in the nation.

Danica Maynard also earned honors, being named the AHA’s Defenseman of the Week for the fourth time this season.

The freshman defenseman recorded four points against Lindenwood, all in the first period of Friday’s 6-3 win and posted a plus-4.

It is the second time this season DeSa and Maynard simultaneously won these awards, the first coming on Oct. 21.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling has no movement in latest InterMat rankings
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
After a dominant victory in Ann Arbor against Michigan, Penn State wrestling didn't see any change in the rankings.

The Nittany Lions defeated the Wolverines 38-3 to continue their undefeated season.

Luke Lilledahl, Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines, Rocco Welsh and Josh Barr remained at No. 1 in their respective weight classes. Penn State has six top-ranked wrestlers in the country for the third week in a row.

The Nittany Lions' star freshmen duo, Marcus Blaze and PJ Duke, remained at No. 4 in the rankings at 133 and 157 pounds, respectively.

Braeden Davis at 141 pounds and Cole Mirasola at 285 pounds remained at No. 12 in their weight classes.

Wrestler-for-wrestler, Penn State has its hardest test against the Buckeyes at 7 p.m. Friday in the Bryce Jordan Center.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Notebook | Penn State women’s basketball eyes strong finish with season on the line
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After earning its first conference win of the season last week against Purdue, Penn State fell back to its losing habits on Saturday as it lost to Michigan State.

Despite these season-long struggles, coach Carolyn Kieger and her squad remain optimistic and keep pushing forward, as she detailed in her weekly media session on Tuesday.

Last week's success

Penn State was the underdog heading into its matchup with the Boilermakers last Wednesday, losing 11 straight contests.

Despite this, the return of Gracie Merkle and the continued success of Kiyomi McMiller lifted the blue and white out of the losing column for the first time since Dec. 20.

“I think we learned a lot from that game,” Kieger said. “We did a really good job executing, and I thought we did a really good job sharing the basketball.”

Against Purdue, McMiller scored 30 points, which was then topped by a 37-point performance against Michigan State.

While the Lady Lions ultimately gave away a double-digit lead and lost by 11 points, Kieger said the first-half toughness was a sign of improvement from earlier this year.

“That fourth quarter slipped away from us, but I thought they did a great job, both executing and playing, with each other on the defensive end,” Kieger said. “That team synergy is continuing to grow, and we just got to keep making sure we’re playing team basketball, because that’s when we’re at our best.”

Maryland matchup

The first game in Penn State’s path to the Big Ten tournament is Maryland, which has had a back-and-forth season this year.

After losing out on Merkle in the transfer portal, the Terrapins picked up Yarden Garzon. The former Hoosier has been dominant this year, scoring 13.0 points per game with 69 made 3-pointers.

Alongside Garzon has been Oluchi Okananwa, who’s the 10th highest scorer in the Big Ten with 17.2 points per game.

“Oluchi is just a phenomenal talent,” Kieger said. “The thing that worries me the most about her is her offensive rebounding ability and her athleticism. She never gives up on a play.”

Following successful bouts against Purdue and Michigan State, the Lady Lions look to carry that momentum into Thursday’s matchup with Maryland.

“Maryland is very similar to Michigan State, where they have a couple elite shooters,” Kieger said. “We’re going to build on what we did at Purdue, and we’re going to build upon the game that we played against Michigan State.”

Moving forward

With three weeks until the Big Ten tournament, Penn State needs to start winning. However, it’s been missing a key piece to its squad over the past few weeks in Merkle, who returned to the bench on Saturday in a boot.

“We’ll see her again this season,” Kieger said. “It’s just a matter of coming back.”

Alongside the Lady Lions’ struggles, the men’s basketball team has just one conference win, with fans calling for action for both squads.

Despite criticism, both teams have supported each other this year and remain each other’s top supporters, according to Kieger.

“We all support each other and lean on each other for words of encouragement or that kind of stuff,” Kieger said. “We’re all one team. We share the gym, we share the training room, and we share the weight room. We’re rooting for each other a ton.”

Part of that rooting comes in the Lady Lions’ upcoming schedule, where they need at least two wins to clinch the Big Ten tournament. Even with a challenging year, the team continues to push toward that goal.

“The biggest thing that we just keep trying to do every day is get better and stack days,” Kieger said. “Get better at practice, get better as a team, get better as coaches. We build confidence, chemistry and just keep stacking winning habits.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Jessica Adolfsson, Nicole Hall help Sweden to undefeated preliminary round
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a week of success from Sweden, its perfect start is complete as it moved to 4-0 in the preliminary round.

The Swedish team defeated Japan 4-0 on Tuesday, putting them in a prime position ahead of the Olympic quarterfinals.

While current Penn Stater Nicole Hall and former Nittany Lion Jessica Adolfsson didn’t play a large role in the dominant win, they’ve been productive throughout the tournament so far.

Sweden got started right out of the gate with a goal by Hanna Thuvik, her second of the game. Thuvik was assisted by Sara Hjalmarsson at the 5:25 minute mark.

After going the rest of the first period without more scoring, the Swedes scored bookend goals to start and finish the second period.

Josefin Bouveng — assisted by Ohio State’s Jenna Raunio — led the way for the first goal, giving Team Sweden a multi-point lead. With two-and-a-half minutes left in the second quarter, Mira Hallin made it a three-point game with assists from Bouveng and Maja Nylen-Persson.

That strong attack continued early into the final period, as Hanna Olsson capitalized on a power play with the help of Nylen-Persson and Thea Johansson.

Despite penalties to both Japan and Sweden for roughing and holding, respectively, neither team found momentum down the final stretch as Sweden’s undefeated preliminary rounds wrapped up.

Up next

The Olympic quarterfinals begin at 10:40 a.m. on Friday and finish with the fourth game at 3:10 p.m. on Saturday.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field falls in latest poll
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After starting the season hot, Penn State fell in the latest poll.

Both teams fell one place in the latest USTFCCCA poll, as the men's squad moved to fifth and the women's squad to 20th.

Indoor Checkpoint No. 3 ✅Competition is heating up, which means rankings are changing across collegiate divisions. Despite the fall, the men's team still saw success: Ajani Dwyer broke the 60-meter school record with a time of 6.52 seconds, and Handal Roban broke the 600-meter record with a time of 1:14.89.

The women's team didn't earn any school records, but had several big moments on Saturday. One of such was the women's 4x400-meter relay, which earned a season-best 3:37.67 from Addyson White, Maddie Pitts, Boh Ritchie and Hayley Kitching.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: South Asian Student Association welcomes Karan Brar to Penn State
author: Brennan Kramp I For the Collegian
description:
Penn State’s South Asian Student Association (SASA) held a Q-and-A event with actor Karan Brar on Monday night at Freeman Auditorium in the HUB-Robeson Center.

Brar is best known for his work as a child actor, starring in roles such as Ravi Ross in the Disney Channel TV shows, “Jessie” and “BUNK’D.” He also played Chirag Gupta in the “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” movie series. At 27 years old, Brar is credited in more than 40 film and television projects, spanning over a decade and a half.

At 5:30 p.m., students lined down the hall of the HUB, waiting for the doors of Freeman Auditorium to open for their chance to see the actor. Inside, a playlist of 2010’s music played, intermixing with the sounds of students packing close together, sharing conversation and smiles before Brar was introduced to a rowdy ovation from the crowd.

The Q-and-A was meant to give Brar a chance to open up about a range of topics from mental health, sexual identity, acting and the ability to connect with students of South Asian descent on what it means to be a minority in such a high profile field. During the conversation, Brar took questions from students in the crowd about anything from advice to his favorite episode of “Jessie.”

Arush Tiwari, the cultural events director for SASA, said he had seen Brar on television as a child, and was glad to see the actor speak live.

“I thought it was awesome,” Tiwari, a second-year studying finance and pre-dentistry said. “Just to see South Asian representation through a form of such a big star that most of us have grown up with, it was absolutely incredible.”

Finding a celebrity of any status can be a difficult task, especially one willing to come and speak at an event. Brar filled the room with laughter and found multiple ways of deeply connecting with students in the crowd as he spoke on various topics.

Sonya Shetty said she appreciated the way Brar spoke about his mental health journey growing up as a minority child actor, his experience coming out as bisexual and how that impacted his professional and social life and finding ways to embrace your situation given the circumstances.

“It was really nice seeing a person-of-color (POC) actor being very open with conversations on mental health and being queer…it was really enlightening seeing him be so open about it,” Shetty, a second-year veterinary and biomedical sciences student said.

Another major point that connected Brar with the attendees was his non-traditional upbringing given the traditional South Asian household dynamic. Students like Katelynn Jassal found that Brar, finding his way into Hollywood as a child actor and not being brought up on an academic based standard, was a comforting and interesting conversation.

“Not having as strict of parents or going down an untraditional path, career wise, through acting…that was really nice to see that he was able to be successful and not do something the stereotypical way,” Jassal, a third-year studying international politics said.

The conversation wrapped up with Brar and the rest of the SASA taking a group photo and signing autographs and banners featuring a young Brar in character as Ravi.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Column | Bleed blue and white or at least wear it
author: Julia Kushner | The Daily Collegian
description:
Back when I toured Penn State in high school, the thing that stood out to me the most was the school spirit.

I had only visited one other university beforehand, but the difference was striking.

Almost every student I passed in State College had on some sort of Penn State gear, whether it was a branded hat in the winter cold or a simple blue and white outfit.

This spoke to me deeply. Not only was this a beautiful campus with a top-tier educational system, but the attendees were so passionate about it. I knew Penn State must be doing something right.

Clothes here serve as a cultural integrator. We are a part of something bigger than ourselves and we are proud of that fact, of the hard work it took to get into Penn State and excel here.

In an age of institutional distrust, albeit much of it warranted, it’s increasingly meaningful to be engaged with an establishment that still commands our respect and our loyalty.

Our choice of education has stood the test of time, and our choice of attire reflects this impressive fact.

And you see this sentiment all over State College. Ninety percent of all of my T–shirts are Penn State related, and I’d bet at least half of yours are too.

It’s so beautiful not just to see this appreciation in State College, but truly all over the world.

I was once traveling in Israel — almost 6,000 miles away from PA — wearing my finest blue and white, when a Penn State alum, also dressed in his spirited gear, said “We Are” to me.

What were the chances that both of us Penn Staters would be in the same place at the same time and both wearing Nittany Lion merchandise?

We struck up a lovely conversation just by virtue of going to the same university, and I’ve had many such interactions, albeit usually a little closer to home.

But even in the great state of Georgia, my home, Penn State alums are crawling all over the place. Just drop a mention of 16802 in an interview where the employee also went to Penn State, and you’re practically guaranteed a call back.

But I digress.

Clothing is often seen as a statement. Something more meaningful than simple cloth that was closest at hand, and for good reason. Clothing is an expression of ourselves and our loyalties, of what’s meaningful to us and has garnered our recognition.

Penn State gear is a sign of belonging, voluntary conformity and traditional symbology.

No one is monitoring our clothing choices, yet day after day, and year after year, you see the same pattern.

We choose to represent our school because of the great experiences we’ve had here, the great community we’ve cultivated and the desire to share that with passersby. We choose to represent our school because of the meaning it has in our hearts and minds.

And we’ve been doing this since 1890. That’s 136 years of blue and white and we’re still going strong.

Students love vintage gear, and for a greater reason than old stuff just looks cool. It’s a reminder of our storied history and legacy. And when passed down from a parent or older sibling, it becomes even more special. You become an integral link in the great chain of generations of Penn Staters.

Penn State’s merchandise brings a whole new meaning to “We Are.”

MORE COLUMNS

title: What to know about free speech at Penn State
author: Anisa Daniel-Oniko | The Daily Collegian
description:
Over the past few years, campus protests have swept through colleges across the United States, sometimes followed by crackdowns on free speech.

Here’s what students need to know about free speech at Penn State.

Federal/State Law

The First Amendment

According to the First Amendment of the United States Constitution, “Congress shall make no law … abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.”

However, the First Amendment does not give all speech equal protections. Federally unprotected categories of speech include incitement to imminent lawless action, true threats, obscenity, defamation, harassment and material and substantial disruption.

Incitement to imminent lawless action must be targeted at a specific person or group of people. There must also be evidence or “rational inference” that the language was “intended to produce, and likely to produce, imminent disorder.”

While there is no explicit list, fighting words are generally understood to be words which “inflict injury and tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace.” Fighting words are examined in totality, contextually, so “speech can still be protected if it is angry or profane.”

A true threat is spoken with the intention of “placing the victim in fear of bodily harm or death.”

Obscenity has proven difficult to legally define, but the typical test used was established in Miller v. California. If speech appears to be of an abnormal, morbid or unhealthy interest in sex, and is patently offensive with no literary, artistic, political or scientific value, it’s considered obscene and not protected by the first amendment.

Intentionally false assertions of fact that are publicly shared and cause injury are considered defamatory and not protected by the First Amendment. Statements can be written (libel) or spoken (slander) and must be capable of being proven false in order to count as defamation.

Harassment is unwelcome behavior based on an individual’s (perceived) protected status. It must be “severe, persistent, and pervasive” enough to “unreasonably interfere with that individual’s educational (or employment) environment.”

If speech “creates or threatens to create” tangible and substantial disruption to a school’s functioning, it is unprotected speech.

The Constitution of Pennsylvania, Section 7

Pennsylvania’s constitution describes “the free communication of thoughts and opinions” as being “one of the invaluable rights of man.” All citizens are allowed to “freely speak, write and print on any subject, being responsible for the abuse of that liberty.”

Penn State Policy

Penn State extends the same protections to student speech, discussions, writings and ideas as the First Amendment.

Penn State’s policy AD51 Use of Outdoor Areas for Expressive Activities gives students the ability to protest on campus, encourages expression and outlines locations suitable for demonstrations. These locations include Old Main front patio, Willard Building grounds (area between Willard and the obselik) and the Allen Street Gaze Plaza. Visit policy.psu.edu for the full list.

However, Policy AD51 has limits on time, place and manner of expression, with eleven requirements for and several caveats on permissible activity.

For example, Penn State prohibits activities that will impede vehicular or pedestrian traffic, blocks exits or university facilities or damages property. The university also prohibits the erection of structures or affixing of posters, and does not allow sound amplification before 8 a.m. and after 6 p.m.

The time, place and manner restrictions take into account environmental, health and safety concerns, potential damage to facilities, direct and indirect costs of the school, appropriateness and overall impact of the event.

Free Speech at Penn State

Penn State students routinely engage in protests, vigils and demonstrations on campus. Recently, students protested against the Iranian regime, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations and the Trump Administration.

Even contentious events, such as President Trump’s 2024 Rally in the Bryce Jordan Center or pro-Palestine gatherings, are typically protected by Penn State’s policy. However, Policy AD51 violations and controversies have led to event alterations in the past.

For example, the Penn State chapter of Turning Point USA hosted Charlie Kirk’s "You're Being Brainwashed Tour” in 2024. A week before, the Student Committee for Defense and Solidarity (SCDS) released an online petition to deny Kirk access to campus, which garnered more than 200 signatures.

On the day of the event, students showed up with placards to protest the presence of the Turning Point founder and conservative political activist. Ultimately, the university did not allow Kirk to deliver his planned speech or debates due to sound amplification violations.

Similarly, Penn State students gathered to protest a scheduled Uncensored America event featuring Proud Boys founder Gavin McInnes and comedian Alex Stein in 2022.

The university eventually canceled the event, calling the views of both speakers “abhorrent” and citing safety concerns.

Free Speech at Private Universities

In 2025, Columbia University disciplined students for engaging in a pro-Palestinian demonstration by revoking degrees, expelling some protestors and suspending others for up to three years.

Penn State students have also demonstrated in support of Palestine, but no similar result has occurred at Penn State.

Crucially, this difference is due to Penn State’s public university status. The First Amendment limits the capacity of the government to abridge free speech, which means public universities must also uphold the right of students to speak.

Private bodies may form their own policies, which is why students who go to private universities, like Columbia, may find their speech more restricted.

As a public land-grant institution, Penn State has stated it “fully supports the fundamental right of free speech – even speech that tests the limits of our tolerance.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball embarks on West Coast trip, faces Washington
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hits the road to the West Coast for the first time all year with a two-game road trip, despite the chance of jet lag. It presents the Nittany Lions an opportunity to gain some momentum to finish out a weak season.

While on the coast, the blue and white travel to two bottom-half Big Ten squads in Washington and Oregon. Since their first game is in the Pacific Time Zone on Wednesday against the Huskies, there’s a chance the time switch affects the blue and white’s performance.

Let's glance at key storylines as Penn State steps into Alaska Airlines Arena for the first time ever and only the second time ever, after the Huskies defeated Mike Rhoades’ unit in the inaugural meeting between the two last season.

Avalanche of absences

As the teams begin to warm to the idea of playing each other in Big Ten play, they’re also getting used to playing without their full squad.

Washington listed four as out in its last game, a 77-73 loss to UCLA, its ninth conference loss of the season, with only four wins — all against bottom-half Big Ten teams.

Penn State endured a similar fate, in its 12th conference loss of the season on Sunday at the hands of a USC buzzer-beater. The Nittany Lions played without three: Tibor Mirtić, Sasǎ Ciani and sharpshooter Eli Rice.

Both squads will look within their ranks to fill those absences, although they're limited in returning personnel from last year’s contest. Washington’s Zoom Diallo is the only starter from 2025 to return for this year.

For the blue and white, its leading scorer this year, Freddie Dilione V, returns with some familiarity with the Huskies, having scored 15 points in last year’s clash.

Dominick Stewart joins Dilione, with a much larger role this season than last. He appeared in only four minutes against Washington, but has been thrust into the starting unit at times this season.

Stars and stats

Despite limited familiarity with the contest, a few names emerge as worth watching. Diallo made a significant sophomore jump for Washington, scoring while leading his squad in assists, and has been a strong second star alongside one of the best freshmen in the country, Hannes Steinbach.

The Würzburg, Germany, native is a walking double-double, averaging over 17 points per game and rebounding figures that lead the Big Ten on both the offensive and defensive ends.

Washington built a solid core around the pair, as Franck Kepnang anchors the paint with 2.3 blocks per game, tied as the second-best average in the conference.

As a unit, the Huskies lead their effort with an extremely physical approach — the Nittany Lions actually edge out Washington’s shooting figures. The Huskies stand out in the conference with their top-three block and rebounding figures, and also post top-half foul, defense and steal metrics.

KenPom ranks Washington just inside the top 50, with its offense and defense just inside the top 60. The Nittany Lions sit outside at No. 130, as both their offense and defense showed struggles. The defense ranks among the worst in college basketball, 253 of 365, while the blue and white offense sits just in the mid-70s.

Statistician Evan Miyakawa’s formulas mirror those of KenPoms, though it puts the Nittany Lions as a Big Ten team with a top-five conference tempo, and surprisingly not that it matters in this one, the blue and white have the best home ranking in the conference.

Washington, on the other hand, is in the bottom five in that same category. Its home venue, which seats around 10,000, reached only 90% capacity this season, when top contender Michigan visited. The rest of the Huskies home games sit around 5,000-7,000 in the stands.

For this midweek contest, it looks to be on the lower side, with tickets under $10 on the Monday before tipoff.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse looks to carry early-season success against UMass
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Kayla Treanor’s first season in Happy Valley is off to a hot start after a 1-0 opening weekend.

Next up on the docket is the team’s season opener against UMass at noon on Wednesday.

The Minutewomen are also 1-0 to start the year, with a big win over Holy Cross last weekend. With Wednesday’s matchup rapidly approaching, here’s a look at how the two teams will match up this week.

All-time contests

The Nittany Lions hold a 9-0 all-time record over UMass, spanning 48 years.

Penn State first played the Minutewomen in 1978, winning 9-3 in the 1978 USWLA Nationals. Two years later, the Nittany Lions won again, 8-3.

After the NCAA started sponsoring women’s lacrosse in 1982, the blue and white were quick to the big stage, defeating UMass in a 7-6 overtime victory in the NCAA third-place game.

Over the next 30 years, the Nittany Lions continued to dominate the Minutewomen, winning another four games by an average of 7.75 goals.

2026 UMass

This year’s UMass squad is off to a hot start after a dominant, 17-8 victory over Holy Cross.

The Minutewomen have been led by redshirt senior attacker Kassidy Morris, who led the team in scoring last season. On Friday, Morris tallied five goals in just seven shots, contributing significantly to the eight-point win.

Junior attacker Katie Peterson also put herself in a good position to start the year, scoring three goals as compared to the two goals she scored all season last year.

Peterson’s success was also seen in draw controls, as she recorded nine in the game. As a whole, Holy Cross won just 13 draw controls.

On the defensive end of the ball, the Minutewomen put up a dominant performance with 15 caused turnovers, which would’ve been good enough to beat the second-best average caused turnovers per game in the NCAA last year.

Wednesday’s matchup

While both teams are coming off their first wins of the season over the weekend, Penn State’s matchup showed slightly more grit and toughness.

The Nittany Lions defeated Richmond in a one-goal nail-biter — a team that just missed out on the NCAA tournament last year. Along the same lines, UMass made it to the first round but fell to Princeton, 19-10.

However, both squads have strong goalkeepers who will make it tough to put any points on the board on Wednesday.

For Penn State, Sydney Manning is starting in net for her third straight season. Against the Spiders, she recorded a 43.8% save percentage as her squad pulled out the win on Saturday.

Lining up across from Manning, however, is freshman Caitlyn Naughton. In her first collegiate game, Naughton recorded a 52.9% save percentage.

While Holy Cross struggled to score on Naughton, the Nittany Lions have several deadly attackers who could add to the stat sheet.

Payton Wainman tied her career-high in goals scored on Saturday as she put four in the back of the net. Alongside Wainman, four-star freshman Rocquette Allen earned her first career start and tallied two goals.

Between Saturday’s dynamic duo and Erika Ho — last year’s leading scorer — the blue and white have some strong attackers who could make Naughton work this week.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Takeaways from Kayla Treanor’s first win with Penn State women’s lacrosse
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State opened the Kayla Treanor era with its first win on Saturday, taking down Richmond 10-9.

Throughout the 60 minutes of action, the Nittany Lions had several standout moments and players who can help define Treanor’s first year in Happy Valley.

Freshmen expectations

Treanor didn’t shy away from the younger athletes when selecting her starting lineup against Richmond. Taking the starting lineup on Saturday were four-star attacker Rocquette Allen and defender Susannah O’Connell.

Allen’s success was apparent right out of the gate, recording her first collegiate goal less than 15 minutes into action.

As the game progressed, so did the Lone Tree, Colorado, native’s goal count. With a few minutes left in the third quarter, Allen scored her second goal of the game, becoming just one of Penn State's athletes on Saturday with multiple goals.

On the defensive end of the ball, O’Connell had a slightly quieter game, forcing just two turnovers.

Wainman time

Less than 30 minutes into the action on Saturday, senior Payton Wainman recorded a hat trick, scoring three of Penn State’s four goals that quarter.

Every time she was on the attack through the first two periods, it seemed like she found the net. The Delray Beach, Florida, native scored half the number of goals she scored all last year in just the opening game.

However, it wasn’t just the number of goals Wainman scored that put her atop the statsheet.

Wainman only shot the ball six times, recording a 66.7% shooting percentage. On top of that, she picked up three ground balls, the most of anyone on Penn State besides the goalkeeper.

Offensive attack

While Wainman found the net four times and Allen twice, four other athletes scored in Penn State’s win on Saturday.

Kelly MacKinney, Erika Ho, Emma Kelly and Anna Salerno each scored against Richmond, kicking off their seasons on a positive note.

As a whole, the Nittany Lions were aggressive on the offensive front, recording 24 shots against the Spiders. Of those 24, only five weren’t on goal.

In addition to Wainman’s high shooting percentage, both Ho and MacKinney went 1-for-1 on the attack, while Kelly, Alen and Salerno had multiple attempts before striking gold.

While they weren’t victorious, Delaney Radin and Elizabeth Anné combined for four shots, adding to the offensive attack from the Nittany Lions.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Where to find love at Penn State
author: Carolena Bongi | The Daily Collegian
description:
With Valentine's day quickly approaching on Feb. 14, Penn State students might be searching for a special someone to spend the holiday with.

Whether you’re hoping to meet the love of your life or just someone who won’t ghost you before your formal, here are the best and worst places to meet your special someone at Penn State.

BEST: HUB-Robeson Center

The HUB is definitely a busy and overcrowded place, but it is perfect to find love and people watch.

With hundreds of students constantly coming and going, there is always something or someone who is there to catch your attention. Sitting in the HUB will give you plenty of opportunities to strike up a conversation and bond over all the people around you.

The HUB is also the perfect place to flirt because everyone is pretending to be busy.

You can easily sit across from someone for hours and only make eye contact exactly twice, but you can still consider it romantic.

BEST: Beaver Stadium during a football game

Beaver Stadium during a football game is a great place to meet your special someone because you already know they’re loyal.

After a season filled with overtime disappointments and failing to win in the big moments, anyone who is still showing up to the games clearly believes in commitment.

Bonding over that one Drew Allar interception during the White Out this season will build a strong and ever-lasting relationship.

If you can survive the heartache Penn State football brings, then you guys can truly survive any obstacle that is thrown your way.

BEST: The Daily Collegian table in Willard Building

The Daily Collegian table in Willard is obviously filled with the best and funniest people in the world.

Everyone there is extremely attractive, intelligent and humble, which makes it the ideal place to meet your special someone.

If you meet someone sitting at the Collegian table, chances are they have a great sense of humor and a deep appreciation for satire. But be careful because everyone there will always correct your grammar.

WORST: Lion’s Den

The Den is not the place where people go to find true love, but it is the place where everyone somehow ends up.

The Den is filled with people who swear they never go there, but are always recognized immediately by both the staff and everyone else inside.

Because the Den has no real standards for who gets in, it’s hard to believe that any connection made there is meant to last. Most of your conversations at the Den are temporary and almost always forgotten by the next morning.

WORST: Pollock Testing Center

The Pollock Testing Center is one of the most stressful places on campus, which makes it an awful place to meet your special someone.

No one is ever relaxed or happy, and everyone is either panicking or already convinced they failed an exam.

If you somehow meet someone here, you will forever associate them with stress and the sudden urge to check Canvas.

The Pollock Testing Center is definitely not where love blossoms. It is a place where it always feels like you’re doing something wrong.

WORST: Canvas Discussion Boards

Meeting your special someone through a Canvas discussion is definitely not romantic.

You might think what they said was really smart, but they probably wrote a paragraph about something they didn't even read.

If you somehow think you’ve found the one through their discussion post, you will have a relationship based on a love for shared procrastination — which isn’t the strongest foundation.

At the end of the day, love can happen anywhere at Penn State … or not at all. If none of these spots work out, there's always next Valentine's Day to lower your expectations.

Until then, good luck and never settle for someone who won’t go to every Penn State game with you.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Weekly Recap | Nemeth returns, newcomers, pitching highlight Penn State softball’s opening weekend
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State set sail for Clearwater, Florida, last weekend, opening its season at the NFCA Leadoff Classic. The Nittany Lions had a more than successful outing, finishing the weekend 4-1.

The blue and white started its competition on Friday afternoon with a 10-inning win over Missouri. With little turnaround time, Penn State shutout Boston College by a score of 7-0 in its second game of the day.

On Saturday, the Nittany Lions picked up where they left off with a two-run victory over Eastern Kentucky and another extra-inning win against BYU.

Penn State couldn’t complete the weekend undefeated, falling to Auburn in walkoff fashion. Nonetheless, the blue and white return to Happy Valley with many positives from opening weekend.

Nemeth’s return

One of the most highly anticipated moments of the weekend was junior pitcher Bridget Nemeth's return after missing the 2025 season. The 6-foot-1 right-hander appeared in four of Penn State’s games and pitched a team-high nine innings.

Nemeth appeared in both Friday contests, coming in relief to earn the win against Missouri, while getting the starting nod versus Boston College. In the two games combined, the Glendora, California, native pitched 5.1 innings, allowing one hit and striking out three batters.

Additionally, Nemeth pitched 2.2 innings against BYU, allowing four hits and recording three strikeouts. The junior worked one inning against Auburn, giving up two hits and tossing two strikeouts.

Nemeth completed the opening weekend with a 1.56 ERA and managed to allow just one walk.

Newcomers

The Nittany Lions’ weekend was highlighted by a few newcomers who made strong debuts in a Penn State uniform. It started with two freshmen coming up big in the blue and white’s 7-4 win over Missouri.

Allison Oneacre and Kirsten Finarelli drove in all three of Penn State’s runs in the top of the 10th inning. With one out and a runner on third, Finarelli doubled down the right field line to bring in the go-ahead run. Two batters later, Oneacre knocked a two-run home run for her first collegiate long ball.

Finarelli was the hero against BYU, hitting a walk-off single to defeat the Cougars 4-3. The Lehman, Pennsylvania, native also recorded her first career home run against Boston College.

Finarelli finished the weekend leading the Nittany Lions with a .368 batting average and seven hits, while Oneacre paced the blue and white with six RBIs.

The newest Penn Staters also made moves in the circle. Freshman Mackenzie Duncan and junior South Dakota transfer McKenna Young both had strong showings.

Young was the only pitcher to start multiple games, going 1-1 on the weekend. The Broadhead, Wisconsin, native pitched 8.1 innings, allowing six hits and tossing seven strikeouts.

Duncan had arguably the best pitching performance of the weekend. The Winter Garden, Florida, native made two relief appearances and earned the win against Boston College.

In Duncan’s two appearances, she threw seven innings, striking out 12 batters and allowing just five hits. The 5-foot-10 right-hander led the Nittany Lions with just one earned run allowed.

Pitching depth

Last season, Penn State was dominant at the plate but struggled in the circle. However, this wasn’t the case in the Nittany Lions’ opening weekend.

The blue and white exercised its new pitching depth, with five arms making an appearance, and sophomore Abigail Britton was the only one who was a part of the rotation a season ago.

In Penn State’s combined 38.2 innings pitched, the staff allowed 28 hits, while tossing 42 strikeouts and finishing the weekend with a 1.63 ERA. The Nittany Lions allowed just 13 runs in their five games, nine of which were earned.

Penn State’s pitching depth against strong competition proved to be the difference maker in its first weekend of the 2026 season.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | James Franklin’s legacy as Black coach won’t be lost in rocky end at Penn State
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
Entering the four-month mark since James Franklin was fired from Penn State, much of what’s discussed among the Penn State fanbase is a sense of anger, disappointment and resentment.

At a shallow level, I get it. Twenty-one losses against AP top-10 teams, one Big Ten championship, a three-game losing streak to conclude his tenure coaching one of the biggest brands in college football. But what’s often ignored is what he did do.

Among other successes, Franklin 's tenure at Penn State made him a modern-day pioneer in an area he holds near and dear to his heart — being a Black coach. That should never be forgotten.

At Penn State, Franklin won 104 games, a tie with Rip Engle as the second-most in program history. He also won four New Year’s Six bowls and brought Penn State to a preseason ranking it hadn’t seen since the late 1990s, an accomplishment even if it all unraveled after three games.

Additionally, Franklin is the winningest African American head coach in FBS history. He’s also the first and only African-American head coach to win a Big Ten title among other notable achievements.

But these accolades, and other on-field statistics only scratch the surface on what Franklin has done as a Black head coach.

The Langhorne, Pennsylvania, native long made it a goal of his to become the first Black head coach to win a national title. Of course to be able to do that on an individual level is important to Franklin, but the impact it may have on other coaches cements his legacy even more.

At the 2025 Orange Bowl media day, he noted the marker of 16 of 134 FBS coaches being Black — a number that has shifted a bit with 136 teams and the firing of coaches like Sherrone Moore.

It was a relative increase from the 6 of 127 FBS coaches when Franklin was the offensive coordinator at Kansas State under fellow Black head coach Ron Prince.

But that increase starts with coaches giving qualified minorities a chance. Franklin did so when he hired Charles Huff, who was on Franklin’s staff at Vanderbilt but never landed a major, full-time position coaching job until he became Penn State’s running backs coach in 2014. Huff went on to take three head coaching jobs.

Even for Huff’s current stop, Memphis, Senior Vice President and Director of Intercollegiate Athletics Ed Scott said Franklin, along with Nick Saban, gave a firm recommendation for Huff.

“What truly sets him apart is his character and integrity,” Franklin said according to Memphis.

Then there’s Terry Smith, who left a 2-10 Temple team where he coached the wide receivers, and was hired by Franklin as cornerbacks coach.

He may have never, and may never, get a shot to be a full-time head coach, but his time as an interim and his role as associate head coach made him one of the more respected, and highest-paid, assistants in the business.

That in its own right is an accomplishment in Black coaching history as according to a 2023 article from the Journal of Intercollegiate Sport, “Black coaches were disproportionately responsible for signing higher rated recruits than their White counterparts.” Said responsibility comes from what’s usually a position coach, a typically underpaid role.

And also with a look through the Lasch Building, the diversity, from all shapes of life and all positions, was evident; Franklin’s a man who wants to give a chance to the most qualified.

But, that didn’t mean it was all perfect.

As the big personality in Franklin fought a passionate, but critical fanbase, many seasons didn’t go by without a “Fire Franklin!” chant of some sorts.

Even in what I’d consider a mishandling of his responsibilities as head man, walking off of the podium when asked for comment on the accusations of rape committed by his former players Jameial Lyons and Kaveion Keys, Franklin had his fair share of incidents that hurt his resume and perception.

But, said turn in perception, regardless of severity of the incident, is a microcosm of the fight Black coaches have fought for a long time.

“I’m sick of us having to be perfect to get the job,” legendary Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson Jr. said in 1998.

Black coaches have often been far behind the ladder when it comes to making the big step.

For Franklin, that started as a non-Division l collegiate player, and included a player/coach job in Denmark that he told Inside the Lions’ Audrey Snyder he laid asphalt during.

It took Franklin 16 years to earn the big shot, though it’s worth noting the sort of systematic privilege as a former quarterbacks coach that was promoted to offensive coordinator got him the opportunity even fast. He also got an 11-plus-year leash — a dream for many others.

But it didn’t change his end at Penn State.

The boos, curses and toxicity made Franklin a subject of pure resentment from a fanbase that, despite his successes, are likely rooted in a feeling of him not doing enough and not appreciating enough.

It’s a setback in his journey that, coincidentally, came in an NFL season that saw Mike Tomlin be fired and no Black coach be hired.

But it’s also a message that Franklin, and many others, aren’t done fighting. As Franklin makes a home in Blacksburg, Virginia, he continues to push for a fair shot for all.

But he isn’t, and can’t, start from ground zero. Despite the darkness — some to his fault and some to others’ — created during his end in Happy Valley, Franklin’s tenure is a marker for true success for a Black coach at the collegiate level.

It shouldn’t be overshadowed.

title: How to send THON Dancer Mail, its impact
author: Emma Naysmith | The Daily Collegian
description:
One of THON’s traditions is Dancer Mail Call, a designated surprise point of the weekend where every dancer is delivered mail from family, friends and the larger THON community.

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

According to Dancer Relations Mail Call Captain Clayton Roynan, this tradition began in 1990 with Mike “the Mailman” Herr, who has become a returning figure during mail delivery.

"We're nearly 40 years into the tradition, and it really just started off where he would hand out some letters and packages to the dancers,” Roynan, a third-year studying accounting and finance, said. “Since then, it's become a much more upscale thing where there's an address specifically for mail.”

Dancer Mail has a deadline of February 11 and can be brought to a letter dropbox outside of 215 Johnston Commons Building or mailed with a postmark by then to be delivered THON Weekend.

There’s also the option for the public to scan and upload letters online to be printed for delivery. For questions and more information, Dancer Relations Mail Call Captain Adrienne Mudry said to visit the Dancer Mail page on the THON site.

The current mailroom for THON Dancer Mail is located in Findlay Commons. Here, THON volunteers, with the help of a few Universal Parcel Service employees, collect and organize the mail by dancer, according to Mudry, a fourth-year studying biobehavioral health.

Mudry said the mailroom also has donations from local businesses to help with the mail sorting effort.

The mailroom receives over 10,000 letters and upwards of 600 packages, according to Roynan.

“This semester we get donations from GIANT, they give us banana boxes which hold all the letter bags we get donated from Wegmans,” Mudry said. “That's to have sustainability, they give us the reusable grocery bags, and then we label every single grocery bag with the dancers, number and letter.”

In the past, not every dancer was sent mail, but Mudry said they now work to ensure that every dancer receives at least ten pieces of mail to read. Each dancer is also able to be given two packages.

“We send out lots of emails to the families and the THON Chairs encouraging them if they know people who are dancing, or if their friends from their org are dancing, to write them letters,” Roynan said. “And if they don't know people who are dancing, they can write generic mail.”

Matt Miller danced in THON 2025 with the Sapphire Leadership Academic Program and said his dancer mail came at the “perfect time.”

“I remember opening the first couple from family and friends … people from my organization,” Miller, a 2025 Penn State alum, said. “I was in Nittany Lion Consulting Group, and folks on our executive board were writing stuff, people that I had been on committees with from two years ago sending stuff, and then even the mail itself is really important.”

Miller said collecting his mail provided him with a “needed boost.”

“You never know the impact it could have,” Miller said. “The impact it has is wonderful, and I still to this day have kept my notes.”

In writing letters to dancers, Roynan said there are a few things to avoid mentioning.

“Try not to mention ‘Oh, you're almost finished, can't wait to go home and sleep or take a shower,’ that kind of stuff,” Roynan said. “When we do it, it's toward the later hours of THON, so a lot of the dancers are typically struggling at that time.”

Mudry said she’s always remembered seeing dancers reading their mail in the THON recap video, and recalls them looking “so happy or touched by it.”

“Even if it's just a silly little letter with some jokes in there, they're not expecting certain letters from some people most of the time,” Mudry said. “People don't realize how important a heartfelt, little, tiny message could be.”

MORE THON COVERAGE

title: Big Ten recap | 6 teams clinch conference tournament appearances with tournament drawing near
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten tournament is just three weeks away, and many teams are paving the way for a spot in the tournament.

Over the past week, two more teams clinched tournament bids while several teams drew further away from an appearance.

Here’s a look at what happened in last week’s Big Ten action.

Minnesota’s upset win earns tournament bid

Minnesota’s season has been fairly predictable — beating the lower-ranked teams and falling to the higher-ranked teams.

On Thursday, that changed as the unranked Golden Gophers toppled No. 10 Iowa in Iowa City.

The Hawkeyes held the early advantage, as expected, as they closed the first quarter with a one-point lead. However, that disappeared in the second quarter as Minnesota outscored Iowa by 11 points.

Minnesota had five players score double-digits on the day, led by Grace Grocholski’s 21 points.

The Golden Gophers extended that lead with a 23-16 third quarter, and held on despite Iowa’s 30-19 comeback fourth quarter.

While Minnesota’s defense only mustered three steals and a block, its high-scoring offense — including 71.43% three-point shooting — had a heyday in its upset win.

Sunday afternoon nail-biter

Amidst a dominant 12-0 conference run, UCLA faced its toughest Big Ten game of the year when it visited Ann Arbor for a top-10 matchup against Michigan.

The game saw back-and-forth success from both sides, as the Wolverines took the first quarter and the Bruins the second. After UCLA entered the final quarter with a nine-point lead, Michigan tried to claw back after outscoring the Bruins 21-15, but ultimately fell by three points.

It was the second- lowest scoring contest for UCLA and the second-lowest for Michigan, finishing at 69-66 on the scoreboard.

Both teams’ highest scorers had just 20 points, as Olivia Olson and Kiki Rice each found success from the court.

The Bruins took strong command with a two-game lead over the tournament’s top seed, while Michigan holds a tied spot for the No. 2 seed.

Indiana’s late-season success

After losing nine straight games to open the new year, Indiana has flipped the switch.

The Hoosiers have won three straight games and tentatively have a spot in the Big Ten tournament. Over the past two weeks, they’ve defeated Northwestern, Wisconsin and Purdue, moving to 14-11 on the year.

In the battle for the current No. 14 seed, Indiana defeated Purdue on Sunday behind another dominant Shay Ciezki performance.

The former Penn State guard scored 29 points against the Boilermakers as she continued her Big Ten Player of the Year campaign, leading the conference with 24.1 points per game.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Tessa Janecke, Team USA move to 3-0 with shutout victory over Team Switzerland
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After outscoring its opponents 10-1 in the first two games of the Olympic prelims, Tessa Janecke and Team USA’s success continued on Monday.

The United States defeated Switzerland, 5-0, as it moved to 3-0 in the preliminary round.

The scoreboard was empty for several minutes of action despite a strong attack from the U.S. Janecke, Abbey Murphy and Laila Edwards all had shots in the first five minutes, but none were successful.

After six minutes of no action on the scoreboard, Haley Winn found the goal, putting the U.S. up 1-0. Winn was assisted by Caroline Harvey and Hilary Knight.

It was pure domination in the first period as the Americans proved they're one of the Gold Medal favorites, outshooting Switzerland 18-6 in the period.

Following Winn’s goal, the ice was silent for nearly 30 minutes as neither side found success putting the puck in the net. However, Joy Dunne scored at the 14:08 minute mark to make it a two-point game.

That U.S. scoring streak began as the final period was underway with back-to-back goals by Hannah Bilka and Alex Carpenter to take a 4-0 lead.

Bilka’s first goal of the game came off assists by Taylor Heise and Harvey, while Carpenter’s score was helped by Knight and Dunne. It was all U.S. through the first two periods and the scoring started to fully break through in the third period.

With the time winding down, Harvey scored her own goal — assisted by Carpenter and Dunne — as the United States won its third straight game with five goals scored.

Despite not showing up on the score sheet, Janecke totaled three shots and was a plus-1, being on the ice for Dunne's goal. She totaled 12:07 of ice time in the victory, averaging 45 seconds per shift on the ice.

Up next

The United States will wrap up the preliminary rounds with its final match against Canada at 2:10 p.m. on Tuesday before kicking off the quarterfinals.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: 2026 Milano Cortina results, updates for Penn State athletes
author: Collegian sports staff
description:
Starting on Feb. 4 with the first events of the 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympics, Penn State will be represented by five different athletes competing during the 19-day event.

Stay tuned below to catch the latest information and updates on every Penn State competitor during the world's biggest competition.

Women's hockey

Penn State will have four representatives compete in women's hockey. Two for Team Sweden, one from the home country, Italy and one for Team USA.

Tessa Janecke, Team USA

Tessa Janecke becomes the first Nittany Lion hockey player to compete for Team USA after competing on the next biggest stages in the Rivalry Series and World Championship team.

Team USA's path to Gold

Team USA vs. Czechia - USA, 5-1

Team USA vs. Team Finland - USA, 5-0

Team USA vs. Team Switzerland - USA, 5-0

Matilde Fantin, Team Italy

At just 19 years old, Matilde Fantin will make her Olympic debut for the host country, Italy. Fantin has stood out in her freshman season for Penn State as one of the Nittany Lions' top goal scorers.

Team Italy's path to success

Team Italy vs. Team France - Italy, 4-1

Team Italy vs. Team Sweden - Sweden, 6-1

Team Italy vs. Team Japan - Italy, 3-2

Nicole Hall, Team Sweden

Nicole Hall received and invitation to Team Sweden's Olympic training camp with the hopes to earn a spot on the team. She did just that, joining another Nittany Lion on the Swedish hockey team.

Jessica Adolfsson, Team Sweden

Jessica Adolfsson makes her return to the Olympics after competing in the 2022 Olympics for Team Sweden. Adolfsson has an Olympic Games under her belt and will compete in her second games at 27 years old.

Team Sweden's path to Gold

Team Sweden vs. Team Germany - Sweden, 4-1

Team Sweden vs. Team Italy - Sweden, 6-1

Team Sweden vs. Japan - Sweden 4-0

Skeleton

Penn State has just one competitor in the sport, competing for Team USA in the Olympic Games.

Daniel Barefoot, Team USA

Daniel Barefoot will make his Olympic debut at 35 years old. His story is unlike any other after picking up skeleton post graduation at Penn State.

Training runs - 4:30 a.m. EST, Monday, Feb. 9

Barefoot's Olympic journey begins at 10:30 a.m. CET, 4:30 a.m. EST with training sessions prior to heats beginning three days later on Feb. 12. Barefoot was dealing with a shoulder injury, but his official training runs should be a go for the Penn State alum.

Preseason recognition from @d1baseball 💪#WeAre pic.twitter.com/qH77QCY3C6— Penn State Baseball (@PennStateBASE) February 9, 2026

title: Penn State women's hockey remains at No. 4 heading into final weekend of regular season
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian

pic.twitter.com/5NDsWbsXwS— USCHO.com (@USCHO) February 9, 2026

title: Gavin McKenna's preliminary hearing moved to March 11
author: Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
The preliminary hearing for Gavin McKenna’s assault case has been moved to March 11 at 8:30 a.m., according to a document from the Centre County District Court’s website.

The hearing was previously scheduled for Wednesday. McKenna was charged with aggravated and simple assault on Feb. 4, following an alleged altercation with a 21-year-old male on Jan. 31 near Doggie’s Pub in downtown State College.

The criminal complaint said McKenna struck the man in the face, causing “facial injuries requiring corrective surgery.”

However, the aggravated assault charge was dropped by Centre County District Attorney Bernie Cantorna on Friday, stating his office and the State College Police Department “do not believe that a charge of aggravated assault is supported by the evidence."

McKenna still faces charges of simple assault, harassment and disorderly conduct.

The Penn State Men's hockey team final regular season game is scheduled for March 6 at home against Wisconsin. March 11 marks the first day of the Big Ten Tournament, with Penn State currently seeded to play at home against Ohio State.

The new hearing will occur during Penn State’s spring break when many students won’t be in State College.

title: Penn State women's hockey forward Matilde Fantin powers Italy to Olympic win over Japan
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
To no surprise of Penn State hockey fans, Matilde Fantin is succeeding on the Olympic stage.

After scoring a goal in Italy’s win over France and being held scoreless against Sweden, Fantin powered through with two goals in Italy’s 3-2 win over Japan.

It was a slow opening period, as the first 12 minutes showed no change to the scoreboard.

Despite no score, Italy's dominance was on display, holding the advantage in faceoffs and shots on goal.

At the 12:34 mark of the first quarter, Fantin found the back of the goal, marking her second score of the Olympic Games.

The Penn State star was assisted by Laura Lobis and Kayla Tutino, putting Team Italy up early.

After another few minutes of Italian dominance on all sides of the ice, Fantin struck again to take a 2-0 lead with 1:09 left in the period.

Fantin’s second goal came off an Italian power play after a two-minute interference call against Japan’s Kohane Sato. With time to spare, Nadia Mattivi and Laura Fortino dished the puck to Fantin with the advantage.

While the remaining minutes of the first period and the first two minutes of the second period were without action, Japan got its first goal on the board quickly out of the middle period.

Rui Ukita put the Japanese on the board early, assisted by Rio Noro.

After Japan’s score in the opening minutes, things came to a standstill for the remaining 17 minutes of the first half. Besides a tripping penalty by Italy’s Carola Saletta, the scoreboard remained empty as the Italians took a 2-1 lead into the final 20 minutes.

That scoreline didn’t last long, however, as Kristin Della Rovere netted an unassisted goal just 37 seconds into the period to make it a two-goal lead again.

Things looked to be smooth sailing the rest of the way for Team Italy, who had control of the puck for most of the third period. However, Akane Shiga made it a one-point game at the 11:01 mark with her first goal of the game.

While the Japanese made things a lot tighter down the final stretch, Fantin and Italy held their momentum and earned their second win of the Olympic Games.

Up next

Fantin and Team Italy will face off against Germany at 10:40 a.m. on Tuesday in their final preliminary game. Italy’s win over Japan put it in position for a quarterfinals appearance, but it will need to hold a top-three finish in Group B to do so.

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Column | It’s OK not to be in a relationship
author: Emma Strickling | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s the final scene in the movie. The two lovers are reunited as the music swells. After a confession of love, they kiss. The screen fades and eventually reads “The End.” The lights come back on as people exit the theatre. Feelings of jealousy, loneliness and angst swirl inside of those who attended alone.

The feeling of wanting to be in a relationship is a year-round occurrence for some. However, it’s often exacerbated with the approach of Valentine’s Day. Our society seems to depict being single as the social equivalent of the plague. But in reality, it’s perfectly fine to not be in a relationship right now.

You might have read that last line with an accompanying scoff, as if that sentence alone can cure the perpetual feeling of yearning, but it’s true. There’s nothing wrong with being alone.

Sure, it might feel awkward if you are one of the only ones in your friend group without a partner, but it’s only awkward if you make it that way. Just because you’re single doesn’t mean you're less worthy than those in relationships.

Of course, there’s a type of validation that comes with being in a relationship and it’s something that can make us feel good. But if it becomes something that you are desperately seeking out from others, then you’re placing your self-worth in their hands.

We put being in a relationship on a pedestal and once we enter one, it’s meant to fix everything or so we’re made to believe.

But I think putting so much emphasis on romantic relationships ends up being harmful. It creates expectations that any problems you have with yourself or in your own life will simply be resolved. But when that doesn’t happen, it leaves you feeling disappointed and frustrated because it wasn’t the magical fix it was built up to be.

This desire for escape can lead to being in a relationship just for the sake of being in one, where expectations are lowered, leading to excuses being made for the unsavory behavior of the other person. At that point, you’re wasting your own time.

It’s also perfectly fine to not want to be in a relationship either. Whether people care to acknowledge it or not, relationships take a lot of time and effort.

If you have areas of your life you want to focus on, then why should you let someone else and their nonsense get in the way. Yes, there’s a possibility to do both. But there’s the likelihood of needing to make compromises that lead to you sacrificing your own goals.

There’s more than one way to live life and you shouldn’t let societal expectations force you into a life you don’t want. This is especially true for women, as it’s often parroted that our only function in life is to be in a relationship. If you have a goal you want to reach, why should you put it on hold for someone else?
