I’m not trying to say that being in a relationship is bad. It’s fine to recognize that it’s something you would like to have in your future. The problem is when it’s something that turns into an obsessive need and your only priority, to the point where you base your self-worth on whether or not you’re getting romantic attention.

It's important to ask yourself why you want to be in a relationship. Go beyond the reasoning of “I just want one,” and think about why.

If you want to share your life with someone and want to grow with someone while maintaining independence, then there’s a possibility for a healthy relationship. If you’re just looking to fill a void, then you should probably turn your attention inward to what it is you really need.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Column | The power of saying ‘Yes!’ in Scotland
author: Samantha DiCamillo | The Daily Collegian
description:
The opportunity to step out of your comfort zone is always there, you just have to be open to it. It’s perfectly normal to feel anxious, worried or out of place. The willingness to participate in events when you’re scared only makes the memories even fonder to look back on.

Being an abroad student in a foreign country has put me in situations I’ve never experienced before. But every time I chose to take the risk, the reward made it worth it.

Edinburgh, Scotland, is an excellent destination to try things you’ve never done before. The vibrant city is filled with a bustling environment, bright red double-decker buses, slanted cobble roads and historic buildings looming in the distance.

Although Scotland sees a generous amount of rain, this doesn’t diminish any of the opportunities it presents. As I grew more comfortable living in this country, I noticed important events I should take time out of my day to participate in. It’s vital to research potential activities or discuss suggestions with friends to make the most of the time abroad.

Scotland is the perfect place for new experiences and saying “Yes!” to embracing the unknown. It’s a great location for travelers to meet people from around the world. Everyone is willing to converse and compare their backgrounds. The exchange of culture and tradition is prominent in the capital, and Edinburgh is proud to share its history with others.

As I walked around the city as a tourist, the number of cafes stood out to me. Each with their own charm, the cafes welcomed customers who were interested in enjoying the calming atmospheres they provided. Cafes are the perfect place for a filling breakfast, a chat with a friend or a delicious coffee with a biscuit. When visiting Scotland, look around for new coffee spots that could be your new study place.

Always say “yes!” when exploring the city. Grab a couple of friends or go on a solo adventure discovering where your favorite place could be. The city is packed with stores, souvenir shops, restaurants, pubs and more.

Being in a foreign country presents the best opportunity to sample unique food and drinks. It might surprise you to learn what food you could enjoy.

Scotland also has many historic locations to visit that require a hike to reach the desired location. There are castles open to the public brimming with Scottish history. One of the most popular attractions is interacting with the highland cows. In Scotland, the word “cow” is pronounced “coo.”

These special cows native to Scotland have a bright orange coat with two long horns. They can be found in multiple areas in Scotland, and are astonishing to see in person.

Tourists are encouraged to visit the farms, and spectate the herd of cows known to roam freely. For people who want to limit the amount of hiking, there are a few highland cows in enclosures at the front of some of the farms. This promotes accessibility to all. It’s important to take time to say “yes!” and go on the journey to see all the sights Scotland has to offer.

By starting your day with saying “yes!” you open the door to a whole new batch of possibilities. My suggestion is to try starting with a small activity to say “yes!” to, and discover the positive effects it has. These can include meeting new people, promoting a healthier lifestyle and boosting your mood.

Penn State is the perfect university to start this small change, and get accustomed to saying “yes!” more often. It’s full of clubs, a variety of food and life on or off-campus. The power of the word “yes!” can be an amazing sight to witness.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: 5 Black artists in The Palmer Museum of Art
author: Ava Crawley | The Daily Collegian
description:
When most people think of lavish art museums, State College doesn’t exactly come to mind — yet right here on campus is a cultural treasure trove that students often walk past. The Palmer Museum of Art, home to the largest art collection between Pittsburgh and Philadelphia, displays walls filled with history, protest and beauty.

As Black History Month approaches, one place to celebrate the creativity of Black artists is the Palmer Museum of Art. From contemporary art to sculptures, to American art, the museum reminds us of the powerful artists and moving stories that extend far beyond the frame.

Howardena Pindell (American b. 1943), Untitled 1969-73

Pindell expresses more through color and texture on a canvas than most can through words. After Pindell studied at Yale University and mentored with Josef Albers, she learned to embrace abstract art during a time when many Black artists began to portray racial identity through their work.

Inspired by Claude Monet and Georges Seurat, Pindell developed her signature style of brightly hued repetitive dots using acrylic paint and stencils. However, the dots represent far more than an eye-catching design, they symbolize her past.

Pindell recalls childhood trips for root beer with her father, moments marked not by sweetness but by segregation. Red circles stamped on the bottom of the mugs, indicating the glasses were reserved for people of color, became burned into her memory. In her work, those circles reappear. Turning from symbols of exclusion into proof of resilience, Pindell confronts racial trauma one dot at a time.

Barkley L. Hendricks (American, 1945-2017), “Father, Son, and …,” 1969

Born and raised in Philadelphia, Hendricks grew up on basketball courts, playing pickup games, and proudly cheering on the Philadelphia 76ers. Before earning a master’s degree in fine arts at Yale University, he focused on his abstraction skills through a series of basketball inspired paintings.

“In Father, Son, and…,” he strips the game down to its essential geometry and color. The work's spiritual title and three paneled composition honors the neighborhood regulars who filled the basketball courts during pickup games, turning cracked cement into spaces of connection and belonging.

Purvis Young (American, 1943-2010), Untitled, 1999

The theme of protest emerges in Young's work. Working with found materials, like discarded wood, Young pays homage to the legacy of the Black Power mural movement of the late 1960s.

His figures — arms raised in defiance — confront injustice face-to-face. Through this piece, Young proves that protest does not need to be grand scale. All it takes is passion, paint and a surface willing to illustrate the message.

Renée Stout (American, b. 1958) “Portrait of Fatima at Forty-Five”, 2004

Stout uses found objects and fragmented images of her body to build Fatima, a middle-aged woman who owns a root store, filled with potions and herbal remedies. Fatima not only represents parts of Stout she felt pressured to suppress in order to feel accepted, but also portrays the spiritual practices of Afro-Caribbean Vodou traditions.

Through this layered portrait, Stout speaks directly to those searching for the power within them.

Louis B. Sloan (American 1932-2008), Untitled (Portrait of a Boy) about 1958-67

Sloan studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, and eventually became its first Black instructor. He was known for his depictions of Philadelphia’s rowhomes and dark alleyways. However, in this piece, the architecture dims and the spotlight shifts to a young boy.

His identity remains unknown, but it's believed that Sloan, an artist, mentor and teacher, could have very easily crossed paths with him before, exemplifying the idea of the countless untold stories that exist beyond the canvas.

Coming Works

“Insistent Presence: Contemporary African Art from the Chazen Collection” is coming to the Palmer Museum of Art Feb. 7 to May 10.

The exhibition features works from artists across the African continent and is arranged in three sections. Each section will invite viewers to reflect on themselves and their relationships, according to palmermuseum.edu.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: This week in State College
author: Neel Ved | The Daily Collegian
description:
Midterms are underway, but there are still plenty of events happening on and off-campus, giving students opportunities to step away from just their classes.

Here are some events to take a break from studying.

Monday, February 9

Sarah Dimick Book Reading

From 6-7 p.m., Sarah Dimick, the author of “Unseasonable: Climate Change in Global Literature,” will be doing a book reading, interview and Q&A at Webster’s Bookstore Cafe. There will also be a dinner buffet starting at 5:30 p.m.

This event is free and open to all, and registration is required for online attendance.

Chess Night

From 5:30-7 p.m. the Centre County Library and Historical Museum will be hosting a chess night. All levels are welcome, whether it be beginners or experienced players.

There will be an instructor available to teach and assist people and registration is not required.

Tuesday, February 10

Stomper Workshop

From 2-4 p.m., the Penn State Counseling and Psychological Services will be hosting a workshop with the Jana Marie Foundation in the HUB-Robeson Center. This will be a creative workshop for participants to help “stomp out” the stigma surrounding mental illness.

Attendees will learn about mental health education and suicide prevention as they work to create a life-sized sculpture from recycled sneakers.

Registration is required to attend.

Salsa Lessons

The Penn State Social Dance Club will be teaching salsa lessons at the State College Municipal Building from 6-8:30 p.m.. The lessons are open to all, from students and faculty to community members.

You can come with a partner or by yourself, as they will pair up solo members for lessons. The first 90 minutes will be lessons, and the remainder of the event will be for social dancing to music.

Wednesday, February 11

Yoga and Mediation

From 12-1 p.m., the Palmer Museum of Art will be hosting yoga and meditation sessions.

During this time, anyone is welcome to let their mind and body fall into a relaxing, rejuvenating yoga and meditation practice. All sessions are led by certified instructors, and everyone is welcome to come no matter their experience level.

Supplies are limited, so it is recommended to bring your own.

Well-being Wednesday

From 3-5 p.m., stop by the lobby of the Intramural Building for wellness activities and resources. There will be outreach tables staffed by HealthWorks Peer Educators for people to learn more about its weekly theme.

Previous themes have included self-care, sleep hygiene, skin protection and stress management.

Love in Full Color

From 4:30-6:30 p.m., stop by the HUB to participate in some creative activities such as painting, coloring and designing your own bouquet to celebrate self-love and uplift your body.

Everyone is welcome and encouraged to attend this event. Registration is not required.

Thursday, February 12

Gallery Talk + Conversation: Insistent Presence

From 5:30-6:30 p.m. stop by the Palmer Museum of Art for an in-depth exploration of the special exhibition Insistence Presence: Contemporary African Art from the Chazen Collection with Amanda Hellman, the Palmer Museum of Art’s director and specialist of African art.

This event is open to all and registration is not required.

Friday, February 13

Penn State vs. Ohio State Wrestling Match

The Penn State Nittany Lions wrestling team will take on Ohio State in the Bryce Jordan Center for a dual meet. The match starts at 7 p.m. and doors open at 5:30 p.m.

Tickets can be found on Ticketmaster, starting around $63.

Saturday, February 14

Sweetheart Swing Dance

3 Dots Downtown will be hosting a Valentine’s Day swing dance from 6:30-9 p.m. Come with a special someone or alone and make some new friends while enjoying the live swinging music of Crooner & Co Swing Band.

There will be lessons before the band’s set, which starts at 6:30 pm., then two hours of social dancing to live music from 7-9 p.m.

This event is free for Penn State students and $10 for non-students.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: 7 things to do for the ‘bit’ at Penn State
author: Suzain Khan | The Daily Collegian
description:
College is already unserious, so why not lean into it. Between sprinting to class, convincing yourself that an iced coffee is a valid meal and spending time on a workload that never seems to go down, there’s a sense of fun to be found almost anywhere.

So if you’re already going to do something slightly unnecessary, mildly inconvenient or a little dramatic, you might as well commit.

Here is a list of things you can do for “the bit” this spring semester.

1. Go out wearing a brightly colored wig and pretend to be someone else

Pick the color with the most personality — blue, pink, purple or whatever your heart desires — and commit fully. Give yourself a new name and backstory, and introduce yourself with confidence like this version of you has always existed. Adopt a whole new persona and then never acknowledge it again.

2. Do something mildly embarrassing on purpose and survive it

Pick anything that might make you feel nervous and do it.

Wear something slightly questionable, speak up when you normally wouldn’t, laugh a little too loudly or pick a “cheugy” word and keep saying it with friends. The moment passes and you’ll realize no one cares.

Embarrassment only lasts as long as you let it, which is kind of freeing and also deeply funny.

3. Dress formally for a 9 a.m. lecture

Everyone else is in sweats, half-asleep and clutching a coffee like it’s life support. Imagine how much fun it could be if you show up dressed like you have a networking event, or take it a step further and wear a prom dress. Commitment matters.

Even if you go straight home afterward, the confidence boost is worth it.

4. Sit in a completely different spot in lecture everyday

Front row today, back corner tomorrow. Pick somewhere you’ve never sat before just to keep things interesting. It changes nothing academically but it keeps everyone, including yourself, slightly unsettled. Sometimes a small shake-up is the only thrill you get before noon.

5. Get a fun drink downtown instead of eating actual food

Is it a meal? No. Does it have nutritional value? Debatable. Will you convince yourself it counts as sustenance anyway? Absolutely. It’s colorful, has ice and feels like a treat, which is honestly enough to justify on a random weekday.

Bonus points if you pick a place or drink you haven’t tried before. Whether you hate it or not, you’ll still get a kick out of trying something new.

6. Go into the wrong class with a friend and stay for exactly thirty seconds

Sit down confidently and start a loud conversation about something completely unrelated — weekend plans, a fake argument or a story that makes no sense in context. Let the confusion settle in. Notice the professor pause, then stand up, walk out calmly and never react. Timing matters, so try to be in and out before it becomes a problem.

7. Complain about Penn State while secretly loving it

You’ll talk about how chaotic, overwhelming and unserious it is — then immediately defend it if anyone else criticizes it. You act like you’re exhausted by it all, but you know you’d miss it the second you left. That contradiction? That’s part of the bit.

One day, Penn State will be something you talk about in the past tense. Until then, embrace the chaos, complain lovingly and do a few things just for the stories made along the way. That’s the bit and it’s worth it.

MORE BLOGS

title: Former Penn State long snapper Chris Stoll wins Super Bowl with Seattle Seahawks
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
SANTA CLARA, Calif. — A former Nittany Lion is leaving California with a Super Bowl win.

Ex-Penn State long snapper Chris Stoll has earned himself a ring with the Seattle Seahawks in their 29-13 victory over the New England Patriots.

Stoll is in his third season with the Seahawks, signing with them as an undrafted free agent in May 2023. He’s played every game as the starter since then, appearing in the last 51 over the past three campaigns.

“I got very lucky Seattle reached out after the draft, had a spot open and was able to do well enough to keep that spot,” Stoll told The Daily Collegian on Tuesday.

He bested former Penn State offensive lineman Caedan Wallace, who was a healthy scratch for the contest. He has only played in four games this season, and appeared in six games in 2024 with a pair of starts after being drafted 68th overall in the third round.

“Rough times last year, and then the build up to this year has been really cool. It’s been a lot of ups and downs, but I'm happy to be right here,” Wallace told The Daily Collegian on Thursday.

Stoll joins the running list of former Penn Staters to win the Super Bowl, as an ex-Nittany Lion has done so in all but five.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘It's really hard to win with 17 turnovers’ | Penn State men’s basketball loses turnover battle to USC
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State basketball hosted USC, and both teams had very different seasons up to the clash, but once they stepped onto the hardwood, the play became intertwined, making it harder and harder to distinguish the two as the clock ticked inside the Bryce Jordan Center.

Ultimately, that remained the trend the entire game, as the Trojans snagged a victory in the last ten seconds of play, courtesy of freshman Alijah Arenas’s buzzer-beater already making the rounds on social media.

The boxscore reinforced that sentiment, with almost all stats level after 40 minutes of play, except on the defensive side of the ball, where the Trojans continued to disrupt any chance at a blue and white win.

Both squads were banged up, with three players sidelined, yet that didn’t appear to fluster the Nittany Lions; they maintained their momentum, though it did halt the fluidity of their play.

“They played good defense,” Josh Reed said. “We made a lot of mistakes, we had a lot of turnovers, and (USC) scored off every turnover. I feel like if we kept our mistakes to a minimum, it would have been a different game.”

The blue and white, which is one of seven Big Ten teams averaging fewer than 10 turnovers per game and is tied for second in the conference in steals per game, yet it was its opponent who implemented those trends in the game.

At halftime, the Nittany Lions led 40-36, with a growing opportunity to earn their second conference win exactly a week after their first. Soon after the break, the lead extended to 12, but the writing was on the wall; the Trojans matched the Nittany Lions' assist and steal totals, while USC turned the ball over three times fewer.

That cleaned-up effort by the warriors from the West Coast allowed USC to cut into the lead quickly after the Nittany Lions got that double-digit lead – a factor that allowed them to steal the win from under Penn State coach Mike Rhoades.

“When we got that lead we had, we made some bad, poor decisions,” Rhodes said. “(Either) with turnovers, or around the basket, jumping up on the air, fighting a shot, and that leads in the turnovers, and I thought that was the difference in the game.”

As the Trojans arrived in Happy Valley, it wasn’t expected to have stellar play ready to disrupt the Nittany Lions on both sides. USC ranked as the Big Ten's leader in turnovers per contest and also arrived with a bottom-five points-allowed figure in the conference – the only teams it trailed all also had negative point differentials.

The Nittany Lions also outranked the Trojans’ steal metrics, as USC tied for No. 6.

“We've done a great job all year with this group of not turning the ball over,” Rhoades said. “I just thought we had way too many turnovers that led to them getting baskets that we couldn't defend.”

The Nittany Lions finished with two more turnovers than USC’s 15, which even clears the Trojans average of the most turnovers in the conference.

Coaching wasn’t happy, players were even less so, and all the fans in the BJC, sporting various-colored shirts for THON, as the stands began to resemble a gumball machine, had their own bubbles burst in what was one of the liveliest home crowds for Penn State this year.

“17 turnovers (is) just too many,” Rhoades said. “I don't care who you play; it's really hard to win with 17 turnovers. Playing talented players, and you give them more opportunities; give them the ball to get going. It's really hard.”

Nonetheless, despite the visibly disgruntled Penn State squad, which appeared heartbroken by such a tragic way to lose, it looks ready to turn around and keep fighting, knowing exactly what to address.

“We're gonna hit the road tomorrow, go out west,” Reed said. “(We’ll) watch film, try to learn from our mistakes, and be ready to play Washington.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘We didn’t execute’ | Penn State basketball makes mistake that allows last-second shot by USC
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
USC guard Alijah Arenas gathered an inbounds pass near the middle of the court. The Trojans and Penn State were knotted up with seven seconds left, and Arenas had a chance to win it for his squad.

Arenas did exactly that as he drove into the paint and laid in a game-winning basket with less than a second left. The shot gave USC a 77-75 victory on Sunday, marking the Nittany Lions’ sixth loss by single digits this season.

Mike Rhoades mentioned Penn State was “switching everything” coming out of the last timeout, saying one of his players didn’t follow that plan.

“We didn't execute the defensive switch at the end,” Rhoades said. “That's just disappointing. That's on me, going to continue to keep helping these guys have late-game mental toughness and approach. You pride yourself as a coach to win close games, and I haven't done that.”

During his time at Penn State, which is since the start of the 2023-24 season, Rhoades has lost 26 games by single digits. For comparison, the Nittany Lions have won 16 matchups by single digits under Rhoades.

On the Nittany Lions’ final defensive possession of Sunday’s game, guard Freddie Dilione V defended Arenas down to the basket. Forward Josh Reed came in to help, and 7-footer Ivan Jurić was guarding a different player in the paint.

Guard Kayden Mingo stayed near the perimeter while guard Dominick Stewart was right next to the paint after defending a player on the opposite side of the court as Arenas.

“He just made a tough move, tough play,” Reed said. “I tried to come over and help. Not much I can do about that.”

Penn State came back to give itself a chance to win, making all five of its last five field-goal attempts. Rhoades said he felt his players executed on some plays down the stretch, but it didn’t happen on the last defensive play of the game.

There’s been other times this season where the Nittany Lions failed to execute late before losing a game by a close margin. Against Michigan on Jan. 6, Penn State didn’t create any open looks on its last possession of the game before losing, 74-72.

“You want to be as mistake-free as you can late in the game,” Rhoades said. “It happens, right? Sometimes a play messes something up, and a guy thinks differently or does differently. I mean, that's why you play the game.”

Prior to crunch time, Penn State led by as many as 12 points in the second half, which came when it led 50-38 with 17:23 left in the game. USC dwindled the advantage as the Nittany Lions endured numerous miscues, first taking a lead at 56-55 with 10:56 left.

But the most impactful mistake came right at the end as Penn State was one less play by Arenas away from picking up its second Big Ten win of the year. Players looked stunned after the game-winning shot, but Reed knows there’s still more basketball to be played with seven games left in the regular season.

“It definitely hurts,” Reed said. “We have basically a game every other two or three days, so we're gonna hit the road tomorrow, watch film, try to learn from our mistakes, and be ready to play Washington on Wednesday.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball falls to USC in annual THON Game
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
In its annual THON game, Penn State hosted USC for the first time in program history.

The Nittany Lions’ 2-1 all-time record against the Trojans took a hit on Super Bowl Sunday, as the blue and white suffered a 77-75 loss that came down to the last few seconds.

“Close, but no cigar. Just not enough to finish down the stretch,” Mike Rhoades said. “We’ve done a great job all year with this group of not turning the ball over, and today we just had way too many turnovers that led to them getting baskets.”

Ivan Jurić won the opening tipoff for the blue and white but failed on his efforts in the post, leading to an easy Jacob Cofie bucket to put USC on the board first.

Josh Reed, who had a solid recent stretch of games entering Sunday’s contest, took it down the court and gave Penn State its first points of the night before quickly getting two more just a couple of possessions later to give the Nittany Lions their first lead of the day.

“I’ve just been trying to play confident and aggressive,” Reed said. “I just want to win… My teammates make me better as well.”

Penn State held on to the lead despite some alternating scores until a triple from Alijah Arenas, son of three-time NBA all-star Gilbert Arenas, put the Trojans back on top with a slight 11-10 edge.

A freshman, Arenas had appeared in just five games prior to his squad’s matchup with the Nittany Lions. Despite that, he is USC’s fourth-highest scorer, averaging 11.8 points per game.

At the media timeout at the 12- minute mark, the Trojans held a 14-13 lead after a Juriċ three-pointer sent the colorful THON shirt-wearing Bryce Jordan Center into a frenzy.

Another big man three-pointer, this time from seven-footer Justin Houser, tied the contest at 16-16. Houser was averaging 1.5 points per game through 11 appearances.

Ezra Ausar put down a big two-handed slam on the fast break after picking up a steal on Freddie Dilione V before Reed hit the tip-in off a missed Houser triple, which tied the game again at 25-25.

Dilione made up for it not long after, though, knocking down a trey to reclaim the lead before USC wrote back, with Jordan Marsh hitting his own three-pointer to keep a two-point advantage.

Kayden Mingo got just his fourth point of the game after a little shimmy shook his defender, as an easy layup cut the Nittany Lions’ deficit to two points, down 32-34 with just over three minutes left to play in the first half.

Dilione fought through some tough contact at the rim off a nice pass from Mingo, but went down holding his knee before a timeout. He may have just gotten tangled up, though, as he was back on the court after the timeout, looking just fine.

Consecutive scores from Reed as time was winding down gave Penn State a 40-36 lead at the half and gave him the second-most points for the blue and white with 10.

The shooting numbers for each side at the half were more-or-less identical, with the Nittany Lions shooting 53% from the field and 31% from three-point range compared to the Trojans’ 50% and 30% marks.

Penn State was also outrebounding USC 19-13 at the half – something that has been difficult for the Nittany Lions, as they’ve been the second-worst rebounding team in the Big Ten this season while the Trojans have been among the best, sitting in the top-five in the conference.

Juriċ started the second half off the same way he did the first, scoring a tough bucket through double coverage before a Dominick Stewart three-pointer the possession after to get the Nittany Lions off to a red-hot start.

In a blink-and-you’ll-miss-it kind of sequence, Mingo picked up a steal off Marsh and dished it down the court to Dilione, who turned it into a big one-handed slam, giving Penn State all the momentum as the blue and white pulled ahead to a 50-38 lead in the early running of the second half.

Mingo is averaging 2.2 steals per game as well as 4.5 assists and is the only freshman in the country to do so along with 13-plus points and 3.5-plus rebounds.

Dilione stayed hot and moved up to 19 points on a fast break, calling his own number to maintain an 11 point lead before the first media timeout of the second half.

A physical Houser block and rebound turned into a standing ovation from the student section as he walked to the bench with Juriċ coming in to replace him, though the freshman was having one of his best games out of a small sample size.

Ausar moved into foul trouble territory after picking up another personal, much to the delight of the legion of blue, which had been vocal all day. It was the 13th personal foul for the Trojans, with eight team fouls.

Marsh, who had been called for a tech earlier, knocked down a triple that moved USC within two points of Penn State’s once 12 point lead, as he cut it to a 51-53 Trojan deficit.

“They played good defense, but I think it was more so on us,” Reed said about Penn State’s scoring deficit. “If we kept our mistakes to a minimum, it would have been a different game.”

The Trojans picked up their first lead of the game since the later stages of the first half after a Kam Woods free throw following a Houser foul.

A Juriċ and-one following yet another USC foul brought Penn State closer to recapturing the lead as the Trojans were sitting on a 64-61 lead with just about five minutes left in the game.

Dilione was the first from either end to reach the 20 point mark as he knocked one down from the charity stripe to cut the Trojan lead to 66-67 with time winding down in the second half.

Reed knocked down a triple off the dump-off from Dilione to make it a 71-72 ballgame with a minute left to play before Arenas was fouled and knocked down both free throws to put the Trojans up 74-71 with just 30 seconds left on the clock.

A Stewart score brought the Nittany Lions within one point of the lead, but with having to intentionally foul, Penn State sent Arenas to the line, where he only knocked down one of two, leading to a Dilione coast-to-coast basket that tied the game at 75-75.

With just 7.3 seconds on the clock, Arenas knocked down the game-winning score, leaving Penn State with just 0.7 seconds to throw up a Hail Mary that wouldn’t fall, as the Trojans escaped with a 77-75 victory.

“It’s on me. I’ve got to do better,” Rhoades said. “We didn’t execute the defensive switch at the end and that’s just disappointing. That’s on me. Going to continue to keep helping these guys have late-game mental toughness and approach. You pride yourself on a coach to win close games and I haven’t done that. I’ve got to do better.”

Injury Report

Tibor Mirtič was once again out with a shoulder injury, while Saša Ciani remained sidelined with an ankle injury.

Eli Rice, dealing with a head injury, did not travel with the team to Michigan a few days ago and did not play against the Trojans.

Up Next

Penn State travels to Seattle to take on Washington in an after-dark contest on Wednesday night.

Tipoff is scheduled for 10:30 p.m. EST.

title: Penn State softball suffers first loss of the season off an error against Auburn
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
After starting the season 4-0 for just the fourth time in program history, Penn State looked to stay unbeaten against Auburn for its last game of the NFCA Leadoff Classic on Sunday morning. Meanwhile, the Tigers entered the contest 3-2 and looked to bounce back after a close loss to Pitt in their previous game.

The blue and white weren’t able to leave Florida undefeated after a costly error ended the game, and it suffered its first loss of the fresh campaign, 4-3.

A pair of right-handed sophomores took the mound for both squads in the Sunshine State. Abigail Britton got the ball for the Nittany Lions while the Tigers started Ella Harrison.

Both starters ran into some early trouble on the base paths but prevailed and allowed no runs. The blue and white went down quietly after Harrison committed a throwing error to first and leadoff Kaylie Walters reached second. While Kylie Shaw led off with a smoked double to left field, Britton settled in and retired the next three Tigers’ batters in order.

Harrison quickly found a groove in the second and struck out sophomore Natalie Lieto and junior Michela Barbanente back-to-back, then senior Madison Seidel grounded for the third out. Despite Penn State’s offense not producing early, Auburn’s offense provided Harrison with some cushion in its half of the inning.

Britton hit McKaela Walker with one out, then Kylie Brockman smacked a double down the left field line, and Britton quickly found herself in a first and third situation. Kyla Stroud lifted a sacrifice fly to right fielder Breanna Hanik and plated the game’s opening run, 1-0.

While pinch runner Georgia Lessmann advanced to third on the flyout, Britton minimized the damage and forced a popout to end the scoring.

The Nittany Lions couldn’t produce much in the third, but Walters’ two-out bunt gave them their first hit against Harrison. With the top of the Auburn lineup due up, coach Clarrisa Crowell turned to her bullpen and brought in freshman Mackenzie Duncan. The Winter Garden Florida native produced a needed shutdown and inning, keeping the deficit at one.

As the game progressed, the pressure continued mounting offensively for the Nittany Lions. Harrison continued her dominance on the mound and struck out all three blue and white batters in the fourth. After surrendering a leadoff single by Haven Roebuck, Duncan mowed down the next three Tigers’ batters.

Just like their comeback victory in the Nittany Lions' last game against BYU, they persevered and finally broke through in the fifth. Lieto led off the inning with a walk, and the inning quickly put pressure on Harrison as she surrendered her second error on another throw to first. With Lieto on third and Seidel on second after she aggressively swiped a bag, Hanik hit a timely RBI infield single to shortstop Alyssa Hastings.

Penn State tied the game at one, but was looking for more. The blue and white stayed aggressive on the base paths with Hanik stealing second. The lineup turned over and leadoff Walters laid a successful bunt down and reached first. However, Harrison escaped the one-out bases-loaded jam after retiring junior Brooke Klosowiza and freshman Allison Oneacre.

The tie didn’t last for long as the Tigers cracked Duncan in the bottom half of the fifth. Shaw caught the Nittany Lions off guard and successfully reached on a one-out bunt. After Ma’Nia Womack flew out to Hanik, Destiny Rodriguez hammered a clutch two-out RBI double to center. Duncan allowed just one run in the inning, but Auburn now took the lead late, 2-1.

However, the blue and white rallied once again in the very next inning. Entering the sixth, Harrison allowed just three hits and recorded an impressive 10 strikeouts. Yet, Penn State found some much-needed offensive momentum.

Barbanente won a very long at-bat, and Harrison suffered just her second walk of the day. Lieto entered the batter’s box with some pressure as the Nittany Lions haven’t had many baserunners throughout the game. The Monroe, Connecticut, native seized the moment and smashed a two-run home run to left field, giving Penn State its first lead of the game, 3-2.

Crowell made another pitching change and brought in star junior Bridget Nemeth to preserve the small lead. The Tigers wouldn’t go down easy as Haven Roebuck split the right center field gap for a timely leadoff double.

After a sacrifice fly advanced Roebuck to third, Brockman delivered an RBI single to right field. The pressure now turned on Nemeth with the game tied once again.

Stroud hit a dribbler and it could’ve possibly been an inning-ending double play, but Walters bobbled it at shortstop, and Auburn had a runner in scoring position again with just one out. However, Nemeth displayed why she’s an elite pitcher and struck out the next two Tigers’ batters to preserve the tie.

The seventh started with some Penn State offense as Hanik singled down the left field line, then stole second. However, Harrison swiftly retired the top of the order, and the big bats left Hanik stranded in scoring position.

Crowell took Nemeth out and replaced her with junior McKenna Young. The Brodhead, Wisconsin, native ran into a jam after she surrendered a leadoff walk followed by a single through the left side by Rodriguez.

While Young forced a groundout and then struck out Roebuck swinging, both runners advanced to scoring position off the wild pitch. Walker should’ve been out after a dribbler to shortstop Walters, but she committed her second error of the game, and it was costly.

Auburn walked off the tight contest on the error and won 4-3, handing Penn State its first loss of the season.

Up Next

Penn State travels to Houston for the Houston Invitation and looks to bounce back against Incarnate Word at 2 p.m. on Friday.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State track and field completes Sykes & Sabock Challenge at home
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Junior Gabrielle Deglau got the action started on Saturday morning with the women’s weight throw, where she threw 17.86 meters for third place and her second personal best in two weeks.

In the men’s weight throw, senior Sam Engebretson continued that personal-best streak, breaking the 20-meter mark with a second-place, 20.28-meter throw.

While junior Joe White didn’t earn a top mark in the men’s long jump, his consistency continued with his second 6.99-meter jump of the year for second place.

Sophomore Amelia McBain scored a personal best in the women’s pole vault, leaping 3.90 meters for fourth place.

Sophomore Addyson White opened the action on the track with a finals-qualifying 7.62 in the 60-meters for second place. In the finals, she earned a big personal best, running 7.52 seconds for second place.

Fellow sophomore Ajani Dwyer dominated the men’s 60m with a school record 6.52 in the prelims, beating his previous mark by 0.02 seconds. Scotty Coffi finished fourth with a time of 6.79 seconds.

Engebretson earned his second top-five finish in the men’s shot put, where he finished fourth with a throw of 17.12 meters.

The Nittany Lions’ success continued on the track in the men’s mile, where junior Jake Borgesi ran 4:09.76 for second place and a season-best, followed by Jacob Smith’s personal-best of 4:10.71.

Senior Tristan McGarrah earned his big break in the men’s pole vault, as he tied the No. 2 mark in school history with 5.20 meters. Mason Bucks finished in fifth place with a jump of 4.75 meters.

Sophomore Jake Palermo’s 400-meter dominance continued on Saturday as he won his second race of the year with a time of 46.39 seconds.

For the second time in a week, senior Handal Roban broke a school record, this time in the 600-meters.

Roban’s time of 1:14.89 broke the record by 0.06 seconds as he won the race, followed by sophomore Jackson Smith in a personal-best 1:19.32.

Lea Hatcher took the track for her first 800-meters of the year and won with a personal-best 2:09.13.

In the men’s 800m, the Nittany Lions took three of the top-five places, led by Niko Schultz.

Schultz ran a personal-best 1:46.67 for second place, followed by Yukichi Ishii’s 1:46.73 for third place and Kaleb Nastari’s personal-best of 1:47.19 for fifth place.

Senior Allison Dougherty crossed the finish line of the 3000-meters for her first finish of the year, running 9:47.24 for fourth place.

The men’s 3000m saw freshman Tyler Rader earn a personal-best 8:21.03 for third place, wrapping up the individual track events.

The women’s 4x400m squad finished first with a season-best 3:37.67. The team was led by White, Maddie Pitts, Boh Ritchie and Hayley Kitching.

Penn State wrapped up the action in the men’s and women’s high jump. On the men’s side, freshman Trip Campbell jumped 2.11 meters for first place, while the women saw Gwen Cudmore tie her personal best with a 1.75 meter jump for third.

Up next

The Nittany Lions will head to a trio of meets on Friday, including the David Hemery Valentine Invitational in Boston, the Husky Classic at Washington and the Tyson Invitational at the University of Arkansas.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: Penn State softball faces Auburn with opportunity for fifth win to close out season opening weekend
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
With the sunshine skies, the Nittany Lions have gone 4-0 in Clearwater, Florida. Facing off against the Auburn Tigers for their final game at the Eddie C. Moore Complex at 10. am on Sunday.

The blue and white opened up with a contest against Missouri in extra innings to take the win, 7-4. After a back-and-forth in the early game, Penn State closed its first day of the NFCA Leadoff Classic with another win, 7-0 over Boston College.

On Saturday, the Nittany Lions defeated Eastern Kentucky, 4-2.

A highly anticipated match against BYU was set for the late afternoon. It resulted in another extra-inning game, which ended with another Penn State victory. Holding the Cougars off late in the eighth inning, 4-3.

Next up: Auburn Tigers

One final match is left for Penn State's opening weekend. Looking to have a weekend sweep and secure their fifth win of the season.

Looking for their second-best start in program history, in 2024, the Nittany Lions started their season with an 8-0 record.

The Tigers also went undefeated this past weekend, even facing other national contenders. Also, in close games: Notre Dame 5-4 and Michigan State 9-6.

Last season, Auburn finished second-to-last in the SEC standings, 6-18 in conference and 35-24 overall.

Auburn’s offense has been entirely reconstructed for the 2026 campaign. Nine graduating seniors, including the Tigers' primary eighth starters, departed.

AnnaLea Adams will lead the Tigers in her sophomore season. After one of the most historic true freshman seasons in program history, Adams was an All- SEC honoree last year.

With a .390 batting average and a .658 slugging percentage, Adams led the team last season. Finishing in the top three on the team in on-base percentage, hits, RBI, doubles and home runs.

The Tigers circle is a young staff, with another key returner, SJ Geurin. Recording 23 wins and four saves behind a 2.97 earned run average. Earning NFCA All-Region honors for her fierceness in the circle.

This matchup will be one to watch, as the Nittany Lions look to make an opportunity to make a run for their second-best start to a season. Auburn's squad will definitely put up a fight. Although it may not have had its best results in the past, the Tigers also look to close out this weekend undefeated. A must-watch as the game will be available for free on GameChanger.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State student seriously injured in hit-and-run
author: Taylor Mcgillvray | The Daily Collegian
description:
State College police responded to a hit-and-run on Saturday around 2:30 a.m, at the intersection of East Beaver Avenue and South Garner Street.

The vehicle allegedly left the scene of the crash, according to a media release by the police department. The victim, a 20-year-old student, was transported to Geisinger Medical Center and sustained serious injuries.

State College police have since located the vehicle and arrested the driver, a 33-year-old male.

Formal charges are pending, and the investigation is currently active.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS COVERAGE

title: Mark Pavlik logs 700th career win as Penn State men’s volleyball sweeps Saint Francis
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
In his 32nd and final year at Penn State, coach Mark Pavlik logged his 700th-career win as the No. 14 Nittany Lions completed a sweep in the Saint Francis series in three sets.

Penn State, coming off a much-needed win against Saint Francis last night, looked to stay in the win column on Saturday.

The opening set started with some brief back-and-forth from both teams, until the Red Flash surrendered four straight points to the blue and white, allowing it to pull ahead.

But Saint Francis was able to diminish that lead. After an attacking error from Sean Harvey, the teams tied at 9-9.

After keeping the score tight on both sides, the Nittany Lions were able to pull away with a two-point lead after a service error from the other end of the court, making the score 15-13.

Penn State kept the lead within two for several points. It finally pulled away to 19-16 after Owen Rose logged the first service ace of the match. Back-to-back attacking errors from the Red Flash put Penn State up 21-16, forcing a Saint Francis timeout.

A kill from Gaige Gabriel put the blue and white at set point. With one final kill from Matthew Luoma, the Nittany Lions were able to take the first set 25-19.

The second set opened with back-to-back points for the Red Flash. While Gabriel was able to sneak in a kill to put the score at 2-1, Saint Francis had an immediate response and scored four straight.

Down 6-1, the blue and white were forced to call an early timeout to reset and recover.

Kills from Harvey and Jaidyn Bethel gave the Nittany Lions a much-needed two points, and an attacking error from the Red Flash gave them an additional. But, the Red Flash kept responding, keeping their lead significant at 9-4.

Penn State’s Michael Schwob logged his first service ace of the year to make the score 11-7. With an attacking error from the Red Flash quickly following, Saint Francis took a timeout after the blue and white closed the lead to three.

Following the timeout, the Nittany Lions were able to keep the lead within three. But after two attacking errors from Saint Francis, Penn State shut down the lead to one at 15-14.

A kill to the back corner from Bethel tied it up at 16-16. And with the help of another attacking error from the Red Flash, the blue and white took the lead for the first time in the set.

The score remained neck-and-neck through the next several points. But after a service error from the Red Flash and a kill from Harvey, Penn State pulled ahead to 24-22 and forced a Saint Francis timeout.

The timeout seemed to do some good, as the Red Flash tied it back up at 24-24 after two quick points.

Needing to win by two, the Nittany Lions produced the necessary points in back-to-back fashion, taking the second set 26-24.

The third set saw more back-and-forth scoring from both sides. But after a few quick points, and a service ace from Harvey, the blue and white pulled ahead 7-3.

After kills from Bethel and Tristan Hassell, as well as an attack error from the Red Flash, the Nittany Lions established a strong lead at 10-3, which forced the Red Flash to use their final timeout in the set.

While Saint Francis was able to get four points, the blue and white were just too hot, keeping its lead 15-7.

But back-to-back errors from the Red Flash put Penn State up 17-7.

While Saint Francis responded with a big kill, kills from Harvey and Hassell and another attacking error from Saint Francis kept the Penn State lead significant at 20-8.

After one final service error from the Red Flash, the blue and white took the third and final set 25-11, cementing Mark Pavlik’s legacy with a historic win.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions will travel to Princeton, New Jersey for a series of matches against the Tigers on Feb. 13 and 14.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 5 Penn State men’s gymnastics come up short at No. 6 Nebraska
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off its first win in conference competition against Illinois last week, No. 5 Penn State did battle with sixth ranked Nebraska in Lincoln on Saturday afternoon.

The blue and white fell short to the Cornhuskers by a score of 318.600-317.150. The Cornhuskers featured strong performances across all rotations, leading them to a conference win on their home floor.

Floor

The Cornhuskers prevailed on the Floor 55.200-52.900 with consistently strong scores. Chase Mondi led Nebraska with a strong 14.250, with Nathan York right behind with 13.950. Shaun Smith posted the best score of the rotation for Penn State with a 13.700.

Pommel horse

Nebraska continued their strong performance as they took the Pommel Horse 52.700-51.850. The blue and white couldn’t put it together in the second rotation, as Ricky Perez’s 13.500 led the squad, with Kacper Garnczarek right behind with a 13.400. Caden Clinton’s 13.700 led the Cornhuskers in the event.

Rings

The Nittany Lions got themselves back in the match with a convincing win on the Still Rings 53.800-52.200. Matt Underhill and Akseli Karsikas led the blue and white with scores of 13.900 and 13.800, respectively. Luke Esparo wasn’t too far behind as he put up a 13.300 as well. An impressive 14.350 from Nebraska’s Asher Cohen wasn’t enough for the Cornhuskers to take the event, but it was an important result for Nebraska to maintain its lead.

Vault

The lead shifted over to the blue and white as they took a 54.400-52.300 victory in the Vault. Underhill’s 13.950 led the way, and a 13.800 from Kellen Ryan sealed the win. The Cornhuskers came up short in the fourth rotation despite a 14.050 from Mondi and a 13.850 from Luke James.

Bars

Nebraska took the lead back with a 54.600-53.100 victory in the Parallel Bars. A 14.350 from York put the Cornhuskers in the driver’s seat for the fifth rotation, and Cohen’s 13.600 clinched the victory in the event for Nebraska, giving them a point advantage going into the final rotation. Landon Simpson’s 13.800 wasn’t enough to put the blue and white over the edge.

Anthony Koppie kicked off the high bar for Nebraska with a 13.300. Esparo went next for Penn State, and he secured a 12.100, followed by Simpson, who managed the same score. Nik Tarca stepped up next for Nebraska with an 11.850, followed by Garnczarek, who came up clutch for the blue and white with a 13.050. Alex Nitache responded for the Cornhuskers with a 12.650. Ryan finished the day with a 12.100, while Max Odden clinched the victory for Nebraska with a 13.800.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions will participate in the Winter Cup in Louisville, Kentucky, starting on Friday, Feb. 20.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Preston Hawkins bounces back despite No. 7 Penn State men’s lacrosse’s overtime loss to Villanova
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Preston Hawkins made his collegiate debut in the season-opener against Colgate last Sunday, nothing went according to plan. A difficult line of sight inside Holuba Hall, coupled with a breakneck pace of offense, resulted in the true freshman being replaced by Hayes Schreiner midway through the second quarter after only making a single save.

Coach Jeff Tambroni elected to once more place his trust in the Powell, Ohio, native on Saturday afternoon when No. 7 Penn State faced unranked Villanova inside Holuba Hall. Hawkins seized the opportunity and put together a solid performance in his second career start, closing out the game with eight saves on 22 shots for a .364 save percentage.

The Nittany Lions were upset in overtime, 14-13.

“(Hawkins) felt like in a lot of ways he let us down (against Colgate), which was not anywhere near the case. I talked to him through Sunday and Monday, watched him rebound this week, just let him know that we still have the confidence in him,” Tambroni said. “It wasn't the physical or the ability piece, it was more the mental piece.”

Unlike the game against Colgate, the Wildcats and the Nittany Lions were locked in a low-scoring affair through the first half. This was in part due to Hawkins’ efforts, making six saves on 12 shots going into halftime with the score knotted at 6-6.

“(Hawkins) seemed ready to go coming in (Holuba Hall) today, and made a huge save at the end of regulation, giving us a chance to even get into overtime,” Tambroni said. (The loss) was in no way, shape or form anything he did. He put us in a position to be in that overtime period.”

Hawkins’ athleticism earned him the majority of his saves. The freshman wasn’t shy to drop to the turf or use his body to block a shot. The goals that evaded him were mostly step-down shots with minimal coverage.

On the clear, Hawkins’ role wasn’t too complicated at this stage in the season. He took the ball from the crease after a save or from the backfield and delivered breakout passes to his defenders. However, the Wildcats were quick to pounce on the clear and caused turnovers in the chaos.

“It was methodical in the first twenty to thirty seconds of every possession, and then you accompanied that with the fact that we're not clearing the ball all that well, not picking the ball off the ground,” Tambroni said. “It just seemed like it was an avalanche of possession time.”

However, midway through the second quarter, Hawkins didn’t see an open white jersey to pass to. As the Wildcats transitioned to a 10-man ride to combat Penn State’s simple clearing strategy, Hawkins took a shot at the open goal but was blocked in the midfield.

Penn State’s newest starting netminder follows in Jack Fracyon’s footsteps and has a reputation to uphold. Last year, the Nittany Lions executed a deep postseason run through the NCAA Tournament but fell in the semifinals.

Hawkins already displayed a flash of the “clutch gene” needed to inherit the long-term position. With the game tied, 9-9, in the fourth quarter, Villanova midfielder Dan Martin ripped a shot aimed for Hawkins’ five-hole. Hawkins sprawled for the save with his stick backed by his right leg before Hunter Aquino scored a go-ahead goal on the other end of the field.

Despite Penn State increasing its lead to 12-9, a series of defensive mistakes allowed Villanova to piece together a 4-0 run to take the lead with under three minutes remaining in the game. After defenseman Alex Ross scored the game-tying goal, Hawkins was faced with a potentially defining moment in his budding career.

Thirteen seconds remained in the game, and Colin Michener performed a dodge past Penn State’s defense. On the subsequent shot, Hawkins came up with the standing save that sent the game to overtime.

Overtime. A single goal separated Hawkins from his first career collegiate win.

On Villanova’s first possession of the overtime frame, the Nittany Lions’ defense came up short.

“We’ve got a lot to clean up,” Tambroni said. “That was a frustrating loss.”

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball defeats BYU in extra innings, setting up undefeated record at NFCA Leadoff Classic
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State faced BYU with a chance to extend its undefeated start to the year, and the two programs had met only once, on the softball diamond in 2007, when the Nittany Lions prevailed.

Penn State prevailed again on Saturday, defeating the Cougars in an extra-inning thriller, 4-3.

There are more connections than at first glance, and only a limited time to act.

It all stems from a football head-coaching search in which the Cougars used an alumnus’ money from his cookie empire to keep their guy, Kalani Sitake and taunt Nittany Lions fans.

There’s now a fitting moniker that should grace every time these schools meet in what looks to be a new rivalry for the ages, between two blue and white schools, mascot by big cats and it’s the name “the Crumbl Cookie Clash”.

With no other set-in-stone matchups in other sports between these two programs, this may be one of the few times they can address their differences, and it might be the best forum.

The softball edition of this meeting is possibly the most high-octane of any possible edition, as both units arrive in Clearwater, Florida, as extremely formidable squads. Penn State cruised to a 3-0 undefeated start, with a decisive win over EKU earlier Saturday in Game 1 of a doubleheader. BYU arrives with more rest, but a 1-2 record, as a unit that received preseason ranking votes, hasn’t made good on the hype.

For the Nittany Lions, freshman Brevyn Kellepouris got the nod inside the circle, only her second collegiate appearance and her first-ever start. The rookie started off shaky with a walk and a wild pitch, but easily got out of the inning with some sweet stuff inside the circle.

Ultimately, the blue and white bats started even slower, going down in order with their first attempt to pull ahead.

Penn State logged the first hit of the game in the bottom of the second, courtesy of second baseman Michela Barbanente, but ultimately it would be its opposition to strike first.

Kellepouris showed her first real signs of adversity this season, allowing a pair of singles and another pair of BYU baserunning moves, first by a passed ball, then a stolen base. Standout slugger Ilove'a Brittingham struck a single to bring in the first two runs of the game, and end the freshman arm’s start.

Coach Clarissa Crowell chose the only viable option: its own superstar, pitcher Bridget Nemeth, who got out of the jam.

Maybe it was the Florida sunshine, but the Penn State bats stayed nocturnal into the bottom of the third frame. The Nittany Lions kept BYU busy, however, with two infield outs and a back-and-forth at bat between Cougars pitcher Kaysen Korth and Cara Bohner, which ended in a seven-pitch strikeout.

Unfortunately for BYU, any momentum it had immediately halted to Nemeth’s arm, as the ace cruised to a three-up, three-down inning, with an exclamation point put on the frame by a pair of punch outs.

The Nittany Lions knocked a pair of hits in the fourth, as they attempted to get level, but a double play and a Barbanente out on a dropped third strike ended the inning.

Nemeth began to show signs of being human in the fifth, as a triad of consecutive two-out singles pulled BYU ahead by another run. Brittingham scored the run for the Cougars, brought in by Bre Townsend.

Penn State’s offense continued to crumble into the home half, as a pair of strikeouts sent them packing despite Breanna Hanik’s single for her first collegiate hit.

The blue and white sent in late-game arm Abigail Britton to the circle to relieve Nemeth, who sent the offense back up unharmed into the sixth frame. Only a singular big swing defined the Penn State offense in that half, however, and it was that of its highest-ranked recruit in 2025, Allison Oneacre, who knocked her second dinger of the year, tying a team-high with Brooke Klosowicz, who homered earlier on the day.

Britton continued her sophomore season breakout inside the circle, with a quick inning to give the bats their last chance of the game to tie things up.

Barbanente stepped up first and reached base with an infield single, then, with savvy baserunning, got to second – rally started. Natalie Lieto attempted to follow up, but went right back to sit on the pine after a four-pitch strikeout. Crowell had just the bat on the bench; however, to shake things up, backup catcher Macy Chamberlin entered and smacked a double to bring the game within one.

Both coaches tinkered from there. Crowell took out Chamberlin on the bases, as BYU coach Gordon Eakin opted for Hailey Shuler inside the circle to save things.

Hanik put the ball in play, and sloppy Cougars’ fielding allowed a run to score, tying the game with a runner on third after a groundout followed.

Bohner was the batter with the chance to send Penn State home with a win, but again went down on strikes in a long duel with the pitcher.

Britton continued to thrive, shutting down the Cougars’ offense in the first inning of extras, punctuated by a fanning punch out to end the frame.

Crowell’s squad then played small ball to almost guarantee the win, with the extra runner on second to start the home half. Oneacre laid down a perfect bunt to put the winning run 60 feet from winning the game.

Freshman first baseman Kirsten Finarelli stepped up to the plate and knocked a single through the infield to send Bohner home and improve Penn State to 4-0. In all four of the Lehman, Pennsylvania, native’s appearances this season so far, she’s reached base.

The last time the Nittany Lions softball started undefeated after four games was in 2024, the last season they made NCAA Regionals.

Up Next

Penn State plays its final game at the Eddie C. Moore Complex in Clearwater, Florida, at 10 a.m. on Sunday, against its second SEC foe of the year, this time Auburn. Streaming is available for free on GameChanger, with the blue and white having a chance to go home undefeated in its first series of the year.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Kiyomi McMiller produces career-high points in Penn State women’s basketball loss to No. 12 Michigan State
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Kiyomi McMiller for two, McMiller for three; those are the two phrases that fans heard a lot of over the public address in Rec Hall against No.12 Michigan State on Saturday.

McMiller finished with a career-high 37 points, but Penn State was unable to pull off the upset bid, falling 81-70. This marked the Silver Spring, Maryland native’s second-straight 30-point outing, and her third of the season. McMiller’s previous career-high was 36 points in the Lady Lions 74-73 loss to Wisconsin on Jan. 4.

The blue and white had one of their best first-quarter performances of the season, scoring 28 points, 16 of which came from McMiller.

“I think we got to figure out a way to capitalize on that first quarter,” coach Carolyn Kieger said. “It was our best first quarter, I thought, in a couple of years.”

McMiller, along with the rest of the Lady Lions, had a near-flawless opening frame. As a team, Penn State shot 11-for-16 from field-goal range, but McMiller went 7-for-8 on her own.

“(I) focused on making those layups and making those points in the paint,” McMiller said. “That was a big game changer for me in my head.”

The sophomore guard’s scoring effort got going right away. After Jalyn Brown got the Spartans on the scoreboard first with a two-point jumper, McMiller quickly answered with a three-pointer on the other end.

This marked the first of two shots from beyond the mark that McMiller netted in the opening quarter. The 5-foot-8 guard’s offensive effort came mostly from two-point range, as she finished with three triples in the afternoon.

Behind the two three-pointers, a couple of baskets from inside, as well as sharing the wealth with other Lady Lions, McMiller guided Penn State to a 12-0 scoring run.

“I thought we came out and had a lot of energy; we were playing really well together,” Kieger said. “Our chemistry was great, we were fun to watch, fun to coach, fun to play with each other.”

McMiller put the cherry on top of a strong opening frame with an elbow jumper as just 12 seconds remained on the clock. This gave the blue and white a 15-point lead to close the first quarter.

The sophomore went quiet in the second quarter, shooting 0-for-6 in the frame, but getting two points from the free throw line with just under two minutes left in the half. Still, McMiller went into the locker room with a little less than half of Penn State’s points.

“I got to the paint a lot, but I didn’t finish the play,” McMiller said. “I think that I (need to) play a complete game all the way through all 40 minutes.”

McMiller was still rather silent in the third quarter, finishing with seven points, but she was the Lady Lions’ only scorer in the frame, allowing Michigan State to creep back into the game.

The fourth quarter was a similar showing, with McMiller scoring 12 of the blue and white’s 18 points.

As a team, Penn State shot 28-for-61 from field-goal range, but McMiller was responsible for more than half of these attempts, going 16-for-33.

“We got to share the basketball,” Kieger said. “We have to move the ball and got to share it.”

Nonetheless, history is history, and despite the Lady Lions not getting the outcome they wanted, it was still a career afternoon for McMiller.

It originally looked like the guard wasn’t going to meet her new career high, as she stood at 35 points with about 30 seconds left. However, a loose ball turned into a fast break layup, completing McMiller’s outstanding effort against a top-15 opponent.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey shuts out Lindenwood in last away game of the regular season
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State showed off its goal-scoring ability after answering an early Lindenwood goal with five of its own in Game 1 on Friday. The Nittany Lions returned to the ice following a 6-3 win for their final away game of the regular season.

In their last game away from Happy Valley, the Nittany Lions used four different goal scorers to shut out the Lions 5-0.

Head coach Jeff Kampersal mixed up the lineup a bit in Game 2. Danica Maynard, who usually plays left defense, played her first game at left wing for Penn State. The Lake Country, British Columbia, native had a chance to show off her two-way ability with a smaller bench than usual. Maynard was among the several changes Kampersal made to the lineup.

The Nittany Lions didn’t take long to get on the board first as Grace Outwater shot a wrist shot off the faceoff in her offensive zone only three minutes into the game. Outwater seemingly can’t stop scoring as this tally marked her ninth-straight game with a goal.

Penn State wanted more as Abby Stonehouse sent a quick wrist shot in the slot that beat Madison Bowtell’s right shoulder.

After Lindenwood spent nearly all of the first period in its defensive zone, a spark of offense was shown from the Lions late in the period. Katie DeSa was tested with three scoring chances in close, all of which she was able to fend off as the opening period reached its end.

Unlike at the start of the first period, the opening five minutes of the middle frame were a back-and-forth affair, with both teams spending time in the attacking zone. Both DeSa and Bowtell were successful when tested with early scoring opportunities.

However, after an early surge from both teams, the puck took on a life of its own as both sides struggled to control it. Neither team had any luck developing a rush because turnovers in the neutral zone prevented it.

That was until Stonehouse had a chance to get her second of the game after a turnover in the offensive zone. Both Maynard and Stonehouse found themselves alone with Bowtell. A swift pass to Stonehouse led to a ringing of the post as the forward got all of the crossbar and none of the net.

The Nittany Lions didn’t miss their next chance as Mikah Keller skated into the offensive zone and scored after a wrist shot deflected off a skate and found its way into the net. Keller was one of the lineup changes, starting at first-line center.

A calmer middle frame came to a close after Leah Stecker went to the box for a late tripping call. Lindenwood wasn’t able to capitalize before the buzzer rang and started the third period with 43 seconds left on the power play.

The Nittany Lions came out of the gates firing in the first five minutes of the third period in hopes of adding to their lead, and that they did. Katelyn Roberts skated into the offensive zone with speed and sniped a wrist shot over the shoulder of Bowtell only five minutes into the final frame.

A dangerous surge of offense developed for the Lions after a Maddy Christian penalty put them on the power play. A scramble for the loose puck in DeSa’s crease nearly resulted in the first goal of the game for Lindenwood. The Pawcatuck, Connecticut, native made a sprawling save to keep the puck out of her net.

Outwater was not done scoring. The Pickton, Ontario, native received a pass from Maddy Christian off the boards and sent a no-look backhand in the slot towards the back of the net. This tally ties Outwater for fourth nationally in goals with 23.

DeSa didn’t take the last 60 seconds of the game off with the lead at 5-0. The senior was tested with a flurry of shots before the final buzzer, one being a rebound opportunity that resulted in another sprawling save.

Up Next

Penn State returns to Pegula for its last series of the regular season against RIT. Game 1 is set to start at 6 p.m. on Feb. 13.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Handal Roban breaks 600m record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another week, another school record for Handal Roban.

Roban broke the 600-meter record at the Sykes & Sabock Challenge on Saturday, running 1:14.89.

Last weekend, Roban broke the 800-meter school record previously held by national champion Isaiah Harris. Saturday's 600m record was also held by Harris.

Roban is coming off a dominant summer, where he ran the second-fastest 800m in NCAA history.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s lacrosse falls to Villanova in overtime loss at Holuba Hall
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State played its second straight game in Holuba Hall on Saturday, but couldn’t achieve the same result against Villanova.

The Nittany Lions played a close game but ultimately fell to the Wildcats in overtime.

Penn State opened the scoring just under two minutes into the first frame when Chase Robertson isolated his defender, dodged downhill and tucked the ball into the bottom of the net.

Villanova evened the score when David Link cut around the back of the cage and sank a close shot past goaltender Preston Hawkins

Hunter Aquino put the blue and white back in front near the quarter’s midpoint with a strong step-down from ten yards away on a nifty feed from Jack Iannantuono.

Villanova returned fire soon after, tying the game with an unassisted goal by Luke Raymond.

The Iannantuono to Aquino connection continued to develop later in the frame, as the freshman fed the sophomore for another strong shot to put the Nittany Lions back in front.

The score was leveled just seconds before the buzzer sounded when Colin Michener ripped a shot over the top, stinging the top right corner to bring the game into the break at 3-3.

Nick Lucchesi scored the Wildcats’ second straight goal early in the second quarter with an on-the-run sidearm shot to give Villanova its first lead of the contest.

Soon after, Villanova found the back of the net again when Michener fed Ryan Welgos to grab the first multi-goal lead of the game for either team.

Kyle Lehman ended the three-goal run by Villanova when he took a hard dodge past his defender and dunked on Wildcat goaltender Denis Fargione to cut their lead to one.

Later in the second quarter, the Villanova lead expanded back to two when Gavin Michener ripped a low shot past Hawkins.

Robertson scored his second of the game with just over a minute left in the half, making a nice move past a defender and going bar-down past Fargione.

The Nittany Lions proceeded to tie the game with just seconds on the clock when Lehman ripped a shot with his knee on the turf, bringing the matchup into the half tied.

Villanova regained the lead just over a minute into the third quarter, with Kessy Cox bouncing one past Hawkins to bring the score to 6-7 in favor of the Wildcats.

Iannantuono knotted the game back up with a dodge from behind the cage, rolling in front of the crease and finishing well to even the score at 7-7. Penn State would then take the lead on a big rip from Robertson to secure his hat trick.

Another tie was formed when Colin Michener scored his second goal of the game on a close shot late in the third quarter.

Jon King, usually a defensive midfielder, drove through several Villanova defenders and found the back of the net to give the Nittany Lions a 9-8 advantage with less than a minute remaining in the frame.

Lucchesi scored his second goal of the game for the Wildcats to tie the game yet again.

Not long after, Penn State went man-up after a Villanova penalty. Aquino face-dodged around his defender after another feed by Iannantuono to give the blue and white a 10-9 advantage.

The Nittany Lions took a rare two-goal lead near the midpoint of the final frame when John Jude Considine went airborne to dunk on the Villanova cage.

Penn State started to pull away in the later stages of the fourth quarter, with Andrew Beard tucking a shot into the bottom right corner of the net as he faded away from the goal.

Villanova cut the lead to two with Lucchesi securing his hat trick with a low-to-high shot that found the top left corner of the net. They got another with 4:27 remaining in the game when Cox ripped a strong shot from 15 yards out past Hawkins.

After being down three goals, the Wildcats came all the way back to tie the game at 12-12 when Dan Martin found the back of the net less than a minute after Villanova’s last score.

They then took the lead with their fourth unanswered goal as Raymond wrapped around the crease and sank another goal past Hawkins.

With Villanova trying to drain the clock, the Penn State defense forced a turnover and went on a fastbreak, where defenseman Alex Ross wound up heavily and powered a tying goal past Fargione as Holuba Hall’s crowd erupted.

Villanova had a good look with just seconds remaining, but Hawkins stayed strong in the cage to deny their chance and send the game to overtime.

After winning the opening faceoff, Martin wound up and scored his second goal of the game to walk it off for Villanova.

The 14-13 loss moves Penn State to 1-1 on the season, and is the Nittany Lions’ first loss to Villanova since 2023.

Injury Report

Liam Matthews returned to action after not playing in last week’s matchup with Colgate

Up Next

Penn State will travel to Annapolis for a 12 p.m. matchup with Navy on Saturday.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Strong 1st half not enough as Penn State women’s basketball falls to Michigan State
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Three days after Penn State’s first conference win of the year, it seemed like the team would make it two straight after a strong first half against ranked Michigan State.

Despite the first-half hoopla, the Lady Lions lost their 16th game of the year, falling 81-70 to the Spartans.

While 6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle returned to the injury report despite playing on Wednesday, Penn State had no trouble starting hot against Michigan State.

The Spartans struck first out of the gate and exchanged the lead back-and-forth through the opening three minutes of action. However, after five points from Kiyomi McMIller made it a one-point game, she got on fire.

Over the next seven minutes of action, McMiller tallied another 11 points, coming to 16 total points in the first quarter. The Lady Lions were up 28-13 while shooting 68% from the field and 60% from deep.

On the other hand, the Spartans shot just 30% and 11.1%, respectively, as they fell behind early to the 8-15 Lady Lions.

Things got a little better for Michigan State as the second quarter was underway, jumping to a quick 6-0 start with buckets by Jalyn Brown, Emma Shumate and Grace Vanslooten.

Penn State fired back with Moriah Murray’s first bucket of the game, but was unable to build any kind of momentum similar to the first period. However, the Spartans’ success continued as they built a 14-5 lead after 10 minutes of play.

The final five minutes of action were a back-and-forth battle between both sides as freshman Nyla McFadden got the hot hand, scoring four of Penn State’s 12 points to end the half up 45-33.

The Lady Lions fell apart after McMiller opened the second half with a basket, scoring just seven points total in the period.

Michigan State, on the other hand, got going quickly and found sustained success during the quarter. After being down double-digits to enter the period, the Spartans ended the quarter with their first lead since three minutes into the game.

After scoring another two straight baskets to start the final period, McMiller found the net again as she totalled 37 points on the day.

However, her success wasn’t enough to fuel Penn State as a whole, which had just five other players score.

Trailing with 10 minutes left, McMiller worked to bring her team back to the win column for a second straight game. Despite scoring six of the team’s nine buckets in the fourth quarter, the Lady Lions fell for the 16th time this season.

Up next

Penn State hits the road for a Thursday night matchup against Maryland at 7 p.m.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse opens Kayla Treanor era with win over Richmond
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A day after Syracuse opened its first season without coach Kayla Treanor with a loss, Penn State had its first game with her at the helm.

The Treanor era opened with a close win for the Nittany Lions, who defeated Richmond 10-9 on Saturday afternoon.

Penn State’s first starting lineup came with a slight surprise to fans, with freshmen Roquette Allen and Lizzie Anné slotting in at attacker ahead of freshman Susannah O'Connell at defense.

However, Treanor’s lineup proved fruitful, as the blue and white scored first with Delaney Radin assisting Payton Wainman to take an early lead. The Spiders quickly evened the scoreboard as Keating Hopkins capitalized on a free position shot.

Richmond took control of the action through the next seven minutes, picking up three of the four first-quarter ground balls and taking the lead 2-1 with Alexis Morton’s first goal of the season.

As the second quarter got underway, junior Sydney Manning faced a lot of pressure in the net after back-to-back shots by the Spiders. Fortunately for Richmond, the second one hit the net as Meghan Rode extended the lead even more.

That storyline continued for another few minutes of action as the Spiders, who only had 11 players on the field, took a three-goal lead, courtesy of Rileigh Meyer.

However, Allen made the most of her starting lineup position, as she trimmed the deficit with the first goal of her collegiate career. Goal No. 2 from Wainman made it a one-score game halfway through the second period.

While Morton’s second goal of the game increased Richmond’s lead, the Nittany Lions tied the game up to end the half with Wainman’s third goal of the game and Emma Kelly’s first.

The blue and white opened the third quarter and quickly took the lead for the first time since the beginning of the game as Wainman earned her fourth goal of the game in as many shots.

Richmond quickly fought back and held Penn State scoreless for 11 minutes as goalkeeper Abby Francioli recorded a game-high 47.4% save percentage in the net. Morton and Rode each scored another goal, taking the lead 7-6.

Allen’s Penn State debut success continued in the end of the third quarter as she scored goal No. 2, tying the game with 10 minutes left.
