The final period was almost all Penn State, who took the lead early in the fourth quarter after MacKinney’s second goal of the game and Erika Ho’s first. Less than three minutes into the quarter, the Nittany Lions were up by two.

While Richmond scored two final goals to end the quarter, midfield transfer Anna Salerno took the blue and white to double-digit goals on the day, ultimately winning 10-9 to open the season 1-0.

Up next

The Nittany Lions return home to face UMass at 12pm on Wednesday in Holuba Hall.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Ajani Dwyer breaks 60m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The young star is back.

After running two of the best 60-meter and 200-meter times in school history to start the season, sophomore Ajani Dwyer struck again, breaking the 60m school record in 6.52 at the Sykes & Sabock Challenge.

Dwyer previously tied the school record with NCAA champion Cheickna Traore, running a 6.54-second time.

The Sewell, New Jersey, native also holds the No. 2 100-meter and indoor 200m in school history, as well as the fifth-best outdoor 200m.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD CONTENT

title: Penn State softball hits on all notes, defeats EKU to improve to 3-0
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
No commentary on the broadcast, a scorebug that shows the score and nothing else, audio that picks up the crowd’s conversations between innings and only a single fixed camera angle behind home plate.

It’s fair to say there was limited broadcasting of Penn State’s opening series in Clearwater, Florida, but despite that, the Nittany Lions brought all the shine to the screen Saturday.

The blue and white’s play was anything but analog, as it distributed talents all over the field, a team that stumbled below .500 last season and contained many falters started 2026 like Dylan going electric, completely rejuvenated, freshened by new life and ready to make some rumblings.

The Nittany Lions started to boogie as soon as they stepped onto the field against Eastern Kentucky: transfer arm McKenna Young, the starter of Friday's season-opening win against Missouri, took the circle and cruised with two punch-outs in the first frame.

Coach Clarissa Crowell’s squad carried that tempo with its bats, as it provided the thumps. Leadoff middle infielders Kaylie Walters and Michela Barbanente had the eye of the tiger and smoothly operated to walks, with Walters eventually scoring the first run of the game on an error on the double steal.

Penn State needed someone to bring the hammer to fall, and that's precisely what cleanup spot freshman first baseman Kirsten Finarelli did with a single to drive in Barbanente – she’s now started her career with three straight games with a run driven in.

EKU starter Bayle Hunnicutt eventually navigated out of the frame, but so did Young when the side flipped over. Three is the magic number, and the junior easily grooved to retire the side with defensive outs despite allowing her first runner of the game via a walk.

When the blue and white bats went out for its second performance of the day, and again the thunder struck, as it bumped Hunnicutt out of the circle. A triad of walks, sac-bunt and continued savvy baserunning flustered the Colonoles’ defense.

Rightfielder Cara Bohner scored in the mosh, but the new arm in the circle, Victoria Byrum, ended the inning soon after when the defense didn’t drift away, as it caught Barbanete stealing.

Young kept hitting all the right notes, retiring the side in order. Brynum looked to steal the stage, but Penn State’s silver slugger, Brooke Klosowicz, stepped up to the plate. The junior showed that “you get what you give” when she took a pitch over the plate, gifted to her by Brynum, deep to left field, extending the lead to four in the second straight game she homered.

Sadly for the Nittany Lions, they learned the same lesson when the lineup flipped over: Young finally gave up her first hit of the game to EKU, yet a pair of swinging strikeouts sandwiched between a walk eventually ended the fourth inning.

The action remained relatively defensive until a single by Jocelyn Owen of EKU and an error by Allison Oneacre at the corner put a runner at third, eventually scoring on a fielder’s choice.

The blue and white went down in order for a second straight inning, and Crowell opted for Abigail Britton to enter inside the circle to do the dirty work of closing out the game.

The sophomore made her second appearance of the season and earned two quick outs, but an error by Barbanente left one on, and the Colonels soon cashed in on the action with a triple to cut the score to 4-2.

The Penn State bats got an opportunity to extend the lead with a Klosowicz encore performance in the batter’s box, after she smacked a double off the wall, yet two defensive outs ended the inning.

In the top of the seventh, it was Britton to close out the game, as both teams’ dugouts began to ring up the chants. Last season’s Penn State save leader got a pair of outs courtesy of her defense and followed with a strikeout to secure the win.

Up Next

Penn State softball resumes action later today, with an opportunity to improve to 4-0 against BYU. The time for the first pitch will be announced on the Penn State softball social media account shortly, with streaming available for free on GameChanger.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Tessa Janecke, Team USA advance to 2-0 while Finland recovers from illness
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Finnish women’s hockey team faced two opponents on Saturday: The United States and norovirus.

After falling ill, Finland fell to the United States, 5-0.

Team Finland has a later start to the Olympics Winter Games than anticipated when its opening game on Feb. 5 against Canada was postponed while several Finnish players were quarantined while dealing with norovirus.

On Friday, Finland practiced with only 11 skaters and three goalies, an improvement from Thursday’s practice with only eight skaters and two goalies.

The Fins had a fever, and perhaps the only cure was more discipline. Finland found itself with one less skater on six different circumstances and allowed the United States to score on two of those, one of which put captain Hilary Knight one step closer to the top of the history books.

The American captain scored on a shot adjacent to the cage and scored on the short side to the right of Ahola. It was her second goal of the Olympics, but more notably, the 14th of her Olympic career, which put her in a tie with Natalie Darwitz and Katie King for the most career goals in the USA’s women’s hockey history.

Team USA drew two minor infractions in the opening period, the first roughly five minutes in when Michelle Karvinen was called for holding the stick against Abbey Murphy. The Americans had a few opportunities, but ultimately couldn’t capitalize.

Penn State captain Tessa Janecke had two assists in Thursday’s match against Czechia, catching the eyes of the nation with the first two points of her Olympic career.

Janecke also caught the eyes of the official when she was brought down with a hook by Susanna Tapani with under five minutes remaining in the first period. After not taking advantage of its first man-advantage the United States only needed seven seconds to get on the board first.

Following the offensive zone draw, Laila Edwards sent a backhanded pass out of reach of a trio of Finnish skaters to Alex Carpenter who ripped a quick snap shot for her second goal of the Olympic Games.

After drawing the penalty that led to the United States’ first goal, Janecke nearly extended its lead with a minute left in the first period, but was denied at the doorstep by Finland’s goaltender Sanni Ahola.

Team USA came out to open the second period looking even better than it did in the first. The red, white and blue scored twice within the first four minutes, with the two goals being scored only 1:26 apart.

Murphy, Britta Curl and Taylor Heise entered their offensive zone in a 3-on-1 and displayed a perfect tic-tac-toe performance that resulted in Heise finding the back of the net on a cross-crease feed from Murphy.

Moments later, Megan Keller made a simple move and navigated her way around the circumference of the far-side faceoff circle and found a gap in the five-hole of Ahola to put the United States up 3-0.

Ronja Savolainen took the third penalty for Finland, a two-minute minor for holding against Kendall Coyne Schofield that led to Knight putting herself in a three-way tie for history.

Janecke had a few opportunities to help extend the United States’ lead late in the second period. Skating on a 2-on-1 with Murphy, the pass from the Golden Gopher was blocked by Finland’s Nelli Laitinen who was laid out on the ice.

That same shift, Janecke and Murphy found themselves in the same situation with flipped responsibilities. Janecke’s pass got through the legs of a Finnish skater, but Murphy failed at her attempt to stop the puck with her skate.

While the offense fired on all cylinders, the defense also pressed its thumb on Finland, and made the game as easy as it could for Aerin Frankel, who stopped all nine shots she faced through the first 40 minutes of play.

Despite holding a four-goal lead, the Americans continued to play with an attacking offense compared to a conservative defense. The results showed in the second half of the final period, when the United States prevented a shot on goal from Finland until there was roughly eight minutes remaining in regulation.

Frankel only faced 12 shots in her shutout compared to the 49 Ahola faced, with the one of the final shots serving as a goal from Murphy that capped off the United States’s scoring.

Up Next

The United States will continue the preliminary round against Switzerland, the newest team to deal with the norovirus, at 2:40 p.m. EST on Monday.

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE

title: QBs coach Jake Waters could've transferred to Penn State 14 years ago, now he's back
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Jake Waters transferred out of Iowa Western Community College in 2012, the quarterback visited Happy Valley.

Waters was “blown away” by that visit, but he ultimately transferred to Kansas State. Now, he’s back in Happy Valley as the team’s quarterbacks coach, and even though it’s been over a decade since he was recruited, the Nittany Lions have stayed on his mind.

“Ever since that visit, I've always had my eye on Penn State,” Waters said. “I would always watch them and have a special place in my heart, even though obviously I wouldn't trade my time at (Kansas) State and with coach (Bill) Snyder for the world and my guys that I met there and the experiences I had, but I always knew this was a really special place.”

Waters threw for 5,970 yards, 40 touchdowns and 16 interceptions across two seasons with the Wildcats from 2013-14. He made brief stints with the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Seattle Seahawks during the 2015 offseason, but he never appeared in an NFL game.

He then spent a season in the CFL, playing for the Hamilton Tiger-Cats and Saskatchewan Roughriders in 2016.

Waters jumped into the coaching industry following his playing career. His hiring at Penn State was made official on Dec. 18, and he said it’s been a “dream come true” to be back in State College.

“It's been incredible,” Waters said. “The people around here are incredible. And then the people I get to work with every day are guys that I love and trust. The players have been awesome, too, but a cool, personal, full circle moment on being here for a weekend and then kind of going somewhere else, but then coming in and being back here. It's been really exciting. It's been awesome.”

Waters first joined a Matt Campbell staff when he was a graduate assistant with Iowa State in 2017 after a season as a volunteer assistant at Iowa Western. He had a three-year stop at UTEP as wide receivers coach, and Waters returned to the Cyclones in 2021.

In 2024, Waters was promoted to quarterbacks coach at Iowa State, where he guided quarterback Rocco Becht, who’s now the projected starter for Penn State next season. Waters made the jump from Ames, Iowa, to Happy Valley with numerous other coaches, and he called it a “no-brainer” to rejoin Campbell.

“It's almost like we just picked up our offensive staff room and just moved it to State College,” Waters said. “It made it really, really easy and comfortable. Obviously, we know we're gonna have to change and adapt, different conference, different opponents, different environment, all that. But we’re really, really excited for the challenge.”

Waters said he was “thankful” for Campbell to give him the opportunity to be quarterbacks coach at Penn State. He said he knew Campbell had to do “what’s best for him” when building his first staff with the Nittany Lions.

Waters has coached at the junior college level, Conference USA and the Big 12. Now, he has the chance to coach in the Big Ten, which he called a “great challenge,” and with the team he was once a potential recruit.

“You're playing in some awesome environments, you're playing some awesome schools, and you get to coach at an awesome school, at the best school,” Waters said. “It's a great challenge. It'll be awesome to roll and go through it. Obviously, there's no one else I'd rather take that challenge on with coach Campbell and our guys and the staff.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | Penn State wrestling used dual against Michigan as training with varied approach
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Penn State wrestling defeated Michigan in dominating fashion by a score of 38-3, but found itself making different decisions and in interesting situations.

Some of the moves and decisions shown haven’t been made before, or as often as they were in Friday’s dual. It became more clear as the dual went on that the wrestlers and coaching staff were testing out some things.

The main catalyst to this is the neutral position. Penn State almost always chooses to go bottom when it has the decision to start the period. Multiple times on Friday the Nittany Lions chose to go neutral, essentially foregoing a point.

It started with Luke Lilledahl, who had a big lead, choosing to go neutral in the second period and ultimately ended up winning by tech fall in dominating fashion. The neutral position allowed him to get to his offense quickly, something that could be a reason why the decision was made.

The next time it happened was at 157 pounds. PJ Duke was leading 7-6 entering the third period and had a point sitting right in front of him if he chose to go on the bottom, barring he’d escape during the two minute frame.

Just like Lilledahl, Duke came out victorious but not without another sign of testing things. Late in the match, the Nittany Lion gave up a takedown to Cameron Catrabone, giving the Wolverine a lead. But, Duke immediately escaped, and in one motion, took down Catrabone to retake the lead. He made this movement look effortless and almost like he had been holding back.

The conceded takedown made it seem that Duke was done messing around and finished things off to get the win.

Two matches later, Levi Haines made the same decision to go neutral. His decision seemed pre-determined as he looked to bench while signaling for neutral. Josh Barr made the same decision to go neutral and won big, just as Haines did.

These matches also came with some precarious positions. Multiple times, Penn State wrestlers ended up in wild scrambles and were on their backs for split seconds. Luckily for the Nittany Lions, their skillset allowed them to come out on top more times than not in these mad scrambles. Penn State is testing things and changing things up against the No. 10 team in the country and still found ultra success.

The neutral position is definitely an interesting tactic. On one hand, Penn State is giving up the potential escape point, but is immediately giving its wrestlers a chance to score on a takedown.

The Nittany Lions remain miles ahead of their competition with the biggest test coming next week against No. 2 Ohio State. Whether Penn State chooses to use the neutral tactic against the Buckeyes won’t be known until Friday, but one thing’s for certain, it specifically chose this dual to test it out, with four different wrestlers choosing neutral and still winning.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Jessica Adolfsson records first goal in Team Sweden’s win over Italy
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
All three current Nittany Lions won their first Olympic game with their respective country on Thursday. A quick turnaround followed the players as they only had a day's rest until they hit the ice for their second game in Italy.

Two current Penn State teammates found themselves on opposite ends of the ice for the first time in the Olympics as Matilde Fantin, representing Italy, went against Nicole Hall, skating for Sweden. While former Nittany Lion Jessica Adolfsson joined Hall on Team Sweden.

“Let the best woman win,” Hall said regarding her matchup against Fantin.

While the two countries will meet again in the Olympics, it was Adolfsson and Hall who got the first laugh as Team Sweden used a three-goal second period for a 6-1 win over Team Italy.

Fantin had her name called early as she made her way through the offensive zone with speed. She quickly found herself in the slot where she met a defenseman’s stick. This led to a violent trip to the boards for Fantin.

The Como, Italy, native slowly made her way to the bench immediately after the collision and was seen grimacing in pain as her left collarbone area was being checked on. She later returned to the ice on her following shift.

Team Sweden opened the scoring nearly 10 minutes into the game. Adolfsson ripped a slap shot from the left faceoff circle that found the back of the net in an instant. It was the Landeryd, Sweden, native’s first goal in her second Olympics.

The puck seemed to follow Sweden after its first goal as they played with heightened aggression. The group forced multiple turnovers in its offensive zone, leading to quick scoring chances, ultimately ending with no additional goals.

Team Italy’s best chance of the first period came with under two minutes to play. After a forced turnover at the blue line, Marta Mazzocchi fed a pass to Manuela Heidenberger, who found herself behind the defense. The Bolzano, Italy, native moved in on her forehand, but was shut down by the left pad of Ebba Svensson Traff.

The opening period came to a close after a late penalty from Italy gave Sweden a power play. With no goal in the remaining 90 seconds, Sweden started the second period on the man advantage.

Momentum from its opening power play carried with Team Sweden as it continued to apply pressure in hopes of getting two on the scoreboard. The Swedish offense was able to get going due to the defense not allowing a shot on net from Italy until under 11 minutes left in the middle frame.

Sweden dominated in the shot department, finishing with 48 to Italy’s 18.

After spending almost all of the first 10 minutes in the offensive zone, Sweden finally found the net. Sofie Lundin went end-to-end and shot a wrister from the top of the faceoff circle.

Only two minutes later, a turnover in the neutral zone led to Sara Hjalmarsson entering the offensive zone with speed. With no defenseman in front of her, Hjalmarsson sent a quick wrist shot that found the net.

Italy found its way on the scoreboard late in the second period after Franziska Stocker sent a rocket at the net from the point. However, it didn’t take long for Sweden to answer, as just over a minute passed before it could get its fourth goal of the game. Hanna Olsson sniped a shot from the slot that made its way to the net.

Team Italy had the first scoring chance of the third period as a quick two-on-one opportunity was turned aside by Svensson Traff.

A quick turnover in its own zone from Italy gave Sweden a quality scoring chance. Thea Johansson didn’t waste time with the opportunity as she went five-hole giving Sweden its fifth goal of the game.

Johansson wasn’t done there as she joined a two-on-one rush with Olsson. She quickly received the pass and elevated it over the left pad of Gabriella Durante.

Team Sweden completely took momentum at the start of the second period and didn’t give it up

Up Next

Sweden will look to continue its successful start against France at 10:40 a.m. EST on Sunday. Fantin and Team Italy will look to rebound against Japan at 6:10 a.m. EST on Monday.

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE

title: Penn State unable to match LSU, falls short on the road in Baton Rouge
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
Despite three straight 196.000+ scores to open the season for Penn State, taking on the No. 3 LSU Tigers on the road in Baton Rouge on Friday Night Heights is unlike any challenge the Nittany Lions have faced this season.

Unable to put together its best meet to challenge the 2023 National Champion LSU Tigers, the blue and white lost 196.125-197.525.

However, despite a loss in the head-to-head matchup, Penn State could potentially use the performance as an away score in the NQS calculation.

Rotation One

Penn State got off to a slow start on the uneven bars, unfortunately unable to hit the 49.000+ mark.

Ellie Monahan got the Nittany Lions off to a strong start. She was aggressive, going for her handstands, needing a large arch in her back before dismount, but took just a small hop on her full twisting double back for a 9.700.

Jessica Johanson had a nice routine on the bars themselves and almost stuck her double layout, but had to take a step forward, which lowered her score to a matching 9.700. Elizabeth Leary turned the tide, got the sticks started, and scored the rotation’s first 9.800+ score in the third slot. She managed a strong 9.850 courtesy of a stuck full-twisting double back.

Ava Cash kept the momentum going. The freshman had a fingertip catch on her piked jaeger but put together a beautifully clean routine, featuring a stuck dismount, for a rotation-high 9.875. Ava Piedrahita had a solid routine on the bars but was unable to maintain that control through the end, needing a big hop back on her dismount for a 9.750.

Dani Latronica was a little shy on her bail handstand and took a small hop on her dismount as well, but finished the rotation strong with a 9.800.

On the vault, LSU did its usual, including yet another stick from star sophomore Kailin Chio on her Yurchenko 1.5. LSU took an early lead, 49.475-48.975.

Rotation Two

The Nittan Lions’ struggles continued on fault as they once again failed to score enough 9.800+ scores to get above a 49.000+

Leary nailed it in the leadoff position, practically sticking her Yurchenko full for a 9.750. Cash followed it up with an almost identical landing, taking just a small hop. Her increased height and strong form improved her score to a 9.800.

Allison Kaempfer has Penn State’s only 10.0 start value. She overrotated her Yurchenko 1.5, taking a big hop and step for a low 9.675. Despite a different fault, Latronica had a similar landing issue. Piking down, she took a large deduction on the landing for a 9.625.

Johanson got the team back on track with a solid Yurchenko full. She took just a small hope for an improved 9.800. Piedrahita anchored with the best vault of the rotation. She took just a small hop, but got massive height for a 9.775.

While Penn State had some shaky landings on the vault, LSU kept its momentum going on bars, extending its lead 98.750-97.750

Rotation Three

Leary led off in a big way for Penn State with a huge 9.850. She controlled all of her tumbling in an effort to get the Nittany Lions on track to bounce back after two low rotations.

Monahan kept the momentum going. She stuck her final pass and managed to control her leaps for a 9.825, the type of score Penn State needed if it wanted a chance to cut down LSU’s lead.

Bella Misiura opened with a clean front double full. The sophomore finished with a front full to layout that she stuck cold for another 9.825. Johanson opened with a big double pike. She had a bit of an uncontrolled hop on her final pass, which dropped her score to a 9.800.

Alyssa Kramer built off Johanson with a big front double full to start. She nailed the rest of her routine for a big 9.875. Kalea McElligott opened with a double tuck but took a small shuffle with her front foot in the lunge, which is a deduction, lowering her score to a 9.800.

Despite some early wobbles on the beam for LSU and a strong floor rotation for the Nittany Lions, they were unable to cut down the lead as they trailed the Tigers 146.925-147.975.

Rotation Four

Despite having basically no chance to beat LSU heading into beam as the final rotation, Penn State had to focus on its national average and put up a strong final rotation to do so.

Monahan was calm and confident in the leadoff position. She had no wobbles on the beam, but underrotated her dismount a bit, taking a small hop back for a 9.750.

Ashley Maul, in her first appearance of the night, delivered a big 9.850. She was solid on the beam like Monahon but managed to stick her dismount.

McElligott showcased her strong triple series. She could not quite hold on to the landing on the dismount, but matched Maul’s 9.850 with one of her own.

Amani Herring opened with a front toss-backhandspring combo, which she kept moving despite a small adjustment. She held on to her dismount for a solid 9.800.

Kramer had great control of her acro series, front toss, and leap series. She took just a small hop on her dismount for a 9.800.

Latronica finished the night with the highest score Penn State managed all evening, a 9.900. Nailing her routine on the beam and sticking her Gainer full off the side, the sophomore put an exclamation point on the night.

Despite Penn State putting together its best rotation of the night, the LSU Tigers did not let up once, running away with the meet.

Up Next

Penn State heads back to State College to welcome Michigan State at 2 p.m. on Sunday, Feb 8th.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball sweeps Saint Francis in first meeting of two-match series
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Three decades in Happy Valley, over 900 career games coached, with almost all of the Penn State men’s volleyball program record book written via accolades he’s earned with his teams throughout the way – Mark Pavlik is a bona fide Penn State legend.

Might as well commission his spot on the S. Allen Street mural now.

Yet, before the Penn State faithful get to that, the Nittany Lions have a chance to send Pavlik off into retirement with nothing but pride in the rearview mirror, but on that conquest, they have staggered to an even 4-4 start.

However, Pavlik and Co. get a look at an excellent opportunity to turn around that start and faltering form when it welcomes one of the bosses’ most familiar foes throughout his tenure – Saint Francis, led by its winningest coach of all time and of several decades, Mike Rumbaugh.

The Red Flash and the Nittany Lions met over 50 times in their program’s history, almost all of which during Pavlik’s and Rumbuagh’s tenures, and the results lean almost entirely in the blue and white’s favor, 54-3 all-time.

While there's familiarity in the matchup with success for Pavlik, and that’s precisely how the 2026 edition went, with the Nittany Lions cruising to a three set sweep. There’s also a new shakeup in the matchup – it’s the first time Rumbuagh’s squad stepped into Rec Hall at the DIII Level and as a member of its new league, the NEC.

For this unique version of a clash of familiar foes, Pavlik sent out his own group of usuals, with typical starters Jaxon Herr, Ryan Merk, Jaidyn Bethel, Gaige Gabriel, Sean Harvey, Owen Rose and Matthew Luoma to complete the first unit.

That group battled back and forth with the Red Flash as the two traded kills and minimal errors to a 6-6 first set.

Penn State then pulled ahead via an eight-point scoring streak, highlighted by a Bethel ace. The rest of the set resembled the start, as the two units traded kills and service errors to a 25-20 Penn State advantage – the closest the first frame finished since a 2023 extra points first set.

The second frame looked to contain more optimism for the Nittany Lions, as a pair of kills and a Red Flash attack error via a Harvey block got the blue and white out to an early 3-1 lead.

However, that fine lead was all Penn State maintained throughout the second set, as the Nittany Lions exchanged blows throughout its duration. The blue and white logged a second ace of the match to pull ahead 14-13, this time courtesy of Gabriel, and it boosted their momentum.

Harvey notched a kill, Saint Francis blundered two of its attacks and Tristan Hassell put up a big block to pull the blue and white 22-16.

Penn State’s offense stayed hot, as Hassell logged a kill to put the Nittany Lions at set point, and then, after a group of Pavlik substitutions, they finished the job. Herr launched a serve over the net, and when the ball came back, the Nittany Lions struck on the opportunity, as the senior assisted Harvey on the set-clinching kill.

Entering the third set, Saint Francis’s Brady Stump logged a match-high eight kills, but also posted five errors, while Penn State had a much more team attack, as four logged three or more kills. Harvey led the blue and white with four errors and five kills – tied with Luoma.

Penn State started the third set with another Harvey kill, and then Herr joined in on the fun, as he logged a pair of kills, a pair of assists and an assist on a Gabriel block, which boosted the blue and white to an 8-1 lead.

Saint Francis clawed back with a triad of kills, but Penn State still became the first to reach double-digits, as it drew closer to a sweep with a 14-7 lead.

Saint Francis cut the deficit to six as the Nittany Lions approached 20 points, and a pair of Bethel kills extended the Nittany Lions' lead closer to victory.

Ultimately, the blue and white used its momentum to take down the Red Flash, despite a four-point stretch in which they narrowed the lead to 23-18 and forced Pavlik to call a timeout.

Bethel made it match point after the break, and a Luoma kill eventually sealed the deal.

Harvey finished with a team-high nine kills and a team-high 11 points, while Herr finished with a game-high 21 assists.

Up Next

The blue and white continue its series against Saint Francis, this time on the opposition’s turf, as it stays in the Commonwealth with a trip to Loretto to face the Red Flash at DeGol Arena.

Streaming is available at 6 p.m. on NEC Front Row.

title: Penn State wrestling dominates on road against Michigan
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Penn State showed up and showed out in Crisler Arena. The Nittany Lions continued their dominance with a 38-3 win against Michigan.

Penn State got five tech falls, and seemed to be in control for many of the matches. Nate Desmond and PJ Duke had comeback wins after being down in both of their matches, but both were able to prevail.

125 Pounds: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs No. 26 Diego Sotelo (MICH)

After a bit of hand fighting back-and-forth, Luke Lilledahl was the first to get a takedown. When Diego Sotelo attempted to get up, the sophomore slammed him back down on the mat. Sotelo eventually got up, but was taken down twice more to take a 9-2 lead.

Lilledahl started in neutral and took down Sotelo immediately. Sotelo started to show some life when he secured a reversal, but it was answered by Lilledahl’s sixth takedown of the match.

The match ended with a Lilledahl reversal to win 21-5 by tech fall.

Penn State leads 5-0.

133 Pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs Gauge Botero (MICH)

After a slow start to the match, Marcus Blaze got things started with a takedown. The freshman got over a minute of riding time, another takedown and four near-fall points to end the period up 10-1.

Gauge Botero was able to get Blaze to under a minute of riding time, but the Perrysburg, Ohio, native escaped and then secured his third takedown of the match. Blaze let Botero up and then took him down immediately to get a 17-2 tech fall victory late in the second period.

Penn State leads 10-0.

141 Pounds: Nate Desmond (PSU) vs No. 26 Dylan Ragusin (MICH)

Nate Desmond got the call and was close to securing a takedown in the first period, but Dylan Ragusin didn’t let it happen and guarded it well. The first period was notched up at 0-0.

Ragusin escaped from Desmond early and continued to show strong defense until Desmond got a hold of his leg and got the takedown. Ragusin got awarded a stall point and the reversal and took a 4-3 lead.

Desmond was on another level in the third period with a reversal after slamming Regusin on the mat. Ragusin was able to escape to tie the match at five.

Desmond got the takedown in sudden victory to get the 8-5 as he wrapped around Ragusin and threw him down on the mat. Penn State leads 13-0.

149: Pounds: No. 4 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs No. 13 Lachlan McNeil (MICH)

These two last wrestled at the NCAA championships, with the outcome being in Shayne Van Ness’s favor. After the first period, neither wrestler was able to find the score sheet.

Lachlan McNeil escaped first and gave Van Ness a point for illegal touch to the back of the head. The junior then got the takedown and was on top of McNeil for the rest of the period.

McNeil got two stalling calls, which awarded Van Ness a point and the junior built off that with a takedown to take an 8-1 lead. With the riding time, Van Ness gets the major decision victory.

Penn State leads 17-0.

157 Pounds: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs No. 13 Cameron Catrabone (MICH)

Cameron Catrabone got the action started with an early takedown, but Duke escaped. After a stoppage for potential injury, Duke was on top and Catrabone got his fourth point of the period. Catrabone ended the period on top 4-1.

Catrabone got the escape to start the second, but Duke started to get aggressive and took Catrabone down soon after. The freshman continued to lead the charge and took a 7-6 lead going into the third period.

Catrabone got the takedown and Duke immediately escaped, got a takedown of his own to take an 11-9 lead. Catrabone escaped and with riding time, Duke got the victory 12-10.

Penn State leads 20-0.

165 Pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs Justin Gates (MICH)

Mitchell Mesenbrink started with a takedown in the opening 30 seconds and another one a minute later to take a 6-1 lead.

To start the middle frame, Mesenbrink got a reversal and continued to be on top of Justin Gates, who eventually escaped, and then got taken down by the junior. Mesenbrink got his fourth takedown to take a 14-3 lead.

The third frame started in neutral and Mesenbrink took Gates down twice and got the 20-5 tech fall victory.

Penn State leads 25-0.

174 Pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs No. 11 Beau Mantanona (MICH)

A lot of back-and-forth action between Levi Haines and Beau Mantanona, with Haines getting the takedown after Mantanona almost had his leg for a takedown. The senior continued to control the match and led 6-1.

Haines continued to be on top in the second with another takedown and over two minutes of riding time.

The Nittany Lions continued to take a neutral starting position. Haines secured three more takedowns to get the 19-4 tech fall.

Penn State leads 30-0.

184 Pounds: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs No. 7 Brock Mantanona (MICH)

The match started with hand fighting between the two until Rocco Welsh grabbed Brock Mantanona’s leg and got him down on the mat to score the first points of the match.

Welsh escaped to extend his lead to 4-0. The sophomore also added over a minute of riding time.

Mantanona got his first escape of the match to lessen the lead to 4-1, but with the riding time, and a late takedown, Welsh got the victory, 8-1.

Penn State leads 33-0.

197 Pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs No. 20 Hayden Walters (MICH)

Josh Barr scored the only points of the first period with a takedown on Hayden Walters. Barr added a second takedown in the second period. Walters was called for his first stalling call of the match, and Barr added his third takedown to take a 9-2 lead.

Barr added another takedown and got a stalling point due to Walters being inactive. The sophomore continued to score more takedowns with another one with 35 seconds left in the final frame.

Barr gets his sixth takedown of the match and the tech fall victory 19-4, extending Penn State’s lead 38-0.

285 Pounds: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs No. 5 Taye Ghadiali (MICH)

It was a stalemate between the two heavyweights and Cole Mirasola had a chance to secure points, but was unable to get Taye Ghadiali on the ground, something we’ve seen earlier this season.

Mirasola started on the bottom and struggled to get up as Ghadali tossed and turned Mirasola all over the mat. Mirasola eventually escaped and almost got another takedown, but it was Ghadali who got the takedown and the lead 3-1.

Ghadali escaped, and Mirasola continued to make attempts to take Ghadali down, but couldn’t get the job done. It looked like, at the end, that Mirasola could’ve been awarded a takedown, but it wasn’t called.

Penn State gets the win 38-3.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Danica Maynard records four points in No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey win over Lindenwood
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
While the snow fell in State College, No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey avoided the poor Pennsylvania weather with a trip to Missouri for the final road series of the 2025-26 regular season against the Lindenwood Lions.

In an eventful five-goal first period, Danica Maynard recorded four points and was one of four different goal scorers in what was a 6-3 win over the Lions in Penn State’s 20th conference win of the season, a new AHA record

The freshman defenseman now has 30 points this season, and it is her second four-point performance she has recorded this season

Perhaps the blue and white dealt with some jet lag following their flight to Missouri, as they allowed a goal just 2:23 into the game. Just the eighth time Penn State has allowed its opponent to score first and has done so in back-to-back games.

Lindenwood’s Zsofia Pazmandi performed a toe drag to evade defenseman Grace Tullock and got a shot off. Katie DeSa made the initial save, but Pazmandi jumped on her own rebound to put the Lions up early.

That goal sparked something in the Nittany Lions' offense.

Only 28 seconds after going down 1-0, Maynard picked up the puck at her own blue line and skated up the far side boards in front of the benches, split two Lions skaters, and fired a shot off of Lindenwood goaltender Lexington Secreto. Grace Outwater put the rebound in on a wide-open net to knot the game at one.

Outwater has scored in each of her last eight games with 11 total points in that stretch.

From there, Penn State’s offense continued to spearhead its attack down Lindenwood’s throat and added three more goals to score four unanswered goals within the first ten minutes of action.

Maynard would soon be awarded for her efforts on Penn State’s first goal after Pazmandi was assessed a two-minute minor penalty for interference.

After a successful clear from Lindenwood, the Nittany Lions drove their way back into their offensive zone. After a few give-and-gos with Kendall Butze, Maynard crept in from the blue line to the top of the slot and sent the puck pass from Katelyn Roberts through traffic to put the blue and white up 2-0.

Roberts continued the trend set by Maynard of assisting on one goal and scoring on the next. After a two-minute scoring break, Roberts caught a pass the length of half the ice from Butze and fed a centering pass to Mya Vaslet, who was brought down on a trip.

No power play needed for the senior winger as she picked up the puck after Secreto’s save, transferred to her backhand and slid the puck past the goal line to put Penn State up 3-1.

Following a faceoff in the defensive zone, Maynard showed off her speed the entire length of the ice and delivered a cross-crease pass to Maddy Christian, which capped off the Penn State scoring in the opening period.

After allowing four goals on seven shots, coach Taylor Wasylk pulled Secreto for Madison Bowtell.

Showing no discouragement of a 4-1 deficit, Lindenwood’s offense challenged DeSa and the Penn State defense early in the second period, including a 2-on-1 only 30 seconds in.

Despite a challenging first period, the blue and white continued their scoring spree in the second period, just a minute after Lindenwood’s scoring opportunity.

Abby Stonehouse blocked a shot with her skate and deflected the puck into the Nittany Lions’ offensive zone. Stonehouse and Robert’s combined presence forced Lindenwood to keep the puck in its own defensive zone. Taylor Lum deked around a skater and delivered a pass to McKenna Walsh, who easily tapped it between the legs of Bowtell.

Just over six minutes into the second period, the black and gold finally found the reward they were searching for.

After forcing a turnover at the blue line on a poke check against Stonehouse, Paige Cline cut to the net on a 2-on-1 with Molly Henderson. Henderson set a screen on Butze, allowing Cline to put one past the blocker of DeSa and cut the deficit to 5-2.

Penn State nearly answered just moments after, but the sophomore goaltender Bowtell made an impressive save to prevent the Nittany Lions from flipping the momentum.

Lum continued to play with a crash-the-net style with passes to the crease. Lum created another scoring opportunity with this style, which led to Shelby Shane scoring her first collegiate goal, the sixth of the evening for Penn State

Despite trailing 6-2, Lindenwood continued to play as though it were ahead. While skating at 4-on-4, Tatiana Blichova sent a pass off the glass to Henderson, who dragged the puck around Tullock for a shot on goal. DeSa lost the puck behind her, and it was poked in by Josey Dunne-Weeks to cut the Penn State lead in half.

The Nittany Lions continued to dominate, but it was Bowtell who dominated in the crease. The 5-foot-5-inch netminder stopped all 11 shots she faced in the third period and made 29 saves on 31 shots in the loss.

Bowtell stood tall on multiple 2-on-1 cross-crease opportunities, and capped off her third-period performance with a highlight-reel worthy save on a breakaway from Outwater.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions improved to 27-4 and will play in their final road match of the regular season at 2 p.m. on Saturday against Lindenwood.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball completes crazed week by hosting USC for first time ever
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hosts USC for the first time in Happy Valley, and in the place it calls home, the Bryce Jordan Center.

It completes a weird week for the Nittany Lions, from a buzzer-beater against Minnesota for their first conference win, to destruction in Ann Arbor at the hands of No. 2 Michigan and now, when it faces a squad with little shared history.

Given that trend, there are a few ways to make sense of the upcoming matchup, as the prevailing narratives surrounding both squads are hard to ignore.

Stats and player personnel

If there’s any way to tell a quick story for a game, it’s in the statsheet, and that’s where many of USC’s storylines persist.

Top-3 conference turnover numbers, a bottom-5 Big Ten defense, and three-point shooting percentage and tied for most fouls per game in the league, headline those worrying overall trends for the gold and cardinal.

The one area where USC excels is in possession metrics, as they’re currently a top-35 team in the nation in possessions per game, a stat in which the blue and white struggled all year long.

In the Trojans’ clash against Indiana, despite a win that improved USC to 17-6 on the year, and an even in the Big Ten after 12 games, a lot of those glaring issues weren’t addressed, but rather patched up with a band-aid in the form of freshman Alijah Arenas.

Son of three-time NBA All-Star Gilbert Arenas, and a top-10 player in the 2025 recruiting class, the 6-foot-6 guard had all eyes on him when he entered college ball, before he suffered a tragic car accident and a torn meniscus, which sidelined him for months. Arenas made his return in the last few weeks and, against the Hoosiers, dropped a career-high 29 points as he began to find his footing.

For a Trojans squad that has a lot of questions looming, a player like Arenas could be the final key to turning around those doubts, and at the very least, fill holes in the lineup that's recently opened.

Injuries

Both the Trojans and the Nittany Lions had their own share of injury problems over the last couple of weeks – a factor that could rear its ugly head on Sunday. In their previous contest, the tip of that iceberg already began to emerge, as Penn State played without its size, with international big men Ivan Jurić, Sasǎ Ciani and Tibor Mirtić sidelined. Joining that group is the only Nittany Lions sharpshooter to post a three-point percentage greater than 40%, Eli Rice.

That lack of physicality handicapped a squad that had to rely on freshman 7-footer Justin Houser, still wet behind the ears, and the blue and white stumbled to a 44-21 disadvantage on the glass against Michigan, as the Wolverines consistently found easy inside buckets. From beyond the arc, the blue and white shot a disastrous 2-for-20, without Rice’s clip present.

Mike Rhoades provided limited insight in his weekly media availability on whether anyone from that group would return. However, Jurić and Rice appear more likely, as their ailments—a fever and an accidental head collision—seem less severe than Ciani’s ankle issues or Mirtić’s shoulder injury, which had been seen in a sling.

For the Southern California competitors, they’ve been nagged just as bad, if not worse, because of absences. USC’s star forward Chad Baker-Mazara missed the Trojans’ last game against Indiana, and a Feb 5 MRI revealed he’s battling a Grade 1 knee strain that leads him to be day-to-day ahead of the weekend clash with the blue and white.

Baker-Mazara joins Rodney Rice, who averaged over 20 points per game over his six appearances this year before a late November injury ended his season, and senior wing Amarion Dickerson, who is out for several months due to a hip injury.

Heading into Happy Valley, ESPN predicts that USC has a little under 70% chance of a win, and while the sportsbooks haven’t officially opened for the game yet, it’s likely Vegas agrees with that sentiment.

The Nittany Lions will likely be heavy underdogs and given a double-digit point spread. This year, the blue and white are 1-12 when opening in that predicament and 1-5 as the dog at home. Against the spread, however, Penn State is 4-2 as a home underdog and 6-7 overall against the spread when the opponent is favored.

Tipoff is set at noon Sunday at noon with streaming available on the Big Ten Network.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball’s pitching leads the way in shutout win against Boston College
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off a thrilling 7-4 extra innings win over Missouri in its season opener, Penn State faced Boston College in the second game of its doubleheader on Friday afternoon.

The Nittany Lions displayed pitching excellence and carried their offensive momentum into this game, picking up the shutout win over the Eagles, 7-0.

After junior Bridget Nemeth closed the door and picked up the win in the blue and white’s last game, coach Clarisa Crowell gave her the start against the Eagles. While senior Halie Pappion got the task to face the Nittany Lions’ lineup after they started rolling late against Missouri.

It didn’t take long for Penn State to strike on offense as the blue and white carried its momentum right into this game early in the first. Junior Michela Barbanente reached base on a one-out walk and then swiped second base for her first steal of the campaign. With a runner already in scoring position, junior star Brooke Klosowicz picked up right where she left off last season.

The slugger powered a two-run home run deep over the left field fence, giving the Nittany Lions an early 2-0 lead. While Penn State threatened again with a few runners later in the inning, Pappion minimized the damage and allowed no more runs.

The hot bats continued in the second, pressuring Pappion into escaping another jam. Senior Madison Seidel led off with a triple dropped into right center and freshman Breanna Hanik followed with a walk.

The Nittany Lions stayed aggressive on the base paths early, as Hanik swiped second base and set Penn State up with runners on second and third. However, Pappion settled and got out the next three blue and white batters, which prevented any runs.

Despite a productive first few innings for the blue and white, the bats settled down. Yet, Nemeth was plowing through the Eagles’ lineup and allowed no runs. The Glendora, California, native threw a dominant three scoreless innings, surrendering just one hit and one walk.

Since Nemeth already pitched 2.1 innings in the earlier doubleheader game, Crowell turned to her bullpen at the start of the fourth and brought in freshman Mackenzie Duncan. The Winter Garden, Florida, native ran into some trouble when Boston College had a runner in scoring position, but Meghan Schouten flew out to right fielder Cara Bohner for the third out.

While Penn State’s bats went cold for three innings, they came alive again in the fifth. Needing some offensive momentum, freshman Kirsten Finarelli delivered her first collegiate dinger into right and gave the Nittany Lions another insurance run, 3-0.

Sophomore Natalie Lieto followed with a walk, which brought in sophomore Bailey Kendziorski, who ended Pappion’s outing. Despite freshman Allison Oneacre walking, Bohner grounded into a fielder’s choice and Oneacre was out at second.

Duncan mowed down the Eagles’ batters in the bottom half of the fifth. The left-handed pitcher struck out all three players she faced and preserved the three-run lead going into the later innings.

Penn State’s bats carried the momentum from the last inning into the sixth. Hannik reached base on a five-pitch walk, and junior Kaylie Walters followed with a single. The blue and white were relentless on the base paths as Hannik stole third and then scored off an error by the Eagles’ shortstop Janis Espinoza.

Despite not scoring any more runs in the inning, the Nittany Lions took a 4-0 lead late. After another shutdown inning by Duncan, Penn State pulled away in the seventh.

Boston College’s first baseman Emma Knight surrendered the Eagles' third error of the game, allowing a leadoff runner. Lieto then smashed a double into deep center field, but Finarelli didn’t score until Oneacre knocked in both runs on a single, making it 6-0. She also made it to second off another fielding miscue by Boston College.

A few batters later, Seidel knocked Oneacre in from third on a groundout to second, and Penn State took a commanding 7-0 lead into the bottom of the seventh. Duncan delivered an impressive collegiate debut, throwing 4 scoreless innings in relief, allowing just 2 hits and striking out 6.

Up Next

Penn State continues its road trip in Clearwater, Florida, and faces Eastern Kentucky in its first game of Saturday’s doubleheader at noon.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘He’s a special dude’ | Penn State OC Taylor Mouser’s journey, work ethic has him well respected
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Taylor Mouser has been at Penn State for two months as the new offensive coordinator, and in that timespan, he slammed a Bud Light at both Beaver Stadium and Pegula Ice Arena for men’s hockey games.

But he does more than crush cans of beer. He’s been Matt Campbell’s right-hand man at Iowa State, becoming “one of the up-and-coming bright minds in college football” as explained by Campbell.

“You’ve watched him mature in terms of who he’s become as a play-caller, a great leader of people,” Campbell said. “When you put the coordinator title to any of these coaches, I think you’re expecting a gentleman and somebody that’s got unbelievable leadership ability and the ability to align and unify a group, and Taylor’s done a great job of that.”

Mouser spent all 10 seasons with Campbell at Iowa State, and took on titles of graduate assistant, assistant director of scouting, senior quality control on offense and tight ends coach before becoming the offensive coordinator the past two seasons.

He additionally spent one year with Campbell when he was the head coach at Toledo as a graduate assistant.

So when Campbell left for Penn State and presented Mouser with an opportunity to be the offensive coordinator and tight ends coach for the Nittany Lions, Mouser said it “wasn’t a hard decision at all.”

After all, when Mouser finished his time playing defensive line for Division II Adams State in Colorado, he was working at Little Caesars trying to get into the coaching world and Campbell was the only one who picked up his calls.

“He’s the only person that hit me back,” Mouser said. “I don’t forget that, and the loyalty that he’s given me to be able to promote me to a spot where I got to be the offensive coordinator for the last couple years at Iowa State, and have success. So, it didn’t necessarily matter. It was Penn State.”

In his short time in State College, Mouser has been impressed by the tradition in the program but also the support from the fanbase. He loved his time going to the men’s hockey games, saying he typically doesn’t get to be a fan, though offensive line coach Ryan Clanton referred to Mouser as the “biggest hockey fan” in Pennsylvania.

There’s been a culture shift for Mouser, and while there’s adjusting to do off the field, there’s also changes on the field.

Mouser made it clear that what worked for the Cyclones might not fly for the Nittany Lions and yet, the belief in those around him show that the 2025 Football Scoop Tight Ends Coach of the Year has what it takes to succeed as a play caller no matter where he is.

“He's a special dude. He can wear every hat,” quarterbacks coach Jake Waters said. “He's extremely smart, football wise, extremely competitive. Wants to be the best and then he cares about relationships a lot.”

Building relationships is part of the identity that Mouser has created. Clanton said “if you believe in something, he believes in it.” Waters said he’s never met someone who met Mouser and said they didn’t like him.

Coming off of a 2025 season where ex-offensive coordinator Andy Kotelnicki and his play calling left much to be desired, he brings a fresh face to the role with high expectations.

Mouser believes in himself, as do many others in his circle, and is ready to put in the work to represent Penn State and what it took for him to get to this point.

“This place is incredible, and it’s a school that you dream about when you’re a small school guy. I played at a Division II,” Mouser said. “As a kid, you watch Penn State football games and the history here. You know about it. Even the idea of coming and coaching at a place like this, it’s so far-fetched. It doesn’t even enter your mind when you know where I was at before.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State field hockey hires new assistant coach Janelle Ward
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State isn't done making coaching changes.

𝑾𝒆𝒍𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒆 𝒕𝒐 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝑽𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒆𝒚 𝑵𝒆𝒍𝒍𝒚 pic.twitter.com/ujp3BmxNor— Penn State Field Hockey (@PennStateFH) February 6, 2026

The blue and white announced on Friday that it had hired Janelle Ward as an assistant coach. Ward spent two seasons at Temple in the same position and was a former goalkeeper for Saint Joseph's and Southern Connecticut State.

Following the 2025 season, the Nittany Lions fired coach Lisa Bervinchak Love and hired Hannah Prince in January to fill the position.

The Nittany Lions finished their 2025 campaign with a 7-10 record, missing the playoffs for the second straight season.

title: Staff predictions | Predicting Penn State women’s lacrosse’s 2026 season record
author: The Daily Collegian Lacrosse Staff
description:
Penn State is preparing for its biggest season in many years in Kayla Treanor’s first year leading the team.

Kicking off on Saturday against Richmond, the Nittany Lions have a full 17-game schedule ahead of them.

Here’s a look at how the Collegian women’s lacrosse staff thinks the blue and white will perform this season.

Noah Aberegg: 15-2

Treanor wants to win with the Nittany Lions, and that’s exactly what they’ll do in Year 1.

Penn State will win nine straight games to open the season, including beating Bucknell by a double-digit margin in mid-February.

The first true test of the season will come on March 15 when the blue and white hosts No. 6 Princeton. The Tigers fell in the NCAA quarterfinals to No. 1 seed North Carolina last year, but will return to beat Penn State 12-9.

The Nittany Lions will win another five straight games, including single-digit nail-biters against No. 15 Michigan and No. 7 Maryland.

Northwestern comes to town on April 12, and despite entering the season as the second-ranked team, will fall in an upset to the Nittany Lions. Penn State defeated No. 1 Northwestern in overtime last season and will do it again this year.

Penn State will fall to Johns Hopkins by multiple goals — its sixth loss to the Blue Jays since 2021 — before closing out the season with a win over Northwestern.

The Nittany Lions will enter the Big Ten tournament as the No. 3 seed and earn a revenge win in the semifinals over No. 2 Johns Hopkins before losing to top-seeded Northwestern in the championship game.

Penn State will earn the No. 8 spot in the NCAA tournament after falling short last year. The blue and white will earn victories over UMass, Virginia, Syracuse — Treanor’s former team — and earn its second victory of the season over top-seeded Northwestern in the semifinals before falling to Boston College in the NCAA championship.

Sam Krasowitz: 12-5

With a new coach and a new season ahead, Penn State will take a step forward from the past few years, but will still struggle against established programs nationwide.

The Nittany Lions will get through their first nine games with one loss to UMass and close wins against Drexel and USC. Their first loss to a preseason-ranked team will come back at home against No. 6 Princeton on March 15.

After getting a big rebound win at home against No. 15 Michigan, Penn State will split its two-game road trip, falling to Maryland but defeating Ohio State. When returning to Panzer Stadium, the Nittany Lions will defeat Oregon before their two toughest matchups of the season.

As the regular season comes to a close, the Nittany Lions will take on No. 2 Northwestern and No. 8 Johns Hopkins, two teams they lost to in the 2025 season. They will drop both games again, creating uncertainty ahead of the postseason.

Penn State will close out its regular season with a win on the road against Rutgers.

The Nittany Lions will clinch berths in both the Big Ten and NCAA tournaments, but will end the season with no hardware. They will fall in the semifinals of the conference tournament, followed by a second-round loss in the NCAA tournament.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: 'The face of homelessness is not what they think it is' | Gimme Shelter concert raises awareness, money
author: Vasco Chen | The Daily Collegian
description:
The South Hills School of Business and Technology hosted its annual Gimme Shelter benefit concert to raise awareness and money for housing security in Centre County Thursday night.

The concert lasted from 6-9 p.m. and featured performances from bands like Biscuit Jam featuring Kelly Countermine, Eric Ian Farmer and Jason O, the frontman for My Hero Zero.

Selden Smith used to be chair of the Citizens’ Advisory Committee of the Community Development Block Grant program in the State College Borough and advised on the distribution of funds provided by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

“From the federal government’s point of view, it’s hardly any money at all,” Smith, one of the organizers of Gimme Shelter, said. “But for the agencies, it’s a godsend.”

After visiting various agencies that provide support for people facing homelessness and seeing the scale of the problem, Smith teamed up with Jason Olcese, who’s the frontman for the band My Hero Zero and was also on the Citizens’ Advisory Committee.

Together, Smith and Olcese came up with the idea of a benefit concert and formed a planning committee of musicians and agency representatives. Eric Ian Farmer, a singer and songwriter who Smith met when they were both on the board of Foxdale Village, proposed the pay-what-you-will model.

After they began planning the Gimme Shelter benefit concert in 2023, they held their first event in February 2024 and their second concert the year after, raising approximately $8000 each time.

Proceeds were divided equally among the five agencies: Out of the Cold Centre County, State College Community Land Trust, Housing Transitions, Centre Safe and the Centre County Youth Service Bureau.

“The face of homelessness is not what they think it is,” Morgan Wasikonis said. “People think it’s just people that are unsheltered, on the streets and they don’t interact with them, but there’s a lot of hidden homelessness that people don’t realize is happening.”

Wasikonis, the executive director of Housing Transitions, said most people who go to shelters already have a job, but it’s not enough to pay for all their expenses.

“Unfortunately, you’re not always aware when you’re not in that situation,” Mary Rocco, a retired nurse, said. “So it’s just nice knowing there are organizations out there that help those people.”

Mayor Ezra Nanes attended the concert to show the borough, who is one of the main sponsors of the event, is committed and invested in helping people when in the community.

“One of the most powerful values and qualities I see in the people here is that they really care and they want to take action on that caring for other people,” Nanes said.

Smith said the influence anyone can have as a community member is to reach out to the others in the community. He encourages students who want to get involved to consider volunteering for one of the agencies.

“When they graduate and move somewhere else, that knowledge and experience is gonna help the communities they move to,” Smith said. “Even if they know they’re not here forever, the experience they gain here will be theirs forever.”

MORE BOROUGH COVERAGE

title: Column | Teams that could create problems for Penn State baseball in the postseason
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
As the spring lingers in Happy Valley, the Nittany Lions have a look at creating a productive season. Ending their 2025 campaign 33-23, their final game against Nebraska resulted in a 6-3 loss.

Looking to bounce back in the 2026 season, the blue and white hope to reach the postseason once again.

After not being able to secure the Big Ten championship, Penn State looks to exceed expectations this season.

For the topic of the postseason to even be brought up, it's important to know how well the Nittany Lions perform in the regular season.

Facing off in Big Ten play is what's most important to monitor. The Nittany Lions can compete with any of their conference rivals; the style of play and the depth of the bullpen are the pivotal keys for the squad.

Regular season stakes

A month into baseball season, the Nittany Lions will face off against the Hawkeyes for a three-game home series. This weekend will be the first look into how Penn State can play within the conference.

In early April, Penn State takes a trip to Haymarket Park in Lincoln to face off against Nebraska for a three-game weekend series.

The Washington Huskies visit State College in May for a Big Ten weekend.

How the Nittany Lions perform in their three-game series is a major determinant for how the squad will progress in the postseason.

When the stakes are high, as history has shown, conference play can be tricky. Maryland and Nebraska are the toughest postseason matchups the blue and white can face.

NCAA regional play

Beyond the Big Ten, Penn State’s challenges rise in the NCAA regional bracket.

The biggest problems stem from the power-hungry programs in the ACC and SEC. Dominating the College World Series, the last time a Big Ten school won was back in 1966, when the Ohio State Buckeyes won it all.

In 2019, Michigan reached the final but didn’t win the hardware.

Teams in the south thrive on extra base hits and home runs, so one poor pitch from the Nittany Lion bullpen can change the game within seconds.

No matter the opposition, the blue and white go up against their postseason fate on the execution of pitching, a very clean defense, and scoring early runs.

While there are many months before the Nittany Lions face the playoffs, how the regular season unfolds is a focal point.

MORE BASEBALL CONTENT

title: Gavin McKenna aggravated assault charge dropped
author: Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hockey’s Gavin McKenna will have his aggravated assault charge dropped, Centre County District Attorney Bernie Cantorna announced in a press conference Friday.

McKenna was charged with felony aggravated assault after allegedly striking a 21-year-old man in the face on Saturday night.

“Both the district attorney's office and the State College Police Department have reviewed video evidence of this incident and do not believe that a charge of aggravated assault is supported by the evidence,” Cantora said in a press release.

Follow up from State College police found that the victim suffered two fractures to one side of his jaw and is not missing a tooth, contrasting previous reports that he sustained fractures to both sides of his jaw.

Cantorna urged people to refrain from speculating about the case, adding that “verbal argument never, never justifies physical violence.”

Cantorna also stated that his office has “unequivocally” not been in contact with ICE, Homeland Security or federal authorities regarding McKenna’s visa/immigration status. McKenna is a Canadian citizen and is reportedly on a student visa.

The charges of misdemeanor simple assault and other summary charges have not been dropped.

Cantorna said McKenna had no attorney listed at this time and could not confirm whether the preliminary hearing scheduled for Wednesday will still occur.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS

title: Penn State men’s lacrosse set for second consecutive indoor game to start the season, hosts Villanova
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following an 18-14 victory over Colgate in Holuba Hall last weekend, the Nittany Lions will be back indoors for a matchup with Villanova on Saturday.

The blue and white’s win against the Raiders was fueled by offensive production that was relatively evenly distributed, with nine different Nittany Lions finding the back of Colgate’s net.

Sophomore attackman Hunter Aquino recorded a team-high six points in the victory, four of which were goals. Aquino was one of three Penn State players to record a hat trick, joining fellow attackman Kyle Lehman and midfielder Michael Faraone.

Aquino’s points came on a team-high 14 shots, a mark only Lehman came close to matching with nine. The attack unit of Aquino, Lehman, and freshman Jack Iannantuono combined for 14 points and eight goals in the win over Colgate.

Saturday’s game will be the season opener for the Wildcats. They also opened their season against Penn State last year, where the Nittany Lions secured a 15-5 victory in Villanova, Pennsylvania.

Villanova went 8-7 last season, with a 4-1 record in conference play. That campaign ended in the second round of the Big East Tournament, when they were eliminated by Georgetown.

The Wildcats placed second in the season-opening Big East coaches’ poll, receiving the only first-place vote not given to No. 5 Georgetown. They also received votes in the preseason Inside Lacrosse rankings, though they were unable to crack the top-20.

The team’s biggest weapon offensively will be Colin Michener, who was tied for the team lead with 40 points last season. The 6-foot-3 senior scored 26 goals in 2025, a mark that ranked second on the team, and his 14 assists were the most by any Wildcat.

Michener, a senior out of Plymouth Meeting, Pennsylvania, is a two-time All-Big East second team honoree and has scored 63 goals for the Wildcats through just two seasons on the field.

Jake Melchionni, a junior LSM for Villanova, received two preseason awards, being named a third-team All-American by Nike Lacrosse and getting a second-team nod by USILA. Fellow pole Jack Shoemaker was also honored as a USA Lacrosse preseason All-American honorable mention.

The trio of Michener, Melchionni and Shoemaker were each named to the preseason All-Big East team, all being unanimous selections.

Penn State holds a 21-9 all-time record against the Wildcats and has faced them in all but one season since 2008. The Nittany Lions currently hold a two-game winning streak over Villanova, following a two-game losing streak in 2022 and 2023.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Penn State softball rallies in extras and wins thrilling season opener against Missouri 7-4
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State traveled to Clearwater, Florida, for its season opener against Missouri on Friday morning. The matchup was the first game of the Nittany Lions’ doubleheader as the blue and white looked to start its campaign off strong with a solid win over a nonconference opponent.

The Nittany Lions pulled off an impressive season opener win in extra innings, with clutch pitching and timely offense, 7-4.

While coach Clarisa Crowell started junior McKenna Young on the bump, Missouri gave the ball to senior Cierra Harrison. Both right-handed pitchers started the game off strong with two strikeouts each in the first.

The Nittany Lions put pressure on Harrison in the second with a couple of base hits by Natalie Lieto and Cara Bohner, but they were both stranded after Madison Seidel struck out for the third out. After being held scoreless in the top half, the Tigers cracked through in their half of the second.

Young walked Madison Uptegrove on four pitches with one out, and then Abby Hay reached on an error by Bohner in right field. Kayley Lenger loaded the bases with a shallow single to center, which led to a sacrifice fly that plated the opening run, 1-0. In her first jam of the season, Young minimized the damage and forced a groundout from the next batter.

Missouri took the early lead, but it didn’t last long as Penn State would quickly respond with some runs of its own in the next inning. The top of the lineup delivered the offensive punch, beginning with a Kaylie Walters walk. With just one out, Michela Barbanente knocked in Walters on a hard-hit ball to the right-center gap.

Barbanente sped around the bases and reached third for an RBI triple and set up star Brooke Klosowicz for an opportunity to give Penn State its first lead of the season. The Johnsburg, Illinois, native delivered with a single into right field and put the Nittany Lions up 2-1.

However, the Tigers quickly evened the score back up in the bottom half. Young struggled with control and walked three Missouri batters, which led to a bases-loaded jam with two outs. The Brodhead, South Dakota, native couldn’t find the strike zone and walked in a run. With the game tied at two, Crowell brought in Abigail Britton, and she stopped the bleeding with a groundout.

While the fourth began promising after Bohner ripped a triple to left field, Harrison stayed composed and struck out the next three Penn State batters looking to prevent Bohner from scoring.

After Britton delivered a shutdown inning, the blue and white broke through on offense in the fifth. Harrison was on a roll and retired five straight Nittany Lions until freshman Kirsten Finarelli lined a two-out single up the middle. In one of the biggest at-bats of the day, Lieto doubled to right field and plated Finarelli, giving Penn State a 3-2 lead.

Britton retired the first five Missouri batters she faced until she lost control and hit Emma Jackson with one out. The sophomore then walked pinch-hitter Saniya Hill, prompting Crowell to bring in freshman Brevyn Kellepouris.

The left-handed pitcher surrendered an RBI single by Uptegrove, which tied the game again, 3-3. However, with runners on first and third, the Olathe, Kansas, native kept her composure and struck out the next two Missouri batters swinging, keeping the game knotted.

Penn State went down quietly in its half of the sixth, but Kellepouris found herself in a jam later in the inning. Sophie Smith smashed a leadoff double down the right field line and a sacrifice bunt quickly advanced her to third. Yet, Kellepouris escaped the scoring threat by retiring the next two batters on a lineout and groundout.

Pressure mounted as the game headed to the seventh, still tied, and neither squad produced much offense in the inning, so the tight contest headed to extra innings.

Finarelli began the eighth on second as the blue and white’s ghost runner and she quickly moved to third off a sacrifice bunt by Lieto. Freshman Allison Oneacre plated Finarelli with a short sacrifice fly and the Nittany Lions took a 4-3 lead.

Kellepouris stayed in the game and faced the bottom half of the Tigers' lineup. While she got the first out off catcher’s interference, Kayley Lenger knocked a single up the middle and plated the tying run, 4-4. Lenger also advanced to second base off the throw to home, so Missouri quickly had Penn State on its heels.

The freshman struck out Smith for the second out, but walked the next two batters for a two-out bases-loaded situation with the season opener on the line. Crowell called upon junior Bridget Nemeth to extend the game. The Glendora, California, native forced a groundout to second baseman Barbanente, who flipped it to shortstop Walters for the crucial third out.

The blue and white came away empty in its half of the ninth, so Nemeth needed a scoreless inning of her own. After a successful sacrifice bunt to first base, the Tigers had a runner on third and a chance to end the game. Yet, Nemeth rose to the occasion and retired the next two Tigers, forcing a tenth inning.

Penn State’s offense finally broke Missouri reliever Courney Donahue after just one run in four innings. With one out and Barbanente on third, Finarelli slipped a single to shallow right field and plated the go-ahead run, 5-4. The Lehman, Pennsylvania, native also advanced to second on the hit due to a fielding miscue by right fielder Claire Cahalan.

The scoring didn’t stop there as Oneacre smashed her first collegiate home run to deep left field and added massive insurance runs, extending the lead 7-4. Now in a prime position to win the season opener, Nemeth retired the Tigers in order and secured the nonconference victory for the blue and white.

Up Next

Penn State plays the second game of its doubleheader against Boston College at 1 p.m.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State softball continues season-opening series in Sunshine State with doubleheader against EKU, BYU
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
As the month of February begins, the Nittany Lions softball season awakens. Penn State softball kicks off its season playing in the beautiful Sunshine State. The NFCA Leadoff Classic will be held in Clearwater, Florida, from Feb. 6-8.

The blue and white will face five opponents this upcoming weekend. After a record-breaking 2025 season, Penn State has a chance to follow up with another successful season. To start the weekend, the Nittany Lions will play a doubleheader on Friday against Missouri and Boston College.

Continuing the weekend with yet another double header on Saturday, going up against Eastern Kentucky and BYU.

Eastern Kentucky

The first pitch of the day will be at Noon, Saturday. Where the Nittany Lions will face off against Eastern Kentucky for their third game of the NFCA Leadoff Classic.

Eastern Kentucky was the No.1 team in the ASUN conference last season. Going 17-5 within their conference and 38-16 in their 2025 run. Chasing another successful season after coming off a Gold Division championship season.

The ASUN Preseason coaches poll placed the Colones at the No.2 spot. Junior Kennedy Drafton was honored with the Preseason All-ASUN Team.

After posting a .356 batting average and tallying 52 hits, 10 doubles, and nine home runs, Drafton has a chance to conquer at the plate once again. Scoring 52 times and driving in 45 runs, the Perland, Texas native hit the second- highest total in the ASUN.

The Colonels’ rising star, sophomore Jada Mcleod will be a leading factor in the afternoon matchup. McLeod, an infielder, was an ASUN All-Freshman team and a Third Team All-ASUN honoree.

Bringing in five home runs, seven doubles, one triple, 27 RBI’s, and 35 hits in her inaugural season as a Colonel.

The Nittany Lions prepare to face off against a dominating ASUN conference team. Penn State has never lost to Eastern Kentucky, having two prior meetings, the Colonels are scoreless against the blue and white.

BYU

Following the Noon showdown against Eastern Kentucky, Penn State will face off against the Cougars at 3:00 p.m.

BYU finished sixth in the Big 12 conference in 2025. A 13-11 record in conference play and an overall 32-17 season finish.

Six of their top nine hitters from last year return.

Ilove’a Brittingham, sophomore catcher and senior Lily Owens are two who were named to the All-Big 12 Preseason Team.

The Cougars offense is one to reckon with, being ranked eighth in the nation in home runs per game last season at 1.63. Finishing No.16 nationally with a total of 80 homers, No.23 in double plays per game and No.23 in slugging percentage.

Ranked No.11 on D1 Softball’s preseason outfielder ranking, Brittingham is also No.14 for utility player ranking by Softball America, and No.49 on D1 Softball D100 preseason player rankings. The Nipomo, California, native is BYU’s star going into the 2026 season.

Prior to this weekend's meetup on the dirt, the last time Penn State faced off against BYU was in 2007 at Fresno State’s Bulldog Classic. A 17-4 victory for the Nittany Lions in five innings.

Saturday’s matchups for the blue and white will be a must-watch. As their second day of doubleheaders, it will be intriguing to see how Penn State performs for the second half of their first tournament. All games will be streamed on Gamechanger.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Looking at Penn State basketball’s Justin Houser’s development as he sees more minutes due to injuries
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State originally planned for freshman Justin Houser to potentially redshirt this season while giving center Yanic Konan Niederhauser a 7-footer he could play against in practice.

Instead, with Konan Niederhauser leaving for the NBA this past offseason, Houser is on a different development path as he’s a depth piece.
