Big men Ivan Jurić, Tibor Mirtič and Saša Ciani have all missed the last two games due to injuries, so Houser’s seen an uptick in playing time, including a career high in minutes during Penn State’s 110-69 loss to Michigan on Thursday night.

“He's the biggest guy on the team when Ivan is not there, so he's got to play, and it's great for him as a freshman to play 21 minutes in a Big Ten game against the No. 2 team in the country,” Mike Rhoades said postgame. “It makes you realize where you're at, how much work you have ahead of you, and you got to build on it. He battled. He was nervous early, and then I thought he battled as he went on.”

Houser hasn’t started either game as the Nittany Lions opted for a small-ball lineup with forward Josh Reed at the five to begin both matchups, but he’s come in off the bench early. The 7-footer subbed in at the 16:47 mark of the first half in Thursday’s game.

The Phelps School product was up against a tough Michigan frontcourt with players like 7-foot-3 center Aday Mara. Houser ended his night with six points, two rebounds and two blocks on 2-of-5 shooting, and he picked up four fouls as well.

Rhoades has said previously that the speed of a game catches up to Houser at times, and he reiterated during Tuesday’s press conference that Houser has to get bigger. Houser’s listed weight is 235 pounds, and Rhoades said the goal is 250 pounds.

While Rhoades outlined the work Houser still needs to do, he gave some praise to the young 7-footer, too. During his limited playing time this season, him giving full effort is apparent.

“Especially since Christmas time, I think he's just really improved, and some things are becoming clearer for him,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “He loves basketball. He loves being here at Penn State. When you're a big guy like him, freshman bigs don't understand how physical the Big Ten is until they get hit a couple times.”

Houser has seen at least five minutes of playing time in three games this season. Last Sunday, he chipped in three rebounds, two points and a block while only recording one foul in eight minutes during Penn State’s 77-75 win over Minnesota.

Earlier this season, Houser played 13 minutes against Pitt on Dec. 21, and while it was an 80-46 loss for the Nittany Lions, he helped provide a spark to begin a comeback attempt before it fell apart. Houser totaled five points and a block with four fouls versus the Panthers.

Throughout his first year in Happy Valley, Houser gets to work with assistant coach Brent Scott, who developed Konan Niederhauser into a first-round NBA draft pick. Houser said his defense has taken the “biggest jump,” saying he thinks he’s improved tenfold.

“It's been great working with coach Scott,” Houser said Tuesday. “I mean, he's helped me a lot after practice. I’m watching film with him. He's working me out. He's helping me improve my skills a lot, which has been awesome.”

Houser is a raw talent who isn’t expected to see much playing time when the depth chart is fully healthy. Jurić, who was listed as “questionable,” still has uncertain availability with Rhoades saying he hopes to have Jurić back for the upcoming USC game on Sunday, while Ciani and Mirtič have yet to shake off the “out” tag on the availability report.

In other words, Houser could still be tasked with a sizable role in the rotation against the Trojans. It’s a different reality from developing under Konan Niederhauser, but Rhoades has one main message to Houser.

“I just tell him to go out there and play harder than the guy you're going against,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “Let's just start with that. I say that to him all the time. Outrun him, outplay him, be more physical than him, and if you get lost in that, then you're not overthinking the game.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s lacrosse opens season with road trip to Richmond
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s lacrosse is finally here.

Months after Kayla Treanor’s hiring, her squad will get their first look of the season at Richmond at 12 p.m. Saturday.

Penn State is coming off its first losing record since 2022 and will look to get off on a strong note against the Spiders.

On the other hand, Richmond experienced success throughout the regular season last year, reaching double-digit wins with a 10-7 regular season record. However, its success ran out in the postseason.

After defeating fifth-seeded St. Bonaventure 11-8 in the first round of the Atlantic 10 tournament, the Spiders scored the same amount of goals against No. 1 UMass, but ultimately fell 16-11.

Richmond had a pair of high-scoring attackers who led the team last year in Colleen Quinn and Alexis Morton.

While Quinn graduated, Morton is back for her senior year after a successful Year 3. The Manhasset, New York, native recorded 39 goals and 37 assists for 76 points — the second-most on the team.

On the goalkeeping end, junior Abby Francioli is back for another year after starting all 19 games last year.

Through 963 minutes, Francioli recorded 155 saves with a 46.5% save percentage.

Saturday’s matchup will likely be a battle in the net, as the Nittany Lions have a dominant goalkeeper of their own.

After cruising through her freshman year and being named Big Ten Freshman of the Year, Sydney Manning has been the go-to goalie for the blue and white. Last year, Manning recorded 110 saves in her 12 starts.

Despite Richmond being without last year’s top scorer, it will still have plenty of other high-power attackers to challenge Manning.

The Spiders return their third, fourth, fifth and sixth leading scorers from last year, as Mortion and Juliana Stanley combine for 74 goals.

In just seven combined starts, Charlotte Edwards and Birdget Lonsinger also scored 31 total goals and will likely improve that number with more time on the field this year.

Just as Manning is challenged in the net, however, the Nittany Lions have plenty of offensive strength that should challenge Francioli.

Senior Erika Ho returns for her final season after leading the team with 46 goals last year. Twenty-goal-scorer Emma Kelly and 49-point scorer Kelly MacKinney will also take the field and earn many starts this year, providing further challenges to Richmond.

While both sides have their fair share of strengths heading into Saturday’s game, the Nittany Lions will look to keep their undefeated all-time 11-0 record against Richmond alive.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Penn State softball’s potential postseason national competition
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s historic 2024 season earned the program its first NCAA Regional berth since 2011. The Nittany Lions were unable to build on that momentum in 2025, finishing 25-27 and falling in the Big Ten Tournament quarterfinals.

However, the blue and white return significant experience and star power on both sides of the ball, and if all the pieces come together, coach Clarisa Crowell’s squad could see its second Regional appearance in three years.

Penn State has made 11 NCAA Tournament appearances, but has never advanced past the Regional round. A push for the program’s first Super Regional, and potentially a trip to the Women’s College World Series in Oklahoma City, is possible in 2026, but the path won’t be easy.

Here’s a look at some of the top national competition Penn State will have to face in pursuit of a deep postseason run.

The SEC

The SEC is expected to be the most dominant conference in college softball this season. In 2025, the SEC set an NCAA record with 14 teams reaching the tournament, the most by any conference in history.

Twelve of the 25 teams in ESPN/USA Softball’s preseason poll reside in the SEC, including half of the top-10. If the Nittany Lions reach the postseason, they’ll likely have to get through at least one SEC team.

The team to beat is reigning national champion Texas. The Longhorns enter 2026 tied for the preseason No.1 spot with last year's runner-up Texas Tech. In each of the last four seasons, the preseason No. 1 team has won the national title.

Last season, Texas led Division I with 630 hits, finished second with 460 RBIs and third with a .352 batting average. The Longhorns return standout hitters senior Reese Atwood and junior Katie Stewart.

Atwood hit .393, with 21 home runs and a nation-leading 89 RBIs, earning her second-straight unanimous NFCA First Team All-American honor. Stewart hit .381 with 17 home runs and 80 RBIs.

Texas also returns its ace Teagan Kavan, who went 28-5 with a 2.16 ERA and 230 strikeouts in 207 innings pitched.

Other SEC contenders include Oklahoma, Tennessee, Florida and Arkansas.

Penn State will face Tennessee in Knoxville on Feb. 27 and 28. The Lady Volunteers owned the nation's lowest ERA last season at 1.82.

Since 2000, the Nittany Lions have made nine Regional appearances, and four have been hosted by SEC teams. Two of those, including the most recent one, were at Texas A&M.

If history is any indicator, then Penn State might once again draw an SEC team if the Nittany Lions hear their name called on Selection Sunday.

Texas Tech

Texas Tech is coming off a historic season, finishing one win shy of a national title in its first-ever WCWS appearance.

The Red Raiders made headlines in the 2024 offseason by landing former Stanford ace NiJaree Canady, who led the Cardinal to two WCWS appearances and was named the 2024 USA Softball Collegiate Player of the Year.

In her first season at Texas Tech, Canady posted a 34-7 record, 1.11 ERA and 319 strikeouts.

This offseason, the Red Raiders added three NFCA All-Americans via the transfer portal, highlighted by Ohio State’s Jasmyn Burns, former Florida Gator Mia Williams and ex-Tennessee slugger Taylor Pannell.

The Red Raiders bolstered their pitching depth with former UCLA arm Kaitlyn Terry, who owns a 2.50 career ERA.

The Red Raiders are expected to control the Big 12, with Arizona and Oklahoma State being the only other top-25 teams in the conference.

Florida State and Clemson

The last leg for Penn State would be the ACC, likely led by Florida State or Clemson.

The Seminoles enter the season ranked No. 7 and return strong duos on both sides of the ball. Pitchers Jazzy Francik and Ashtyn Danley were the ACC’s top two arms, combining for a 1.55 ERA and just five total losses.

Offensively, Isa Torres and Kennedy Harp anchor the lineup. Torres led Florida State with a .436 batting average and struck out just five times. Harp hit .412 with 49 RBIs and tied for the nation 's-best mark of 10 triples. As a team, the Seminoles posted the ACC’s second-highest batting average at .346.

Clemson, a program that debuted in 2020, is the only team on this list without a WCWS appearance. The Tigers reached a Super Regional last season before falling to Texas.

Clemson returns reigning ACC Freshman of the Year Macey Cintron, who went 8-2 with a 2.25 ERA. At bat, Cintron hit .292, recording 51 RBIs. Julia Knowler also returns after driving in 62 runs, batting .313 and hitting 15 home runs

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Position preview | Talented returning defenders, goalie, headline Penn State women’s lacrosse
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
While a majority of Penn State’s team can expect to see new faces sprinkled throughout in Kayla Treanor’s first year, the defense and goalkeeper situations should remain fairly steady from last year.

With a majority of last year’s line returning for another year, here’s a look at the Nittany Lions’ defenders and goalkeepers entering this season.

Returning defenders

Among the returners, redshirt sophomore Cailin Hetrick stands as one of two defenders who started all 16 games last year.

Despite her youth, Hetrick recorded 17 ground balls and caused eight turnovers while only giving up seven balls.

Alongside Hetrick is senior Maggie Driver, who took a big leap in Year 3 with 16 starts. Driver played arguably more aggressive defense, picking up 18 caused turnovers and 30 ground balls.

Lauren Tinson and Lily Spilker each found their spots in the starting lineups eight times apiece last season, making their marks on the Nittany Lions.

Tinson’s stats weren’t super flashy, but she recorded nine ground balls and five caused turnovers nonetheless. Spilker saw the same success with ground balls, but also forced 16 turnovers.

Ava Stummer, Lily Strohecker and Brooke Lattanzi all had little to no playing time last year and will look to see the field more this season.

Freshmen defenders

Compared to the rest of the position groups, Penn State’s defense has the smallest freshman class with just two athletes.

Sarah Anné comes to Happy Valley as a two-time Utah Women’s 5A State champion, earning the honor in 2022 and 2024. In that year, she was named the Utah State Playoff MVP and earned All-American honors from USA Lacrosse.

Susannah O’Connell joins the Nittany Lions from a little closer to home, hailing from Summit, New Jersey. There, O’Connell served as a tenacious defender, breaking her high school’s record for most caused turnovers while earning USA Lacrosse All-American honors and being named a two-time All-State honoree.

Goalkeepers

The Nittany Lions’ premiere goalie over the past two years has been Sydney Manning, who’s started in all but six games.

Now in her junior year, Manning will look to continue that stretch and improve on her performance. In her freshman year, she recorded a 41.3% save percentage and improved to 43.7% last year.

Out of the other three goalies on Penn State’s roster, only Emily Bette has seen playing time, recording seven minutes in 2023. She will likely be the backup keeper for her senior year.

Sophomore Arden Jansen and freshman Makenna Gagliardi have yet to see action for the blue and white and likely won’t this year. Jansen won the district and league championship for Radnor High School in 2024, while Gagliardi was the 2023 and 2024 Suffolk County champion.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: No. 5 Penn State men’s gymnastics visits Midwest, faces No. 6 Nebraska
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s gymnastics takes a trip to the Midwest for a meet against Nebraska on Saturday.

This is the Nittany Lions’ second Big Ten matchup, and they are coming off of a win against Illinois 316.800-311.000. The blue and white are having a strong season so far, with all wins except for a second-place finish at the Sam Mikulak Invitational earlier this season.

The Cornhuskers have seen less action than the Nittany Lions this season, competing in the Rocky Mountain Open against Oklahoma, Stanford, USAF Academy, Arizona State and the Rocky Mountain Mavericks. Ultimately, Nebraska finished in third, and also took a loss against Ohio State last Saturday.

Penn State has a break after this meet, resuming the season on Feb. 20 for the Winter Cup, so seeing it have a chance to push for a win and end on a good note is expected.The Cornhuskers need a solid win to head in the right direction, so putting up a solid lineup and finding ways to push the Nittany Lions is another thing to expect.

Looking at areas of focus for the Nittany Lions, pommel horse and vault will be important since those are where most of the top numbers are coming from. Ricky Perez and Landon Simpson are looking strong to lead on pommel horse, with both gymnasts consistently putting up 13.500 and above all season. Simpson also comes in strong on vault, with Shaun Smith also having high numbers on the event.

The Cornhuskers have a few options to go head-to-head on vault against the Nittany Lions, with Luke James having 14.500 against Ohio State and Alex Nitache, who put up a 14.300. Nebraska likely chooses Nathan York for pommel horse, who secured a 14.000 against Ohio State.

Nebraska will need to consider using athletes like James and York across multiple events and spread out its roster to target the areas the Nittany Lions excel.

Penn State has figured out its groove this season, having worked out the holes in its lineups and moved gymnasts around to be effective in more than one event. Nebraska has been using the same athletes in the same event and has not quite found a way to have high scores across multiple apparatuses.

Looking at starting a winning streak will be important for the Cornhuskers to have a successful rest of the season. With the strong roster of the blue and white, this meet could be a tool to test out what a possible lineup for Nebraska could look like against a more settled team.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: The Press: Community in a glass
author: Veronica Figg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Press Cider & Craft Beverage Taphouse opened last October at 113 Heister St. I’ve passed by it multiple times on my way to class, but I’ve never had the chance to go. I recently got the opportunity to try out their menu on a hopping Friday night where not only the drinks warm you up, but the atmosphere as well.

The Press invites you to take a seat wherever you like via a chalkboard near the entrance, and tells you to order at the bar when you’re ready. The Press was lively when I arrived, with music playing from the speakers at a volume that was comfortable enough to hear your friends speaking. The taphouse has very warm lighting that gives the space a welcoming vibe.

It’s a drinks-only establishment with a bring-your-own-food invitation. I brought a wrap with me from On a Roll at Redifer Commons in Penn State’s South Food District. My wrap had roast chicken, mayonnaise, sliced tomatoes, red wine vinegar, olive oil and Italian seasoning. I also got Miss Vickie’s Salt and Vinegar chips as a side.

The Press’s menu is organized into four sections: cider, wine and mead, craft PA beer, craft cocktails and non-alcoholic options. I ordered a flight of four 4 ounce samples and asked the bartender for recommendations on both their sweetest drinks and other popular favorites. He recommended I try number nine and number four as sweet options, and number two and number nine for favorites.

Number Nine: Chucklin Berry

Chucklin Berry was the sweetest drink and my favorite of the night. This is no surprise for a person with a love of sweet drinks (think strawberry daiquiris). It smelled sweet, but in a pleasant, fruity way. The drink was a cider with blueberry, strawberry and raspberry flavors, and the fruitiness of the drink made it very sweet.

The aftertaste was a very sweet strawberry flavor, and that paired with the blueberry was more pronounced in the drink over the hint of raspberry. This made for the cider to be smooth with a bit of a tang.

However, the hint of raspberry tied the drink together for a great three-berry flavor combination. I finished the whole thing and would recommend it for any fellow sweet drink lovers out there.

Rating: 10/10

Number Four: Cranpus

Number four was my second favorite. Cranpus was a half-cider, half-wine combination drink.

It smelled the sweetest, which made sense since it was half-wine. It was not as smooth as the number nine and in fact was a little sharp. This sharpness could have been from the drink’s higher ABV.

I could taste the wine right away. The cranberry and pomegranate were the flavors that stood out the most, and they overpowered the subtle hints of raspberry.

Even with the overwhelming taste of cranberry and pomegranate, it was still one of my favorites and had a very sweet and fruity aftertaste.

Rating: 8/10

Numbers nine and four tasted the best with my wrap and chips, with the sweetness of the drinks acting as a nice juxtaposition to the salty chips. This made for a great flavor combination.

Number 2: Ginger? I Pear-ly Know Her

This drink was dry, which is expected in an off-dry cider. What was not expected was the bitterness in both taste and smell.

The ginger also overpowered the pear where I could still taste it and it struck a nice balance, but I wished the pear would have been a little stronger overall. This drink wasn’t my favorite, but for any ginger-lovers out there, this is the drink for you.

Rating: 6/10

Number 10: Monkey Step Wine Spritzer

I thought I was going to like this one because it was wine — I was wrong.

This drink smelled and tasted the most bitter, but still maintained a smooth finish.

The lavender was so overpowering I could not taste the blueberry flavor at all. The too-much lavender taste made this my least favorite drink of the four. However, for those of you who love the seasonal Starbucks Lavender menu, this would be heaven in a glass.

Rating: 4/10

Veronica’s Food Sensitivity Corner

As a student who was recently diagnosed with a dairy sensitivity, I am always on the lookout for foods that fit my new dietary needs, and I am also aware there are other students who may have similar needs as well.

The ciders, wines and meads offered at The Press are all gluten-free.

I will definitely be returning to The Press in the future to get another glass of the Chucklin Berry and bring my friends along with me. For delicious drinks with a side of warm atmosphere, look no further than The Press.

A downside is The Press is closed on Mondays and Tuesdays, but it’s open on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 6 p.m. to midnight, and on Saturdays from 2 p.m. to midnight and Sundays from 2 p.m. to 8 p.m.

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Column | Out of my depth
author: Julia Frederick | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s 11:15 a.m. on the first day of classes and my mind is screaming, “What am I doing here?”

English 515: Creative Nonfiction Workshop/Appropriation is the second graduate-level class I’ve taken in my integrated bachelor’s/master’s program.

Going into it, I was incredibly excited. I love writing (if you couldn’t tell by the fact that I write these columns for fun) and creative nonfiction is the niche within English that I plan on getting my master’s degree in.

As class began, we went around the room introducing ourselves. Each of my classmates sounded so sophisticated, intelligent and confident. Just hearing them speak for a few minutes, I could tell that they were talented writers.

Despite the kindness of my professor and fellow classmates, I quickly felt out of place. They had their acts together and I most certainly didn’t.

After that first class, I found myself struggling to write. I told myself that whatever I wrote needed to be perfect. I had to prove to everyone, and myself, that I belonged.

Words failed me as I stared at a blank Google Doc.

On the phone with my mom, I told her bluntly: I feel completely out of my depth.

I can imagine that for graduating students in the midst of starting new jobs, internships, or graduate programs, I’m not alone in this feeling.

Something I’m sure you’ve heard of is “imposter syndrome.” Psychology Today describes it as feeling “undeserving” of accomplishments and as doubting competency and intelligence.

If you were a so-called “gifted kid” or are, as Psychology Today puts it, a “high achiever,” you’re more likely to deal with this internalized feeling of not being enough. In fact, the outlet also says “around 70 percent of adults may experience impostorism at least once in their lifetime.”

Psychology Today indicates that to overcome imposter syndrome, you should stop comparing yourself to others and remember all that you’ve accomplished.

You passed the interview process. Your application was accepted. You earned the right to be here.

On a different note, we often go into things expecting them to be easy. However, as is frequently the case in the great unfolding of life, things aren’t.

As an anxious individual, challenge can sometimes manifest as discomfort. I so desperately want to feel like I’m part of the group, especially in the field I hope to enter. When things feel off, it feels safer to retreat than to engage.

Let me remind you that just because things are difficult doesn’t mean they aren’t worth doing.

Whether it’s a new job, graduate school, or whatever your next step is, it’s likely not going to be what you’re used to. Give yourself time to adjust.

Everyone was once the newbie at something. It’s OK to feel a little overwhelmed. The important thing is seeing it through.

Finally, let me share with you one of my favorite poems, “Wild Geese” by Mary Oliver.

I’ve turned to it in many a stressful and uncertain moment and it helps bring me a sense of calm.

I encourage you to read the whole thing, but the first line sums up what I hope you get out of this column: “You do not have to be good.”

That sounds bad taken out of context, but what Oliver is getting at is you don’t need to be perfect. You need to be you, and that’s enough.

I’m looking forward to my next 515 class. I’m not going to let self-doubt ruin what I’m sure will be a rewarding opportunity for growth.

As Mary Oliver says, “the world offers itself to your imagination.” Go forth and do great things.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Position Preview | Penn State baseball welcomes veteran-led outfield
author: Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State baseball is on the rise. After recent success under coach Mike Gambino, the blue and white will seek to remain competitive in 2026.

Last season, the Nittany Lions marked one of their more successful years in recent history, finishing 33-23. In 2024, Penn State reached the Big Ten Tournament Championship, narrowly losing to Nebraska.

If anything, all indications are pointing to a successful season ahead. And, as the backbone of the roster, Penn State’s outfield will have a shot to replicate its dominance from last year.

Luckily, Gambino and the Nittany Lions are welcoming continuity with four of their six outfielders returning. Penn State will embrace its large veteran presence.

Here is what you need to know.

Returners

Last season, Penn State was on the opposite end of the spectrum. The team welcomed a clean slate of outfielders, and it paid dividends.

College baseball has revealed several key factors to success, one of which is consistency. The Nittany Lions built their roster around the outfield, which generated an explosive offense last season. Among those talents was Paxton Kling, who led the team in batting average and left for the MLB Draft.

However, not far behind him was Jack Porter. Now, in his redshirt junior year, Porter will seek to replicate his past success.

The 6-foot-1 Clearwater, Florida, native provides a versatile ability to aid with his hot bat. While batting .310, he also tallied 57 hits with a .549 slugging percentage. Porter will undoubtedly be the focal point of the offense as he started and played in 47 games last season.

Right behind him was Jesse Jaconski, who, like Porter, presents a utility threat, being able to play multiple positions. The former North Carolina and Hartford Community College transfer played a major role in last year’s excellence from inside the batter’s box.

Jaconski, a right-handed senior, started and played in 55 games, and marked the third-highest batting average at .298. But it's all about the power. His extreme efficiency accounted for 61 hits, 54 RBIs and 12 home runs.

Aside from two of last year’s stars, Penn State will also welcome back Cohl Mercado, who played more of a backseat role. The 5-foot-8 redshirt junior, formerly transferred from Boston College, found a unique role in Happy Valley.

Mercado started 38 games last season and played in 46 games, tallying a .230 batting average. He contributed 32 runs and 31 hits and endured spurts of struggle. While he wasn’t a regular starter, there is momentum for him to fill out the final projected starting role on Opening Day.

Jack Messina is the final returner for Penn State, who is listed as a first baseman and outfielder. The State High product played in one game last season and tallied one at bat. He will likely be a bench reserve once more for the blue and white.

Transfers

Last year, the Nittany Lions proved the transfer portal is vital to success. Now, in a less urgent situation, Penn State’s transfer prospects will look to add depth and balance to the lineup.

Penn State acquired two transfer prospects in this year’s cycle, both of which came from non-power conference schools.

Maddox McDonald, a Trinity transfer, had success in Division III, leading the Bantams to a SCAC regular-season title, SCAC tournament title and the Division III regional final.

The stat sheet appears even better. McDonald appeared in 81 games, making 76 starts over his two seasons with the program. He batted .329 with a .532 slugging percentage across his collegiate career. As a steady bat, he also presents loads of speed, having successfully stolen 19-of-22 bases last season.

McDonald certainly will be in the mix for a starting role with the Nittany Lions, most likely in center field.

Justin Turcovski rounds out the small incoming class as a former Pitt-Johnstown transfer. The 5-foot-10, redshirt senior, will aid Mercado and Messina as the left-handed bats in the outfield.

This gives Turcovski a good chance to be featured in the lineup. Nevertheless, he had much success in his long tenure with the program. The Huntingdon, Pennsylvania, native played in 156 games, making 149 starts in his four seasons.

Turcovski has been a very consistent player over his career, batting .282, slugging .505 and securing a .373 on-base percentage. While he likely won’t be in the starting mix, he might be featured as a player off the bench and used sporadically

Projected Starters

While Porter is the most experienced player amongst the group, he was used as a designated hitter last season. Still, he will likely aid Jaconski as the other veteran outfielder. These two will likely start in right and left field.

Behind these two, McDonald is most likely to start in center field, given his speed and reliable bat, providing highlight-level plays to patrol the grass.

MORE BASEBALL CONTENT

title: 5 Romance book picks for this Valentine’s season
author: Rebecca Fein | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s the season of love, Penn State. For those in happy relationships., those who are still trying to find their other half and others enjoying their singleness, we hope this list of romance books can get you through February 14th.

“Heated Rivalry”

Coming to you live from the cottage, it’s Shane Hollander and Ilya Rozanov. Author Rachel Reid scored a goal with this one. It starts to get hot on the ice when hockey rivals Shane and Ilya begin to notice there’s something more to their competitive feud.

If you love a slow burn, this is the book for you. Shane and Ilya’s “situationship” goes on for years before the two give in to their true desires.

With its recent HBO adaptation gaining popularity, you can live the sports romance on the page and screen, and witness the pair share salacious messages and looks.

And when they do, let’s just say it’s so hot that the ice melts a little.

“The Notebook”

A devastating classic, Nicholas Sparks has inflicted pain and turmoil on us since 1996. “The Notebook” follows the epic love story of Noah Calhoun and Allie Hamilton.

The two fall in love at a young age, but after outside forces push against their love, they are driven apart by distance and time. They reconnect later on in life, and Allie must decide if she’s going to leave her new life behind for her first love.

The book delivers a moving romance with a heartwrenching twist sure to leave you needing recovery time and a box of tissues, all carried by a second chance romance.

If you need a good cry, this is the book for you.

“The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo”

Taylor Jenkins Reid wrote the romance book of a century.

The story starts with Monique Grant, a journalist, seeking out a front page story when Evelyn Hugo, a Hollywood icon, agrees to share her life story as a way of finally putting rumors to rest and leaving the public eye.

Per the title, Hugo goes through seven different husbands in her lifetime, the novel is definitely worth a read.

“Funny Story”

The queen of rom-coms, Emily Henry, knocks it out of the park with a bizarre, yet touching story.

The book picks up when Daphne is dumped by her fiancé Peter for his childhood best friend Petra in the opening chapters of the book. Heartbroken and looking for a place to live, Daphne moves in with no other than Petra’s jilted ex-boyfriend Miles.

The two, in a scheme to make their exes jealous, begin a fake relationship, which soon devolves into real feelings. While figuring out their budding and somewhat awkward romance, the two realize the situation is nothing short of a “funny story.”

“Regretting You”

This would not be a romance book list without the ruler of them all, Colleen Hoover.

This novel, recently adapted as a movie starring actress Mckenna Grace and rising star Mason Thames, follows the story of the strained mother-daughter relationship between Morgan and Cara, who recently lost two beloved family members in a fatal car accident.

This warped love story highlights the idea of second chances. If you’re looking for a sort of twisted book about finding your forever, this is the one for you.

Whatever you decide to do this Valentine’s Day, just know, you are never alone. You always have a world of romance squeezed in between a hard cover to keep you company.

MORE BLOGS

title: Column | Penn State men’s track and field can win conference championship in 2026
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Over the past several weeks, Penn State has broken nearly a dozen school and NCAA records in various events.

Between Allon Clay’s 1000-meter school record at the Nittany Lion Challenge and Handal Roban’s 800-meter school record at the Penn State National Open, the Nittany Lions have looked unstoppable.

For the men’s squad in particular, that success will pay off with the postseason drawing near.

In last week’s USTFCCCA poll, the Nittany Lions were ranked No. 4 — the highest in program history. Coupled with four athletes with top-five marks in the country this season, the men’s team is capable of winning its first Big Ten indoor title in program history.

Since the western expansion to the Big Ten, Oregon and USC have been the frontrunners in the conference, with Ohio State, Purdue and a few other schools popping up here and there.

While the Ducks and Trojans remain powerhouses this year, Penn State’s success has been unmatched and may be enough to dethrone Oregon.

Across the board, the Nittany Lions have seen success in nearly every event, including Ajani Dwyer in the short sprints, Jake Palermo in the long sprints, Roban, Clay and Yukichi Ishii in middle-distance, Nick Sloff in long-distance and several dominant throwers.

According to the current top marks in the Big Ten this season, Penn State is expected to finish runner-up to Oregon with 87 points, falling short by 27 points.

However, with the current rate of growth by this year’s squad, nothing is out of the question for the blue and white as its athletes have shown they’re still far from the top of their games.

In the men’s 60-meter and 200-meter, Dwyer holds the No. 1 and No. 2 times in program history, respectively. While those times both lead the conference so far, the second-team All-American has stumbled out of the blocks in almost every race and is far from his potential.

After setting a new school record in 45.65 in the 400-meter last year, Jake Palermo is already just 0.33 seconds from that mark despite running just one race this year. In addition, he too leads the conference in his respective race.

Ryan Henry and Dylan Lambrecht each have top-five Big Ten marks in the shot put after setting the No. 4 and No. 5 marks in school history in January.

The weight throw has experienced similar success as Collin Burkhart threw a personal-best 21.22m throw last weekend to set the No. 5 throw in school history and the conference this season.

While those marks alone represent a successful Penn State squad, the mid-distance and distance groups push the team’s Big Ten chances over the edge, with school records in the 800m, mile and 3000-meter this season.

Over the past month, Sloff has broken the school record in the mile and 3000m while setting the No. 2 mark in the 5000-meter.

However, the 1000m and 800m have seen the most success so far.

At the Nittany Lion Challenge, Clay, Roban, Ishii and Sloff set the No. 4, 8, 9 and 10 marks in NCAA history in the 1000m while Clay broke the school record. Two weeks later at the National Open, Roban and Clay ran the No. 2 and 5 marks in NCAA history in the 800m, also setting the top-two marks in school history.

With a little less than a month until the Big Ten championships, the Nittany Lions are in a strong position and capable of winning their first indoor conference title this season.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Fresh off first Big Ten win, Penn State women’s basketball hosts No. 12 Michigan State
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn started its February off strong, earning an 85-82 overtime win on the road against Purdue on Wednesday night. This marked the Lady Lions’ first victory since Dec. 20, and their first in the conference.

Now with some momentum on its side, the blue and white welcome a tough task in No. 12 Michigan State. Tipoff is set for 1 p.m. on Saturday at Rec Hall

The Spartans were also in action on Wednesday night, but didn’t have as much to celebrate as Penn State did. Michigan State fell to No. 22 Maryland 86-70 on its home floor.

The Lady Lions put themselves up against one of the top scoring teams in the Big Ten. The Spartans average 85.5 points per game, which is third in the conference behind only Michigan and UCLA, who are the Big Ten’s top two teams.

The blue and white may struggle with the high-octane Michigan State offense, as Penn State has held a conference opponent to under 80 points just twice this season.

Defensively, the Spartans hold opponents to 63 points per game, which is 11.5 points less than the Lady Lions' average per contest.

Penn State’s win over the Boilermakers was paced by a 30-point performance from 5-foot-8 guard Kiyomi McMiller. This marked the sophomore’s 22nd double-digit outing this season, along with the second time she’s reached 30 points. Additionally, McMiller recorded five rebounds and a team-high nine assists.

McMiller’s 19.4 points per game lead the Lady Lions and is tied for fourth in the Big Ten. The Silver Springs, Maryland, native also paces the offense with 4.5 assists per game.

Michigan State’s leading scorer in its loss to the Terrapins was 6-foot-3 forward Grace VanSlooten, who scored 19 points. The senior also led the Spartans' box score with nine rebounds and four blocks.

VanSlooten is Michigan State’s top scorer with 15.3 points per game. She’s also the Spartans' leading shot blocker, with 24 on the season.

These two teams are similar in the way that both have multiple offensive weapons and don’t rely on one go-to scorer.

Penn State’s 6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle is right behind McMiller on the stat sheet, averaging 19.3 points per game. The redshirt junior recorded her seventh double-double of the season against Purdue, with 19 points and 20 rebounds.

The Lady Lions also see high production from sharpshooter Moriah Murray, who averages 10 points per game. The 5-foot-8 guard scored 15 points on Wednesday night after going 5-for-6 from beyond the arc. Murray’s 2.8 made three-pointers per game are tied for the most in the Big Ten.

Michigan State provides a balanced offensive attack, with five players averaging double-digit points. After VanSlooten, the Spartans second highest scorer is 5-foot-9 guard Kennedy Blair.

Blair netted 15 points against Maryland and averages 13.8 points per game on the season. The redshirt sophomore’s 5.5 assists per game lead the team and is the fourth-best mark in the Big Ten.

As Penn State tries to build off its first conference victory, Michigan State enters Saturday's matchup looking to get back in the win column after dropping its last two games.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | Michigan men's basketball program showcases what could be at Penn State
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
ANN ARBOR, MICH. — At the University of Michigan, in the shadows of the Big House, lies Crisler Arena. Inside the complex lies a modern-day coliseum, which houses some of the best basketball the Big Ten has to offer. Coach Dusty May has led the No. 2 Wolverines to their best start in program history after a 110-69 drubbing of the Nittany Lions.

21-1 Michigan fosters a program levels above the operation currently running in Happy Valley, built upon core principles that define the team over individuals in the NIL era.

“We have a team of elite talents all coming together with a common goal,” guard Nimari Burnett said.

May’s success is derived from the established Michigan program attracting talent from around the country, then guiding it to camaraderie that keeps players in Michigan long term. Even after an 8-24 season, the team rebuilt to a top program in the country with a core of talented veterans staying the course.

“(May) recruited a bunch of unselfish guys willing to do whatever it takes to win,” Burnett said. “We love to see each other succeed while being elite talents.”

But on top of the dominant play on the court, Michigan has the basketball experience perfected. Penn State basketball and the Bryce Jordan Center could take some notes.

An elite program and sustained success leads to gameday tradition that fosters an unforgettable experience. Much like Penn State football’s success bred a fanbase known for its signature voice during plays, Michigan basketball has developed a devoted following united with sound.

A flock of students clad in pink, blue and maize entered the arena through the gates of Michigan Stadium. They filled up a student section the size of Penn State’s early, then filled into sections 132 and 128 above the Wolverines’ exit gate. 12,000 fans surrounded the students to create a full arena that hasn’t been seen in Happy Valley in years.

Lights strung onto the guardrails of the staircases flashed, adding to the mystique, while fans sounded a boisterous yell for big moments, even in a small game for the home team. The fans united for a signature dance, similar to that of the Roar Zone, to honor veterans and to sing happy birthday to one of their players.

While the game itself was a breeze for a talented roster, with one media member quipping “it was nice to have everything written by halftime” after the game, the crowd continued to stay invested, blowing the Nittany Lions’ home environment out of the water.

Even in the blowout, the people in the arena were brought together behind a story shared for "Block Cancer” night. A Michigan alumnus named Alyssa was brought in front of the crowd. She was diagnosed with cancer four months after the birth of her son and leaned on the University of Michigan Health to battle her diagnosis. 22 years later, her son has graduated from Michigan, and she stood healthy in front of her alma mater to a smattering of cheers as she delivered a message to an attentive community.

“Find a way to enjoy life and always find a silver lining,” Alyssa said as the crowd united behind her.

Crisler Arena was built in 1967, but it feels like luxury compared to the newer BJC due to renovations in the 2000s and investments into the building. It contains a museum, merchandise stores and features that feel like a professional environment rather than a college venue. The Bryce Jordan Center, much like the program it houses, feels like it has an identity crisis, holding back its potential.

Penn State has a large donor base, a large arena to work with and some of the most passionate sports fans in the country. The school has everything needed to foster a program that can reach the heights of the Wolverines. But to do so, they must be willing to invest in basketball like Michigan to build a tradition that can withstand struggles and place Penn State in the upper class of college basketball.

However, the process won’t be quick. Mike Rhoades continually talks about how the path to success in the NCAA is utilizing the transfer portal to build an older, experienced roster.

“We have to have a level of urgency in the program to move forward, and I'll do that,” Rhoades said on Jan. 27. “The culture of college basketball now is to get older quicker.”

However, that is unsustainable for a program like Penn State, which lacks the foundation to replenish those assets yearly. If Penn State wants to truly become a contender long-term, it has to start from the ground up, rather than putting band-aids on a terminal illness. The quick fix isn’t compatible with the problem at hand.

Penn State has successfully built wrestling, volleyball and hockey into national mainstays over the last two decades and rebuilt a football program from sanctions unheard of at the time. The road to relevancy in college basketball will never get easier, but it's never too late to start climbing a mountain that won‘t move itself out of the way.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘We’re undermanned’ | Penn State men’s basketball was blown out by Michigan in midst of injuries
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Penn State coming out victorious on Thursday was a tough task in itself. The Nittany Lions were entering a hostile environment at the Crisler Center against the No. 2 team in the country, Michigan.

This doesn’t even factor in that Penn State was without key impact players, which left the team with just eight players.

“We’re undermanned,” Mike Rhoades said. “Their size and length really hurt us early, and they got it going.”

Penn State scored the first two points of the game, and proceeded to give up the next 15, and Michigan didn’t look back from there.

“We really made it hard on ourselves early in the game and put ourselves in a hole,” Rhoades said.

The biggest player missing from the lineup — literally and metaphorically — was 7-footer Ivan Jurić, who played a big role in Penn State’s close loss to the Wolverines to begin 2026.

The Nittany Lions fell to the Wolverines, 74-72, on Jan. 6, with Jurić scoring 20 points and four rebounds. The Zagreb, Croatia, native was 6-of-13 from the field and 2-of-5 from behind the arc.

“Obviously, they’re injury-depleted,” Michigan coach Dusty May said. “Jurić had his way with us up there. We were looking for the challenge to see if we could do a better job on him because he’s strong, he punishes switches, he made a couple threes against us.”

With Jurić out of the lineup, and Saša Ciani also ruled out before the game, Penn State started Josh Reed at center, lining up against 7-foot-3 Aday Mara for the opening tip-off.

When the 6-foot-8 forward wasn’t the big man on the court, true freshman Justin Houser was the big man. Houser tallied the most minutes in a single game in his freshman season with 21.

Ultimately, the Nittany Lions didn’t have any answer for the paint presence of the Wolverines. Mara tallied 11 points and six rebounds, while 6-foot-9 forward Morez Johnson Jr. scored 12 points with eight rebounds.

“When we played them at our place, I thought we out-toughed them and outplayed them, but we didn’t win the game,” Rhoades said. “They just beat us in all facets of the game.”

While Penn State didn’t have any answers for Michigan’s offense, allowing 110 points, the Wolverines seemingly had every answer for the Nittany Lions’ offense until the game was out of reach.

The difference in the two defensive units wasn’t close, as Michigan out-rebounded Penn State 44-21. This led to 22 second-chance points compared to the Nittany Lions’ six.

“We didn’t stop them either,” Rhoades said. “They got themselves going, and they really scored a lot of (points). I mean, they hit a bunch of threes, but they really scored around the basket and that had us leaking.”

Rhoades hopes to “have (Jurić) for the next game, when Penn State takes on USC. A unit that was fully depleted ultimately didn’t stand much of a chance against a Michigan unit that’s now 21-1.

“We knew the situation we were in,” Rhoades said. “I felt we had to make 10 to 12 threes to give ourselves a chance today, and we didn’t, but we didn’t stop them.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: How Matt Campbell is instilling core values into his version of Penn State
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Every morning, Matt Campbell parks his Ford Explorer in the Lasch Building parking lot and heads inside. The “whirlwind,” as he called it, of the last two months has somewhat settled down, although he’s still got a few more weeks on the road recruiting.

As Campbell walks through the halls of his new home, a family has somehow already been built. Penn State lost 50 players to the transfer portal and had just two 2026 signees, but Campbell and his staff put their heads down, meeting every day to discuss roster outlook.

Who was staying, who was leaving — they went through all of it all the time. But as Campbell looked to fill the holes and form a roster, he made one thing clear: If you want to be a Nittany Lion, you better embody the traits required of one.

“I feel like we went with the mentality of not wavering from who we want this football team to be,” Campbell said Tuesday. “What are the value systems of character, and young men that love the sport of football, young men that love Penn State, and I would say, most importantly, young men that understand the value of an education from this institution. Those core values were really critical for us to kind of build this football team forward.”

It was the same required values for the staff, most of whom have an unwavering loyalty to Campbell. Offensive line coach Ryan Clanton called his boss “the best head coach in the nation” without hesitation — the two have only been working together for three seasons, with 2026 set to be his fourth.

But it doesn’t feel that way to Clanton. Campbell treats him the same now as he did on Day 1, and Clanton knows that’s hard to find in today’s era of college football, so he certainly doesn’t take it for granted.

“It felt like a family the day I arrived. It's never been different,” Clanton said. “In all the years I've worked for him, it's never been like, ‘well, I thought he was like this, and he's really like that.’ He drives a Ford Explorer, you know, he's just like a normal dude, right?”

The most loyal of them all is offensive coordinator Taylor Mouser, who was working at Little Caesars 12 years ago and calling every school in the country trying to find someone that would take a chance on him, even if it was just in the smallest role available.

Campbell was the only one who answered. Since then, Mouser has been with Campbell.

“What that guy has done for me in my life, I'd still be at Little Caesars if it wasn't for coach Campbell, and I don't forget that,” Mouser said. “And it doesn't matter if he's made me the GA or he's made me the offensive recruiting quality control, whatever it is. I've tried to do it all just to repay him back for being the only guy that returned my phone call.”

Mouser and Clanton’s devotion trickles down to every member of the staff, especially those who came from Iowa State. Safeties coach Deon Broomfield said Campbell has helped him learn and grow as a father and a husband, while quarterbacks coach Jake Waters knows he’s working with a guy he loves and trusts.

Those relationships caught defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe’s eye when defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn asked him to move cross country to Penn State. Malloe even drew similarities between Campbell and former Washington head coach Chris Petersen, who Malloe spent three seasons coaching under.

“A guy that I hold dear to my heart is Chris Petersen. And his whole foundation was relationships, and that's what that guy is all about,” Malloe said. “So I was excited to be a part of that and kind of join that, his philosophy, and the way he does it is very old school. It really is. You kind of earn your keep, and you get up and you work.”

It’s often said that players are a reflection of their coaches, and coaches are a reflection of their players. And that’s exactly how Campbell wants it. He’s set on embodying the history and values of Penn State — unselfishness, integrity, humility, class and culture.

But Campbell also knows culture isn’t built in a day, and it isn’t just a word to throw around. “It’s how you live, it’s how you act, it’s how you carry yourself,” he says. And he’s ready to inject that into a Penn State football program that lost it a year ago.

“We sit in the proudest football tradition in all of college football. Do we understand that it's about those that came before us?” Campbell said. “Do we understand what we play for is bigger than us? Man, do we understand all the other things that come with football? Situational football, get in the best shape, playing for each other, all things that are critically important.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Position preview | Penn State baseball acquires new infielders through transfer portal
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State enters 2026 off its best season under coach Mike Gambino after going 33-23 with a 15-15 Big Ten record. A major part of the success was both stellar infield play and consistent hitting in the lineup.

However, after losing key players to the draft and graduation, Gambino looked to the transfer portal for talented additions. Along with the freshman class, the portal brought in several infielders who have the chance to fill much-needed voids.

The only certainty in the infield for Gambino is Bryce Molinaro starting at third base. Molinaro was drafted by the Washington Nationals, yet he elected to return for his junior year. The Drums, Pennsylvania, native started all 56 games at third base last season. He finished with a .267 batting average and 61 RBIs.

The redshirt junior’s RBI count sat at second all-time for a Nittany Lion in a single season.

The opposite corner was home to both Joe Jaconski and Cole Wagner throughout the season. The 2025 campaign marked Jaconski’s last as he used all years of eligibility.

With both consistent hitters gone, many possibilities begin surfacing for the first base position. The front-runner for the open spot is Michael Anderson. The Havertown, Pennsylvania, native returns to his home state after spending his junior season with Arkansas. However, he last played a full season in his sophomore year at Rhode Island.

The senior finished with a .252 batting average and hit 13 home runs before going to Arkansas.

As for the middle infield, Gambino has a variety of returning and new players he could use at both positions. Jayden Davis could make an impact in his first year at Penn State, coming from a competitive SEC group. The Cookeville, Tennessee, native’s best season with Vanderbilt came his sophomore year, where he hit .315 with 38 RBIs. His most recent season was cut short by surgery after an April injury.

With second base being his primary position and being a senior addition from the portal, Davis could hold the starting role at second for Gambino’s unit.

Shortstop seems to be up in the air after Ryan Weingartner was drafted to the St. Louis Cardinals. Weingartner started all 56 games at shortstop, leaving possible competition for the vacant position.

Spencer Barnett could potentially come out of that competition with the new starting job. Barnett had a batting average of .278 and 26 RBIs after his last season with West Virginia. The Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, native displays versatility as he has played second base, shortstop and third base throughout his career.

Although finding more time at second and third base, Barnett has given up fewer errors at shortstop.

The rest of the infield consists of freshmen and new players from the portal who could use this season to learn and improve for next season. They could also be potentially called in as a backup option.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's basketball suffers blowout loss at hands of No. 2 Michigan
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Penn State men’s basketball got its first Big Ten victory of the season last week against Minnesota and looked to continue its momentum against No. 2 Michigan.

The Nittany Lions were unable to do so as they lost 110-69. The Wolverines dominated the entire game as they outscored the blue and white 56-24 in the opening half.

Penn State started off with the first basket by Freddie Dillione V, and then proceeded to get outscored 15-0, leading to a timeout on the floor with the Nittany Lions trailing 15-2.

Penn State got its next points of the night from a Melih Tunca free throw attempt with 12:18 left in the first half. Dillione V put the squad on his back offensively, but anytime he scored a basket Michigan would answer back.

The Nittany Lions offense was struggling with Kayden Mingo scoring his first points of the game with just under six minutes left in the half. Meanwhile, Michigan big man WIll Tschetter was spreading the ball all over the court as he had back-to-back assists on two-straight three pointers.

Penn State got bullied all around the court. The Nittany Lions allowed the Wolverines to score seven of the last eight field goals with 3:24 left in the half.

Morez Johnson Jr. drove through the entire team on the court, capping it off with a slam dunk, an easy layup and a fade away for three-straight baskets to extend Michigan’s lead to 31. The Wolverines outscored Penn State by 32 in the opening half. The Nittany Lions entered halftime with a 56-24 deficit.

Michigan opened the second half on a 7-0 scoring run. Tunca scored the first points for Penn State, again from the free throw line. Michigan’s defense had back-to-back blocks by Aday Mara.

Tschetter continued to fool the Nittany Lions as he did all night. The graduate student had a lob to Oscar Goodman for the easy dunk to give the Wolverines a 78-40 lead.

Mara continued to showcase his defensive abilities with another big block against Josh Reed. The Wolverines clamped Penn State from beyond the arc as the squad went 2-of-17 from downtown.

Penn State made Goodman look like he was the star player on the court. The redshirt freshman tallied six points.

Penn State’s defense was atrocious, allowing the Wolverines to shoot 63% from the field, and just as bad was the blue and white’s offense, which shot 35% from the field.

The only decent stat the Nittany Lions had was from the free-throw line; the squad shot 77% from that spot, which was still worse than Michigan’s 88 percent from the line.

After his second three-pointer of the game, Tschetter got the Wolverines to 100 points and then over that amount with back-to-back threes. Nimari Burnett was the main source of offense for the Wolverines, shooting 70% from downtown and leading the team in scoring with 31 points, which was half of what Penn State scored as a team.

Penn State got outrebounded 44-21 throughout the entirety of the game. Penn State got dominated with even less than a minute in the game, allowing Michigan to score two baskets off of lob passes. Penn State lost by 41, 110-69.

Injury report

The Nittany Lions were without Ivan Jurić, Eli Rice, Tibor Mirtic and Sasa Ciani for the game.

Up next

Penn State returns to the Bryce Jordan Center for a matchup with USC at noon Sunday.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State wrestling faces Michigan on the road
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Penn State is coming off its closest dual of the season with a 26-12 victory over Nebraska.

Now, the Nittany Lions will travel to face Michigan in an expected raucous environment at the Crisler Center. Last season, Penn State shut out the Wolverines, 39-0, in the Bryce Jordan Center.

Here’s how the 2026 edition of the dual sets up.

125 pounds: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 26 Diego Sotelo (UM)

Luke Lilledahl will take on Diego Sotelo for the first time in their careers. Against common opponents, Lilledahl is 15-3, while Sotelo sits at 16-9, giving Lilledahl the advantage.

This season, no wrestler has been able to keep up with Lilledahl’s lightning pace as he’s given Penn State the best option to lead off a dual. With the Nittany Lion’s pace, Sotelo will have to stay steady as Lilledahl tends to get started quickly.

133 pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. Gauge Botero (UM)

After multiple tough matches for Marcus Blaze, the competition lightens up against the Wolverines. Gauge Botero holds a 4-11 record on the season and has struggled to keep up with the top competition.

This match could end quickly with Blaze’s low, quick style, and if Lilledahl gets the dual started off on the right foot, Blaze could fully take the life out of the Crisler Center with a quick match.

141 pounds: No. 12 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 26 Dylan Ragusin (UM)

Braeden Davis will attempt to get back on the right track after losing by pinfall to Brock Hardy. Davis got out the gates quickly against Hardy, but got into a precarious position, allowing Hardy to take advantage.

Davis will face Dylan Ragusin, who’s 6-3 on the season. The two wrestlers have a similar number of matches this season, but Davis has a tendency to come out on top against wrestlers ranked below him.

149 pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 13 Lachlan McNeil (UM)

The 149-pound bout is a rematch of the NCAA Tournament last season. Shayne Van Ness came out on top with a 7-2 decision against Lachlan McNeil, who was at North Carolina at the time.

Van Ness has wrestled on a new level this season and is the current top-ranked wrestler at the weight class. McNeil holds a formidable 11-3 record on the season, but Van Ness is on another level, with the next highest ranked Big Ten wrestler being Maryland’s Carter Young at No. 4.

157 pounds: No. 4 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. No. 13 Cameron Catrabone (UM)

PJ Duke lost his first match of his collegiate career to Antrell Taylor of Nebraska. However, he’ll face Cameron Catrabone, who’s dropped four matches this season.

Duke couldn’t get to his offense against Taylor but with a wrestler ranked lower than Taylor’s No. 3 spot, he could find more success and keep the train rolling on an impressive start to his career in a blue and white singlet.

Duke has a tendency to send the dual to intermission on a high note, and with Penn State having the higher-ranked wrestler at every weight class, it could happen once again.

165 pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. Justin Gates (UM)

Mitchell Mesenbrink is the reigning national champion and is still undefeated in the 2025-26 season. Mesenbrink will take on unranked Justin Gates with a chance at a quick match.

Mesenbrink has taken the junior-year Levi Haines jump where there’s more of a focus on back points. Against an unranked wrestler, Mesenbrink could earn nearfall points quickly, potentially ending this one early by fall.

174 pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. No. 11 Beau Mantanona (UM)

Haines will face who Mesenbrink faced last season. Mesenbrink came out victorious with an 18-4 major decision over Beau Mantanona. Haines pinned his opponent last year against Michigan, but will face a much better wrestler in Mantanona.

Beau is 14-4 on the season compared to Haines’ 15-0 record, maintaining his perfect season. With Haines’ highly ranked victories this season, it won’t be a different look against the Wolverine.

184 pounds: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 7 Brock Montanona (UM)

Rocco Welsh has continued to grow his dominance this season, and is the lone undefeated wrestler left in the weight class.

Brock Mantanona is No. 7 in the country but won’t be a different look for Welsh, who has the biggest win of the season over former No. 1 Angelo Ferrari.

Welsh’s strength has played a major factor and could play a huge factor again over the Wolverine.

197 pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 20 Hayden Walters (UM)

Josh Barr is the final of four straight No. 1 wrestlers for the Nittany Lions. He’ll take on a wrestler who’s 7-4 on the season. Hayden Walters has yet to face a wrestler to the caliber of Barr, which could cause issues for the Wolverine.

Barr is 13-0 on the year and is on a tier of his own in the weight class. He holds the best victory in the class, defeating No. 3 Stephen Little earlier in the season. Returning to his home state, Barr could have a hometown showcase in Michigan.

285 pounds: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. No. 5 Taye Ghadiali (UM)

It’ll be another major test for Cole Mirasola when he takes on Taye Ghadiali. The Wolverine just defeated Nick Feldman of Ohio State, a wrestler Mirasola lost to last season. Mirasola held a close bout against AJ Ferrari, but couldn’t get over the hump against a top-five wrestler.

If Mirasola wants to re-insert himself into the top 10, he’ll need a victory over Ghadiali to create mass parity in the Big Ten at the heavyweight position. Ghadiali’s 16-2 record matches up with most wrestlers around him in the rankings.

title: Tessa Janecke records two assists in Team USA's Olympic win over Czechia
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Written on a piece of tape on Tessa Janecke’s stick is “BTGC,” an abbreviation for “Be the game changer,” a message her parents would send her in her days of youth hockey, as reported by Kathryn Tappen on the NBC broadcast.

Janecke was certainly a game changer in her Olympic debut, recording a pair of assists in the United States’ 5-1 win over Czechia.

“I tried to just do what I could,” Janecke said during the second intermission. “It’s obviously a little different being at centre now, so it’s more comfortable for me. I’m just trying to play downhill in the [offensive zone] and create opportunities.”

The name of the game was “speed,” for the Americans and lots of it. Performing at such a quick pace and tempo, Team USA was able to maintain possession of the puck for the majority of the opening period.

Not only was speed a crucial factor from an offensive perspective, but a defensive one as well. The United States’ defense prevented the Czechia offense from being able to cleanly enter the zone without resorting to dumping the puck. The United States was able to hold the Czechs to just one shot in the first 13 minutes of play.

With just under six minutes remaining in the first period, Team USA had a chance to open the scoring after Czechia goaltender Klára Peslarová came out of her crease to play the puck but mishandled it behind the net.

On her way back to the crease she fell to one knee, making a save on a Kelly Pannek shot that deflected off Peslarova’s back. Kirsten Simms nearly buried the loose puck, but Peslarova froze the puck on her side.

On a power play following a Dominika Lásková penalty for an illegal check, Hannah Bilka added another high-danger scoring opportunity for the United States, but Peslarova managed to get her glove down just in time. It seemed like the Americans could do everything but score.

Until they did.

Laila Edwards sent a one-timer pass from the faceoff dot to Megan Keller, who ripped a slapshot. On its way to the net, it deflected off the stick of Alex Carpenter and through the five-hole of the goalie Peslarova.

Not even two minutes into the second period, Czechia reminded United States goaltender Aerin Frankel to stay on her toes. Tereza Plosova skated around Britta Curl and Caroline Harvey and hit the post with her shot on a breakaway.

When the red, white and blue came out for the second period, they added another aspect to their already fast-paced game: crisp passes. The Americans seemed to utilize every square inch of the ice’s surface, constantly moving the puck around, and it played a factor in increasing their lead.

From behind the cage, Janecke handled the puck and fired a quick centering pass to Joy Dunne, who scored her first Olympic goal to put Team USA up 2-0.

After a battle along the boards, less than two minutes later, Janecke fired a quick-look backhanded pass to Hayley Scamurra, who turned, battled a Czech skater, and fired the puck under Peslarova’s left pad, giving the United States a 3-0 lead.

Team USA continued to keep its foot on the gas, but hit a slight bump in the road on the way to victory.

Barbora Juříčková was in the penalty box serving the final seconds of her two-minute minor for interference when the Americans sent a shot that rebounded off Peslarova and right on to the stick of Natálie Mlýnková. With Jurickova out of the box, Miynkova sent a pass up the length of the ice to Jurickova, who beat Frankel low-blocked to put Czechia on the board.

United States captain Hilary Knight added one more to the American lead with the 13th goal of her Olympic career, putting her third on the women’s all-time list behind Natalie Darwitz and Katie King, who are tied with 14.

The Americans started the final period down a skater while Edwards served the remaining time on her tripping penalty that carried over from the second period.

After a successful penalty kill, Team USA continued to own the game in a controversial fashion. A potential missed tripping call against the United States resulted in Andrea Trnková losing the puck, turning it over to Scamurra, who put Team USA up 5-1 with her second goal of the game.

The Americans had another power-play opportunity in the final minutes of the game and failed to score, but what they had already done was good enough to earn victory in their first game of the Winter Olympics.

Up Next

The United States continues its preliminary round at 10:40 a.m. EST on Saturday when it faces Finland, its opponent in the semifinal round of the 2022 Winter Olympics. Czechia will look to bounce back at 8:40 a.m. EST on Friday against Switzerland

MORE OLYMPICS COVERAGE

title: Gov. Josh Shapiro proposes funding allocations for Penn State during 2026-27 budget address
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Gov. Josh Shapiro proposed a $30 million funding allocation for Pennsylvania’s state-related universities, which includes Penn State, during his 2026-27 budget address to the Pennsylvania General Assembly on Tuesday.

The proposal is part of the commonwealth’s new performance-based funding model.

Shapiro also proposed an allocation of $242.1 million for Penn State’s general support appropriation which would serve as the university’s funding baseline with any increase coming from the State-Related University Performance Fund following approval from the General Assembly, according to a Penn State News press release.

Shapiro’s proposal does not address a previous general support funding request of $49 million for the 2026-27 academic year that, if approved along with the other funding proposals, would be used to offset educational costs for students who are Pennsylvania residents and freeze tuition costs for all undergraduate students for the 2027-28 academic year, according to the press release.

The press release said Penn State President Neeli Bendapudi is expected to speak before the Pennsylvania House Appropriations Committee on March 11 to discuss the university’s funding with legislators. A final budget package is expected on June 30, which is the end of the 2025-26 fiscal year.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s hockey’s Matilde Fantin scores first Olympic goal in Italy’s 4-1 victory over  France
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
Matilde Fantin and host nation Italy kicked off its home campaign in the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics against France on Thursday.

Behind a strong offensive attack and outshooting the French 46-15, Fantin and Italy put on a show for their home crowd against the French, winning the game 4-1 and putting themselves in an optimal position to advance into the quarterfinals.

Alice Philbert started between the pipes for France, while Martina Fedel got the start for the Italians.

Puck dropped with both sides easing into the contest, slowly putting pressure on both goaltenders.

France got the first blow ten minutes into the first period on the power play, with forward Gabrielle de Serres putting the puck past Fedel to give the Italians a 1-0 advantage early.

It was all Italy from there. Exactly one minute later, Italian captain Nadia Mattivi delivered an accurate pass to forward Kayla Tutino, who equalized the contest for the Italians 1-1.

As the second period began, the Italians started to dominate puck possession and had complete control over the neutral zone. In the closing minutes of the second period, Kristin Della Rovere carried the puck into the French zone and fired a shot that went off Philbert's pad. Rebecca Rocella took advantage of the opportunity and slotted the rebound into the back of the net, giving the Italians a 2-1 advantage going into the final frame.

Just 14 seconds into the third period, Penn State’s own Matilde Fantin recorded her first-ever Olympic goal, unassisted, giving the Italians a 3-1 lead.

Four minutes later, Delle Rovere made up for her first opportunity in the second period, as she scored the fourth goal of the day for the Italians, assisted by Anna Caumo.

The Italians controlled the remainder of the contest, giving the French no chance to mount a comeback as Italy prevailed 4-1, giving them all three possible points.

Up Next

The Italians look ahead to their Group B match against Sweden at 8:40 a.m. EST on Saturday.

MORE OLYMPIC COVERAGE
